column2: The Englishman is intelligent, active, and brave to rashness. He loves and seeks danger, and is pleased with venturous, even hopeless, tasks. Many are ruined in this way, but many more come out victorious from the conflict.

CHICAGO, June 29.--A bill was filed in the County Court to-day contesting the right of William M. Devine to hold the office of City Treasurer of Chicago, on the ground that he did not receive a majority of the legal ...

KENOSHA, Wis., June 29.--During the week a game of baseball had been advertised to take place here yesterday between the Milwaukee "Reds" and the Kenosha "Regulars." At the appointed hour the ball grounds were thronged by nearly 5,000 spectators.

Inspector Steers is making an investigation into the disappearance of Patrick Manning, a carpenter, living at No. 601 West Forty-eighthstreet. Manning was working last week at NewRochelle, and was sunstruck there on Tuesday.

The agreement under which the 21 members of the American Wall Paper Association have been working during the past year expires by limitatton at noon to-day. Yesterday at Delmonico's the members met to renew, if possible, their agreement for another year. With the 13 members of the pool proper met representatives ...

WORCESTER, Mass., June 29.--The University of Pennsylvania crew arrived this noon, accompanied by Ellis Ward their trainer, and Mr. Hunter, a member of the Regatta Committee of the Intercollegiate Association.

The woman who shot O'Donovan Rossa, chief of New-York dynamiters, while proffering him pecuniary assistance for his cause, in the public streets last February, was put on trial in the General Sessions Court yesterday. She was brought from her cell in the Tombs early dressed as jauntily as though she contemplated spending a day in the woods or at the seashore.

The wedding of Princess Beatrice has been definitely fixed to take place in Whippingham Church on Tuesday, July 23, at 1 o'clock. Canon Prothero, the Rector of Whippingham, has no reason to congratulate himself on account of the Queen having decided that ...

Among the steerage passengers of the White Star steamship Republic, which arrived yesterday from England, were six members of the crew of the Nova Scotian ship Cyprus, which was lost in the South Atlantic in April.

Mr. Matthew Arnold has gathered together into a volume published by Messrs. Macmillan Co. the series of addresses delivered by him on the occasion of his recent visit to the United States. They include the lecture on Emerson, spoken in that famous thinker's "own delightful town of Boston," and the lecture ...

TORONTO, Ontario, June 29.--An incendiary set fire to a large roller skating rink, which was partially constructed, in Trenton, a town on the Grand Trunk Railway, east of here, today, and before the small fire apparatus could check the flames almost the entire business part of the place was burning.
LONDON, June 29.--The rebellion of the London newspapers against Reuter's News Agency, which was begun two or three weeks ago, has not yet been brought to a decisive issue.
ELMIRA, N.Y., June 29.--Thomas Saunders, while riding on a tricycle handcar to-night near Cameron Mills, was struck and killed by a Lehigh valley express train.

MADRID, June 29.--The official cholera reports for Sunday are as follows: Castellon de la Plans, (city,) new cases, 6; deaths, none; (province,) new cases, 143; deaths, 74. Valencia, (city,) new cases, 73; deaths, 35; (province,) new cases, 556; deaths, 293. Alicante, (city,) new ...

A very good programme is offered by the Coney Island Jockey Club to-day, and the entries are so numerous that some spirited racing may be anticipated. It is likely that the track will be somewhat heavy, and this may cause surprises to the knowing ones. The first race will be particularly trying to them, as the majority of the announced starters are very fast at the distance.

The proceeding by which a complete change has been made in the Board of Assessors of the Department of Taxes and Assessments is one that cannot be regarded with entire satisfaction. It is not unlikely that a change was demanded by the interests of the public.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29.--An "infernal" machine of a rather clumsy pattern was sent by mail to-day to L. Lum Smith, publisher of a weekly paper. It was a wooden box about 5 inches square and 3 inches high.

TALLADEGA, Ala., June 29.--Last night the crew of the South-bound passenger train on the railroad passing here, picked up, apparently dead, the body of Jane Goldston. She had been the victim of foul play and was placed there to be run over and thus destroy the traces of the crime. She was covered with wounds and will die. Six men have already been arrested charged with the offense.

At an early hour yesterday morning the servant girl employed by W.B. Taylor, in Wyandotte, Kan., was awakened by some person passing through her sleeping chamber out into the hallway. She quietly arose, locked the door of her room, and passed out onto the porch through the open window by which the burglar entered.

OMAHA, Neb., June 29,--The most sensational failure ever known in Omaha has been made known during the last 36 hours. Loyal S. Smith, who came here from Chicago, opened a dry goods store Nov. 3, left the city yesterday at 8 O'clock in the forenoon, going south over the Kansas City Road, and taking his chief ...

The attendance at the Brighton Beach races yesterday was unusually large, notwithstanding the unpromising aspect of the weather, and the racing was fair, when the muddy condition of the track is taken into consideration. The favorites had a bad run of luck, winning in only two out of five events, the hurdle race being declared off.

Rudolph Rudoloff, aged 42, a German tobacco broker in Front-street, residing at No. 735 East One Hundred and Forty-first-street, shot himself at his home at 7:15 o'clock last evening. Dinner had just been served, and his wife and five children were in the dining room when they heard a pistol shot. Rushing up stairs.

There is a truly wild and Western flavor about the tale of L.S. SMITH, of Omaha, whose ambition it was to be known as "The Merchant Prince of the Prairies," but who is, in fact, known only as the evasive insolvent of the Missouri Valley.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 29.--At Gananoque, Ontario, on Saturday, the wife of Dr. Fraleigh, a prominent physician threw herself in the river with her babe in her arms and both were drowned.

There is one matter in which Paris is declining every year--I mean cookery. The increase of clubs where bachelors find a house dinner at a moderate price has deprived the high-class restaurants of a considerable number of customers whose place has been taken by foreigners.

Since the Administration is every way committed to civil service reform and the enforcement of the law on that subject, it was a gross and boorish offense to good taste and propriety in Mr. Hendricks to open his mouth on the subject. Mr. Hendricks is a very good man.

Chief of Police Murphy, of Jersey City, has notified the proprietors of the rooms in which auction pools on races and sporting events were sold that they must close and keep closed. This change of front on the part of the Chief is probably due to the advice of County Prosecutor Winfried. The owners of the place have discharged their assistants and locked their doors.
Superintendent Murray had a conference with the Police Captains at his office yesterday in relation to their compliance with his orders to keep the streets clear of disreputable women.

Judge Robertson expects to surrender the office to the new Collector to-morrow. Josiah S. Knapp, who has been a clerk in the Auditor's Department more than 10 years and is a brother-in-law of Mr. Hedden, will, it is believed by his friends, be appointed private secretary to Collector Hedden. There are about 210 Places in the Custom House to which the civil service rules do not apply.
NEW ORLEANS, June 29.--Chess Carley's standard coal oil warehouse, on New Canalstreet, caught fire at 10 o'clock to-night and is still burning. Two thousand barrels of oil were destroyed.

LYONS, N.Y., June 29.--The most destructive rainstorm ever known in this vicinity occurred early last evening, continuing over two hours. For the first hour the water came down in immense torrents. In a few minutes the gutters in all of the streets of the village were overflowed, and pools of water several inches deep covered the roadways. Window glass everywhere was broken by the force of the rain.

CHICAGO, June 29,--For some unaccountable reason the gamblers of this city were generally led to believe that from to-day on they would be allowed to run their games without interference. To-night this belief is tinged with grave doubts.

The commission appointed by President ARTHUR, to visit the countries to the south of us for the purpose of investigating the condition of our trade with those countries and to recommend means of improving it will probably return in a few weeks.
HARTWELL, Ga., June 29.--A colored boy named John Ellis, while picking strawberries near his home Sunday morning, was bitten by a rattlesnake and died in great agony in the afternoon.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 29.--In an action in the Circuit Court here for $5,000 damages against the Southern Bell Telephone Company for cutting the telephone wire of a subscriber during the existence of a contract with the company, the jury found a verdict for the plaintiff for $1 and costs.

The following letter was written by the Rev. Dr. Duryea, of Boston, who was recently elected President of Union College, to Dr. David Murray, one of the committee appointed to notify him of the honor conferred upon him. President Landon received it from Dr. Murray this morning:

Chearles E. Johnson was married to Florence A. Benedict, of Monroe-place, Brooklyn, in 1876, and soon afterward, it is alleged, he began to cruelly treat her. He had not been married a year when, in a fit of anger, he drew a revolver and shot her, inflicting a painful wound.

One hundred ladies and gentlemen met at No. 208 Eighth-avenue last evening to celebrate the third anniversary of the James A. Garfield Lodge, No. 61, Independent Order of Good Templars. After a musical programme had been acceptably rendered, ex-Postmaster-General ...

At a recent meeting of the Ladies' Health Protective Association one of the association's officers reported that the city was unusually clean. It is undoubtedly much cleaner than it would have been if this association and other societies formed for sanitary work had not urged on and assisted the Board of Health ...

Judge Barrett, in Supreme Court, Chambers, has refused to grant a peremptory mandamus to compel Register Reilly to permit the New-York Title Guaranty and Trust Company to make use at will of the records in his office.

ROCK ISLAND, III., June 29.--Yesterday forenoon, while out bathing in the river with companions, George L. Kline, a Chicago, Burlington and Quincy brakeman, was drowned. He was a good swimmer, but he was taken with cramps and could not reach the shore. He lived as Beardstown. He was formerly from Rochester, N.Y., where his relatives now reside.

CHICAGO, June 29.--At 11 o'clock to-night the fully 3,000 persons assembled at Battery D Armory had for nearly two hours good naturedly witnessed the ambitious efforts of half a dozen embyro sluggers. When Jack Burke and Charles Mitchell faced each other in the ring for the fourth time in their lives, the appetite of the crowd had been keenly whetted ...

WINSTED, Conn., Saturday, June 27.-- From Pastor of a little church of 150 members in Paterson, N.J., to President of Bowdoin College and Professor of Philosophy is quite a promotion for a young man of 27, only two years out of a theological seminary and but six years out of college, but the ability and acquisitions ...

MONTREAL, June 29.--Detective Fahey has received a cablegram from Scotland Yard that both Hall and Fox, now confined in St. Vincent De Paul, are well known to the London police, and are wanted in England on several charges.
CHICAGO, June 29.--William Drummond, at one time Chief-Justice of Utah, was arraigned in a police court here to-day on the charge of larceny.

One day last Spring a resident of the north end had his attention called to an oriole that was apparently in some serious trouble. Examination showed that it was fastened to a limb by one of its nest strings. A lad disengaged it and it flew away. Later in the day the boy saw a bird fluttering in the grass, and after catching it it proved to be the same bird, a remanant ...

A short time ago it was oracularly announced on the authority of some of our Congressmen that it "had been arranged" that there should be no changes in the Federal offices of St. Louis until Fall. It appears that the gentlemen who entered into this "arrangement" on behalf of the Administration and the State of ...

NEWARK, June 29.--The identity of the girl who was found in Brooklyn last Friday with a letter which gave her name as Nellie Wymess, the daughter of a fish dealer on Broad-street, New-York, has been established in this city.

H.H. Barlow, a broker, was overcome by the heat in Exchange-place yesterday, and was taken to Chambers-Street Hospital. After remaining a short time at the hospital he went to his home, No. 850 Putnam-avenue, Brooklyn, against the advice of Dr. Outerbridge, who considered the case rather serious. Mr. Barlow is 56 years old.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 29.--The Supreme Court Judges to-day decided the act constitutional by which the Legislature authorized an expenditure of $4,000,000 in paving certain streets with granite blocks.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., June 29.--R.B. Fortman, of New-Orleans, went up yesterday to a high point at Tallulah Falls, where'a chasm of 250 feet deep lay before him. Becoming dazed he fell over and went to the bottom. He is dying.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 29.--A party of six young men left the Gurnett House for a sail yesterday. When near Bath their boat was struck by a squall and upset. N.W. Gavin, Assistant Postmaster here, and B.A. Lincoln were drowned.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 29.--On Sunday afternoon two boys were drowned at Charles Hillard's mill-dam in Salisbury Towship. A party of boys went in bathing in the pond, John A. Robinson, aged 14 years, son of Wilson Robinson, and George W. Anne, aged 12 years, ...

The official axe fell upon the members of the Board of Assessors yesterday, as was foreshadowed in THE TIMES on Friday last. With the charges of Mayor Grace before them, and a letter signed by Assessors Lydecker, Jacobus, Mullaly, and Gumbleton, sharply protesting against the proposed action, the Tax Commissioners voted for their removal.

Mount McGREGOR, N.Y., June 29.--Gen. Grant has kept his room all day, writing a little but saving himself most of the time by quiet and sleep. The morning broke clear after a full day of storm, and the sun was warming.

WASHINGTON, June 29.--The death of Lieut Col. Gentry causes the following promotins: Major J.J. Van Horn, Thirteenth Infantry, to be Lieutenant Colonel, Twenty-fifth Infantry; Capt. D.M. Vance, Sixteenth Infantry, to be Major, Thirteenth Infantry, and First Lieut and Quartermaster W.V. Richards, ...

When the Commissioners of the Harlem River Improvement shecme made their report two years ago, objection was made to it, on behalf of some of the owners of property to be taken for the canal or other purposes, on the ground that the scheme was obnoxious to the State Constitution.

LONDON, June 29.--Prince Albert Victor, son of the Prince of Wales, was to-day tendered the freedom of the city at Guildhall. The Prince and Princess of Wales, United States Minister Phelps, and most of the Ambassadors in London were present.

The appointment of Prince Leiningen, one of the Germans who have come to England "for our goods," as one of George I.'s German ladies said, to the command at the Nore is a public scandal. The only ground for his promotion is that he is a German royalty, and his only qualification is that, when enjoying the comfortable berth of Captain of the Queen's yatch he ran down the Mistletoe and drowned a few Englishmen.

WASHINGTON, June 29, 1885 Marshal McMichael to-day removed a Demo cratic subordinate for "offensive partisanship." The statement cabled from London on the authority of the Vienna correspondent of the Times that the appointment of Keiley to be Minister to Austris had been withdrawn is officially denied.

CLEVELAND, June 29.--Maxey Cobb, the trotting stallion, has arrived here from NewYork and Maud S. is expected to-morrow. The race between Maxey Cobb and Phallas next Saturday promises to be one of the greatest turf events of the season.

When he married his niece, Cecilia, in 1876, Charles Salzburg, who keeps a variety store at No. 356 Grand-street, had three daughters approaching womanhood. He and Cecelia now have a son, Clairmont, age 7 years.

MONTREAL, June 29.--News has just been received here from London, England, that the Canadian 4 per cent. loan of 4,000,000, tenders for which were opened to-day, and which has been negotiated by Sir Leonard Tilley, was sub scribed for three times over, and that it has been taken up at about 101 2-3.

"Nanon," a three-act operetta, which was first made known in this country at the Thalia Theatre, and was then reviewed in this place, was presented with English words instead of the German text, and by an English-speaking company, at the Casino last evening.

PEEKSKILL, June 29.--The real work of camp life for the Ninth Regiment began at 6 o'clock this morning. After the men had swallowed their early slice of bread and cup of coffee the companies assembled for company drill and worked for an hour.

LONDON, June 29.--The Right Hon. Will- iam Henry Smith, Secretary for war in the cabinet of the Marquis for Salisbury, has been re-elected to Parliament for westminster. The Liberals did not contest the seat.

The leading manufacturers of Lawn tennis and other outdoor sporting goods held a conference yesterday afternoon and decided to close their establishments at 1:30 P.M. on Saturday during July and August.

BOSTON, June 29.--Gen. John A. Logan was dined this evening by the Norfolk Club and a number of Massachusetts Republicans. He arrived with Mrs. Logan and his sons from Portland early in the afternoon, and while in town is the guest of the club. This is an organization similar to the Bay State Club, which last week entertained ...

ELLENTON, S.C., June 29.--Mrs. S.A. Snelling, whose home was about six miles west of Barnwell, died Saturday under remarkable circumstances. Ever since her husband's death, some years ago, she has insisted on living alone, and frequently said that when she died she wanted to die alone.

NYACK, June 29.--An elopement has just come to light that has caused a ripple of excitement in the southern part of Rockland County and that portion of New-Jersey which adjoins it. The parties concerned are John G. Demarest, a young man but little more than 20 years of age, living at Piermont, and Miss Rachel Ann Vanderbeck, a charming little blonde of 16, whose father is a well-to-do farmer of West Paskack.

BEDFORD, Penn., June 29.--Grant Miller and Josiah Wolford were last night having a friendly tussle in East Clair Township, when Wolford accidentally fell upon an open pocket knife which Miller held in his hand and was stabbed through the heart. He died almost instantly.

The reigning sensation in Jersey City yesterday was the charge of libel and persecution made against Contractor Thomas Potter by Mrs. Plume and her son Robert, the details of which were published in THE TIMES yesterday. It had been the design of Plume and his counsel to make the complaint before Police Justice Stilsing, but that officer proposed to put Plume ...

The Board of street Opening at its meeting yesterday authorized the opening of the following streets: One Hundred and Fortyeiqhth-street, from Eighth-avenue to the Hudson River; One Hundred and Forty-ninth-street, from Eigth-avenue to the Hudson River; One ...

HARTFORD, Conn., June 29.--The Rev. Prof. George L. Westgate, of Wesleyan College, died at Norfolk. Conn, of consumption on Sunday night, aged 41. He was a graduate of Wesleyan in the Class of '65 and of the Union Theological Seminary of New-York. He was settled as Pastor at several churches before taking his Professorship of Political Economy at Wesleyan.

Our readers will remember the case in which a tradesman named Brun was grievously assaulted on presenting his bill to a lady at the Hotel Continetal. The facts have now come out in the police court. Baroness de Vautheloret, the accused, contested the amount of the bill, but as ...
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 29.--Byron P. Myers, dealer in rubber stamps at Adams, has failed. Liabilities, $10,000; assets, $3,000.
There was a pretty story circulating along Vine-street, below Fourth, and elsewhere yesterday about a shower of fish from the clouds during the morning storm.

A funny little situation was developed at the house of Mr. Oscar Fowler, on White Hall farm, the property of Mr. William Ward Henderson, near this town, lately. Mr. Fowler lives upon the river shore, and is fond of gunning and fishing.

MONTREAL, June 29.--A dispatch was received in the city to-day from Capt. Lung, commanding the steamship Invermay, bound for this port from Pictou, N.S., to the effect that the vessel had run ashore at a point nine miles below Cape Chatte, on the gulf coast.

CHICAGO, June 29.--The card at Washington Park to-morrow embraces five events, and in all of them large fields will face the starters. The entries and pools sold on the races, at the Palmer House, to-night are as follows:

MONTREAL, June 29.--The rumors which have been afloat to the effect that some irregularities have existed in connection with the United States Consular Service in this district are found, upon inquiry, to arise out of the fact that certain revenues ...

The following letter appeared recently in the London Times: "On Dec. 27, 1884, you referred in a leading article to the proposed restoration of the parish church of Stratford-on-Avon, which you informed your readers was at that time seriously contemplated.
Ten Scottish estates were offered for sale last week, but not one changed hands, and for four there was not a single bid.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 29.--State Treasurer Burke has given notice that the interest due July 1 on 4 per cent. Louisiana consols will be paid by B. Newgas, financial agent of the London Bank in New-York City, and by the State National Bank's fiscal agent in New-Orleans.

CHICAGO, June 29.--The County Board to-day adopted a resolution providing for the letting of a contract for building a new wing to the Infirmary for $23,000. Commissioners Wrenn and Senne denounced the scheme as "infamously extravagant" under the circumstances, the county revenues being almost entirely wrecked.

The Brooklyn players retired the Metropolitan nine for nine successive innings yesterday without allowing them to score a run. They have long desired to administer a sound thrashing to the champions, but a "Chicago" was above their highest expectations, and it is needless to say that there was joy in Brooklyn last ...

WASHINGTON, June 29,--Mr. Edward L. Hedden, the new Collector, and Mr. Hans S. Beattie, the new Surveyor, called upon the President to-day to thank him for the honor of appointment to the offices for which they have been named. Mr. Hedden had never met the President.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29.--Three thousand troops had taken up quarters in the National Military Encampment by 8 o'clock tonight. From an early hour this morning companies and regiments have been arriving from the South and West. The scene in and around the camp is a busy one.
WASHINGTON, June 29.--The following letter has been sent to the Commissioner of the General Land Office since the publication of the report of the Commissioner to the Secretary of the Interior:

CITY OF MEXICO, June 29, via Galveston, --Included among the companies whose subsidies were stopped is the Vera Cruz Harbor Improvement Company, a French concern. It is announced to-day that this company will have to suspend operations, leaving the most important part of its work incomplete.

Charges of neglect of duty and improper conduct were yesterday preferred by Superintendent Murray to the Police Commissioners against Capt. John Sanders, of the Twentythird Precinct, for permitting the faro bank of "Capt." Frank Wells to do business at One Hundred and Fifth-street and Third-avenue and failing to break up the establishment. This is the place which was raided by the Superintendent on Saturday night. The charges will be submitted to the Police Commissioners to-day.

The little box of an apartment up under the roof of the Stewart Building that little Referee Thomas calls his office was so suffocatingly hot yesterday afternoon that pretty Mrs. Truman was made seriously ill, and the reference in her suit for divorce against her husband, ...

CHICAGO, June 29.--At a late hour tonight the indications are that the conductors and drivers on the West Division-Street Railway will go on strike to-morrow. The railroad company recently discharged several members of the Conductors ...

SHENANDOAH, Penn., June 29.--This place was invaded by 30 or 40 intoxicated tramps yesterday, who assembled at the Red Bridge, on the outskirts of the town, and remained there untill 11 O'clock last night, when they made a raid on Stamptown, situated in the extreme end of the First Ward.

An incident which occurred the other day in a neighboring city ought to prove a valuable suggestion to scientific persons and manufacturers. A child weighing about sixty pounds fell out of a fourthstory window into the paved courtyard below.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 29,--The Supreme Court to-day rendered a decision in the celebrated Hill-Sharon divorce case, denying the plaintiff's motion to dismiss the appeal, and staying all proceedings for payment of counsel fees and alimony pending the appeal.

The political and other friends of the Hon. James O'Brien had a very select piece of news to discuss last night. It was stated that the leader of the Independent Democracy was likely to be appointed United States Marshal for this district, and in circles where he is best ...

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 29.--A hotly contested prize fight took place Sunday afternoon at a spot seven miles west of Weatherford, on the Texas Pacific Road. The principals were the "St. Joe kid," of Fort Worth, weight 152 pounds, and "kid" Bridges, of the Gordon Coal Mines, weight ...
WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 29.--Hanlan and Lee will row on Friday on silvia Lake, St. Lawrence County, for a purse of $1,000. On Saturday they will row again at Clayton.
The fluctuations in the price of oil yesterday made the market very active and somewhat exciting. The price opened at 92 . It declined to 91 and subsequently advanced to 94, closing at 93 5/8.
Room Committeemen Goepel and Ware, of the Produce Exchange, have reconsidered their determination to expel "Aunty" Higgins and "Aunty" Kelly, the venerable apple women, from the building.

The big thermometer at Hudnut's inflicated a temperature of 84 at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Six hours later the mercury in the same thermometer was down to 62 . This extraordinary change was brought about by a gusty visit from a cold wave which had been traveling in this direction from the Northwest ...

S.J. Hart, a lifelong resident of this city, was found dead in bed at Heart's Ease, his Summer residence, on Storm King Mountain, last Sunday morning. His death was caused by a carbuncle on his neck. Ten days previous to his death the carbuncle first showed itself in the form of n pimple the size of a pin head.

CHICAGO, June 29.--The schooner J.S. Taylor, Capt. Hanson, which reached this port to-day, brought four shipwrecked yachtsmen who had been picked up in the middle of Lake Michigan, after being afloat in a heavy sea for 12 hours.

The cool wave sent shivers over the visitors outside the hotel at Manhattan Beach last night, but within a private dining room a merry party of diners felt anything but cold. They were military men, 42 in all, who had come down to the dinner of the Officers' Association ...

MONTREAL, June 29.--A meeting of the Free Navigation League was held this moring, when it was decided to appoint a delegation to go to Ottawa to-morrow to urge upon the Government the necessity of immeditately assuming the Lake St. Pater Channel debt and of considering the other grievous burdens which the traffic by the great Canadian waterway has to bear.

This bank commences business July 1, prox., at the corner of Wall and Pearl streets, under special favorable auspices. Its Board of Directors consist of some of the leading east side merchants, among whom may be mentioned James E. Ward, of James E. Ward Co.; Michael ...

The announcement that the "round-up" would be at the mouth of Crow Creek on Thursday induced many of our citizens of the "ten derfoot" section to avail themselves of the only opportunity they would have during the year to see a "round-up" at so short a distance from Greeley. For this purpose many were up by 3:30 O'clock on Thursday morning and ready for ...

William W. Richards, at one time of California, afterward of Chicago, and at present of this city, is anxious to discover what has become of $25,000 to which he fell heir on the death of his wife, and of which he knew nothing until a few months ago. Richards married in San Francisco. His wife was an actress, and the` widow of Theodore T. Cooke.

One of a party of hardy Scots, who, hearing that Mount Vesuvius was in a state of ferment, determined to, and did, ascend the laboring pile, wrote from San Remo, on May 22, to the Edinburgh Scotsman as account of the adventure, in part as follows: Horses and a guide were awaiting as at 1 A.M.

CHICAGO, JUNE 29,--The hearing of the Mackin perjury case was begun in the Criminal Court, before Judge Moran, this morning. The substance of the indictment is that the defendant, Joseph C. Mackin, appeared Jan. 12 last as a witness before the special Grand Jury impaneled by Judge Rogers to investigate the Eighteenth ...

A brother of Vice-President Wilson is a guide in the Bureau of Engraving and Printing at a dollar and a half a day, and President Cleveland is asked to give him something better. It is curious how the same blood which produces greatness in one member of a family produces mediocrity or worse in another.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 29.--The priest of the parish in which the riot occurred yesterday is the Rev. Vincent Sewandowski. He has for the past three years in some way made himself obnoxious to a portion of his flock, but has heretofore refused to resign, asserting that the Bishop would not fill his place should he leave.
CHICAGO, June 29.--The following will appear in the Farmers' Review to-morrow, as the result of a summary of the crop reports up to the close of the present month:
William Keyes, 45 years of age, by occupation a nurse, fell from the roof of the tenement house No. 149 West Fourth-street, about 11 o'clock last night, and was instantly killed.

Hermon Paterson, of No. 120 Bloomfieldstreet, Hoboken, and George Bickman. living at No. 86 River-street, Hoboken, were in a small rowboat on the North River last evening and attempted to catch on to the tugboat America. Their boat was upset and Bickman was drowned. His body was not recovered.

AUBURN, N.Y., June 29.--Fish, the convict banker, spent a quiet Sunday in the receiving cell at the prison here, reading a small book part of the time, but sitting at the head of the bed busy with his own thoughts most of the day.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 30.--The schooner Elias Runyon, of New-Brunswick, N. J., sand ladon, before reported as sunk in Buzzard's Bay, arrived here this afternoon in tow of the tug T.A. Scott, Jr., with a steam pump on board. She is full of water.

Judge Wheeler has rendered a decision in the United States Circuit Court denying a motion to remand to the State courts the suit of Julien T. Davies, Receiver of Grant Ward, against Walter Johnson, Receiver of the Marine Bank.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 30.--The Brown University crew arrived to-day and took up their quarters with the Cornells and Bowdoins at the Eyrie. Their boat, for which they found a place at O'Leary's, is a Waters paper shell, 40 feet long, 19 inches wide, and weighs about 130 pounds. It is fitted with the Davis sliding seats and rowlocks.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 30.--A very bitter war between the Prohibitionists and AntiProhibitionists has been in progress at Armourdale, just across the line, for several months past, and several persons who endeavored to smuggle liquor into the State have been arrested and fined for the offense.

The inaugural reception of the female department of Grammar School No. 76, of which Miss Kare G. Broderick is the Principal, took place yesterday, and attracted to the handsome schoolhouse at Lexington-avenue and Sixtyeighth-street a large assemblage of the parents and friends of the pupils.

CHICAGO, June 30.--The residents on the "West Side" have come to town to-day on foot, in wagons, and every way except by the usual street car lines. The expected strike of the drivers and conductors on the West Division Railway began this morning and has lasted throughout the day.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 30.--The proceedings of the United States District Court here have been enlivened by a peculiar incident. Several men had been convicted of moonshining when the case of Dick Morris was called.
Sergt. Cunningham, of the Central Park police, and several others, yesterday made a raid upon the cowboys in Morningside Park and captured 16 cows that were grazing there and impounded them.

WALTON, N.Y., June 30.--In 1866 the Rondout and Oswego Railroad Company obtained a charter to build a railroad from Rondout to Oneonta. The towns along the line bonded themselves to aid in the promotion of the enterprise.
When Gen. PORFIRIO DIAZ came into office as President of Mexico in December last he found the Treasury bankrupt, many of the dues of the Government uppaid, and the republic on the verge of anarchy.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 30.--Prof. Joseph K. Chickering, for 12 years Associate Professor of English Literature at Amherst College, has tendered his resignation. He feels it necessary to secure relief from his continuous class work.

PITTSBURG, June 30.--The proposed advance in freight rates on the through lines west of this city will not go into effect to-morrow, as was the original intention of the officers of the Western roads. At the conference held in Cincinnati last week by representatives of the Western roads it was decided to advance the rates.
OTTAWA, June 30.--A large deputation, representing the forwarding interests of Montreal waited upon the Government to-day to urge the total abolition of tolls on the St. Lawrence canals.

Edward A. Boyd and George H. Boyd, his son, glass importers, who were convicted of fraudulently passing plate glass through the Custom House by means of free permits, came before Judge Benedict, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, to receive sentence.

BOSTON, June 30.--It is stated that subscriptions to the extent of $2,000,000 have been secured for the building of the proposed bridge over the Hudson River at Storm King. The friends of the enterprise here are feeling jubilant.

LONDON, June 30.--A dispatch from Teheran states that 1,000 Persians are at work constructing the Transcaspian Railway. Warlike preparations are still being continued by Russia. Rumors are in circulation in the bazaars of...

At a Special Term of the Supreme Court, held in Newburg-yesterday, Judge Brown heard arguments for and against a motion made by the United States Trust Company, as Trustee of the West Shore mortgage, to compel the New-York.
There is an excellent opportunity for the establishment of a new sect based upon the doctrine that kisses should be exchanged only between those of the same sex.

The Custom House was the scene of unusual stir and anxiety yesterday. The 300 and odd employes who are not protected by the civil service law were visibly ill at ease, and some of them appeared to be working in a quiet way to get a favorable word spoken in their behalf to the new Collector.
MONTREAL, June 30.--Information from the salmon streams of this Province and of NewBrunswick indicate that they are at present being fished by a large number of distinguished anglers.

Lights burned as brightly as ever in the showy restauraunt of the Hotel Brunswick last night, and there were no indications in any part of the famous hosteiry that the establishment was to be closed on July 1. Clerks and other employes insisted that the hotel was not to be closed.
ALBANY, June 30.--The Morning Express will appear to-morrow under its new management with Prof. Lewis Boss as editor. Referring to the report that it would be a Blaine organ it says:

ERIE, Penn., June 30.--James Clary, a notorious burglar, from Pittsburg, was fatally shot to-day in an encounter with the police while issuing from one of seven stores he and his gang had robbed during the night.
LONDON, June 30.--The Times in an editorial thinks Mr. Gladstone's letter may check the Radical unrest and enable the Conservatives to finish the business and dissolve early in August.

In the suit of Levi L. Brown and others against the insolvent firm of Halsted, Haines Co. and its Assignee, brought for the purpose of having the assignment of the firm set aside as having been made, not for the benefit of creditors, ...

Thousands of Brooklyn people turned out yesterday afternoon and gathered about the site of the new Hall of Records to witness the ceremonies attending the laying of the cornerstone of that edifice, and the city itself was decorated as for a holiday.

Serenity and good feeling marked the meeting of the Tammany Committee on Organization last night until the report was circulated that Mr. Dorsheimer had been selected as United States District Attorney and Martin T. McMahon as Marshal of this district.

GONCORD, N.H., June 30.--Col. William R. Patten, ex-Clerk of the House of Representatives end ex-City Solicitor of Manchester, was committed to the asylum for the insane in this city to-day. His insanity resulted from softening of the brain.

NEW-LONDON, June 30.--The new steam yacht Wanda, built for Messrs. William Woodward and James Stillman, is a success. She had a trial trip to-day from New-York to New-London in a rough sea, and developed such speed that it is believed that she can beat anything of her inches in a long run.
The United States man-of-war Omaha, which was repaired at Portsmouth at such great expense, and which was recently ordered to the...
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 30.--Maud S. arrived here to-day and was immediately taken to the track at Glennville. She occupies her old quarters at the Orchard between Phallas and Maxy Cobb.
MOUNT McGREGOR, June 30.--A dreary day, with rain part of the time, has made outdoors the reverse of attractive and enabled Gen. Grant to put to his credit further rest and quiet.

From one end of the American metropolis to the other everything that could possess the slightest interest to foreigners has been shown to Admiral Lacombe, Commander de Saune, and the gallant officers of the Isere and La Flore.

CHICAGO, June 30.--The trial of Joseph C. Mackin for falsely swearing before a Grand Jury that he had nothing to do with the printing of the bogus ballots in the Leman-Brand contest, was continued before Judge Moran and a jury to-day.
OWATONNA, Minn., June 30.--Sells Brothers' circus train was wrecked here this morning while on its way from Faribault to Austin.

The clouds lowered at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, and the wind blew with vigor, bringing with it a late October temperature not at all in consonance with the desires of those who ventured near the sea lightly clad. A great crowd gathered at the track and has its patience severely tested with long delays in starting the races.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--The 300 or 400 people who went to Echo Park this afternoon saw a good wrestling bout between Owen McCarty and Matt Acton, a young brother of the invincible Joe.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--A rumor, pleasant for Tammany, and calculated, if true, to justify the prediction made a day or two ago that the organization would get the places of District Attorney and Marshal, got abroad here to-night.

CORNING, N.Y., June 30.--Marcellus Rouse, a well-to-do young farmer, became a convert a month or so ago, to the Salvation Army's religious belief, under the ministration of a branch of the army in this place.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 30, via Galveston. --The Government this morning announced in the Diario Oficial, its plan for the consolidation of the entire debt of the country with the exception of the floating debt, which is already provided for in an authorized issue of $25,000,000 bonds at 6 per cent.

DETROIT, Mich., June 30.--Christopher R. Mabley, head of the great clothing house which bears his name and one of the most prominent merchants in the West, died early this morning at his residence in this city.

CHICAGO, June 30.--William S. Reyburn, of Philadelphia, who yesterday recovered a judgment by confession against the Consumers' Gas, Fuel, and Light Company for $30,076, today filed a creditor's bill against the company, asking for the appointment of a Receiver.

The College of St. Francis Xavier, which is conducted by the Jesuit Fathers, in West Fifteenth-street, has just been endowed with the large sum of $100,000, through the munificence of Mr. John F. O'Connor, S.J., a graduate of the Class of '72.

Andrew Wesley Kent, William G. Mitchell, George W. Palmer, George Steel, Louis Rosenfeld, and Henry Rosener are the incorporators of the American Standard Ordnance Company, whose certificate of incorporation...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30.--The reception of Judge Foraker and Gen. Kennedy, the candidates for Governor and Lieutenant-Governor on the Republican ticket, was one of the best conducted affairs of the kind ever undertaken in Columbus.
A meeting of members of the grain trade in the Produce Exchange was held yesterday for purpose of discussing the following amendment to the rules which was suggested some time ago:

Some days ago William M. Smith, Health Officer of this port, declared that he intended to issue a circular defining exactly what be would require in the matter of the disinfection or imported rags. He at the same time expressed a willingness to give a hearing to the rag importers before deciding upon any fixed policy.
CHICAGO, June 30.--Frederick H. Marsh, the new United States Marshal for the Northern District of Illinois, will to-morrow enter office as the successor of H.M. Jones.

BATAVIA, N.Y., June 30.--There were delegates present from all but two towns at the Genesee County District Convention of Prohibitionists here to-day, and five delegates, in accordance with the new system of representation, were elected to the State Convention to be held in Syracuse.
BOSTON, June 30.--The annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club took place to-day off Marblehead over a triangular course, all yachts to sail over the course twice, making the distance 30 miles.
BALTIMORE, June 30.--The home club won a slow and tiresome game from Brooklyn to-day. Some few pretty plays were made, but errors were frequent and costly, and both pitchers were batted freely.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--Secretary Lamar has appointed his son, L.Q.C. Lamar, Jr., as his stenographer and private secretary, to fill the vacancy caused by the promotion of E.P. Hanna, made in February last. Mr. Hanna will remain with Secretary Lamar in a confidential capacity.
On Saturday night Policeman James Arrandale went to the house of Mrs. Julia Borleon, No. 53 Holland-street, Newark, N.J., in a grossly intoxicated condition and demanded admittance.

Mrs. John McCullough and her two sons, Mrs. Wirth, of Dunmore, Penn., sister of the unfortunate actor, and William F. Johnson, a lawyer, are expected to arrive here from Philadelphia this forenoon to confer with some of Mr. McCullough's friends regarding the actor's mental condition and the future disposition of his property.
SHENANDOAH, Penn., June 30.--The tramp disturbance here is occupying the attention of the authorities, while the arrival of another gang to-day increases the excitement of the citizens.

DETROIT, June 30.--The second game of the series with the New-York Club on the home grounds, was played here to-day before an audience of about 1,000, and was won by the visitors in one inning on errors.

COLUMBUS, June 30.--Charles J. Canda, Charles W. Opdyke, and Grinnell Burt, as purchasing Trustees, acting in behalf of certain holders of the first mortgage bonds of the Ohio Central Railroad Company, who purchased all the right and franchise of that road, to-day filed...
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 30.--The colored men of MahaskaCounty, largely coal miners, have held a convention at Oskaloosa and nominated...
All probabilities of a rate war among the manufacturers of wall paper are at an end for another year at least.
The meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club will close to-day with an interesting series of races, in which several of the cracks are to compete.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30.--Henry Martin, for nearly 30 years President of the Manufacturers and Traders' Bank here, resigned to-day. He was one of the oldest bank officials in the country. He is in his eighty-third year.
MONTREAL, June 30.--A printed report of the Canada Northwest Land Company has been sent out from England in advance of the meeting which took place in London last Friday.
CHICAGO, June 30.--A warrant was issued to-day for Morris Brown, a baker, charged with deserting his wife for his housekeeper, a woman named Anna.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--The revenues of the Post Office Department will be seriously affected by the new legislation. To-morrow letters weighing one ounce or less may be sent through the mails for 2 cents and the rate on newspapers mailed by publishers will he reduced from 2 cents to 1 cent per pound.

It was with a pale face, a tired, listless manner, and eyes that looked as heavy as if she had spent the night in watching at the bedside of the sick, as she used to do when she was a professional nurse, that Lucille Yseult Dudley faced for the second time, yesterday, the jurors who were trying her for shooting O'Donovan Rossa.
The Directors of the New-York Central Railroad met yesterday, and without promulgating any financial statement for the last quarter declared a quarterly dividend of per cent., payable July 15.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30.--The horticultural exhibition, for which the members of the Natural History Society have been preparing for several weeks, was opened this afternoon in the old Unitarian Church.

MONTREAL, June 30.--The receipts at the Montreal Custom House for the six mouths ending June 30, 1885, were $3,166,622.65, as compared with $3,097,557.65 during the first six months of 1884, showing an increase of $69,065.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 30.--Lottie Watson, the woman with the iron jaw with Van Amburgh's circus, met with an accident this afternoon that will cause her retirement from the ring.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 30.--Reports have been received from 33 points in the Arkansas Valley regarding the condition of the wheat harvested. There were seven questions asked, the principal ones being as to the yield as compared with last year and the quality and size of the berry.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--The First Controller of the Treasury has received a letter from George B. Loring, late Commissioner of Agriculture, acknowledging receipt of his letter announcing a disallowance in the account of payments for the laboratory from Oct. 1, 1884, to April 1, 1885.

Capt. Kelly, of the steamship Santo Domingo, which arrived from San Domingo City last evening, reports that on June 17 the schooner Susie P. Oliver, bound for this port, struck on the rocks while leaving the harbor of San Domingo City.

James Henry Work, brother-in-law of William S. Warner, and a member of the broken firm of Davies, Work McNamee, who in the palmy days of Grant Ward were counsel for that firm, fell into the hands of Francis N. Bangs yesterday afternoon.
NEW-ORLEANS, June 30.--About 1 o'clock to-day Andrew J. Dumont committed suicide by shooting himself through the head with a revolver at his home in Algiers.
NOGALES, Arizona, June 30.--It is rumored that the Yaqui Indians have defeated the Mexicans, killing 400, including Gen. Garcia, and wounding Gen. Loaiza.
When the steamer Richard Stockton left Jersey City yesterday morning she carried a very fair representation of the newspaper talent of New-Jersey and Pennsylvania.

HAWLEY, Penn., June 30.--On Saturday Jonathan Bryant and his wife, of Berlin Township, in this county, were on their way to Honesdale. They were riding in an open buggy, to which was hitched a spirited young horse.
Langsdorf Co., who have been conducting a public Exchange at Nos. 31 and 33 Broadway for dealing in stocks and petroleum, suspended yesterday.

The Queen's bounty of 63 has be received by William Piercy, a farm laborer at Reighton, near Driffield, Yorkshire, whose wife recently gave birth to three children--two girls and a boy-all of whom are doing well.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., June 30.--The monthly oil report for June will be given to the oil trade to-morrow. It shows that during the month 245 new wells were completed, with a production on June 30 of 3,249 barrels.

TORONTO, June 30.--Sentence of 10 years' imprisonment each was passed here to-day on Thomas White and Charles Bent, who were convicted a few days ago of getting forged circular letters on the National Bank of Scotland cashed at a bank here.

The new postal law increasing the unit of weight for letters to be delivered for 2 cents will go into elect this morning. Letters weighing not more than one ounce will now require only 2 cents postage.

CHICAGO, June 30.--J.W. Watts, one of the heaviest jewelers in Racine, Wis., turned his entire stock over to his creditors to-night, and it will be sold at creditors' sale. J.H. French, of Chicago, representing several creditors, has the stock in hand. When sold it is claimed 100 cents on the dollar will be paid.

Argument was made before Judge Brown, in the United States District Court, yesterday, in regard to the prize vessel Ambrose Light, which was seized off the coast of the United States of Colombia by the United States man-of-war Alliance, as a privateer.

TROY, Penn., June 30.--A few months ago the coal mines at Carbon Run, Bradford County, were abandoned, and the village was in a short time deserted by most of the miners, who were its sole inhabitants.

It is impossible to keep human nature cut of a jury box. That seems to be the explanation of the verdict acquitting Mrs. DUDLEY. If O'DONOVAN had been a decent citizen pursuing an innocent calling and Mrs. DUDLEY had shot him, without any previous acquaintance with him, the act would have been without doubt proof of "homicidal mania."

The consummation of an important pooling agreement between the railroads known as the Gould and Huntington systems was semiofficially announced yesterday. It will go into practical effect immediately.

At a parish church in Dorsetshire on Sunday week a considerable sensation was produced in consequence of the Vicar "publishing" his own bans of marriage. The reverend, gentleman is in his eightieth year.

The gentlemen whose reputation as prophets and guides would be hopelessly ruined if President CLEVELAND did not turn out a hypocrite--and an incompetent one at that--are very much delighted because his appointment of a Collector and Surveyor of the Port of New-York has not met with unqualified approval from some of his independent supporters.

The gentlemen who went to Washington on behalf of the American steamship companies that carry the United States mail between New-York and foreign countries, to induce Postmaster-General Vilas to divide up the $400,000 appropriated by Congress for the payment of such mail charges, returned yesterday in a very disappointed frame of mind.
Judge Henry Van Reed died in Reading, Penn., yesterday, in the sixty-fourth year of his age, of a complication of diseases.

A very large audience filled Chiekering Hall yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the annual Commencement exercises of the pupils of St. Bridget's Academy, Nos. 313 and 315 East Tenth-street. The progamme included some 20 numbers of music, dramatic, and literary selections.

Pallid and weak from the shock of the wounds he inflicted on himself last Thursday, John Carpenter had to be supported by two Deputy Sheriffs as he entered the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning.
H.W. Jenkins, a broker and a member of the Petroleum Exchange, is going into the country with his family, who reside at No. 308 West Forty-fifth-street.
A considerable sensation has been created in Vienna society by the announcement of the betrothal of Prince Lichtenstein to the daughter of a merchant in that city.
SYRACUSE, June 30.--The First Presbyterian Church, whose congregation is perhaps the leading one in the city in point of intelligence and social standing, has called to the Pastorate...

SCRANTON, Penn., June 30.--About 1:30 o'clock this morning an explosion of gas which shook the entire city and caused something like a general panic occurred at one of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company's coal shafts in the northwestern portion of Scranton.
TRENTON, June 30.--Robert Lanning, a painter, living at No. 107 West Front-street, was arrested last night for assault and battery on the charge of Emma A. Lanning, his wife.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 30.--The beautiful campus of College Hill, which in some respects is unquestionably the finest in the country, was in holiday garb to-day for the class tree exercises of Hamilton College.

OTTAWA, June 30.--People from the maritime Provinces have become alarmed at the prospect of having a large number of Spanish steamers in their ports this year, as the result of the stringent regulations which are being enforced...
Washington E. Connor's steam yacht, the Utowana, which ran into pier No. 4 North River, a week ago yesterday, met with another accident last Sunday.

KINGSTOWN, N.Y., June 30.--This has been a gala day in the pretty Huguenot village of New-Paltz, 15 miles from here, the occasion being the visit of Gov. Hill and the commission appointed to inspect the academy and grounds and to receive proposals from the Trustees for converting the same into a State Normal School.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 30.--The Pioneer Press has received reports from over 1,000 points in the Northwest on the condition of Spring wheat.

The review of the business of the country for the past six months prepared by R.G. Dun Co. indicates a more hopeful condition of business than has been generally anticipated, owing to the universal reports of dullness, want of profit, and prospective depression.

KINGSTOWN, N.Y., June 30.--The weather here last night and to-day was extremely cold for this time of year. This evening the thermometer registered 60 . It is reported that snow fell last night at Durham, Greene County. Owing to the cold fires were built in the mountain houses in the Catskills, and they were also found necessary in the cars on the Stony Clove and Catskill Mountain Railroad.

LIVERPOOL, June 30.--The White Star Line steamer Adriatic, which has arrived here from New-York, reports that on Thursday at 9 P.M. she sighted the Cunard Line steamer Gallia, Capt. Murphy, which left New-York June 20 for Queenstown and Liverpool.

OLEAN, N.Y., June 30.--Seven years ago Norman Barnhart, of Sherman, Chautauqua County, was bitten by a dog which he always insisted was mad. Since that time he has lived in constant terror of dying of hydrophobia.
When the steamship Holland, of the National Line, from London and Havre, arrived off Quarantine yesterday, W.G. Hibdige, one of the firemen, was found to be suffering from smallpox.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 30.--The funeral Of Andrew Peterson, the murdered police officer, took place this afternoon. Mayor Wallace, whose term of office expires to-night, and Mayorelect Rhoads, with their Chief of Police and full forces, were in attendance.
LONDON, June 30.--M. Patenotre, the representative of France in the peace negotiations with China, has gone to Pekin, where he will reside as the French Ambassador.

Mayor Grace, Controller Loew, and Commissioner Squire, of the Department of Public Works, will meet at noon to-day to arrange for the appointment of Commissioners to superintend the placing of the telegraph and telephone wires under ground.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 30.--Joseph M. Worrall tells a wonderful story. He says he came from California to see the Exposition. He has been a miner, and when he was told he could join one of the Honduras mining expeditions with profit to himself he resolved upon going.

Miss Parloa delivered her second of a course of five lectures on the subject. "How to Cook for Patients," before the school for trained nurses at the Charity Hospital on Blackswell's Island yesterday afternoon, and was listened to by about 50 of the students.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--About 2,000 persons witnessed a great "slugging" game to-day between the Athletics and Metropolitans. The home club, however, did much the better fielding, and thus secured a victory. The score is as follows:
OTTAWA, Ontario, June 30.--Much opposition was offered in Parliament to-night to a vote of $50,000, to be paid to a line of steamers making fortnightly trips between Quebec and France.

TROY, N.Y., June 30.--Judge Westbrook to-day handed down a decision denying the application of John F. Bridgeman for an order directing Benjamin H. Hall to turn over to Bridgeman the books and papers of the Chamberlain's office.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--Leave of absence for three months, with permission to go beyond sea, to take effect as soon after July 1 as his services can be spared by his immediate commanding officer, has been granted Capt. James C. Ayres, ordnance department.
About 100 boys, from 7 to 14 years of age, were gathered in the chapel of Grammar School No. 38, on Clarke-street, yesterday afternoon to assist in the celebrations of the graduating class.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 30.--At a meeting of the Alumni of Williams College today the voting for Alumni Trustees resulted in the election of Judge J.M. Barker, of Pittsfield, for five years, and James Gilfillan, of New-York, for three years. David Dudley Field, of NewYork, made a pleasant speech.

Gilbert Hunter, an old man 85 years of age, was charged with being an impostor in the Tombs Police Court yesterday. He had called at the Vestry office of the Rev. Dr. Dix and told a pitiful story of suffering.

Two hundred or more voters in Senator Gibbs's (Eighth) Senatorial district," without reward to political affiliations," as the circular calling them together announced, had an enthusiastic meeting in Grand Opera House Hall last night to nominate a candidate for Senator.

CHICAGO, June 30.--One of the Illinois statutes, under the head of "Gaming," provides that any person who, by betting on any lot, casualty, chance, or contingent event, loses any sum of money, may recover it by suit against the party to whom he lost it within six months.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 30.--The Class Day exercises at Amherst College to-day were attended by a large crowd. The morning was occupied with an exhibition by the Sophomore Class in the Pratt Gymnasium, a concert in the college church, and the usual ceremony of planting the class ivy, H.V. Abbott, of Cornwall-onHudson, being the orator, and Charles H. Smith, of Hinsdale, N.H., the poet.

Herman Alexander, the alleged keeper of the gambling house as No. 130 Hester-street that was raided by the police on Monday evening, was taken to the Essex Market Police Court yesterday. Fifteen men who were found in the place were also arraigned. Justice Gorman held Alexander in $700 bail for trial and discharged the other prisoners.

Lawrence O'Brien and George T. Truman, the eminent gamblers who cut and shot each other in Broadway on the evening of May 14, met each other in the Harlem Police Court early yesterday morning for the first time since the affray. O'Brien arrived first.

BALTIMORE, June 30.--An inventory of the estate of the late John W. Garrett, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was filed this morning in the Orphans' Court of Baltimore County by the Executors, Messrs. William F. Frick and T. Harrison Garrett.
The Columbia Yacht Club held their eighteenth regatta on the Hudson off Bloomingdale Heights yesterday. A good breeze from the northwest prevailed during a greater part of the race.

POTSDAM, July 1.--The Crown Prince and Princess of Germany gave a reception to-day to United States Minister Pendleton and wife.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 1.--Rosa Meisel and Sarah and Fannie Rosenberg were burned to death at an early hour this morning during a fire which destroyed the frame tenement house of Dan Odell, Nos. 349 and 353 Broadway. Three families occupied the second floor.

Among capitalists and business men in this city who had hoped that the Administration would infuse a vigorous reform element into the Union Pacific Directory, the appointments of Government Directors made Tuesday were not received with satisfaction.
The members of the Music Teachers' National Association held the first session of their ninth annual meeting at the Academy of Music yesterday.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 1.--The weather this morning was just cool enough to make it pleasant to attend the closing exercises of Williams College.
DETROIT, July 1.--To-day's baseball contest was an example of the fact that one error often decides the fate of a game. Detroit had a lead of 1 in the seventh inning. Connor got his base on balls.

A party of over 500 Mormon immigrants arrived yesterday on the Guion steamship Wisconsin. Elder J. Hansen was in charge of the party.

Mayor Grace, Controller Loew, and Commissioner of Works Squire met in the Mayor's office yesterday as a commission to appoint Commissioners to superintend the placing of telephone and telegraph wires under ground.

The annual meeting of the Newark (N.J.) Turn Verein was held last night, and W. M. Krause was elected First Speaker. There is some prospect that the Riege, which won the first prize, may go to the Turnfest in Dresden. Liberal subscriptions have been made for that purpose.
WATERVILLE, Me., July 1.--The graduating class of Colby University held its final exercises this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The President has determined to reappoint Commodore Montgomery Sicard as Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance. The appointment will not be made, however, until next Autumn, at the expiration of four years from the time he was confirmed by the Senate.
Foreman Daniel H. Callaghan, who was recently promoted to that position, was yesterday assigned to Engine Company No. 31.
Ed Hammons, the janitor at the Capitol, has a tendency to indulge in dreams whenever he falls asleep--and some of the dreams are unpleasant and oftentimes queer.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The President to-day appointed Thomas H. Beale as Postmaster at Hamilton, N.Y., vice E.W. Cushman, resigned. The Postmaster-General appointed the following named fourth class Postmasters: Benjamin Kenyon at Triangle, N. Y., and Nathan Waterbury at Forest Port, N.Y. There are at present 11 Presidential Post Offices where the commissions of the Postmasters have expired and where no appointments have yet been made. Among these are Waterford, N.Y., and Bellefonte, Penn.

JACKSON, Miss., July 1.--The State Prohibition Convention held its fourth annual meeting in the House of Representatives to-day. Three hundred delegates, representing 52 out of 74 counties, were present; about 30 of the number were colored men.

The June meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club was brought to a close yesterday with the most exciting day's sport of the season. The programme was a most attractive one, and the crowd that went down to Sheepshead Bay was probably the largest of the meeting.

CLINTON, N.Y., July 1.--The stone church was packed this afternoon by a crowd eager to enjoy the Class Day exercises at Hamilton College. E.W. Ruggles presided. T.C. Miller was orator and Irving F. Wood poet.

OSWEGO, July 1.--Chief of Police Joel A. Baker died to-day from erysipelas and brain fever superinduced by a blow on the back of the head received about two weeks ago, accidentally, while playing baseball at a picnic.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 1.--A disgraceful prize fight occurred outside of the city's limits this afternoon between John Kelly, of this city, and James Gorman, of England for a private purse and the gate receipts.

Mrs. John McCullough, the wife of the tragedian, and Mrs. Wirth, his sister, of Dunsmore, Penn., arrived in this city yesterday with their lawyer, and were for some time in conference with Mr. Conner, at the St. James Hotel.

TROY, N.Y., July 1.--Chamberlain B.H. Hall to-day began an action against Mayor Fitzgerald and John F. Bridgeman, the Mayor's appointee to succeed Hall for $10,000 damages alleged to have been sustained by Hall by the police, acting under ordors of Fitzgerald and Bridgeman, violently ejecting him from the Chamberlain's office on Jan. 26.

The first performance of an entirely novel exhibition was presented last evening at Manhattan Beach in the amphitheatre formerly devoted to the Manhattan Beach Bathing Company, which has been refitted and contains seats for 2,500 people.
Constable Daley, of Jersey City, yesterday arrested Edward Hernemeir, a German boy, 19 years of age, on a charge of having abandoned his 16-year-old wife.

LONDON, July 1.--At the Newcastle and Gosforth Park Summer meeting to-day, the race for the Northumberland Plate of 1,000 sovereigns was won by Mr. A. Craig's (formerly Mr. J.R. Keene's) 5-year-old ch. h. Blue Grass. Mr I'Anson's 3-year-old b.c. Hambledon was second and Mr. R. Jardine's 5-year-old br. h. Greenbank third. There were seven starters.

Coroner Levy began an inquest yesterday in the case of William H. Howe, a painter, who died at the New-York Hospital on June 15 from injuries received by the fall of a scaffolding at No. 80 Madison-street about June 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1.--Newport's fashionable flower show continues to draw a large number of patrons. The attendance this evening was unusually large. The awards on plants were to have been made to-day, but it was decided not to announce them until to-morrow.

The jury in CARPENTER'S case was out yesterday for ten minutes and found him sane and guilty. The day before the jury in the case of Mrs. DUDLEY was out five minutes and found her insane and innocent.

BALTIMORE, July 1.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judges Bond and Morris filed their opinion in the case of Stewart and others against the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal.
Gotthold Haug, who was jointly indicted with Charles A. Buddensiek for manslaughter, was discharged yesterday by Judge Gildersleeve on his own recognizance.

In just 10 minutes after they had left it, at the conclusion of Judge Barrett's charge, the jury is the trial of John Carpenter returned to the room of the Court of Oyer and Terminer and announced that they had found the prisoner guilty of murder in the first degree.

Thomas James, member of the Illinois Legislature from Randolph County, who was arraigned at Springfield Saturday on a charge of criminal assault on Nannie James, a little girl employed as a House page, was discharged after a four-hours' examination of the principal witness. It would seem to have been a deliberate attempt at blackmail on the part of the girl's parents.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 1.--Collector of Internal Revenue Troup took the oath of office before Judge Shipman at Hartford this morning, and took possession of the office. He recommissioned all of the present Deputy Collectors.
The Common Council of Rahway, N.J., at its meeting on Tuesday evening passed the annual tax levy.

Miss Elizabeth Devereux Umsted-Blake, a daughter of Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake, was married last evening at the Church of the Transfiguration to John Beverly Robinson, a young architect of this city.
VIENNA, July 1.--If the United States Government refuses to recall Mr. Keiley the Austrian Government will formally decline to recognize him.

With the debt statement of the month of June the Treasury gives to the public an abstract of the receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year. As has been expected, the former have been less and the latter more than last year.
WORCESTER, Mass., July 1.--The Intercollegiate Rowing Association could not have selected a lovelier spot for its annual regatta than Lake Quinsigamond.

The recent meeting of the importers at the Merchants' Club, and the subsequent visit of the committee to Washington to seek a revocation or modification of Secretary Manning's order of June 10 relative to reappraisements, have apparently been misunderstood by the mercantile community.

A young ward physician of this city was called, during the present week, to treat a case somewhat out of the usual line. A family in his district failed to elicit any response to the bell which was rung for the cook to send in dinner.

The Board of Health have been for weeks past considering the subject of stable manure, and discussing various suggestions for the proper removal and disposition of the vast quantities of manure which have heretofore been allowed to accumulate in this city.

BOSTON, Mass., July 1.--The annual report of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company for the year 1884 has been issued. The total earnings for the year were $1,086,862 and the expenses $1,159,013. There was no new main...

PITTSBURG, July 1.--Judge Ewing to-day rendered a decision which is of great interest to railroad contractors. Two months ago B.F. McGrann, the contractor and builder of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Road, was nonsuited in his case against the company to recover $600,000 for extras in constructing the defendant's railroad. He moved the court to take off the nonsuit.

LONDON, July 2.--John Bright has written a letter to Deputy Passy, of Paris, in which he says: "If European nations would accept commercial liberty--that is, moderate or abolish customs--Europe might soon tend to an era of perpetual peace.

The transfer of the office of Collector of this port from William H. Robertson to Edward L. Hedden was made with very little ceremony about 10:30 o'clock yesterday forenoon. Judge Robertson reached the office about 9 o'clock, and soon afterward Mr. Hedden came in.

Mr. John T. Raymond has not yet decided what play he will produce at the MadisonSquare Theatre a week from Monday, but the chances favor "Open House," a posthumous comedy by Henry J. Byron.

Mr. James Hatfield, a well-known citizen of Walker County, Ga., who lives near the State line, six miles from this city, was arrested last Friday on a very serious charge. Hatfield was employed as a teacher at the Dobb's schoolhouse prior to the present term.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of Naphtali Lodge, No. 10, .Independent Ordar Free Sons of Israel, was celebrated last evening at Sulzer's Harlem River Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1.--The trial of A.J. Spreckles, charged with a murderous assault on M.H. De Young, proprietor of the Chronicle, ended to-day. The jury rendered a verdict of "not guilty," and the defendant was discharged.

The tablet stone of the new Centennial Baptist Church, on Adelphi-street, near Myrtleavenue, Brooklyn, was put in place yesterday afternoon, with the celebrations usually attending a corner stone laying.

CHICAGO, July 1.--The oath of office was administered by Judge Blodgett to-day to Frederick H. Marsh as United States Marshal for the Northern District of Illinois. Mr. Marsh immediately appointed as Deputies W.H. Mitchell, of Freeport, and Carl Haerting, of Chicago. Mr. Haerting has been connected with the Illinois Staats-Zeitung, and was its Springfield correspondent during the last session of the Legislature. Both Deputies gave a bond of $10,000.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 1.--The first civil service examination held in the civil service room in the new Custom House took place today under the supervision of Judge Thoman, one of the Civil Service Commissioners.
Surrogate Rollins yesterday rendered a decision confirming the report of Referee Charles E. Soule in the controversy over the estate of John Russell, the miser printer,...
LIMA, July 1, via Galveston.--Minister Tovat on Monday advised the Government that Gen. Mas had resigned his command, as he insisted upon a peaceful arrangement with Gen. Caceres.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 1.--A duel with pistols was fought this morning at sunrise at the unfrequented place in the northern suburb of the city known as Lower City Park.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Eight thousand people witnessed the racing at the Washington Park grounds to-day, and the day was full of surprises for the fraternity. The track was in firstclass condition, though somewhat hard.

CHICAGO, July 1.--The second day of the strike of the conductors and drivers on the West Division-Street Railroad was marked by a good deal of excitement and some pretty hot brushes between the strikers and the men who were put on to take their places, backed by the police and Sheriff Hanchett's Deputies.
A large new map of Chicago was found hanging in the room of the Cable Railway Commission when the session opened yesterday morning.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 1.--Secretary Franklin B. Dexter to-day announced the result of the recent election for the two members of Yale's corporation.
The stock of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company (par value $100 a share) commanded $130 a share in the market two or three years ago.

MONTREAL, July 1.--The Chief of Police has discovered that a number of second-hand stores in this city are simply "fences," and the proprietors are in league with "fences" in NewYork and Boston, with whom they exchange stolen goods.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Joseph C. Mackin, the Democratic "fine worker" and ex-Secretary of the City and County Democratic Committees, spends to-night in the County Jail, and there is more or less sorrow in the circles in which Mr. Mackin has been wont to shine.
MOUNT McGREGOR, N.Y., July 1.--"In war," the Rev. Dr. Newman said this afternoon, when he returned from the Grant cottage, "the General was a man of surprises. He is no less so now.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 1.--The evidence in the Fiske will case was concluded here to-day. The trouble and delay of sending a commission to examine Prof. Fiske, now in Italy, was obviated by a stipulation that he would swear that he was ignorant of any limitations in the charter ...
TORONTO, July 1.--The Hanlan-Lee race here to-day was a huge fizzle, designed to attract thousands of pleasure seekers on a holiday to a pleasure resort on the island opposite Toronto.

President Little, of the Jersey Central Railroad, said yesterday that the Philadelphia and Reading Company had not paid the promised dividend, and furthermore, the Jersey Central officers did not expect that it would be paid. It is expected that a conference will be held today to determine what is best to be done relative to the default.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 1.--The Picayune will publish to-morrow a statement which tends to lessen the confidence in official facts. The coinage act of 1873 made it the duty of the Director of the Mint to have the general supervision of all United States mints or assay offices.
LONDON, July 1.--The Cabinet Council to-day decided to entirely abandon coercion in Ireland and to rely upon a strict administration of the general law.

The papers agree in saying that William H. Robertson has made as good a Collector as a defective system of laws permits and as a Treasury policy virtually subordinating him to the Surveyor and Naval Officer in many respects will allow.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--C.B. Phipps, the lessee of Belmont Park, and W.W. Bair, the trainer of Maud S., denied very vigorously today the statement in a Cleveland dispatch that the mare had arrived in that city, and was in training there preparatory to an attempt to lower her record. The tangled web of litigation concerning "The Mikado" is becoming more confusing, and threatens to introduce legal points of such extreme nicety that they will be carefully kept among the archives of the law.

The aggregate amount of July disbursements on corporate securities is nearly $50,000,000. This includes interest on bonds and dividends on stocks, which is payable from the 1st to the 15th of the month.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 1.--All the window glass factories in this district have closed for the Summer vacation--that is, until Sept, 1.

MADISON, Wis., July 1.--At the Dane County Medical Society's annual meeting last evening an interesting and unusual feature was the exhibition by Dr. Sethers, of Stoughton, of a young Norwegian named Iverson, who was suffering from leprosy. The patient presented a horrible appearance, his face being bloated and covered with ugly blotches, the whole red in color and strangely unnatural. The wife of Christian F. Mueller, of No. 308 West Kinney-street, Newark, N.J., died yesterday from accidental poisoning. She drank carbolic acid instead of soda water. The bottle was lying in the ice box. She was 30 years old.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Mr. J.H. McVicker, who was the last Chicago manager to give up stock companies, opened his twenty-ninth season this evening with a strong stock company in a new five-act American drama called "True Nobility," by John C. Freund. Mr. McVicker's theatre has been altered and greatly improved since it was closed, the reconstruction ...

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The President made the following appointments to-day: William W. Rockhill, of Maryland, to be Secretary of the Legation to China, and Charles Deuby. Jr., of Indiana, to be Second Secretary of the Legation to China.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The commission appointed by the President to visit the South American countries in the interest of the commerce of the United States has reported, under date of April 25, to the Department of State the result of its observations while at Lima, Peru.

Clapp Lynch about five weeks ago opened a liquor and billiard saloon at No. 2,009 Third-avenue. Both are well-known baseball players, Lynch being the pitcher of the Metropolitans.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--Ever since the inauguration of Mayor William B. Smith the gamblers and policy men of Philadelphia have openly and notoriously plied their calling.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Early in June the Chicago Board of Trade cut off quotations to the Louisville Board because it was found that they were being furnished by members of the board to nearly all the bucket shops in the South.

Before County Judge Isaac N. Mills, holding a Court of Sessions at White Plains yesterday, a motion was made by Joseph S. Wood, representing a large number of the creditors of J.M. Masterton Co., the late Mount Vernon bankers, to dismiss all proceedings under the indictments found against them.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 1.--Oystermen in this vicinity are greatly agitated over the recent discovery that a very destructive insect has been at work on their oyster beds, and that of the 100,000 bushels of seed planted last year about 90,000 have been destroyed.
