PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 1.--Eli Buel, aged 60 years, committed suicide on his wife's grave in the cemetery here this morning. His first wife committed suicide by hanging, and he had been divorced from his second wife.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 1.--The Tennessee Manufacturing Company to-day closed their plain cloth mill, thereby depriving 350 persons of employment, for two months. The company was unable to secure cotton of the grade required at a proper figure and the market is overstocked with the class of goods made in the plain mill. The proprietors of other mills throughout the State are reported as seriously considering a partial suspension of operations during the Summer months.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 1.--It is proposed by the Government to abandon the White Sea fleet. The White Sea, an arm of the Arctic Ocean, is frozen over in greater part from October until May. A million and a half of roubles have been granted to complete the fortifications in the harbor of Nicolaiev, about 100 miles northeast of Odessa, on the Black Sea.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 1.--The Dominion Government will soon take charge of the lighthouse at Cape Race, Newfoundland, now maintained by the British Government, and abolish the light dues which have been collected for the maintenance of this light for years past from all vessels entering the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

MONTREAL, July 1.--Being Dominion Day, this was observed as a general holiday, and thousands of people left here for the country by boat and train, although the rain came down in torrents all day, The Central Vermont Railway ran three special trains of 18 cars each to one pleasure resort alone.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 2.--A telegram was received from Judge Gresham to-day recommending the appointment of Gen. John McNulta, of Bloomington, Ill., as Receiver of the Cincinnati, Toledo and St. Louis Railway, to succeed W.J. Craig. The appointment will be formally made to-morrow.

RICHMOND, Va., July 2.--A telegram received here last night from Wytheville, Va., states that heavy frost prevailed in that section Tuesday night, and ice formed at Crockett's Station, in Wythe County, Wednesday morning.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 2.--The State Prohibition Convention reassembled at 10 o'clock this morning. The following permanent officers were elected: President--B.S. Higley, of Mahoning; Secretary--Mrs. Mary A. Woodbrige...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 2.--United States Marshal Tillman has called the attention of Commissioner Miller, at Washington, to the constant violation of the internal revenue laws in Grundy County, where, owing to the large number of illicit distilleries in operation, a great deal of lawlessness has prevailed for some time.
GALESBURG, Ill., July 2.--A sensational double suicide occurred at Gibson yesterday, the victims being Melissa Steepleton, a school teacher, and her affianced, Edward Southerland.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 2.--The horticultural exhibition had a host of fashionable patrons to-day.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 2.--Members of the Ninety-eighth Pennsylvania Volunters and their friends to-day dedicated a monument of Quincy granite in the rear of "Wheatfield."

It has been discovered that the famous tree from the bark of which quinine is obtained furnishes no quinine except in malarial regions. If the tree is planted in a malarial region it will produce quinine. If it is planted in a non-malarial region it will flourish, but it will not produce quinine.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 4.--The catrigged sailboats Nellie, Groton, Kitten, Edith, Ethel, and Wizard started at 11 o'clock this morning for a race of eight miles around Bartlett Reef Lightship for cash prizes. The Nellie won in lh. 56m. 8s., with the Groton second, about l0 minutes later.

STOUFFVILLE, Ontario, July 4.--During a thunder storm this afternoon Henry Rangle and George Cline, while working on a farm, were struck by lightning. MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 5.--Mrs. Ann Beasley, 76 years old, was burned to death here this morning while in bed. She struck a match to light a candle near by, and the mosquito net caught fire. GALVESTON, Texas, July 5.--A dispatch to the News from Fort Worth says that at a picnic in the park there last evening 11 persons, 10 white and 1 black, were poisoned from eating canned meat purchased at a lunch stand on the grounds. MOUNT McGREGOR, July 5.--This has been the most delightful day since Gen. Grant's arrival. He was fortunately able to enjoy part of it out doors. It was not until 1 o'clock that he left the sick room, the morning having passed languidly, after a fair night's rest.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 5.--The Rev. Joseph K. Mason, for five years Pastor of St. Paul's Universalist Church in this city, resigned to-day to accept a call to the Church of Our Saviour, Fifty-seventh-street, New-York. CHICAGO, July 5.--Meagre details have been received here of a disastrous fire at Stoughton, Wis., this morning. Ten tobacoo warehouses containing 1,100 cases of tobacco, valued at $550,000, several stores, and a railroad station were destroyed. Stoughton is about 22 miles from Madison, and help was sent from that city to the town.

The attendance at Brighton Beach yesterday was as large as usual and the racing was close and exciting, especially the closing event, which resulted in a dead heat, but which was not run off, the owners consenting to divide.
Another pool has been formed in pig tin. It commenced operations two months ago at 16 cents. Last night pig tin cleared strong at 22 cents.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 8.--The Masonic Grand Lodge of Canada met at Hamilton today. Grand Master Hugh Murray gave his decision in answer to a question regarding the expulsion of a member from King Solomon Lodge, of Toronto, some time ago.

PARIS, July 8.--Admiral Miot telegraphs from Madagascar urgently demanding a prompt dispatch of reinforcements. Admiral Galiber, Minister of Marine, will ask an immediate credit of $2,400,000 for preparing and sending to Madagascar 4,000 reinforcements.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 8.--There is serious trouble threatened between the ranchmen and the Cherokee Outlet and Texas drovers.

Ashbel Green, Receiver of the North River Construction Company, has filed an answer in the suit of the United States Trust Company for the foreclosure of the West Shore mortgage. The answer discloses some of the interesting questions that are likely to develop in the foreclosure proceedings. Following are the principal points of the document:
The Young Men's Democratic Club of the Nineteenth Assembly District met last evening in its new hall, at Eighth-avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-second-street.
Probably the most economical man in Essex County resides in West Lynn. He is a hard worker, and three crackers and a half pint of milk and water is a banquet for him.

READING, Penn., July 8.--John Boylan, with several others, jumped on a Reading Railroad coal train this morning at Pottstown to steal a ride. In the vicinity of Keims's Crossing the engineer shut off steam.

Frank Rochester, the actor and singer, has begun suit in the Supreme Court, by his attorney, Thomas J. Sullivan, for absolute divorce from his wife, on the ground of adultery. An order of publication was granted by Judge Andrews last week, and the papers will be served ...

CHICAGO, July 8.--Mayor Harrison is systematizing his defense of his office as Mayor. He and his friends hold meetings daily and discuss plans. City Treasurer Devine and the Mayor have pooled their issues and will fight it out together.

Frederick A. Robinson, colored, a well known character at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, who goes on errands and otherwise attends to the wants of the officers, has begun a suit for $10,000 damages for slander, in the Kings County Supreme Court, against Lieut. J.A. Calhoun, United States Navy, who is stationed at the commandant's office in the yard.
The Paris Figaro attributes to Admiral Veron, the new Senator for the Ille-et-Vilaine, a curious merit that of being able to carry more liquor than any man in the French Navy.

MONTREAL, July 8.--The merchants of Montreal have still another grievance against the Government and threaten to send a deputation to Ottawa to ask for explanations as to why the Inland Revenue Department since Saturday last have refused to accept money in payment of duties in highwines and tobaccos.
The action of the convention held at Harrisburg yesterday is somewhat discouraging to those who hoped that national defeat might exercise a regenerating influence upon the Republican Party.
An agreement has been made by Austin Corbin and Andrew Culver to operate a union railroad from Bay Ridge to West Brighton, Coney Island.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 8.--Thomas Murray, James Manning, W.A. Barton, John Gibbons, and A.J. Davidson, long-term prisoners, escaped from the York County Jail about midnight last night. They sawed the bars of a window, and after reaching the roof descended to the ground by means of a rope. None have as yet been recaptured.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The President will be unable to accept the invitation to the dedication of the Niagara Falls Park. He has not yet completed any arrangements for his Summer vacation. It is probable, however, that he will leave hereabout he 1st of August for the Adirondacks, and it is not likely that any member of the Cabinet will accompany him.
The French population of Hudson County, N.J., will unite with L'Union Mutual Aid Society on Saturday, Aug. 8, in a concert and picnic in Schuetzen Park, Union Hill.

MOUNT McGREGOR, N.Y., July 8.--No day since Gen. Grant's stay here has been so full of incident as this. He was up early. Dr. Douglas's attendance in the sick room had been required only once during the night, and when the General felt the soft air wafting into his room this morning he was not satified to take it through his window, but wanted ...
CHICAGO, July 8.--The fifth annual convention of the American Tonic Sol Fa began here to-day. The attendance is smaller than was expected.

An aged woman, respectably attired, went into the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday and insisted upon speaking to Justice Ford. She said she was Isabella Curry, otherwise known as "God's Prophetess."

Stacked in a neat little pile on a big table in Hamilton Cole's once, in Broadway, yesterday, were bank checks representing $6,667,185 34. Bundles of accurately folded papers, marked "contracts," were piled up on the same table.

A tall, muscular-looking man, whose face was terribly bruised and who looked as if he had been kicked or beaten all over his body, limped painfully into Police Commissioner Partridge's office, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, and told that officer a strange story.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 8.--At the Eastern Trotting Circuit meeting at Island Park to-day, the attendance was 3,000. The track was fast and the weather clear. Following are the summaries:
WASHINGTON, July 8.--The PostmasterGeneral has received a report from Special Agent Murphy, who was detailed to follow Hibbs, the defaulting Idaho Postmaster.

The other day Gilbert Clunen was at the bottom of a 30-foot well on Frank Weed's place, in Sing Sing, stoning up the sides. A stone about 10 inches in diameter rolled over the side at the top, and falling struck him on the head.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--Miss Emeline Schermerhorn, of Fall River, was for 24 years a teacher in the public schools of that city. Last April she resigned her position and went to New-York to act as traveling agent for a house in that city.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 8.--Mrs. Bayard, wife of Secretary Bayard, is seriously ill at her home in this city, her condition being such as to awaken the gravest anxiety from her friends and family. The Secretary has been summoned to her bedside, and it is probable he will remain until there is some change in the patient. Mrs. Bayard has been a sufferer from acute neuralgia for many years.
John Fitzpatrick, of No. 25 Ninth-street, Brooklyn, came home drunk on Tuesday night and demanded money from his sister.
The Mayor of Onzain, France, has issued the following order: "The proprietors of dogs or cats suffering or suspected to be suffering from rabies shall be put out of existence immediately!"

It was discouraging yesterday to men who toiled busily beneath a blazing sun to have the young officers who manage the weather for the Government give out a bulletin that at 3 o'clock, the hottest part of the day, the mercury did not climb above 85 .
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 8.--At a town meeting in Fairhaven yesterday the fine schoolhouse which has been built to the order of Mr. ...

MOBILE, Ala., July 8.--The announcement of the appointment of the Hon. Willis G. Clark as Collector of the Port of Mobile is received with genuine pleasure by the citizens of this place and of Alabama generally.

The programme far to-day at Monmouth Park is interesting, and will bring some fast horses to the pest. Three stake races are to be decided, the July, for 2-year-olds; the Monmouth Oaks, for 3-year-old fillies, and the Monmouth Cup.
BROKEN ARROW, Ala., July 8.--A deplorable state of lawnessless exists in St. Clair County, which is known as a "dry" county, and has a large mining population.
GALVESTON, Texas, July 8.--The News will to-morrow publish complete crop reports from several counties in Texas, compiled by its own correspondents. Speaking of the cotton crop it says:

NEW-ORLEANS, July 8.--Four homing pigeons from Brooklyn, N.Y., were released here at 7:38 o'clock this morning by Sergt. Hermann, of the Signal Service. They took a northerly direction. The weather was favorably for the fly home. These birds have heretofore made a journey of 500 miles. They have now set out on a journey of 1,150 miles from this city to Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, July 8.--About 3,000 people saw the St. Louis Club defeat the New-York Giants to-day. The St. Louis were minus the services of Caskins, who was too ill to play and Seery, who is laid up with a sprained ankle. The game opened with the St. Louis at bat.

CHICAGO, July 8.--It was reported to-day that Charles E. Felton, Superintendent of the Bridewell, had filed his papers in Washington for Collector of the Port of Chicago. Col. Felton is said to be an old friend of President Cleveland, and the politicians were predicting that he would be appointed.
CHICAGO, July 8.--Capt. Reed, of the tug Anthony, and his engineer had a narrow escape from death this morning, almost within sound of the city.
What a different sight Bantry Bay saw in the last week of 1796 from that which it witnesses to-day! Then there was a fleet there, but a hostile one that of the French Republic.
A reception was given to the Houston Light Guards, of Houston, Texas, and the Montgomery Grays, of Montgomery Ala., by members of the Seventh Regiment at their armory last evening.

MILWAUKEE, July 8.--The Wisconsin Central Railway Company has at last taken a decided step toward securing an outlet to Chicago and the East, and a line of road is to be built immediately from Schleisingerville, on the Wisconsin Central, to Chicago.

The managers of Lodging House No. 1 of the Sanitary Aid Society for the Tenth Ward have submitted a report to the Board of Directors showing that during April, when the house was first opened, they accommodated 600 lodgers.

J.A. St. John, the backer of Jacob Gaudaur, the oarsman, called at the Turf, Field and Farm office yesterday and met Wallace Ross. He offered to back John Teemer and Jacob Gaudaur against Ross and mate to row a double-soull race.
FREEHOLD, N.J., July 8.--The jury in the trial of Frank Patterson, charged with raising note of Nelson E. Buchanan Co. from $200 to $2,200, rendered a verdict of guilty last night.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 8.--The Hathorn Spring, having been pumped out, will be allowed to settle for a few days.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 8.--Ross and Hamm have challenged Teemer and Gaudaur to row a double-scull race about Sept. 1. Teemer and Gaudaur will probably accept. The regatta here next week promises to be a great success, nearly all of the prominent oarsmen having entered. The purses aggregate $2,000.

ALBANY, July 8.--The party of Mexican editors who are making a tour of the country spent the morning inspecting the sights of the capital city. They were welcomed by Mayor A. Bleecker Banks and representatives of the local press, who escorted them to the Capitol. The Executive Chamber was first visited, and each member of the company was presented to Gov. Hill. The Governor, giving them a hearty greeting, said:

CHICAGO, July 8.--To-day the attendance at Washington Park was large, there being not less than 8,000 people on the grounds when the race for the Washington Park Cup was run. A stiff wind blew from the west all the afternoon and militated against the making of any very fast time, though the track itself was in excellent condition.
CHICAGO, July 8.--L.D. Voak, stock agent of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad, was at the yards to-day.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 8.--The Western Nail Association held a secret meeting here today with Mr. J.N. Vanoe, of Wheeling, in the chair, and George Wise, of Wheeling, as Secretary.

The Berlin Tagblatt announces that from next August a uniform will be assigned to the students of the Russian universities, the wearing of which will be obligatory on all solemnities, festivals, an official assemblies.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 8.--A German probably 70 years of age, a stranger here, was found in a dying condition on the streets last night, and after his removal to the hospital he died. He gave his name as John Myers, of Frontstreet, New-York. On a card among his effects were the words: "The Erie W.L. Lunch. R.F. and F.W.W. Semkin, N.Y., branch of Idle Rest Hotel, Bath, L.I. G.H. Henjes, Bath, L. I. Coal yard."

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that all signs point to the conclusion that the negotiations between the Pennsylvania and New-York Central Railroad Companies have reached a basis of settlement, though there are some details yet to be arranged.
MADRID, July 8.--The number of new cases of cholera reported in Spain yesterday, exclusive of those in Murcia and Castellon de la Plana, was 1,109, and the deaths 628.
At a meeting of the Board of Education yesterday the following persons were appointed teachers in the evening high schools for the coming season:

LONDON, July 8.--The Standard, in an editorial, says it is a pleasing duty to acknowledge the admirable tone in which Mr. Gladstone dealt with the Government plans in his speech in the House of Commons last night. The speech was a statesmanlike response to a statesmanlike appeal.
CHICAGO, July 8.--The Rock Island Railroad Company has awarded the contract for building its new extension to St. Joseph, Mo., to the firm of Mandeville Grace, of St. Louis.
TORONTO, July 8.--The Globe publishes this morning extracts from the diary of Louis Riel, the rebel chief, which was found at Batoche by Gen. Middleton among other papers.

William H. Pudney, the sexton of St. George's Church, who on May 24 decoyed Eva A. M. Michel and Lizzie Spearschneider, two little girls, each about 10 years old into the organ loft of the church and assaulted them, was tried for the offense yesterday in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Cowing, and convicted. He is 50 years old and a married man.
WASHINGTON, Penn., July 8.--J.M. Miller, Jr., a prominent merchant of Beallsville, a day or two ago made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors, his assets being $20,000.
CHICAGO, July 8.--Sydney Rosenfeld advertised this morning for chorus singers for his "second company."

On Tuesday evening Sergt. Thomas Farley, of the Fourth Police Precinct, gave permission to Officer Joseph Stewart to be away from duty until 11 o'clock.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 8.--The United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross arrived here this afternoon from St. John's. Newfoundland, with a scientific party on board. After coaling she will leave for Newport.

Nicholas Helmer was a prosperous wigmaker three years ago. His place of business was under the Star Theatre on Broadway. He had a steady income and all went well with him until one day he saw a boy touch the steel spring of a flying top and send it whizzing into the air. He was so much impressed with the toy that he went right off and bought one.

The new sidewheel freight steamer Nashua, of the Providence and Stonington Line, made a successful trial trip to Sandy Hook and to Spuyten Duyvel yesterday, and will soon begin running regularly on the line.
To the great regret of archaeologists the old Town Hall of Vienna, which has just been abandoned for the new palace on the Ring is to be demolished.

On the Fourth of July some of the passengers of the Guion steamship Wyoming, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, proposed holding a celebration. The Hon. S.G.W. Benjamin, United States Minister to Persia, who was one of the passengers, offered to read the Declaration of Independence. Some of the English passengers objected to this and left the saloon. The American passengers remained, and Mr. Benjamin read the Declaration of Independence to them.

The office of Collector of Internal Revenue for the Brooklyn District was yesterday formally turned over to the new appointee, Robert Black, who was much gratified, he said, in finding everything in such good order. After Mr. Black had taken charge he announced the following appointments:
PARIS, July 8.--Gen. de Courey telegraphs from Hue under date of Tuesday night as follows: "We are absolute masters here now. The enemy's troops are dispersing.
Collector Hedden stated yesterday that he had been trying to devise some means by which the employes of the Custom House might be paid their salaries for June.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 8.--S.W. Tallmadge presents herewith his fourth general report on the condition and outlook of the wheat crop of the United States for 1885. Notwithstanding the current rumors that the wheat condition has developed great improvement during the past 10 days the reports show the contrary.
The Newark (N.J.) Lawn Tennis Club held its annual handicap tournament yesterday at Woodside. The attendance was good, a number of ladies anxiously watching the play of their favorites.
CLEVELAND, July 8.--A heavy detail of police was sent into the Eighteenth Ward early this morning to subdue the strikers if it should become necessary.
CHICAGO, July 8.--James W. Stable and Charles Morehead fell into a dispute yesterday over a horse belonging to the latter. In the meantime, the wives of the two men took up the quarrel in the house.
The city residence of Richard Stacpole, of the law firm of Martin Smith, is at No. 165 West Forty-seventh-street. He has a Summer cottage on Long Island.
CHICAGO, July 8.--Not the slightest clue to the whereabouts or littte Lillie Schaffer, who was kidnapped yesterday from her father's house in Wesson-street, has been discovered to-day.

OTTAWA, July 8.--The Dominion Government refuses to exercise its vote power and disallow an act recently passed by the Legislature of Manitoba exempting property held by merchants and traders of that Province from seizure.

MONTREAL, July 9.--The incoming Allan Line mail steamer Sardinian is reported with a case of smallpox on board. She was stopped at Grosse Isle, quarantined, the patient placed ashore and the ship thoroughly fumigated, after which she was showed to proceed to this port, where she arrived last night. There were only two new cases in the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 9, 1885. The corporate-existenoe of the Fulton Na tional Bank, of New-York, has been extended to July 17, 1905.

Expressman Bernier lives in South Fifth avenue, not very far from Tailor Cohen, of Spring-street. In the early part of last Fall each owned a female Newfoundland dog so much alike that they might have been taken for twins, and about the 1st of November both the animals disappeared at the same time.

The bark Monrovia arrived yesterday from Liberia and Sierra Leone with 21 cabin and 21 steerage passengers. Among the latter were nine persons who were sent from this country by the Colonization Society. They settled at a small village on the St. Paul River, but were dissatisfied with the country and the climate, and concluded that they could do better in America.

PITTSBURG, July 9.--Prof. C.P. Langley, of the Allegheny Observatory, returned to-day from Europe. He is making researches as to solar heat and spots upon the sun for the Government. The greater part of his trip was spent at the various observatories in England and France.

Sir Henry Thompson writes: "Most persons might naturally be aware that the primary object of drink is to satisfy thirst, which means a craving for the supply of water to the tissues --the only fluid they demand and utilize when the sensation in question is felt. Water is a solvent of solids, and is more powerful to this ...

Considering that it makes no particular difference to anybody except American tourists who desire to attend Court balls whether or not we are represented in Italy by a Minister, our troubles over the Italian mission have been wonderful to consider.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--The President to-day made the following appointments: William K. Meade, of Arizona, to be United States Marshal for the Territory of Arizona.

CHICAGO, July 9.--Seven of the sixteen men whose discharge by the Western Division Railroad Company precipitated the recent strike have been restored to the company's service, President Jones finding that they had been unjustly dismissed.
CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., July 9.--Charles R. Maylander, glove manufacturer at Johnstown, failed to-day. Liabilities, $40,000; assets, $15,000.

Though certainly not so intended, the peculiar doctrine regarding the tariff laid down by the Quay Convention at Harrisburg is at once an indication that the policy of "protection for protection's sake" is in a weak condition, and a blow that must help to still further undermine it.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 9.--The French flagship La Flore, Admiral Lacombe arrived here this afternoon from New-York.

The ballooning festival held at Guienne on Monday and Tuesday, the 25th and 26th of last month, was in honor of Jean Pierre Blanchard and Dr. John Jeffries who, on the 7th of January, 1785, crossed the English Channel in a balloon. In the January number of the Magazine of American History Dr. B. Joy Jeffries, of Boston, a descendant of Dr. Jeffries, presents an interesting account of this event.

At a meeting on Wednesday between the representatives of the Long Island Railroad Company and the Atlantic-Avenue (Brooklyn) Railroad Company final articles of agreement were entered into by the two companies for the construction of the Brooklyn and Long Island Cable Railway, which will be laid from South Ferry via Atlantic-avenue to Brooklyn-avenue. It is probable that the work of construction will be begun at once.

An unknown man rang the bell of the house of George Kremmentz, the well-known jewelry manufacturer, at No. 347 Washingtonstreet, Newark, about 10 o'clock on Wednesday morning. He was answered by Miss Kremmentz.

PORT AU PRINCE, Hayti, June 23.--The political atmosphere is disturbed. The Salomonists are doing their best to have their chief reelected. Tho Deputies and Senators are opposed to modifying tho constitution, the object of which is the re-election of Salomon. It appears that parties aro conspiring in favor of Legitime. Ill-feeling exists among the blacks against the mulattoes.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--A special dispatch to the Times from Indiana, Penn., says: "The five thousand people of this town are in a condition of mind bordering upon terror through the fear that any night their homes may be burned over their heads. LONDON, July 9.--The Marquis of Salisbury, replying to a letter from Glasgow asking his views on the proposal to disestablish the Church of Scotland, declares his opposition to the movement. He contends that the Established Church secures to the poorest as well as to the richest districts regular ministrations of religion, which, he says, is so necessary to the public welfare.

The programme was rather light yesterday for Monmouth Park, and consequently the attendance of spectators was not as large as on the preceding day, yet there were 6,000 or 7,000 persons on the grounds. The heat was very oppressive, and a thunderstorm seemed imminent during the afternoon, but fortunately the clouds kept seaward until the crowd was far on its way homeward.

Peter W. Downing, a middle-aged colored man, with white gig-lamp whiskers and a winning smile, has kept a small lunch counter on the ground floor of the Custom House Building for 20 years. He has paid no rent, and the Government has supplied him with light and warmth.

ATHENS, Ohio, July 9.--Developments for oil have been advancing quietly for some months at a point on Federal Creek 10 miles from Athens, in Athens County. To-day authentic information was received that one of the wells had been drilled into the ...

WILKESBARRE, July 9.--During a terrific storm here this evening A.W. McIntosh, a florist, was struck by lightning while sitting in his office. He was found soon after, lying on his back unconscious, and his condition is thought to be serious. Six other persons received severe shocks; fortunately none were killed.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 9.--Thomas Clary, who lost both feet at the ankles a your ago, and who now has a pair of artificial ones, proposes to give an exhibition walk shortly in this village. Clary is confident that he can cover a mile in a fair heel-and-toe walk in less than 15 minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--The session of the Agricultural Convention this morning was devoted to the passing of resolutions approving the suggestions made by Commissioner Colman. These resolutions call for a Signal Service station at every agricultural college, a bureau in the Agricultural Department for communication with the colleges, the publication ...
Capt. John Cummings, one of the best known tugboat pilots of this port, died yesterday of consumption at his residence, No. 139 Sackett-street, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Bennie, who was stabbed by her brutal husband in Jersey City the other evening, after he had hunted out a hiding place to which she and her children had fled to escape his violence, hid after the assault so that the police had difficulty in finding her.

A young man named Charles Carpenter, who lived on a farm in "The Purchase," about three miles from Rye, Westchester County, went out with his shotgun yesterday morning to shoot squirrels, having remarked to other members of the family that he had seen a number of large ones in a piece of woods near by. Soon after he had gone his dead body was found.

TROY, N.Y., July 9.--Tuesday evening Miss Isetta Snyder, aged 80, left her home on North Second-street, in this city, to visit a female friend. She did not call on her friend, nor did she return home. Search was made for her, but without success until this afternoon, when her dead body was found floating in the river at Lansingburg.
"E.J.B."--Charles Dickens died before completing "Edwin Drood." Bayne's Sixty-ninth Regiment Band will play at the Battery this evening. The concert will began at 8 o'clock.

TORONTO, July 9.--The President of the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts, Mr. L.R. O'Brien, representing himself and several other leading artists, has written to Mr. Erastus Wiman, President of the New-York Canadian Club, offering to place upon its walls a picture by each of the artists of some home scene in Canada in recognition of the important and useful mission which the club has undertaken in the chief American city.

ALBANY, July 9.--Ex-Speaker George B. Sloan was in town to-day, and talked freely on the political situation. He said: "I think a short campaign is desirable this year. The Republican Party has its own pronounced opinions and policy. When party opinion has measurably crystallized the party should hold its convention ...

LONDON, July 9.--The excitement over the exposures of London secret vice made by the Pall Mall Gazette continues unabated. Northumberland-street, where the office is situated, has all the afternoon been packed with a mass of excited people. As many as 3,000 news vendors have at times been in the crowd, elbowing and otherwise struggling for opportunities to purchase copies of the Gazette to vend.

Bureaucratism is not quite dead yet in Prussia. The Director of a Pomeranian court recently issued the following order of the day; "It has been brought to the knowledge of the Director that some officials connected with this court do not salute their superiors when meeting them in the street with that thorough respect which is due them.
"I have the scheme here that will catch Cincinnati people next season," said a well known restaurant man yesterday. At the same time he produced a package containing a white, powdered substance.

NYACK, N.Y., July 9.--An excursion party to Iona Island to-day, composed of the Nyack Reformed and Episcopal Sabbath schools, had an unhappy experience on the return trip this evening. A few days ago the E. Myers Excursion Line, of New-York, contracted with ...
SAVANNAH, Ga., July 9.--The Norwegian barb Erbin, from Valencia, and supposed to have cholera on board at the time of sailing, arrived in St. Simon's Sound, off Brunswick, yesterday.

Mary Huffner, a bright, good looking girl of 12 years, went to the Mulberry-street police station last night with her mother and complained that she had been outrageously assaulted by Patrick Dugan, the proprietor of a 5-cent restaurant in the basement of No. 23 Springstreet, and that he was aided in the assault by Mary Crowell, a young woman ...

ATLANTA, Ga., July 9.--Great excitement among mechanics has resulted from the discovery that men have been sentenced to work on the county chain gang for six months for no other offense than their poverty. Georgia has a stringent vagrant law intended for habitual and dissolute idlers.
CITY OF MEXICO, July 9, via Galveston.-- It is announced this morning that the Government will try the arrested editors for high treason. Two editors have been sent to the Belem Penitentiary.

ISLIP, Long Island, July 9.--George Sweeney, while passing through the woods near this village late this evening, was shot in the back with either a pistol of heavy calibre or a rifle. The wound, it is feared, will prove fatal. Who fired the shot, or whether it was accidental or intentional, is unknown.

Henry A. Blake, Stephen N. Fullerton, and Charles E. Rushmore are the incorporators of the Aguan Navigation and Improvement Company, the certificate of incorporation of which has been filed in the County Clerk's office. The company is to improve the navigability of the Aguan River, in the Republic of Honduras.

MOUNT McGREGOR, N.Y., July 9.--Gen. Grant paid to-day for yesterday's exertion. The penalty has been lenient compared with what was dreaded, but it has kept him almost constantly in his room. He realized this afternoon what a tax it has been on his strength, and said nothing of the kind must occur again. R.U. Johnson, of the Century magazine, to-day called ...

PARIS, July 9.--The Ministry is being strongly urged to annex Anam. The pressure in this direction is almost irresistible, and it requires all of M. de Freycinet's skill to prevent his colleagues from acting precipitately in the matter.

MONTREAL, July 9.--A relative of Robinson, who was arrested in Mexico for forging paper on the Bank of Montreal to the amount of $65,000, says that Robinson had been in New-York, and when there the bank discovered he had been forging. On his return to St. John's he was confined to his house with illness and was then visited ...

Moir and William Moir, a merchant of this city. Mrs. Elizabeth A.T. Phelps, also a sister, renounced all claim to such letters in favor of Mrs. Moir. PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--A special to the Times from Chambersburg, Penn., says: "A spicy little romance has just come to light which has furnished an interesting and amusing topic to the citizens of Hagerstown and this place. On Monday last a large number of invited guests assembled at the residence of Mrs. Andre H. Hager, in Hagerstown, to witness the announced ...
MONTREAL, July 9.--The steamer Amord, lying at Carillon, was burned to the water's edge to-day. She was insured for $3,500.
Ex-Senator George Raines, of Rochester, is at the Gilsey House. Prof. T. Sterry Hunt, of Montreal, is at the Murray Hill Hotel. Dr. William H. Pancoast, of Philadelphia, is at the Everett House.

Now that yellow fever has caused the deaths of three persons in Vera Cruz who had been inoculated by Dr. CARMONA'S method, the people there may lose faith in the value of a discovery that promised to afford protection against that disease.

ST. LOUIS, July 9.--Keefe, of the NewYork Club, umpired to-day's championship game between the St. Louis and New-York Clubs. The regular umpire failed to connect. Notwithstanding his connection with [the visiting team, Keefe's rulings gave satisfaction throughout. The game was the most exciting played on the home grounds this year.

The newly formed I Zingari Club yesterday achieved a very creditable victory over the second eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club. At the end of the first inning the islanders led by 31 runs. The second inning put a totally different aspect on the game. The sharp fielding of the I Zingaris and the good bowling of Mart ...

LIMA, July 9, via Galveston.--News from the interior is to the effect that on the 3d inst. Gen. Caceres notified the Government that as no steps had been taken by Senor Tovar to proceed with the peace negotiations he considered the armistice canceled. On the 4th inst. the entire force of Gen. Caceres attacked the Government troops near Jauja.

BOSTON, July 9.--The race to-day for a sweepstakes of $400 between the schooner yachts America, Gitana, Mohican, and Fortuna, off Cape Ann, attracted a large number of spectators. The weather was clear and the wind fresh, and everything was favorable for a food contest. The race was run 20 miles to windward and return.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--The race for the Sharpless Cup on the Schuylkill River to-day between the eight-oared shell crews of the Atalanta Club, of New-York; Narragansett, of Providence; Columbia, of Washington; and Fairmount and Malta crews, of this city resulted in a victory for the Fairmount eight.

Arundel Commissioner to take testimony under a writ de lunatico inquirendo. The writ was granted upon the filing of the following petition by the tragedian's wife:

Louis Flock, of the Central Park Police, while patrolling in the neighborhood of Seventy-sixth-street yesterday afternoon, heard a cry of distress coming from the direction of the lake, and running there saw that a little boy had fallen into 16 feet of water, and was about to drown. Without stopping to remove any of his clothes, the Sergeant jumped into the water ...

The shelving of Sir Stafford Northcote was as dirty a trick as ever was played in the political arena. There had been an agreement between him and Lord Salisbury that whichever the Queen sent for, in the event of the Liberals leaving office, should be the leader of the party.

The committee of the Irving Hall Democracy appointed to reorganize the committee in the Fourteenth Assembly District completed its labors last night.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--Gen. Nelson A. Miles, commanding the Department of the Columbia, has been ordered to relieve Gen. C.O. Augur, commanding the Department of the Missouri, who retires from active service to-morrow.
ALBANY, July 9.--The following applications for Executive clemency were denied by the Governor to-day:

WASHINGTON, July 9.--Charles Knott, a shoemaker residing on Virginia-avenue, near Seventh-street, Southeast, to-day entered the house of George Morris, at Third and K streets, Southeast, and asked Mrs. Morris to return a photograph which he had given the family. BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9.--The body of Prof. H.A. Bruton, of the Young Men's Christian Association gymnasium here, who has been missing since Thursday last, was found floating in the lake outside the breakwater to-day. Prof. Bruton, with a companion named Frank White, started from Dunkirk for Buffalo last Thursday in a yacht named the Phantom, which the Professor had just purchased. No trace has yet been found of the yacht or of White's body.

PRESCOTT, Ontario, July 9.--Fong Ah Hong, a Chinaman, who is suspected of murdering Sing Lee on July 1, at Rome, N.Y., and for whose arrest there is a reward of $600 offered, was in this city last evening en route for Brockville. He called at a private residence here and asked for some supper, leaving afterward for the West on foot. Fong Ah Hong speaks English fluently. The police authorities were on his track to-day.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 9.--Thursday was the day fixed for the hanging in Ellisville, Miss., of William B. Martin, a young white man with prominent family connections, for the murder of a negro boy by hanging him in a mere spirit of wantonness while on a drunken frolic. Yesterday Gov. Lowry granted a respite until Aug. 25. The Governor has now before him a petition for commutation of the sentence.

OTTAWA, July 9.--The debate on the vote of censure of the Government for neglect, delay, and mismanagement of the Northwest affairs closed this morning. A vote was taken and the Government sustained by a vote of 105 to 49.

The house of Mrs. A. Mandeville, of No. 113 Eleventh-street, Brooklyn, was painted about a month ago, and yesterday one of the painters who had done the work called and said that Mr. Mandeville had instructed him to varnish the doors. Mrs. Mandeville went down to the basement, and returning a little later found the man gone--also $250 worth of jewelry which sue had left in her room. Detective Stolesworthy is looking for the painter.

There was a novel game of baseball on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, when the baseball reporters of Philadelphia and NewYork battled for supremacy. As was to be expected, a number of misplays and errors were committed, some of the men not having played a game in five or six years.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9.--To-night reports of damage from last night's storm continue to come in, and indications are that it will yet be several days before all small towns of the interior will be heard from. The storm appears to have passed entirely across the State diagonally from northwest to south-east.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 9.--The cotton and corn crops for June of the Memphis District, which embraces West Tennessee, North Mississippi, North Arkansas, and North Alabama, to be published to-morrow by Hill, Fontaine Co., will say: "The weather during June has, in the main, been favorable for both cotton and corn. Too much rain is reported from some portions of Arkansas.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9.--At the session of the American Institute of Instruction to-day Prof. Hadley read a paper on "Horace Mann." Commissioner of Education Eaton, Gov. Wetmore, Mayor Franklyn, and Mr. E.C. Carrigan, Principal of the Evening High School of Boston, also made short speeches.

AUGUSTA, Kan., July 9.--A report was received to-day from Douglas of an altercation between Capt. Couch and a member of his Oklahoma company named Bush. A dispute arose over the attorneys' fees in recent cases brought by the Government, and Couch struck Bush a blow which it is feared will be fatal.

A simple-minded fellow named Howard was told upon alighting from a train at the South Orange Railroad station in New-Jersey Wednesday afternoon that he could make a five-dollar bill by going to the house of Patrick Smith, a carriage manufacturer, and tuning a piano. Mr. Smith's daughter admitted him, and he went to work on the piano.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, July 9.--A westbound freight train on the Pan Handle Railroad jumped the track near Holliday's Cave, West Virginia, yesterday, reducing to kindling wood 16 cars and instantly killing Fireman Thomas Wilson and seriously injuring Engineer James McCullough, Fireman O'Shaughnessy, and Henry McGinness, of the wrecking force. Trains were delayed five hours. The loss to the company will reach $30,000.

Since the excise fund is no longer distributed to the hospitals, the Trustees of the House of the Holy Comforter feel compelled to appeal to the public for funds to maintain the institution for another year. It is the only free church Home for incurables in the diocese of New-York.

A colored woman who perhaps had reached 60 years of age, seated on one of the benches in Union-square a few days ago, attracted the attention of passers by. CHICAGO, July 9.--A friend of Jesse J. Cook, the restaurant keeper who disappeared so mysteriously last Sunday night, to-day received a dispatch from Minneapolis saying that Cook had been seen on the street there and would be home Sunday. No reason for Cook's sudden departure is given, nor can his friends here explain it. His wife believes that her husband is dead, despite the dispatch from Minneapolis, which is simply signed "J.S."

NEW-ORLEANS, July 9.--During a thunderstorm here this morning the lightning struck a house in course of constuction at the corner of Third and Chestnut streets. In the house were two sons of E.R. Chevalley--Leon, aged 17, and Marshall, aged 11 years. The former was badly stunned and the latter instantly killed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 9.--Late yesterday afternoon a slimly built young man not over 30 years of age, and with sandy hair and a reddish mustache, walked into the United States Hotel and registered as J.C. Kearns, of New-York City.

The Tiempo says that the mummies in the museum should be clothed, as they offend the modesty of spectators. The request of the Tiempo need not be heeded. The mummies are so distorted and disfigured that they bear but little likeness to a human being. Their grotesque shape is the secret of their value, as showing the sufferings the unfortunates endured in the act of death.

When John Parselle, the actor, who was connected for many years with the Union-Square Theatre, died on Feb. 17 last, he left property both in England and this country. He made duplicate wills on Aug. 13, 1880, and left one copy in London, and the other was placed with the Central Deposit Company, of this city.

A curious story was told the other day by a gentleman who buys and sells old books, pamphlets, and papers, and now and then includes in his stock in trade old deeds and mortgages and property maps. One would think that articles of the latter class were absolutely worth less, but that they are not this gentleman is ready to testify.

Joseph C. Bryan, a plumber, of No. 104 Madison-street, was yesterday arraigned in Essex Market Police Court on complaint of Martin Rourke, who charged him with the larceny of a check for $415, which was negotiated by August J. Blaustein and indorsed by Rourke and John F. McGinnis. Bryan said that he got the check from McGinnis, who is now out of the city. He was held for examination.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 9.--The Bell telephone injunction case was terminated rather summarily yesterday by Judge McKennon refusing to hear the defense and granting the injunction against the Western Company. All the Commissioners, John Jay, Chairmain, and ex-Judge Augustus S. Schoonmaker and Henry A. Richmond, were present.

ALBANY, July 9.--The office of Collector of Internal Revenue, held by editor James S. Smart, is worth some thousands of dollars annually to the incumbent. Mr. Smart has not yet been disturbed by the Administration, though his office is in the list of Presidential appointments.

Barrett, one of his would-be captors, in the Poikstreet station in this city, was found to be insane in Judge Prendergast's court today and ordered to be confined in the Elgin Asylum, Reaume's wife met him in court ...

The opposition to the stock assessment scheme of the Board of Directors of the Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company is concentrating under the leadership of John Bloodgood. There are several stockholders who are unwilling to pay the desired 7 per cent. assessment, and they have signified to Mr. Bloodgood their willingness to combine and try to defeat the scheme.

The ferryboat Hackensack left her slip at the foot of Barclay-street for Hoboken shortly before noon yesterday. She had barely got out into the river when her pilot discovered that the excursion steamer Sylvan Grove was coming down the stream close in to the docks. The engines of both boats were reversed, but it was too late to avoid an accident.
MONTREAL, July 9.--Another confidential clerk has left for the States after embezzling $6,000 of his employers' money.

Political affairs in this State are apparently in a quiescent condition, but there are indications here and there that Gov. HILL is very busy laying pipe for the purpose of directing influences through the various counties for the promotion of his own candidacy.

Thirty members of the Old Guard and 75 veterans of the Seventy-first Regiment went to visit their comrades at Peekskill yesterday afternoon. NEW-ORLEANS, July 9.--Of more than a dozen appointments to Federal positions in Louisiana or of Louisianians abroad every one has represented the element opposed to the Burke-Houston-McEnery ring, save possibly Mr. Walker Fearn as Minister to Greece, which appointment has no political significance whatever.

Every Thursday morning Carolus Duran is at home to his admirers, whether known or unknown, in the boudoir sanctuary which serves him as a studio in the Passage Stanislas, away over the water in the Rue Notre Dame des Champs. After mounting one flight of stairs we enter the studio through a doorway draped with a rich hanging of embroidered silk, such as you see on fete days hung on the balconies of Spanish towns.

The Queen having on Saturday last entered upon the fort-ninth year of her reign the thoughts of many of her subjects will turn to the nexth 26th of June, when her Majesty will commence her "year of jubilee."

The discussion as to the motives and the methods of the Pall Mall Gazette's exposures of vice in London has made most people forget how serious and far-reaching the consequences of that exposure are likely to be.
GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., July 9.--Frank J. Mills, bookkeeper in the Fulton County National Bank, is short in his accounts and has been asked to resign.

However freely and widely the Virginian may dissent from the political ethics of Mr. George W. Childs, it is a real pleasure to concede that he is a citizen of whom the country may justly feel proud. To simplify the statement, he is a grand man. It would require a volume of space to record the deeds to which his noble heart and mind have prompted him.

H.B. Bishoff, a grocer of Fifty-eighthstreet and Avenue A, left his horse and wagon standing unhitched in front of his store yesterday morning. The horse became frightened and ran off. At First-avenue and Fifty-eighth-street Victoria Lang, 72 years old, of No. 422 East Fifty-eighth-street, who was crossing the street, was unable to avoid the horse, and was knocked down, runover, and seriously injured. Bishoff was arrested.

Edward F. Williams, a young bartender, obtained a situation at the liquor store of Patrick O'Rorke, at the corner of One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street and Third-avenue about a year ago. He boarded with the family of his employer, a member of which was Miss Emily O'Rorke, of whom O'Rorke was guardian. She was a cripple, having one side paralyzed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 9.--The Garfield Statue Commission to-day accepted the report of the committee which has examined the statue at Washington and accepted the same. They decided to erase from the pedestal the letters "James A." and have only the name Garfield in large letters thereon. Gov. Hoadly will present the statue to Congress by letter, and it will be unveiled immediately without formality.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--In the case of Frederica. A. Peck against George W. Peck Judge Cox yesterday refused the divorce on the grounds that the parties had not been legally married. WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 9.--The fever at Plymouth is fast disappearing. The number of sick now being cared for is 163. During the last week 5 new cases were admitted to the hospital and 38 have recovered.

CHICAGO, July 9.--Mrs. Thomas A. Smith, of No. 50 Eldridge Court, figures to-day as an alleged victim of a bold robbery. Mrs. Smith tells the police and other curious people that early Wednesday afternoon two men representing themselves as plumbers sent to repair the water pipes gained entrance to the house.

Osear Ehler, a respectable looking German,of No.42 New Bowery, appeared yesterday in the Tombs Police Court, and Officer Thomas McCurdy, of the Fourth Precinct, told Justice Smith that the previous evening Ehler and several friends were drinking beer all over the sidewalk, and when he told them to go indoors Ehler assaulted him and then ran into the house.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9.--The rainstorm this evening interfered with the Casino dance. However, there was a fair attendance of fashionable people. The German Minister at Washington, Baron H. von Alvensleben, has arrived here for the Summer. He was introduced at the Casino to-day by August Belmont, the President.

James Graham, of No. 465 West Fortyseventh-street, is a gentleman with a well developed sense of humor. He left home a week ago without saying anything to his wife, and as the days went by and nothing was heard of him she nearly went mad with anxiety, and finally set the police to looking for him.

Auctioneer Dailey struggled long and hard to dispose of the 100 horses, 80 stages, and the several hundred sets of harness which were put up for sale at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the Madison-avenue stage stables in East Forty-first-street. He had to retire, however, after the first few stages had been sold and Mr. Van Tassell took his place.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 9.--Prof. Lewis Swift, of the Warner Observatory, here, has received information that Prof. Barnard, of the Vanderbilt University Observatory, at Nashville, Tenn., discovered on the evening of July 7 a pretty but very faint comet in Ophinchus.

WILMINGTON, Del. July 9.--Although Mrs. Bayard passed a comparatively comfortable day her condition gives no hope of improvement, and recovery is regarded by her physician as almost impossible. Being an invalid for several years her constitution was weakened when attacked by her present illness, which is a liver ailment, an enlargement of that organ.

CHICAGO, July 9.--In spite of the threatening weather nearly 6,000 people attended the races at Washington Park to-day. LONDON, July 9.--The race for the Chesterfield Stakes, for 2-year olds, was run-to-day at the Newmarket July meeting, and was won by the Duke of Portland's b.f. Modwena. Mr. R. H. Combe's br.c. Volta was second, and Lord Haldon's br.f. Storm Light third. There were nine starters.

CHICAGO, July 9.--Some excitement was caused to-day in the County Building. Attention was called to the fact that the law requires that the County Commissioners, officials whose duties and powers are similar to those of Supervisors in New-York State, stall be commissioned by the Governor. Only five members of the present board have ever taken the trouble.

NASHVILLE, July 9.--Sheriff Pearson, of Yalobusha County, Miss., passed through the city to-day for Mississippi, having in custody J. H.B. Smith, arrested in Lawrenceburg by Constable Beckham. Sheriff Pearson had a requisition from the Governor of Mississippi for the arrest of Smith, who has had a remarkable career.

HAVANA, July 9.--Francisco Casa, formerly Secretary of the General Government of the island, took charge provisionally on July 2 of the general direction of the Treasury. He was succeeded as Secretary by Joaquin Carbonell.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, July 9.--On the afternoon of July 2 the scouts under command of Capt. Chaffee came upon a band of Apaches near Guasabus, on the Oporte River, in Sonora. A spirited fight followed, in which 40 Indians were killed and three bucks and 15 squaws captured. Chaffee lost one soldier and had one or two scouts wounded.
LONDON, July 9.--Lord Rothschild took his seat in the House of Lords this afternoon. He was formally introduced to the peers by the Earl of Rosebery and Baron Carrington.
