White is a question that greatly interests the Alumni of that institution, and especially those of NewYork and its vicinity. Members of the NewYork Alumni Association discussed the matter earnestly at an adjourned meeting yesterday ...

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 9.--The Congregationalist, of Boston, has been sued sor $100,000 by the Rev. Edward Payson Tenny, of Manchester, Mass. Tenny was President of a Congregational college in Colorado and has been suspended he alleges, on account of articles published in the Congregationalist.

CHICAGO, July 9.--The Chicago and Northwestern train leaving here for Milwaukee at 11:30 A.M. had attached this morning the dining car Excelsior. Just after leaving Glencoe, W.H. Brown, a waiter, gave an order to Charles Robinson, the colored cook. The two men fell into a dispute over the ...
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9.--A meeting of the leading business men of Buffalo and of the Merchants' Exchange was held to-day. The Secretary of the exchange read the following report:

The police were directed yesterday to make search for Edward Carr, who was a clerk employed in the office of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, and boarded at No. 338 West Fifty-first-street. He has been missing since the 18th ult. He left his boarding house, saying that he was going West, but has not been heard from by his mother, at Catasauqua, Penn.

Yesterday afternoon the jury in the case of The People against A.B. Spreckels brought in a verdict of not guilty. The facts developed in the long trial may briefly be recounted here. On the 19th of November, 1884, the accused entered the business office of M.H. De Young and shot him twice.

PALMYRA, N.Y., July 10.--For over 25 years Wayne and Ontario Counties have been among the leading wheat producing counties in Western New-York, and during the past 10 years the acreage has been rapidly increasing to the exclusion of the production of other field grains. Thousands of acres are devoted to it, and hundreds of farmers depend largely upon their sales of the wheat crop for their success in farming.

Much anxiety prevails at sanitary headquarters because of the discovery of several cases of smallpox and the inability of Dr. James B. Taylor and his inspectors to learn where the disease was contracted.

MARMONT, Ind., July 10.--The Democratic State Editorial Convention to-day passed resolutions declaring it their belief that radical reform in Government affairs is only possible through the appointment to civil positions of persons in full sympathy with the Democratic Party as represented by its statesmen and leaders.

CHESTER, Penn., July 10.--The decomposed remains of Bridget Lee, who gained a livelihood by begging, were found in a small house near Fernwood last night, and, as she was sup osed to have had a good deal of money, murder is suspected.
RALEIGH, July 10.--Civil service reform is contemptible in the eyes of the average Bourbon Democrat, except as a means by which to make a clean sweep of the Federal officials who are Republicans.

TROY, N.Y., July 10.--Superintendent Organ, of the Hudson Valley Knitting Mill, Waterford, becoming aware to-day that the spinners employed in the mill were again contemplating a strike--the third within a short time--discharged all of them.

The big barn on the farm of Harry A. Leavitt, at Great Barrington, was burned last evening. The cause of the fire is unknown and is supposed to be accidental, since no motive for incendiarism can be alleged. The building was entirely destroyed.
Secretary of State Kelsey, of NewJersey, has made public the following letter in reference to the answer of Senator McPherson to the charges published in the Trenton True American:
ALBANY, July 10.--This was the closing day of the Eastern Trotting Circuit at Island Park. The following is a summary:

Lord Rosebery yesterday announced that as the name of Liberal is good enough for Mr. Gladstone, is good enough for Mr. Bright, "I am quite willing to walk under an umbrella with these two gentlemen." So are we all, if Mr. Gladstone carries the umbrella.
TTOY, N.Y., July 10.--Oil has been struck at the Galway oil field, in Saratoga County, at a depth of 100 feet. In boring the drill passed through a stratum of salt and afterward struck a vein of gas.

Christian Bach, 13 years old, son of a confectioner, of No. 230 West Twenty-ninth-street, and John B. Ward, 16 years old, son of a shoemaker, of No. 228 West Twenty-ninth-street, went bathing in the North River at Twentyninth-street yesterday afternoon. Neither could swim, and they had been forbidden to go in the water by their parents. The place is treacherous, for the bottom suddenly pitches to a hole of great depth.

WASHINGTON, July 10, 1885. Assistant Secretary Fairchild has written to the Collector of Customs at Oswego, N.Y., stating that the circular of July 2 in regard to the termination of certain articles of the Treaty of Washington does not impose upon domestic products shipped from one American port to another through Canada by routes ...

BOSTON, July 10.--The visiting Mexican editors were this evening entertained at a banquet at the Parker House by the Commercial Club. About 600 gentlemen were present, and speeches were made by Lieut.-Gov. Ames, W. H. Lincoln, R.M. Pulsifer, President Wade, of the Mexican Central Railroad; Ireno Paz, President of the excursion; Augustin Arroye de Anda, Secretary Gregoria Mendezabal, and others.

CHICAGO, July 10.--The attendance at Washington Park to-day was again large, although the weather was cold and cloudy. Spring overcoats and wraps were in good demand. The track was in fair condition, although not fast, and the sport was of the most spirited description.

A new "Municipal Council" of the Irish National League was organized last evening in the District Court Room, at Seventh-avenue and Twenty-second-street. Delegates numbering 50, representing 20 branches of the League, were present. John Fahey, of Branch No. 159, ...

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Cotton has made material improvement during June. Tnere are few imperfect stands reported. Temperature and rainfall have favored growth, and fruiting has commenced in the Gulf States. Local droughts are very rare and moisture generally sufficient from Virginia to Texas. It is somewhat in excess in low lands, interfering with cultivation and stimulating the growth of grass.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in a circular just issued regrets that the churches did not more generally contribute to the funds of the Permanent Commit tee last year so as to have enabled it to meet all of its obligations.

LIMA, July 10, via Galveston.--It is stated that the new Peruvian gunboats Socrates and Diogenes, hitherto retained in England, will leave that country for Callao within a few weeks in charge of an officer of the Peruvian Navy.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 10.--A half holiday movement was formally inauguarated in this city at noon to-day. About 30 stores, dry goods, hat, clothing, shoe, fancy stores, and others were closed. The streets wore a Sunday aspect, as the clerks, as a rule, with their friends went out of the city to lakeside resorts. Tomorrow other merchants will give their employes a half holiday.

CHICAGO, July 10.--The Chicago Eastbound Passenger Committee held a special meeting to-day, and among other things discussed the proposed formation of a money pool on eastbound passenger business. The representatives of the Pennsylvania lines asked that the plan of the proposed pool be submitted to the meeting of the passenger department of the Joint Executive Committee in New-York next week.

Shortly after 11 o'clock last night an alarm waa struck from box No. 34 for a fire in the confectionery store of Mr. S. Riddle, No. 620 St. Lawrence-street. The firemen think the fire was the work of an incendiary.

The philologists who are now in session at New-Haven are having a delightful time. They spend the heat of the day in discussing philological topics, and as they are very enthusiastic persons nearly everything that they see or hear immediately suggests to them a new philological train of thought.

TROY, N.Y., July 10.--At the Grand Army of the Republic reunion at Round Lake to-day numerous distinguished veterans were present. Reminiscences of prison life were related and addresses delivered. Col. Fred Grant arrived this afternoon, and was met by Gen. Carr, Grand Marshal Cantine, and a number of Grand Army men. A band headed the procession which escorted Col. Grant to Dr. Newman's cottage.

CHICAGO, July 10.--The true facts in the case of the "audacious robbery in broad daylight," by which Mrs. Thomas A. Smith, of No. 50 Eldridge-court, was deprived of $1,030, came to light to-day, when Mrs. Smith made a full confession to the police, and assured them that the facts as she had stated them have existed only in her own very fertile imagination.
CINCINNATI, July 10.--The following is a summary of the last day of the Chester Park races:

WILMINGTON, Del., July 10.--Mrs. Bayard has had another very bad day, and to-night her condition is so critical that her death is expected every moment. She is just alive and no more, and her attendants think she cannot live until daylight.

SIERRA NEVADA FOOTHILLS, Fresno County, Cal., July --.--As I was eating my rural noontime dinner to-day an able-bodied grasshopper of good average size whirred through an open window and landed himself squarely in my plate of stewed "cotton-tail" rabbit. He (or she) was promptly transferred to the outer world, where a healthy young pullet "made no bones" of gobbling him (or ...

PARIS, July 10.--A dispatch to the Government from Hue, the capital of Anam, received to-day, says that Gen. de Courey has issued a manifesto to the effect that, with the exception of a few of the ringleaders who planned the recent unprovoked attack on the French troops at Hue, all those rebels who surrender within 12 days will be granted a general amnesty.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Secretary of the Navy purposes effecting an entire reorganization of the nine Government navy yards not later than next Fall. An investigation looking to this end has been in progress for some weeks. Committees at the various yards have been examining the books and papers covering a period.

CHICAGO, July 10.--Senor M.R. Mendez, Lieutenant-Governor of the State of Puebla, Mexico, is in Chicago. He will remain here for a week, for the purpose of investigating the public schools, their management, curriculum, and sources of revenue, with a view of incorporating some of the American features in Puebla.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 10.--In the United States Circuit Court this morning the ease of Blind Tom, which was brought into court yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus sued out by his mother, came up.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 10.--The information that Secretary Manning has reconsidered his former order of dismissal and restored to duty Col. John W. Glenn to his place as Superintendent of Construction of Government Buildings, was received here this afternoon with unreserved manifestations of satisfaction.
MONTREAL, July 10.--The Hon. Mr. Chaplen, Secretary of State, is lying seriously ill at the residence of Mr. L.A. Senecal, on Dubordstreet.

For a good many years now a belief in free trade has been a cardinal point of political orthodoxy in Great Britain. No man who aspired to a reputation for soundness, or who wished to be thought of in connection with any post in commercial and financial administration, would have ventured to deny it.
A much larger crowd than that of the previous day attended the sale of the old vehicles of the Fulton Ferry and Fifth-avenue stage line at the stables in West Forty-third-street yesterday morning.
Steamship Zaandam, (Dutch,) Chevalier, Amsterdam 13 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Funch, Edye Co.

A collision occurred in the East River off the foot of Whitehall-street yesterday morn ing between the steamer Castleton, of Starin's Glen Island Line and the ferryboat Winona, of the Atlantic-avenue line. The Castleton left the foot of Cortlandt-street at 10:15 o'clock with about 200 excursionists for Glen Island. Capt. Carr, who was in command of the boat, brought her around the Battery, but as she entered the ...

AUBURN, N.Y., July 10.--James D. Fish, ex-President of the Marine Bank, has been given employment in the prison shoe shop. He has been assigned to the packing room, but is at present in the office to familiarize himself with the duties. In going to meals he does not march in lockstep, but follows the company at will, as do most of the older prisoners.

A pathological laboratory has been fitted up in connection with the New-York Polyclinic School of Medicine, on East Thirty-fourth-street, and the Faculty has secured the services of Dr. Frank S. Billings as instructor. The object of the new department is to instruct practitioners, not only in the nature of diseases, but also in the nature of their causes, so that they may be able ...

Mr. George Roberts, of the Secretary of State's office, has gone to Fisher's Island and has occupied his cottage. This cottage is a curiosity in its way, and is said to be the joint device of Chief Clerk Hinman and Mr. Roberts. Four posts are planted in the ground and carried up to a height of about 12 feet.

The Street was somewhat agog yesterday over a number of circumstantial statements declaring that the differences between the Western Union and Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Companies were about to be settled.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 10.--Shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday a big cloud came up from the west. It moved over to the northeast and seemed to rest over the woods just above Parker's Hotel, Niskayuna, Men and women were frightened by the peculiar aspect of the cloud, and many ran from their houses and took refuge in neighboring houses, alarmed by the aspect of the sky.
Moise Bloch, day watchman at Stern Metzger's abattoir, No. 616 West Fortieth-street, was in the yard of the place yesterday afternoon, when William Beresford, a lounger, asked him for a cigarette.

The will of Susan Maria Edson, who died recently, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The will is dated Aug. 2, 1884, and the Executors are Mary Augusta Edson, a sister of the testatrix, and John E. Parsons, an old friend. According to the terms, one-half of the house and lot at No. 16 East Seventeenthstreet and one half of a portion of land in Cornwall, ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 10.--The Genesee Bicycle Club to-night decided to hold a grand tournament in this city in September. An effort will be made to secure Hendee, Prince, and other noted bicyclists, including the English riders who will compete at Springfield. Prizes amounting to $1,200 will be offered.

BAY CITY, Mich., July 10.--The strike among the lumber mill employes in this city shows very little change. What there is is in favor of the strikers. Two meetings were held yesterday at Madison Park. At the morning meeting State Representative Barry, of Saginaw, made an address. At the afternoon meeting Mr. Green, of the firm of Green Stevens, ...

Although the farmers of Southwestern Kansas are recovering from their fright and Gov. MARTIN is now satisfied that the troops recently stationed along the southern boundary of the State will protect the settlers and prevent an invasion from the ...

Kindness to children should not be made obtrusive or burdensome. The child on its holiday, or in its every day half hour or whole hour of recreation, desires nothing more than to be left free to pursue its own pleasure in its own way. In the following of its own devices (innocent of course) and the attempt to carry out its own plans childhood is happy.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 10.--A complaint comes from the smallpox infected district near Creston that it is impossible to get conveyances to carry the dead to the cemetery. The people are panic-stricken. The dead lie unburied several days. Much indignation is expressed.
Underhill, Slote Cornell, clothiers, of Broadway and Astor-place, will close their stores on Saturdays during the season at 4 P.M.

CHICAGO, June 10.--Judge Gardner this morning, at the instance of Mr. High, attorney for Augustin Daly, the New-York manager, granted a perpetual injunction against Robert B. Peattie and Wolf Von Shierbrand to restrain them from producing their adaptation of the "Rape of the Sabines," a four-act farce by the Schoenthan brothers.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 10.--A gentleman returning from Springfield to-night says a canvass has been made of the Central Methodist Church in that city, of which the Rev. Dr. Leonard, the Prohibition candidate for Governor, is Pastor. The church has a membership of about 800, of whom not more than 20 will vote for Dr. Leonard.

A gentleman who has just returned from the Adirondacks says the deer hunting law, passed by the last Legislature, has had no effect in that region. Its violation is an open secret in Essex, Hamilton, and Herkimer Counties. The hotel and store keepers encourage these depredations. He thinks the law can be enforced only in small constabularies with officers uninfluenced by the hotel keepers.

President Walker, of the Board of Education, appeared before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday and said that the $1,000,000 worth of bonds which the Controller had been authorized to issue to build additional schools had not been subscribed for because the rate of interest to be paid had been restricted to 3 per cent. Mr. Walker thought the board should remedy this defect.
The following is the programme to be given by Conterno's military band in Prospect Park at 4 o'clock this afternoon:

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 10.--Senator Gillette is reported through Dun Co.'s agency to have transferred his real estate to his wife for a nominal sum and his banking affairs to O. Clark. The street rumor current here, that he has absconded, is scouted at by President Towne, Gillette's correspondent here, who speaks warmly of him, and says he could get help if he were really in deep water.

ALBANY, July 10.--The following companies filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State to-day: The Croton Lake Terra Cotta Company, of New-York, with a capital of $22,000; the International Postal Supply Company, of New-York, with a capital of $2,000,000, and the Manufacturers' Company, (Limited,) of New-York, with a capital of $40,000.
Yesterday made the third day of the Newark Lawn Tennis Club's annual tournament at Woodside, and attracted a large attendance. The results of the play were as follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10.--In referring to the incident which occurred in Washington, in which Gov. Hoadly suggested the name of exGov. Noyes as one of the Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad, Gov. Hoadly says:

The midsummer meeting at Monmouth Park will begin to-day, and as the programme is a very attractive one, there will probably be a great crowd present. There will be seven races, with the Stockton Stakes for 3-year-olds as the main attraction.

WABASH, Ind., July 10.--The passengers on the Atlantic express on the Wabash Road, due here last night, had a narrow escape one mile west of Wabash. A connecting rod on the engine snapped in two, destroying the cab and breaking a large hole in the boiler, from which the steam issued in such quantities that John Glenn, the engineer, could not reach his reverse lever, but was forced to hang out the gangway.

CHICAGO, July 10.--Jesse W. Cook, the restaurant keeper who disappeared suddenly last Saturday night, returned home to-day. He is partially insane, and from his incoherent talk it is inferred that he was mentally unsound when he wandered away Saturday night. It is known that he visited Minneapolis, Joliet, and Davenport, and that Freemasons, to which order he belongs, induced him to return home, and saw him started on his way.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Indian troubles, as looked upon from Washington, are becoming more serious. Gen. Sheridan left here to-night for Fort Reno, Indian Territory. The General desired to be at the scene of the conflict. A telegram has been sent to the officer in command which says the outbreak must be suppressed even if the Cheyennes are wiped out of existence.

Dr. Rufus H. Gilbert, the projector of the elevated railroad system of this city, by whose name the Metropolitan Elevated Road was first known, died early yesterday morning in his residence, No. 464 West Seventy-thirdstreet, unattended by any of his family or ...
The intimations that have been published that the trials of the iron sloop yacht Priscilla have shown her to be a failure were indignantly denied yesterday by Mr. J. Frederick Tams.

"In the hard matter-of-fact railroad world," said President Chauncey M. Depew, of the New-York Central, yesterday, "we have but few good things happening, but occasionally something turns up which breaks the monotony of business.
A fire broke out at 3 o'clock yesterday morning in the yard in the rear of the lard oil factory of Josiah Macy's Sons, Nos. 521 to 529 Water-street, and for a time threatened serious consequences.
ERIE, Penn., July 10.--Two young ruffians yesterday put a bunch of firecrackers under the dress of Miss Elizabeth Waggoner, which ignited her dress and burned her to death.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 10.--A party of Lehigh Valley Railroad officers, consisting of W. C. Alderson, Treasurer; John S. Lentz, Master Car Builder, and others, arrived in this place last evening from a fishing excursion down Cayuga Lake. Over 100 pounds of black bass and 66 pounds of perch and pickerel were caught during the several days' cruise. The party was highly pleased with the trip, and proposes to return here later.

MONTREAL, July 10.--A meeting of the Free Navigation League was held to-day, Mayor Beauregrand presiding. It was agreed to communicate immediately with Boards of Trade throughout the country, and to urge upon them the desirability of establishing branch leagues with a similar object. It was also decided to draw up a statement of the principles of the league for the benefit of the public.

OTTAWA, July 10.--The Government have amended the bill restricting Chinese immigration by inserting a clause providing that as regards Chinese immigrants who arrive from any port in the United States the bill shall go into effect 30 days after it receives the GovernorGeneral's signature, and as regards those arriving direct from any port in China, it shall go into operation on Jan. 1, 1886.

Many members of the Faculty at Hamilton College are not at all pleased with the action of the Board of Trustees in suppressing the report of its committee. They say that, inasmuch as the charges which they preferred against President Darling were given to the public without their knowledge or consent, they do not see the justice of keeping this report secret.

The latest returns regarding the damage occasioned by the earthquake in Cashmere on May 18 state the loss of life at 3,081 persons, besides 25,000 sheep and goats and 8,000 cattle. The number of dwellings ruined is computed to reach 75,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--Congressman Hilary A. Herbert, of the Second District of Alabama, arrived in the city early this morning, to inquire into the case of D.W. Ford, a member of the Montgomery Grays, of that State, who was arrested in this city last Monday on the charge of committing an aggravated assault and battery on Samuel Jeffries, of No. 5,001 Paschal-street.

Some of the Western towns are now complaining of the thefts of a man pretending to be deaf and dumb, and known as Roy M. Cameron alias W. Rush Taggert alias S.R. Douglas. Concerning him Dr. J.H. Shultz, of Logansport, Ind., writes to the Indianapolis ...

NEW-ORLEANS, July 10.--Dispatches have been received here to-day from New-York and Chicago asking if there is any yellow fever in this city. To these interrogatories only a negative answer could be given, and it is clear that reports to the contrary are put in circulation for their effect on trade.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 10.--Interest in the Dunbar case is at fever heat to-night over the report that a hardware dealer named Martin had testified at the inquest that he sold Dunbar a "defender" revolver on April 9.

TROY, N.Y., July 10.--Suspicion is directed toward a crank known as "the man from Peru," who has just served a term in Clinton Prison for an attempt to blow up the steamer Drew, as the person who placed the box of ex plosives on the railroad bridge near Plattsburg on Wednesday night. He had been around the place for some weeks, but has now disappeared.

On Thursday afternoon Harry Lensingstone, aged 14 years, residing with his parents at Sag Harbor, was trying to recover a pigeon which had flown away from him and was resting on the roof of the barn of Mr. J.H. Root.
NEWPORT, July 10.--The thermometer was up among the eighties to-day, and many rushed to the beach and cliffs. Few guests arrived at the hotels. Many are expected to-morrow to spend Sunday.

Three hundred New-Jersey people, including 50 Newark Sabbath school children, started on an excursion to Newburg yesterday morning, taking the Pennsylvania Railroad to Jersey City and the steamer Richard Stockton for the remainder of the trip.

There will be a flutter among connoisseurs--the United States is awake, I am told, to the fact--at the sound of the auctioneer's cry on Aug. 1. On that day there will be offered in the salesrooms, Wellington-street, Strand, the autograph manuscript of Lord Beaconsfield's "Iskander, King of Epirus," also the first part of the same writer's "Ixion in Heaven;" Lord ...

CHICAGO, July 10.--The Coroner's investigation to-day into the death of Frederick Schlenzau, proprietor of the American Hotel at Lemont, Thursday has tended to deepen instead of clear up the mystery. Schlenzau was a hard working, quiet, middle-aged German who had lived in Lemont 18 years.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 10.--The Metropolitans won this afternoon by bunching their hits. The game was marked by heavy batting, and at times was very exciting. There were 1,500 spectators. The score was as follows:
The city authorities of Bangor are rigidly enforcing the dog law. But that is a high license not a prohibitory law.--Portland (Me,) Advertiser.
The Academy of Music has been mortgaged by Herman R. Le Roy, President and manager, and A.J. Murphy, Secretary, to William J. Schenck and David G. Legget for $195,000, payable in five years.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--It is stated today that there is a probability of the suit of the President of the Jersey Central Railroad Company against the Reading Railroad, for the recovery of the former's property, not being brought.
MADRID, July 10.--United States Minister Foster has suspended the negotiations with Spain concerning the proposed new commercial treaty with the United States.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 10.--In order to allow two full days between the Fall racing meeting here and that at Louisville, which begins on Sept. 22, the managers of the Kentucky Association will announce a six days' meeting to begin Sept. 14. The stakes for this meeting and those of the following year will close on Aug. 1.

The Zoological Society has met with considerable loss in the death of the only polar bear and the only giraffe in the extensive collection of animals at the "Zoo." About seven years ago the society procured a male and a female polar bear, which were considered fine specimens.

CLEVELAND, July 10.--The determined attitude taken by the civil autho ities had its result to-day in the utter absence of any aggressions or demonstrations on the part of the striking iron workers. The streets in the Fourteenth and Eighteenth Wards were almost deserted, and the few Poles and Bohemians who were encountered had left their clubs and weapons at home.

HILLSBOROUGH, Texas, July 10.--For several days past rumors have been current that W.A. Jackson, senior member of the big cattle firm of W.A. Jackson Brother, was mysteriously missing. About three weeks ago Mr. Jackson started for Chicago with a train load of cattle.
Gov. E.A. Perry, of Florida, is at the New-York Hotel.

HAMILTON, Ontario, July 10.--A boiler explosion occurred in the West Flamborough Paper Mills, eight miles northwest of this city, last evening, with fatal results. Edward Maloney, fireman, was blown about 25 feet and instantly killed. John A. Stutt, a member of the firm, was struck on the head and killed. Samuel Adams, who was working in an outbuilding some distance away, was badly hurt by the collapse of the roof over him.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 10.--The Browns and Brooklyns played a ten-inning game to-day. It was marked by very light batting on both sides, and at the close of the ninth inning the home nine had secured only two singles and the Brooklyns three.

MONTREAL, July 10.--There will be a grand pilgrimage of Irish Catholics of Montreal to St. Anne de Beaupre on Saturday. In 1872, 17 pilgrims visited St. Anne de Beaupre; in 1873 the number was trebled; in 1874, 582 persons made the pilgrimage; in 1875 the number of pilgrims was 27,000, and last year it was 60,725.
Joseph Mulvaney, of No. 306 Hudsonavenue, Brooklyn, charged with assisting in robbing Nicholas Conti at No. 22 Mulberrystreet on June 27, was tried in the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 10.--An unusually large movement in grain from Texas and the West is expected this season, and in fact, quite a quantity has already been moved to New-Orleans over Morgan's Louisiana and Texas and the Texas and Pacific Railroads.

ST. LOUIS, July 10.--In the absence of the regular umpire Welch, of the New-Yorks, umpired to-day's baseball game between the St. Louis Club and New-Yorks. In the ninth inning, with two men on bases, Welch deliberately called Sweeney out on strikes, and this gave the NewYorks the game.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, July 10. --The Government has excepted from the provisions of the decree consolidating its debt the carbajal bonds held to the extent of $300,000 in New-York. These bonds mature on Oct. 1. Only the sum named remains unliquidated.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Attorney-General Garland has given an opinion to the Secretary of the Navy on the questions of law involved in the controversy with John Roach concerning the dispatch boat Dolphin. Secretary Whitney declines at present to give the opinion to the press. It is understood, however, that it is of such a character that the Secretary will accept the vessel.

Prof. Gustavus Jager, of the Agricultural College of Hohenheim, is well known in Europe as the apostle of woollen clothing. He has a number of disciples in Austria, who dress strictly according to his hygienic rules, and proclaim their tenets to the world by the eccentric cut of their coats.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Postmaster-General has appointed the following named fourth class Postmasters: In New-York, W.F. Paige, at Kaaterskill; David Blair, at Broadalbin: James McCarty, Jr., at South Plattsburg; W.B. Ennist, at West Hurley; John W. Havens, at Ellenburg; L.I. Channell, at Peru; Jones Ransom at Mooers: S.G. Carpenter, at Highland; Thomas Hill, nt Shandaken; Edgar Snyder, at Woodstock; John J. Schoonmaker, at Accord.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 10.--John Freese, of Newfield, was so badly injured on Wednesday afternoon by a tree falling on him that he died the same night. He was engaged in peeling bark, and was unable to get out of the way when the tree fell. The unfortunate man leaves a widow and family.

JOLIET, Ill., July 10.--Joliet society glories in a sensational elopement which, however, was nipped in the bud, and a penitent belle is under lock and key. The heroine is Miss Ida Stillwell, and the hero an itinerant painter by the name of Clarke.
A horse attached to a truck walked slowly down Beekman-street yesterday morning. As he reached No. 26, between Nassau and William streets, he stopped suddenly.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--A fire started yesterday in the great cranberry belt of Burlington County, N.J., swept over hundreds of acres of valuable bog, and is still burning. The continued drought made the grass and vines very inflammable, and the fire spread with lightning-like rapidity.

Mrs. Susan Cottam, alias Brown, alias Baker, was convicted of bigamy in the Hudson County Special Sessions yesterday. The story of her crime was told in THE TIMES at the time of her arrest. John B. Baker, who is employed as an inspector in the Pennsylvania Railroad yards, advertised for a housekeeper in March ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--President Roberts and Vice-President Thompson, of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, were not at their offices to-day, and it was ascertained that they had gone to New-York on the 8:20 A.M. train.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 10.--The appointment of Charles E. Montfort as Superintendent of the Government Building was revoked to-day.

About a year and a half ago there was a conference of Republicans in the city of Brooklyn which in a certain sense was the forerunner of a political movement which had significant results. On Thursday evening last there was another conference ...

Sandy Hook pilots complain that the masters of some of the sailing vessels which enter this port try to evade the payment of pilotage fees by means of tricks. The compulsory pilotage law requires each vessel coming into port to take on board a pilot, providing the vessel is signaled to do so. The pilot boats usually lie in wait for vessels, and endeavor to see that pilotage facilities ...
The first great cricket match of the season between clubs representing New-York and Philadelphia will be played to-day on the Staten Island Club's grounds at Camp Washington.

Daniel Monahan, of No. 38 Cherry-street, reported to the police of the Third Precinct last night that a man jumped off of Pier No. 28 East River at 9 o'clock in the evening. The suicide was dressed in a dark suit and overcoat, with a black hat. His body was not recovered.

The dynamite scare has reached officials high and low, and yesterday it took in the Mayor's office and its inmates. When the messenger was sorting Mayor Grace's mail he came across a small box about 6 inches long and 3 inches wide and deep.

James Rohan, a stalwart Irish laborer, living at No. 429 West Seventeenth-street, went into the yard of the Manhattan Gas Works at the foot of Eighteenth-street, North River, on Thursday afternoon looking for work.

Roundsman Rorke, of the Third Precinct, stood at Court and Dean streets, Brooklyn, shortly after 9 o'clock last night, and just as he was moving away he heard the loud report of a pistol coming from Dean-street, followed immediately by two more detonations.

At a meeting of the Finance Committee of the Commissioners of Emigration yesterday it was decided to call a meeting of the board for next Monday in order to discuss a communication received from the District Attorney in regard to the sanitary condition of Castle Garden.

Wharton, of that State. To the cowardice of the politicians in power and to the bravery of the participants involved ...

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The President has appointed Col. John Gibbon, of the Seventh Infantry, to be a Brigadier-General of the Army, vice Gen. C.C. Augur, retired to-day. This appointment causes the following promotions: Lieut. Col. Henry C. Merriam, Second Infantry, to be Colonel of the Seventh Infantry; Major J.S. Fletcher, Jr., Twenty-third Infantry, to be Lieutenant-Colonel of the Second Infantry; ...
WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Commissioner of Agriculture to-day received the following telegram:

The Press Club committee met yesterday to make arrangements for the reception of the Mexican editors, who will arrive here from Boston early to-morrow morning. They will be met on landing by a committee of the club, who will escort them to the Hoffman House.

MONTREAL, July 10.--T.E. Hanrahan, a well known stock broker, is suing F.J. Kelley, a former clerk of his, for $21,990. The case is a most peculiar one. On May 22 Hanrahan purchased 300 shares of Montreal Gas Company's stock on margin, the City and District Saving Bank advancing the money.

BOSTON, July 10.--James Russell Lowell writes to the Advertiser that his name was used in connection with the Presidency of Cornell University without consulting him, and he adds that he was not and is not a candidate for the place, as he is not and would not be for any other.

LONDON, July 10.--Mr. John E. Gorst, Solicitor-General, has been re-elected to Parliament for Chatham without opposition. William Thackeray Marriott, Conservative, has been reelected without opposition to represent Brighton in Parliament.

George Truman, the gambler, who put his knife into Larry Brien during their Broadway fight a few months ago, gave himself up to Detective Reilly, and was carried before the District Attorney yesterday. In the Court of General Sessions he formally pleaded not guilty. James E. Kelly, of the firm of Kelly Bliss, pool sellers, appeared as his bondsman for $5,000. Truman was then released.

David Jarvis, 13 years old, of No. 421 West Thirty-third-street, was dangerously injured last evening at Tenth-avenue and Fourteenth-street by being run over while endeavoring to steal a ride on a freight car drawn by a dummy engine of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad. The engineer, W.H. Hildreth, was arrested, and the boy was taken to the New-York Hospital.
LUCAN, Ontario, July 10.--Robert Varley, a farmer, while returning from his work last evening, was struck by lightning and instantly killed. He was carrying a hay fork on his shoulder at the time.

Los Angeles is the centre of this trade. A Fresno house has sold 700 pounds of arsenic since last Saturday, and has orders on hand for some 400 pounds more. A prominent San Francisco drug house has sent 2,000 pounds of arsenic into the valley in the past few days. This gives some idea of the onslaught that is being made on the grasshoppers. The preparation suggested by George West is found to work like a charm.
Sir Frederick Leighton cannot possibly remain a simple knight now that two of his flock of Royal Academicians are Baronets; he should have a peerage, and take the title of "Lord of the 'Iles."

The Board of Aldermen yesterday authorized the Broadway Surface Railroad Company to erect and maintain a "temporary" booth at Bowling-green, opposite Beaver-street. The resolution was presented by Alderman Cleary, and contained no restrictions as to dimensions, and nothing to show the use which is to be made of the "booth." As an Alderman remarked, the "booth" might "give shelter to a car-starter or to all of 'Jake' Sharp's rolling stock."

The ship John McDonald, Capt. Storer, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, was detained at Quarantine, two of the seamen having died of smallpox during the voyage. J.A. McKinly, aged 35, was the first victim of the disease.

The fiscal year which has just closed is frequently described as one of difficulty and even misfortune for the Government, chiefly because the decrease in the public debt has been less than has for some time been made. As a matter of fact we have to go back seven years to find one in which the reduction has not been greater ...

TROY, N.Y., July 10.--Great excitement prevails over the finding of the body of Miss Snyder in the river yesterday, and the wildest reports have been circulated. A rumor that she had been assaulted and murdered and her body thrown in the river by men whose names were mentioned found general belief.

Forgetting that the mercury was striving to beat the record, and that the air was full of sunstrokes, its inhabitants to a man, woman, and child have been boiling over with excitement, and all because two railroads seemed determined to occupy the same piece of ground.

LANSING, Mich., July 10.--The Secretary of the State of Michigan has received crop returns from 1,005 correspondents, representing 740 townships. Six hundred and sixty-three of these returns are from 425 townships in the southern counties.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 10.--The Brown University crew arrived at Lake Quinsigamond to-night, and will begin practice for next Thursday's race with the Bowdoins to-morrow. The four-oared shell has been here since the Fourth of July race.
One of the Aldermen who was going down on a Michigan-avenue car yesterday looked so pale and worried that a friend felt compelled to ask if he was ill.

The revival of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association has not so far been a brilliant success. The selection of Lake Quinsigamond was a mistake, for the lake does not admit of a straightaway course, and for that reason was long ago abandoned by Yale and Harvard.

LONDON, July 10.--Cardinal Manning has accepted the proposition made by the proprietors of the Pall Mall Gazette to submit complete proof of all its revelations, including every name and detail, to a party of responsible men, to include the Cardinal and the Hon. Samuel Morley, the examiners to have the privilege of reporting to the public upon the affair as they may deem best.

MONTREAL, July 10.--The wrecked steamer Lake Manitoba was sold to-day for $1,300. The cargo realized $3,900.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 10.--The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Thomas Pugh, the erratic though wealthy Welsh farmer, near Hubbard, is yet unsolved. The blood-stained buggy which he had used the day of his disappearance, and which was found with the horse hitched to it at his gate, has been closely examined and the blood analyzed and proved to be human.

TORONTO, July 10.--Considerable interest was awakened here to-day in Riel's approaching trial by a statement made by Thomas Holmes, a Wingham barrister, and widely circulated by the newspapers, pointing out that there is a flaw in the indictment against the rebel chief through which he will in all probability get acquitted, and so through a stupid blunder escape punishment.

One of the results of Superintendent Murray's raid on "Capt." Frank Wells's faro game, at One Hundred and Fifth-street and Third-avenue, on the night of June 27 was the preferring of charges of neglect of duty against Capt. John Sanders, of the Twenty-third Precinct. He was tried yesterday, before Commissioners French, Voorhis, McClave, and Porter.

ALBANY, July 10.--Albany is the second city in the State to awake to a realizing sense or the blunder which Gov. Hill committed in determining to have his kind of a census or none, and to prepare at its own expense to remedy the blunder.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 10.--The Fall River and New-Bedford teams of four shot today for the county shot-gun championship, 25 blackbirds, 5 angles, 18 yards' rise. Fall River scored 74; New-Bedford, 68. Best individual score: Andrew E. Butts, of New-Bedford, 23.

SCIPIO, Ind., July 10.--Great excitement exists here over a shocking affray that occurred two and a half miles northeast yesterday afternoon. Daniel Carnes accused Reuben Miller of stealing his chickens, which was resented. Both men used pistols, and are said by their physicians to be fatally injured.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 10.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judge Shipman delivered an opinion in the suit of the Brush Electric Light Company against the Naugatuck Railroad Company and others.

Mr. Stanton, Secretary of the Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera House, who has been in Europe for several weeks engaging a company for the coming season, is expected to sail for this city next Saturday. OTTAWA, July 10.--A cablegram from Rome announces that the Rev. E. Gravel, Cure of Saint Hyacinthe, has been appointed Bishop of the new diocese of Nicolet, which includes all that portion of the old diocese of Three Rivers south of the St. Lawrence River. The new Bishop is a Laval University man, and is now in Rome representing the Archbishop of Quebec and the university.

The holders of more than $2,000,000 of the 7 per cent. second mortgage bonds of the Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Railroad have assented to the proposed reorganization plan. Those bondholders who desire to participate in this reorganization must sign the agreement within 30 days and deposit their bonds with the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company.

MOUNT McGREGOR, July 10.--Gen. Grant's condition seemed so easy this morning that Col. Grant, with his wife and Mrs. Sartoris, went to Round Lake to spend the day at the Grand Army reunion. They met Gen. Buckner at Saratoga, and on their report he came up at noon and saw the General.

The New-York policemen are happy. Last evening a pleasant smile adorned the face of nearly every member of the force. The cause of their joy was the result of the game of baseball played on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon between the picked nines of the NewYork and Brooklyn departments.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 11.--Late last night Judge Fitzgerald finished the preliminary hearing in the case of Dr. Joseph McKenzie, George A. Smith, and Marcus Smith, charged with the murder of Charles S. Botkins, of Sidney, Ohio, in this city on June 19. The accused persons were held to answer to a charge of murder in the first degree, and were sent to jail, no bail being allowed.
CHICAGO, July 11.--Mrs. John W. Coventry to-day obtained a divorce from her husband, John W. Coventry, formerly a Captain in the British Army.

BELVIDERE, N.J., July 11.--A man named Heintzman, a resident of Harmony Township, Warren County, on Friday night last committed suicide in a remarkable manner. He fastened a strap about his neck and, lying down in a manger in his barn, strangled himself to death by the weight of his head and neck. He was a wealthy man and unmarried. No reason can be assigned for the act.

Two out of the three Philadelphia appointments made thus far by Mr. Cleveland are of good soldiers who served with distinction during the war of the rebellion. They were not only good soldiers then, they have been good citizens since the war.

WILMINGTON, July 11.--The physicians in attendance upon Mrs. Bayard authorize the statement that their patient is rather weaker, with a pulse more frequent than yesterday and the temperature below normal.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., July 11.--The wife of Ira D. Warren, a lawyer having an office at No. 170 Broadway, New-York, was taken sick while on the way to visit here, and died at the Hotel Wagner to-day. She was a prominent and wealthy lady, and resided at the FifthAvenue Hotel, New-York City.

ALBANY, July 11.--Gov Hill has decided a novel point which has arisen in connection with the requisition issued by the Governor of Delaware on him, asking for the return of Francis H. Carter alias Francis McDonald, commonly called "Big Frank."

Gilbert drove the mare a mile without a break in 2:21 . Mr. Lewis, Superintendent of the track, and other well-known horse men, were the judges. After the trot the party sat down to a bountiful breakfast.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 11.--Some excitement was created here to-day by the arrest of a New-Yorker named Charles Kercher on a charge of desertion from the Eighth Regiment at New-York. CHICAGO, July 11.--Owing to the fact that east-bound freight rates are to be restored to the twenty-cent basis Monday, the railroad companies expected that shipments during the past week would be unusually heavy, because shippers always take advantage of the prevailing low rates to get as much stuff forward as possible previous to the advance.
Two detectives saw two men trying to pawn a handsomely bound Bible in the Bowery yesterday and arrested them as suspicious persons.

ST. Louis, Mo., July 11.--The beautiful weather, together with the fine playing of the New-York and St. Louis teams, attracted the largest Saturday crowd of the season to the Union Grounds this afternoon.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 11.--The British steamer Colombo, from South Carolina, with a cargo of phosphates for Dublin, in calling at North Sydney for bunker coal, ran ashore on Scatary Island yesterday morning. She is full of water and a total wreck. The Captain and crew are now on their way to Sydney.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 11.--Peter Berg, a laborer, probably 50 years old, was arrested this evening and is now in jail for assaulting the 7-year-old daughter of John Nelson. It is feared that the girl is permanently injured. The community is greatly excited, and threats of lynching are freely made. The prisoner has a wife and daughter, but is known as a cruel fellow. He will be examined on Monday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 11.--It seems to be the opinion of the municipal authorities that the backbone of the strike is broken. In answer to a telegram from Gov. Hoadly this morning, inquiring if any more ammunition was needed. Mayor Gardner replied that there was plenty of ammunition to meet any emergency, and that the strikers were now conducting themselves in an orderly manner.

CHICAGO, July ll.--The rioters during the street car strike were dealt with in court today. Sixty-eight were dismissed, and 41 were fined $1 each and costs. INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 11.--It was announced on Wednesday that two young men-- Charles Harding and James Townsend, farmers living near Evansville--who had been paying attention to the same girl, Sadie Corning, would meet Friday morning and fight for her according to the rules of the prize ring.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 11.--The time given the striking nailers by the Western Nail Association to either accept the manufacturers' terms or forfeit their positions expired at noon to-day without any of the strikers returning to work. They are still firm, and insist on last year's scale of wages.

Surrogate Woods had before him yesterday the matter of the contested will of Daniel Harris, who was found dead in bed, in March last. His estate consists of property valued at several thousand dollars. He made a will, in September last, giving his property to Miss Louisa Ostrom, a sister-in-law.

CHICAGO, July 11.--There was another very large attendance at Washington Park today, the closing one of the meeting. Not less than 10,000 persons were on the grounds when the bell tapped for the first race.

LONG BRANCH, July 11.--The thermometer has come out of its shell. It has suddenly arisen to a consciousness that Winter is no longer lingering in the lap of Spring. On Thursday the mercury rose right up and dallied around in the neighborhood of 94 . When it reaches that point down here it is hot.

TORONTO, July 11.--The Canadian Press Association last night decided upon the route of their annual excursion, on which they will start next Tuesday. They will leave for Boston, the White Mountains, and New-York, and return by Niagara Falls.

KANKAKEE, Ill, July 11.--Sixty persons are reported to have been poisoned at Momence, in this county, by eating dried beef retailed by dealers there and bought from the merchants in Chicago. Twenty of the victims are said to be seriously ill. The remainder are not so sick, but most of them are confined to their beds. No deaths are reported.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 11.--The leading business houses of this city closed at 1 o'clock this afternoon for the first time, in accordance with their agreement to give the employes half a holiday each Saturday during July and August.

LAWRENCE, Mass., July 11.--At a testimonial benefit tendered Raby, the English pedestrian, this afternoon, Raby walked in one hour 8 miles 508 yards, beating the best American record of 8 miles and 301 yards made by John Meagher, of Lawrence. MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 12.--Soon after 5 o'clock this afternoon a heavy wind and rain storm passed over Lake Minnetonka. The small steam yacht Minnie Cook, with eight persons on board, was capsized and every one drowned.
A wild steer caused greet excitement on Sixth-street, Jersey City, last night. The animal was a large and vicious brute, who had escaped from the abattoir. He ran along Sixth-street to the Meadows.
EAST SAGINAW, Mich., July 11.--All mills and salt works on the river are now idle, having been closed down by strikers where they had not previously done so.

MONTPELER, Vt., July 11.--The Record correspondent met ex-Senator Luke P. Poland at the Pavilion House last evening. The latter denied emphatically the report that he was intending to oppose Senator Edmunds.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 12.--The Lake Erie Iron Company, which usually employs 400 men, but now has only half that number, has made a 10 per cent. reduction in the wages of its men. Merchant iron and car axles are its specialty. The managers say they have only followed Pittsburg prices in this instance, as has been their course in the past. The men will accept the reduction with a protest, but without a strike.

The general order, recently published, limiting hereafter to the enlisted men of the army all appointments as hospital stewards secures to them exclusively a source of promotion which they have hitherto had to share with applicants from civil life.

Yesterday might be called an Armenian Sunday for the congregation of the Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh-street, for at the evening services an Armenian missionary was ordained and addresses on Armenian manners, customs, and religions were delivered.

The Central Labor Union held its usual secret meeting yesterday at No. 352 Bowery. It was reported on the outside of the closed doors that a row of the first magnitude was in progress in the meeting, and the fact that there were several small knots of excited and gesticulating union men in the ante-room seemed to give some color to the report.

ALBANY, July 12.--All the wires of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company were cut a second time, by the Western Union, at 3 o'clock this morning. After they were cut Friday night, the Bankers and Merchants' obtained possession again and held them during yesterday.

ST. LOUIS July 12.--The new State Board of Health has mapped out a comprehensive plan of operations for the coming year, which includes the organization of various committees to report on different matters regarding public health.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--Seuor Becerra, the Colombian Minister at Washington, received to-day a telegram from Bogota announcing that the rebels of Barranquilla, persisting in their determination to ascend the Magdalena River, had been completely routed at Calamar.

Peter Messemer was more than 97 years old last week when he died, at No. 150 Secondavenue, the residence of Coroner M.J.B. Messemer. He was buried yesterday. Over 100 friends and relatives attended the funeral. The body was taken to the Church or the Most Holy Redeemer, in Third-street, and after services there to Calvary Cemetery.

On July 1 the Justice, of Paris published the following letter addressed by John Bright to his friend, M. Frederic Passy, Deputy and Member of the Institut: "My Dear M. Passy: I received in due course your too amiable letter of the 3d of April, and the speeches you delivered in the Chamber of Deputies on your new corn laws.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 12.--After a refreshing sleep Mrs. Bayard awoke this morning feeling more comfortable and more inclined to take nourishment. Her temperature was normal and pulse better during the forenoon, and she was more free from suffering. In the afternoon she grew worse, but to-night there is no special change.

LONDON, July 12.--Mr. John Bright writes that the time has arrived for a reform in the land law which shall be equitable alike to the nation and the landlords--not a wild, one-sided scheme. He says he cannot himself enter into the great movement, but hopes to see the reform accomplished.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 12.--The work of preparation for the celebration at Niagara Falls on July 15 is well high done. Fine decorations appear about the hotels and an arch spans Fallsstreet. Slight modifications have been made in the official programme.

That there is serious trouble in the Tammany Hall Democracy no one familiar with the condition of political affairs in this city can doubt. The Tammany men are grievously of fended at what they term the ingratitude of the President, and they make no concealment of their attitude to those in their confidence.
The Right Rev. William Ingraham Kip Bishop of California, and Mrs. Kip yesterday celebrated the fiftieth anniversay of their wedding. Friends had decorated the residence with flowers.

CHICAGO, July 12.--Gen. Nelson R. Miles, who is to succeed Gen. Augur in command of the Department of the Missouri, arrived here today from Oregon, and, with-Lieut. Gen. Phil Sheridan and Col. STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, July 12.--The Thirteenth Regiment has 656 men in camp to-day. Until Saturday 170 of this number had never put a uniform on. Before the week is out some of them will probably wish they never had put one on. The mere act of getting into a uniform is no trouble at all in comparison with the numberless ills it entails.

The Chicago Club still holds a lead of one game in the National Baseball League over the New-Yorks in games won, but both have been defeated 13 times. Manager Mutric is well pleased with the result of the Western trip.

MACON, Ga., July 12.--Harrison Brown, a well known colored hackman, was murdered some time during last night and his body placed on the railroad track in a deep cut in the suburbs of the city. The body was found this morning horribly mangled. Three negros with whom Brown had quarreled last night have been arrested on suspicion of being the murderers.

Coroner Menninger, of Brooklyn, yesterday contined his investigation of the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. Clara Groblewski, who died on Friday at her residence in Gold-street and Myrtle-avenue, and whom, it is claimed by relatives, was poisoned. Mrs. Groblewski had only been married a few months, and the last month of her life was far from happy.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--The forest fires which began at Oak Knoll, N.J., a litttle German settlement, have burned over the belt of cranberry bog property extending for 10 miles from Goshen, in Burlington County, to Braddocks Mills, in Camden County.
QUEENTOWN, July 12.--The Cunard Line steamship Aurania, Capt. Hains, from Liverpool, aid, hence today for New-York.

France is now one gigantic gambling sheol. At Paris, and at every watering place, there are licensed gambling establishments where swindlers and dupes abound. A friend of mine was recently in Paris. I asked him what the political feeling was there. "Politics!" he said: "no one thinks of them; there is but one subject of discussion; it is whether a man should stand or take a card at five when playing at baccarat."

A young married woman has just lost her life at Lyons by a curious mistake. She was returning from Vaise, where she had been to spend the day with a young man, when, in passing along the quay, she exclaimed, on seeing a person approach, "Heaven, here is my husband!" and running to the river jumped in and was drowned. The man who had unintentionally caused her alarm was a stranger to her.
MADRID, July 12.--The returns from all the cholera districts show that on Saturday 1,533 new cases and 648 deaths were reported.

WICHITA, Kan., July 12.--Judge J.D. Scott, of Eureka, and Col. S.A. Martin, of Fort Scott, Kan., are the projectors of a new railroad which will give the lower Arkansas Valley another outlet to Chicago and the East. The company is chartered as the Chicago, Nebraska and Texas Railway Company, with its principal offices and headquarters in Wichita.

ITHACA, N.Y. July 12.--The terrible accident to the Sage family last night is the allabsorbing topic of conversation in Ithaca today. The particulars of the unfortunate affair are substantially those wired yesterday.

This will be the last week this season that fresh strawberries can be obtained in the markets of this city. The supply of berries from Oswego and other western counties of this State last week was quite liberal, and very nice Wilson's Seedlings were wholesaled all the week at less than 13 cents per quart.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 12.--John A. Luby, the stalwart politician, who was removed from the position of Surveyor of Customs last month by President Cleveland for offensive partisanship, and Daniel Wheeler were killed at a fire early this morning in the piano factory of Boardman Gray.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--First Auditor Chenowith has declared, with some show of enthusiasm, that if the fight against him in the Kellar matter is kept up it will result in electing him Governor of Texas.

CINCINNATI, July 12.--A jury has returned a verdict for $1,300 and costs in favor of John McAuley, the Louisville theatrical manager, in his suit against the Kiralfy Brothers for failure to fulfill an engagement at his theatre last sea son.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 12.--About 12:30 o'clock this morning two non-union molders employed at the co-operative foundry, the employes of which are on a strike, left the warehouse, where they are lodged.

DALTON, Ga., July 12.--To-day the Western and Atlantic Railroad changed its schedule so as to reach this place in time to make connection with the Alabama Division of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 12.--In the Freeman murder case, Charles Townsend was yesterday sentenced to be hanged on Aug. 28, and his accomplice, Warren Neal, to be imprisoned in the penitentiary for life. Townsend yesterday confessed the murder, which, he stated, was committed for the purpose of robbery. He secured $24.80. He then fled, but was captured and imprisoned. Another negro who was implicated has been liberated. No appeal will be taken.

Coney Island had gone to bed. It was go early yesterday morning that the big hotels had put out their lights and stood out colossally black as shelter for the vast Saturday crowd which the hot weather had driven to the seaside. The wide avenue was deserted, the stragglers had become beautifully less.

An item has been going the rounds of the press concerning one Hugh M. Brooks, who was lately put upon the pension roll, and in it occurs the statement, as of something strange and wonderful, that he is the first ex-Confederate soldier to receive a pension from the United States Government.

M. Jablochkoff, who was the first to introduce electric lighting in our midst on a practical scale, has for some time past directed his attention to the production of electricity by means of a primary battery.

Cecelia Denny, age 49, the wife of a clerk residing at No. 17 Orchard-street, committed suicide at 11:30 o'clock last night by swallowing a portion of a box of "Rough on Rats." Excessive drinking induced the act.

--Another firm of publishers taking new quarters in West Twenty-third-street follows the prevalent fashion of decorative effects. The parlors, rooms, desks, shelves, and minor appurtenances of the premises occupied by Messrs. E.P. Dutton Co. at No. 31 are intended to make visitors welcome--pleasing the eye, while the brain is being tickled with light and solid mental food.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 12.--Quebec, Halifax, Toronto, and other regiments have arrived here. The Ninetieth, of Winnipeg; the Queen's Own, the Midland York, Simcoe, and other regiments will arrive on Tuesday. A reception is prepared on a large scale. Gen. Middleton will review all the troops here on Wednesday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 12.--The 10-yearold daughter of Albert Carver accuses Frank Crawford, 83 years old, a boarder in the family, of criminally assaulting her while her parents were at church this morning. Crawford denies the charge. He was looked up.

BOSTON, Mass., July 13.--After a year's negotiations the three electric light companies of Boston have determined upon combining their forces. They are the Brush Electric Company, the New-England Weston Electric Company and the Merchants' Electric Light and Power Company.

MADRID, July 13.--The cholera has broken ont in four places in the Province of Jaen. Forty-two new cases were reportea yes terday in that Province and 18 deaths from the disease. WATERFORD, Ireland, July 13.--The anniversary of the battle of the Boyne yesterday caused a large increase in the usual Sunday number of drunken men to be on the streets last night. Among them were many of the soldiers belonging to the Welsh regiment doing garrison duty here.

OTTAWA, July 13.--On motion in the House of Commons to go into supply this afternoon, Mr. Weldon moved as an amendment the consideration of the fishery question. The programme for to-day's racing at Monmouth Park is far beyond the average, both in the number and character of the entries in all of the six races. With the exception of the first race it will puzzle the experts to pick the winner; and the Midsummer Handicap, with its 16 acceptors, is a hard nut to crack, with the apportionment of the weights.

CINCINNATI, July 13.--The starting of the Mitchell Tranter Iron Mill, with a force of 300 men, last week, was followed to-day by the lighting of the furnaces in the Riverside Mill of the Swift Iron and Steel Company. Three hundred men were put to work, and a night run will be started the middle of the week.

CHICAGO, July 13.--Sir Arthur Sullivan, the composer of the music of "Patience," "Pinafore," and, last, of "The Mikado," was in the city to-day on his way to California. "There seems to be an endless muddle about 'The Mikado,'" a reporter said to him.

ALBANY, July 13.--The Consumers' Gas Company, of Buffalo, with a capital of $500,000; the Rochester Sewer Pipe Company, with a capital of $100,000, and the Rappaport Association, of New-York, were incorporated to-day.

RICHMOND, Va., July 13.--There has been considerable excitement for several days past in Henry County, in the vicinity of Martinsville, over the mystery involved in the death of Mrs. G.L. Stone, who was found dead last Monday.

Last night came a dispatch to the News from Cokerville, Wyoming Territory, that Gov. Bunn and his fellow tourists, Congressman Bingham and Counselor Eshleman, were en route home from the far West.

READING, Penn., July 13.--Considerable excitement was caused at Sheridan, Lebanon County, this morning, by the receipt of news from South Mountain, three miles distant, that a mine of mica had been discovered on the Joel Trexter tract. A 30-foot shaft has been sunk. A rich deposit of fine mica, worth from $3 t0 $9 a pound, was struck.

Inspector Robinson has discovered a shortage of $500 in the accounts of the Postmaster at Ord, Neb. The deficit was made good, but the sureties recommend the removal of the Postmaster.

BOSTON, July 13.--As the steamer City of Macon, Capt. Kelly, from Savannah, was entering this port last night, her wheel fouled a buoy. The tugs Storm King and Despatch went to her assistance and started to tow her to the city, buoy and all. In coming through the Narrows the buoy took the bottom and forced the steamer ashore on Lowell's Island, where she remained until this morning, when she was hauled of.

WILMINGTON, Del. July 13.--Mrs. Bayard rallied a trifle on Sunday, but has relapsed into her critical condition of Saturday. Her family and attendants realize that the end is graving near.

The New American, of Richfield Springs, offers a combination of attractions which fully explains its always increasing popularity. Its situation, opposite the springs, is the very best; its rooms are airy and comfortably furnished, and its cuisine, under the management of Hoffman House cooks, unexcelled. DAYTON, Ohio, July 13.--Albert Hunt, a young man residing a short distance southeast of this city, has been seized with a peculiar mania, prompted by a feeling of despondency and remorse, to seek a burial place in a remote and unfrequented place.

MATTAWA, Ontario, July 13.--Six men while running Calf Rapids, four miles from here, were upset. Four of them clung to their boat and the other two swam ashore. The four on the boat floated down to the Demicharge Rapids, half a mile below, and were there washed off the boat and drowned. Their names were George Hodd, William ,Christin, Philip Martin, and George Langlier. None of the bodies have yet bean recovered.

HILLISBOROUGH, Texas, July 13.--It was learned here to-day that W.A. Jackson, the well known cattleman, who recently fled from the country, leaving debts to the amount oY $300,000, has finally turned up safely in Cuba.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 13.--Prof. Charles Kendall Adams was chosen President of Cornell University to-night by an almost unanimous vote of the Trustees. The selection was no surprise here, as it was known that a majority of the Trustees would favor Prof. Adams's election.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 13.--The steamships City of Dallas and S. Oteri, engaged in the Honduras fruit trade, were due here last Saturday. Their non-arrival gave rise to numerous sensational rumors. Yesterday afternoon the statue of the late Lord F. Cavendish, erected in the Town Hall-square, Barrow-in-Furness, was unveiled by Earl Spencer, the former colleague of the deceased nobleman.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--Inspector Armstrong has succeeded in carrying out his instructions to open up the cattle trails through the Indian Territory. He telegraphed Secretary Lamar this morning that all differences between the drovers and ranchmen have been settled, and that cattle from Texas are now moving northward without obstruction.

A meeting of holders of the stock and bonds of the Texas and St. Louis Railroad will be held some day this week in this city for the purpose of discussing measures to reorganize the property. Heretofore all efforts at reorganization have failed for want of harmony among the security holders.

KANKAKEE, Ill. July 13.--Reports from Momence, where the wholesale poisoning from dried beef occurred last Saturday, are that Mrs. Shronts has died from the effects of the poison; Mrs. H. Worcester is lying very low, as is also Mrs. A. Cullon, Miss L. Burton, Miss Lillie Looker, and Mr. E. Giebault. About 40 others are seriously ill.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 13.--It is reported to-night that Henry Seaman is now a candidate for Superintendent of the Government Building. It is known that his brother, James Seaman, had an interview with Cyrus Swan this afternoon, and that James H. Seaman, who is employed in the State Capitol, left here for Yonkers on the 8:30 P.M. train to see John O'Brien, a member of the Democratic State Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--The Presidential party returned to-night from their fishing trip to Woodmont, arriving here at 11:30 in a special car attached to the New-Orleans express. Their arrival was unexpected, and consequently there was no crowd present...

BUFFALO, July 13.--James Galvin, pitcher of the Buffalo baseball nine, is about to join the Pittsburg Club. He has been released from the Buffalo Club, and will be off duty for 10 days. The arrangements were made to-day. His friends say that Galvin believes the Buffalo...
Cen. George S. Field, of Buffalo, is at the Victoria Hotel.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 13.--There was considerable excitement at West Point today over the drowning of Warwick McCray, who was in the Third Class of cadets, from Pennsylvania. He was bathing in the Hudson, when he was seized with cramps. One or two cadets endeavored to rescue him, but failed. Grapplers have been at work this afternoon endeavoring to find the body. Out of the last examination in a class of 67 he stood 14.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13.--The weather continues clear and cool. Rain is needed. The arrivals at the hotels to-day were not numerous. The dance at the Casino to-night was well attended, more people being present than at any of the two dances which preceded it.

Conrad N. Jordan, Treasurer of the United States, informed the New-York Clearing House Association yesterday that under the present condition of affairs the country was steadily drifting toward a silver basis.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., July 13.--The 11th day of June, 1884, a party of about 30 children, mostly boys, ranging in ages from 8 to 17 years, were brought here from the New-York Juvenile Asylum and homes secured for them with citizens of this county.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 13.--A new case of fever came to light at Plymouth yesterday in the person of an employe at the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad station in that town. The patient has not drank a drop of Plymouth water but has been using water procured at Pittston ever since the first outbreak of the epidemic. The phsicians pronounce his ailment to be genuine Plymouth fever.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 13.--Katie Heil, 10 years old, was sent to a drug store yesterday morning, but did not return, To-day a man in Geddes, a suburb of this city, who had read a description of the girl in a morning paper, telephoned to Police Headquarters that the child was in Geddes with an old man. Detectives responded, but before they reached Geddes the old man had gone.

NEW-HAVEN, July 13.--Canker worms ruined many of the orchards in Fairfield and Litchfield Counties last Spring. The pest disappeared and the trees are now beginning to put forth new leaves. The apple crop throughout the infected district is, of course, gone.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 13.--The Chinese recently ordered the expulsion of the English traveler Dagleish from Yarkand. The Governor, having acted hesitatingly in the execution of the order, has been punished, and Dagleish has been forcibly expelled from Yarkand by the Chinese authorities.

CLEVELAND, July 13.--The strike took a very sensational turn to-day in the arrest of Garsuch, the noted Socialist, of Chicago. Garsuch is editor of the Socialistic paper called the Alarm, and reached the city yesterday morning. Several of the local leaders, at whose suggestion he had come, organized a meeting among the English, Scotch, Welsh, and Irish strikers.

The New-Yorks returned from their Western trip yesterday and suffered defeat at the hands of the Providence champions in a game played on the Polo Grounds. Nearly 5,000 persons assembled to welcome the Giants home again. Every seat in the grand stand was taken, and the spectators were packed in the free stands like sardines.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 13.--Sidney M. StaNiforth was a young lawyer of remarkable talent, of fine English family, the representative of considerable wealth and of the highest standing in San Antonio and Austin. He was handsome, of powerful physique, gentle and generous, and liked by all.

MONTREAL, July 13.--Six new cases of smallpox were reported to-day. There were 15 deaths from the disease during the past week, l0 of which were inside the city limits. This makes 32 deaths in the city alone in three weeks.

NEW-HAVEN, July 13.--New-York people who summer at Newtown have had Daniel Ferris pointed out to them as not only the most heavily built man in that part of Connecticut but the biggest land owner as well. Yesterday while riding with his wife he suddenly fell over in his carriage dead. He was about 65 years old.

The Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company sent word to the Board of Aldermen of that city yesterday that the company had been requested by many citizens to extend its road from Lexington-avenue through Broadway to the Grand and Roosevelt Streets Ferries, in the Eastern District.
There were over 5,000 persons at the Brighton Beach races yesterday, and they were furnished with good sport. A feature of the day was the succession of good starts that were made.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 13.--Daniel Anderson, of Spotswood, N.J., while rowing on a small stream near that place on Sunday afternoon, with his wife and four children, ran the boat on a snag. While he was attempting to get it off the boat capsized in 15 feat of water. Anderson rescued his wife and two daughters, but was unable to save his two boys, aged 5 and 7, Their bodies were afterward recovered.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 13.--There is an epidemic of Sunday bloodshed among the colored people. The record of this character of crime of late has exceeded all precedent. Yesterday John Brooks, a worthy and respected old negro, reprimanded his stepdaughter for her...

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13.--The South ern New England Telephone Company has an office in this place with About 100 subscribers. The company has raised the rates twice, and trouble is imminent. A petitson is said to be passing around asking the subscribers to remove their instruments. A number have agreed to do so, and it looks as if a large percentage of the Telephones will be removed before long.

MONTREAL, July 13.--The pianos which were being imported from the United States by officers of the Royal Electric Light Company, were seized to-day at Longueuil, as they had been entered as household effects. One of the instruments was invoiced at $1,200 and the other at $400. Checks for the full amount of duty were at once deposited with the Collector of Customs.

Flames burst, forth suddenly soon after 1 o'clock yesterday in the bay and feed store of Devine Rush, Nos. 405 to 411 Washingtonstreet. The building consists of a wooden shed, 100 feet front on Washington-street, and about the same frontage on Laight-street.

NOVI, Mich., July 13.--An unknown tramp entered the house of William Jones last night and demanded lodging. On being refused he commenced to break the furniture and drove the family out of the house. Jones returned with a gun and shot the tramp, killing him instantly. The Prosecuting Attorney refuses to prosecute Jones entirely exonerating him from blame.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 13.--A letter from the Rev. Joseph T. Duryea to Judge Landon, Acting President of Union College, causes confident belief the Dr. Duryea will accept the Presidency of the college. Judge Landon says positively that Dr. Duryea will accept. A formal acceptance is expected soon.

Two weeks ago Bernard Connelly, who owns a liquor store at No. 357 Fourth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was annoyed by a crowd of boys. To get rid of them he turned a hose upon them. They retreated,and, filling their pockets with stones, came back and assaulted the saloon keeper.

CHICAGO, July 14.--In obedience to the circular of Secretary Manning of June 12 reducing the running expenses of the Government building Collector Spalding to-day discharged two elevator conductors, four firemen, two watchmen, and two cleaners employed in the Custom House. WASHINGTON, July 14.--An army retiring board having found Second Lieut. James M. McCarty, Ninth Infantry, Incapacitated for active service, and that his incapacity is not the result of any incident of service, he has, by direction of the President and in conformity with section 1,252 Revised Statutes, been wholly retired from the service, to take effect this date and his name will be henceforward omitted from the Army Register.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17.--Tom Hanlon, aged 37, confined in jail with delirium tremens, broke a window pane and with a triangular piece of glass stabbed himself in the left lung. Turning the glass round and round, he made a horrible aperture, into which he thrust his hand and pulled out a portion of the lung. He is still living, but will die.

SHARON, Penn., July 17.--Executions were issued on Thursday against the Wheeler Iron Company, of this place, to the amount of over $70,000. The Sheriff has attached the property of the firm, which consists of a rolling mill at Middlesex, company store, and a number of company houses in the same town. Dullness of trade is supposed to have caused the failure. The company thought of converting the mill into a steel mill this fall.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 21.-The Rowan County troubles have developed another grand farce. To-day Craig Tolliver and eight others, who were on trial for the murder of Edward Rayburn, were acquitted. Craig Tolliver was again arrested and is in jail in charge of the military.
