Gaylord Co., of St. Louis, their financial agents to carry out the plan. The bonds involved amount to $700,000, and are held in different parts of the country, but chiefly in New-York and the East. Leavenworth County saves 5 per cent. interest by the readjustment.
CHICAGO, July 22.--The Brighton Pier Company, of Chicago, proposes to build a pier into the lake at Thirty-first-street.

Two hundred pearl buttonmakers in eight different shops in Newark struck yesterday. This action was the result of a notice posted by the employers demanding that the men concede them the right to employ nonunion men if they desired, otherwise they would lock up their shops on Friday. The strike was simultaneous in all the shops.

Brimmer, Jr., Assistant Chief Engineer of the Norfolk Fire Department, at Virginia Beach last night without provocation. E.E. Couch, an ex-police officer of Atlanta, now in the service of the City Court, has published a handbook for Sheriffs, police officers, detectives, , giving full description of fugitives from justice for whom rewards have been offered in Georgia in the last 18 years. A dispatch from Washington stating that three bars of silver, valued at $1,900, are missing from the mint was confirmed this morning by Superintendent Fox. Mr. Fox, however, declined to converse on the subject. He admits that the loss was discovered recently, but declines to say when or how. The dispatch states that the bullion was stolen from the mint. but Mr. Fox refrains either from affirming or denyine the report.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 23.--The race between Edward Hanlan and George H. Hosmer at Cazenovia Lake, 15 miles from Syracuse, was rowed at 5:30 P.M. to-day. It was made the occasion for running special trains from one end of the State to the other, but less than 2,000 people saw the race.

A large and promiscuous lot of unclaimed personal property which has been left in the cars of the elevated railroad during the past year was disposed of yesterday at public auction by direction of General Manager F.K. Hain.

The Newark (N.J.) Cricket Club put in their first appearance this season on the grounds of the Staten Island Club, at Tompkinsville, yesterday. Both teams were well represented, and at one time the game looked as though it would prove a close contest.

HERKIMER, N.Y., July 23.--Daniel Strong, a prosperous farmer of Columbia, and a patron of the cheese factory there, was caught watering his milk recently. The association imposed a fino of $50 on him.

LONDON, July 23.--Col. Mapleson has engaged Signor Ravelli, the tenor, for a full season of opera in New-York. He is gathering a strong company for the season in that city.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23.--Walt Whitman, the venerable poet, while sitting on the stops of his residence in Camden, N.J., last night, was prostrated by heat and fell to the pavement. He was carried into the house, and in a short time recovered consciousness. He is much better to-day, but complains of his head.

There were 171 deaths reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics during the 24 hours ending at noon yesterday. Of these 94 were of children under 5 years of age. The total deaths from diarrheal diseases were 64, of which 52 were of children under 5 years.

Mackin, sentenced to five years in the penitentiary for perjury in connection with the Eighteenth Ward election fraud. WASHINGTON, July 23.--The Mexican editors were received by President Cleveland in the East Room of the White House at 10 o'clock today. The meeting was merely one of introduction, and no speeches were made.

NEWPORT, July 23.--Among the cottagers entertaining to-day were Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mrs. Cyrus W. Field, Mrs. H.L. Livingston, Mrs. W.R. Travers, Mrs. John W. Ellis, Mrs. W.H. Osgood, Francis P. Freeman, Robert Goelet, and others.
A party of 40 gypsies from Bosnia arrived yesterday on the Bordeaux steamship Chateau Leoville. Of the party 13 were men.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24.--The Third District Democratic Congrssional Convention last night, on the one hundred and seventy-second ballot, nominated T.C. McRae for Congress, to fill the vacancy caused by the election of Representative James K. Jones to the Senate.

Mrs. Cramer, a sister of Gen. Grant, arrived from Europe yesterday on the steamship Wieland. She was accompanied by her husband, who has held a diplomatic post abroad. Mrs. Cramer was informed of her brother's death as soon as the steamer reached Quarantine. Mr. and Mrs. Cramer went at once to their home in Elizabeth, N.J.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 24.--Peter Agger and Herman Sunning, manufacturers of bedsteads under the firm name of Agger Sanning, made an assignment to Jordan Bodemer yesterday for the benefit of their creditors.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 24.--William George, a colored preacher, and formerly Pension Agent at Lake Providence, is to-day on trial before the District Court for shooting to death a colored woman named Peggy H. Johnson on Aug. 2, 1882. George escaped to Texas after the killing, but was captured and brought back about six months ago. The jury is composed of four white and eight colored men.

Cable advices received in this city yesterday report the destruction by fire on Thursday of the entire business portion of the city of Cardenas, Cuba, and a consequent great loss of property in sugar and molasses.

Frank White, a pugilist, yesterday told Referee George W. Lyon how Owney Geoghegan had introduced him to his wife and child. The introduction, he said, occurred at No. 105 Bowery in 1880. White said he was at one time manager of Owney Geoghegan's place.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 24.--The first bale of cotton of the season of 1885-88 was received in this city Wednesday night from De Witt County, Texas. It weighed 570 pounds, and was classified as middling. It was sold at auction on the floor of the Cotton Exchange yesterday, bringing $100.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--Some time since the Department of State demanded the release of Suntos, a naturalized American citizen, who way imprisoned by the Ecuadorian Government on the charge of being connected with a revolution in that country.

CHICAGO, July 24.--The roads in the Colorado Association west of the Missouri River refused to-day to sanction the two years' life which the Colorado Railway Association had voted for its agreement, and the time was reduced to one year.

KANKAKEE, Ill., July 24.--The Illinois Central freight train No. 19, running wild, ran into freight No. 18 here to-day, demolishing 16 freight cars and the two engines. A tramp, stealing a ride, was killed, and some of the train heads were injured. The money loss is $25,000.

Mr. Flint was unable to learn her whereabouts yesterday. Mr. Leutze arrived from Savannah yesterday in search of his wife.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24.--From the Indian Territory it is learned that intense excitement exists in the Indian country owing to the proclamation of the President removing cattlemen from the Territory within 40 days and declaring their leases to be void. The situation is very grave and stockmen are greatly depressed.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 24.--The announcement is made this evening that C.L. Waite, Postmaster of this city and a former editor of the Hawk-Eye, has bought that paper, paying something over $35,000. The paper, now a five-cent quarto, will appear on Tuesday as an eight-column folio. No change will occur in the staff.
CLEVELAND, July 24.--A large meeting of the strikers was held this evening at Monumental Park. A delegation, variously estimated at from 2,000 to 3,000, marched in from the Eighteenth Ward.

ESCANABA, Mich., July 24.--Part of the crew of the schooner R. Halloran arrived here in their yawl this afternoon, and reported the schooner ashore about 10 miles south of Death's Door, probably on Spider Island.

ONANCOCK, Va., July 24.--While heroically attempting to save a little boy from drowning, Capt. John M. Fosque was drowned in Onancock Creek, near here. The lad was out bathing and had gotten beyond his depth. He had sunk twice when Capt. Fosque came up. He sprang into the water and prevented the boy from drowning, but in so doing lost his own life.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--The President has appointed as Presidential Postmaster Frank P. Crotzer at Nantlooke, Penn., vice John H. James, resigned.

CHICAGO, July 24.--Rumors are rife today that two prominent fast freight lines are taking wool to the East at rates far below the regular tariff.

Yesterday the annual meeting of the American Canoe Association began at Grindstone Island in the St. Lawrence. This is the fourth meeting since the organization of the association, and from a membership of thirty-three it has grown to a membership of nearly a thousand.
GALVESTON, Texas, July 24.--The conference of Texas railroad managers has resulted in an organization that will be known as the Texas Traffic Association.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--Rome time ago the President asked Attorney-General Garland to look up the legal questions involved in the Indian Territory cases.

OMAHA, Neb., July 24.--Milton W. Smith, who murdered his wife, was hanged in the jail yard at Osceola, Polk County, this morning. An immense crowd of people surrounded the inclosure, and the town wore a Fourth of July appearance.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 25.--Prof. E. T. Fristoe, of the Columbian University, Washington, D.C., to whom was sent for analysis specimens of the silver ores recently found near Cleveland, 28 miles from this city, has sent back his report.

MOBILE, Ala., July 25.--The flux, which has been widely prevalent in Western Alabama, is now very severe in Choctaw County. Reports are to the effect that in the southern part of the county the disease outnumbers all other causes of sickness and that few of the people attacked recover. Many families in the infected district have abandoned their homes and considerable distress exists in consequence.

OSWEGO, N.Y., July 25.--Secretary Manning has issued an order reducing the force in the Oswego Custom House five men, to go into effect Aug. 1. The saving in salaries will be about $5,000 per year.

CHICAGO, July 25.--The prediction that east-bound freight shipments by rail would dwindle down to almost nothing if an attempt was made to carry out the new twenty-cent tariff is verified by the statement of shipments during the week just ended.

ELKHART, Ind., July 26.--A cow belonging to William Hueuryeager died yesterday from a snake bite. The farmer traced the serpent to its den, three miles south of here, and killed it with dynamite. The snake measured 17 feet in length and 16 inches in circumference. Great joy at its fate prevails in that vicinity, as numerous lambs were required to satisfy its voracious appetite.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 25.--The Haggerty place, at Lenox, occupied by Secretary Whitney and family, was entered by burglars last night and $300 worth of silverware, much of it family heirlooms, was stolen. Besides this it is supposed that much other valuable property was taken. Secretary Whitney and wife are out of town.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25.--The weather to-day has been very changeable, and it was the first stormy day for several weeks. It was also an exceptionally hot day. Rain fell this morning and also this afternoon, leaving the middle of the day very pleasant. It is very damp and foggy to-night.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 25.--Last night Peter Stamps, colored, was lynched at Douglasville by a mob of 500 men for an alleged assault committed upon Ida Abercrombie, daughter of a well-to-do white farmer.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 25.--A somewhat peculiar suit in Chancery Court was settled to-day. A livery firm here was given the exclusive privilege of carrying visitors to the point on Lookout Mountain, the scene of the famous battle above the clouds.

A very close and interesting match was placed at Staten Island yesterday between the Staten Island and Tile Company Clubs. Each club played 12 men a side and the result was in favor of the Tile Company men by 2 runs in the first inning. Clevercy's bowling for the victors was remarkable.

Grant in NewYork instead of here, but there is no desire manifested to disregard the wishes of the great commander as expressed by him before his death or the desires of his family made known since.

DOVER, N.H., July 25.--The White Mountain express train, due here at 11:36 A.M., met with an accident a mile south of this city on the Western Division of the Boston and Maine Railroad. Two Pullman cars attached to the rear end of the train, filled with passengers, were thrown from the track by the breaking of a journal. The passengers escaped with a slight shock.

MONTREAL, July 25.--The international cricket match between the Longwood Club, of Boston, and the Montreal Cricket Club was concluded here to-day, the match being won by Montreal by 26 runs. The Bostonians concluded their first inning to-day, making 88 runs.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 25.--Thomas Hoops, of New-York City, to-day swore out a complaint against George T. Van Woert and Edward Wolcott, charging them with criminally using for themselves money which belonged to the firm of Nelson Morris Co., of Chicago, of which Mr. Hoops is the agent.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--M.D. Helm has brought suit against the Washington Critic, asking an accounting and the appointment of a Receiver. Haliet Kilbourn, R.H. Sylvestor, and W. Scott Towers are the defendants.

NYACK, N.Y., July 25.--The heaviestthunderstorm known in years visited this region this afternoon. A house occupied by Charles Tayleure at Mont Moor was badly damaged by lightning. Mr. Tayleure was stunned, but not badly hurt. Considerable damage was done in Rockland County.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--The Mexican editorial excursionists to-day visited the Luray caverns in Virginia, and departed to-night for Pittsburg over the Pennsylvania Road in the Mann boudoir car Fra Diavolo, planed at their disposal by the Mann Company. They will spend Sunday at Cresson Springs, on the Alleghany Mountains.

CATSKILL, July 24.--A card in a contemporary's columns last Sunday set forth the astonishing attractions of a Catskill boarding house "8,000 feet above the sea."

Felix Rodriguez, a well known compositor, has died in the city. He was one-armed, but very expert, and held his stick in the stump of his left arm. Years ago he had a trial of speed with another compositor. and, losing in the race, had his own left hand cut off in rage.

ROCHESTER, July 25.--This afternoon the body of a man, evidently a tramp, was found in a ravine about four miles northwest of the city. The throat was out and near by was a razor half open and with blood stains rusted on it. The body had evidently been in the ravine several weeks, and was frightfully decomposed. In a small notebook in a pocket was found the following: "Robert McCartney, No. 7 Dalkeithplace."

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 25.--Ex-Senator B.F. Jonas, recently appointed Collector of this port, took charge of his office to-day, Gen. Badger, the retiring Collector, having everything in order to make the necessary transfer of the public property in his charge.

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 25.--Mrs. A.A. Scott, of Midway, was shot this morning by her husband and so seriously injured that she will die. They had been quarreling. The murderer is in jail in this place.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--The members of the South Pennsylvania syndicate who live in this city are very indignant over the treatment that they have received at the hands of Mr. Vanderbilt.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 25.--Cottage life in this resort is fast assuming the proportions attained by Newport and Long Branch. Elaborate cottages have been erected, mediaeval in tone and structure, many gabled, with towers and turrets, deep piazzas, and portecocheres.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--During a dispute this morning between Thomas Brailor and Samuel Johnson, two employee of the contractor for removing the citp's garbage, the former plunged a pitchfork into the latter. Johnson fell dead in a few minutes. Brailor is colored. He surrendered to the authorities, claiming the deed was done in self-defense.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 25.--Maud S. trotted a mile at the Glenville track to-day in 2:11. The intention was to give her a warm mile, and she was sent to the first quarter pole in 0:34 . She was going so smoothly that Bair gave her the rein, and she went the second quarter in O:32 , and the last half in 1:04.

MONTREAL, July 25.--The lacrosse championship pennants were competed for here today by the Montreals and Ontarios, of Toronto. The match was a one-sided one, the Ontarios being overmatched and playing a defense game.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 25.--"Like the Texan who wanted a revolver very much one day, it I need you at all, young gentlemen, I will need you powerful bad."

The gang of thugs which for so long a time terrorized Sal Soda, Fla., and styled themselves the Sal Soda Vigilance Committee has been completely exterminated, although Jason L. Halford, the Captain of the band, has thus far escaped his pursuers and is still at liberty.

SHIRLEYSBURG, Penn., July 25.--Thirty years ago John R. Hick, a then prosperous young potter of this place, mysteriously disappeared. Large rewards were offered, but to no purpose.

UTICA, N.Y., July 25.--The ninth annual picnic of the hop growers of Central New-York was held at the grove at Beacon Beach, Oneida Lake, to-day. For the first time in the history of the association the day opened with rain, and the attendance was reduced by at least onethird.

LONG BRANCH, July 25.--The joyous manner in which the week opened, with a great increase in the number of guests and several festive occasions announced, received a severe blow in the news of Gen. Grant's death.

The crowd endured the intense heat at Monmouth Park yesterday with apparent goodnature, but it was very trying even to the most even-tempered of men or women. The atmosphere was laden with moisture, and the clouds rolled up from the sea, threatening to deluge the track, but the rain did not come and the sport was not interfered with.

LONDON, July 25.--I have the information, which the Observer will print to-morrow, that the Russians now occupy Zulfikar Pass. They are said to have been there a fortnight, and it is stated that the Marquis of Salisbury has known of the occupation for several days.

FORT SNELLING, Minnesota, July 25.--Major Logan, in his official report to Gen. Terry today, says that the trouble on the Rosebud near Miles City was greatly exaggerated. The trouble was only between a faction of the Cheyennes, and there was no fight with cowboys.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--The following circular was issued to-day to the coal operators shipping via the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad: "The quota for the month of July will be filled on Saturday, 25th inst. All shipments of coal will, therefore, be discontinued after that date. It has been arranged that all collieries in the Schuylkill region shall work on full time during the month of August."
STREATOR, Ill., July 25.--The body of an unknown man was found in an alley in this city this morning with a bullet hole through his brain.

SARATOGA, July 25.--The weather at the track to-day was warm and cloudy when the sport began, but the attendance was good. Before the steeplechase was run there was a heavy storm, which converted the track into a muddy and very heavy course. Following are details of the sport:

SYRACUSE, July 25.--Papers have been served on William Porter Sabey in a suit for breach of promise of marriage alleged to have been made to Minnie Eva. Moore, daughter of Mrs. A.E. Moore, a widow. The damages claimed is $50,000.
FORT PLAIN, N.Y., July 25.--Daniel Weiting, a wealthy furniture dealer and a lifelong resident of this place, was found dead in his once this afternoon. He was 70 years old.

Just one game separates the Chicago and New-York Clubs in their race for the leadership of the league. Both teams are winning with the utmost regularity, and it is presumed that the positions will remain unchanged until next Saturday, when the giants of the arena meet on the Polo Grounds.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 26.--The story of a merry maiden's marriage comes from Webster, in Jackson County. Miss Douglas was a pretty 13-year-old daughter of the Register of Deeds in that county.

BALTIMORE, July 26.--Father Michael J. Brennan, assistant priest at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, died suddenly this afternoon of apoplexy, superinduced by the heat. He said mass during the day, and officiated at a baptism shortly before his death. Father Brennan was 35 years of age. He was ordained to the priesthood three years ago at the Cathedral in this city, and has occupied his present position ever since.

LONDON, July 26.--There was more firmness in the money market during the week. It is believed that the decline in the value of money has reached the limit of its movements pending a certain increased demand for the accommodation of the Egyptian loan and several colonial loans. Harvest requirements will also soon contribute to a rise in rates.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., July 26.--A new system of water supply lately introduced here is now nearly completed and will furnish an ample supply for domestic, sanitary, and fire purposes. SALT LAKE, Utah Territoy, July 24.-- This is the thirty-eighth anniversary of the entrance in Salt Lake Valley by Brigham Young and 142 Mormons, who made their journey from the Missouri River by ox teams.

Gen. W.T. Sherman reached the FifthAvenue Hotel in this city late on Sunday night and went directly to bed. He had come through from St. Paul, Minn., without a stop, and he was tired. Early callers at the hotel yesterday morning, however, found the General up and walking about. He said that he was feeling splendidly, and his looks substantiated his words.

MOBILE, Ala., July 27.--A duel is on foot between W.B. Walker, late Democratic Elector for the First Mississippi District, and S. J. Dalton, Jr., editor of the Aberdeen Examiner. The party has gone toward Memphis, and will fight at daylight.

LONDON, July 27.--It is now announced that the services in memory of Gen. Grant at Westminster Abbey will take place at 4 o'clock Tuesday, Aug. 4. The Dean of Westminster will read the Episcopal service, and the Rev. Dr. Farrar will deliver the address. Seats will be reserved for Americans. The remainder of the Abbey will be open to the public.

There was an odd assault and battery case tried in the County Court at White Plains yesterday, the plaintiff being Wright Eckert and the defendant Wright Flewellin. The plaintiff is a grandson of the defendant, who is 86 years of age. Both live at Mount Kisco.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 27.--Saturday afternoon's storm, which did a good deal of damage in many parts of the State, was felt very severely in South Manchester, nine miles from this city. CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27.--This morning, just after feeding time, 50 horses belonging to the Superior-Street Railway Company were taken sick, several of them dying in a very short time. Upon examination it was discovered that the horses' food had been saturated with croton oil.

The Underground Wire Commission met in the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday, with President Loew in the chair. Secretary Theodore Moss announced that he had notified 22 companies and individuals controlling telegraphic or telephonic wires of the resolutions passed by the commission at its first meeting, and had taken a receipt for his communication in each case.

Mr. Leveson Gower has been directed by Mr. Gladstone to explain that his letter to the Midlothian Liberal Association did not contain any promise to stand again, though it held out some prospect that Mr. Gladstone might, under certain circumstances, find it his duty to take that course.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--The American Iron and Steel Association has received from the manufacturers complete statistics of the production of pig iron and Bessemer and open hearth steel in the United States in the first half of 1885, together with the statistics of the stocks of pig iron on hand and unsold at the close of this period.

MOUNT McGREGOR,July 27.--Manager Fonda gave directions to-day for the preparation of a car in which to take the coffin containing Gen. Grant's body down the Mountain Railroad to Saratoga a week from to-morrow.

ALBANY, July 27.--Gov. Hill to-day issued the following invitation in response to the request of a large number of Senators and members of the Assembly and after consultation with President McCarthy, of the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--A meeting of the Board of Managers of the Reading Railroad took place to-day in President Keim's office. There were only four of the managers--Messrs. Keim, Wanamaker, Sayre, and Williamson-- present.

CHICAGO, July 27.--The remarkable depression in lake business is becoming more serious every day and vessel owners are unable to see any prospects of a revival. Fully 500,000 bushels of capacity was offered here to-day at a one-cent rate to Buffalo and not a pound of grain was loaded.

A young woman becomingly dressed in a white suit and light straw hat tried to jump off the ferryboat Farragut yesterday morning as she was entering her slip at Fulton-street. She was stopped by a couple of young men who had been attracted by her strange deportment.

Detective John Sullivan, of the Mercerstreet police station, applied to Justice Kilbreth yesterday for a warrant for a raid on the "Black and Tan," a place of bad repute at No. 153 Bleecker-street frequented by both white and colored people. The warrant was refused, but one was issued for the arrest of Patrick Mee, proprietor of the place, for keeping a disorderly house. Mee was arrested last evening and the place was closed.

Marchesi, the famous singing professor, about her still more famous pupil, Gabrielle Krauss, we digressed into a talk about the vocal gifts of the different civilized nations of the world. CHICAGO, July 27.--A private dispatch received here to-day says that within a day or two the Pennsylvania Railroad will advance emigrant rates over its line from New-York to Chicago to $13.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 27.--Nathaniel Sands, of Norwalk, who was held under $150,000 bail for alleged frauds against the city of NewYork, has occupied the poor debtor's cell at the count jail in this city for several days. Sands went before Judge De Faust to-day and took the poor debtor's oath. He is still in custody, but will probably be liberated in a few days.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, NEAR PEEKSKILL, July 27, 1885.--The detail of men who were sent up the valley last night to establish an outpost returned to camp this morning just in time to hear the sounding of the reveille.

BUFFALO, July 27.--The Chautauqua statesmen haves a candidate for State Treasurer whom they seriously think of booming. The southwestern portion of the State has not been favored with any office of prominence for several years and local pride is a trifle affected in consequence.

WASHINGTON, July 28.--Secretary Endicott's action in dispensing with the services of his Military Secretary, Gol. Barry, is in accordance with his views of administrative reform.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 28.--The weather was quite cool here yesterday and was comfortable to-day. Last night the postponed hop came off at Congress Hall. A piazza hop will be given at the Kensington to-night.

CAIRO, July 28.--The Khedive formally opened the General Assembly to-day, and asked its assent to the $45,000,000 loan. The loan will be issued on Thursday next.

The changes of malfeasance in office against Justice Delahanty, of Long Island City, were further investigated before a Referee yesterday. S.B. Noble, counsel for the defense, was directed to produce the book of record kept by the Justice that the court might know the character and disposition of cases which had been brought before him. Mr. Noble objected, but the Referee insisted.

CoLUMBIA, S.C., July 28.--Cotton worms have attacked the plant in Sumter, Colleton, and Beaufort Counties, and the farmers are much disheartened. The appearance of the worm is attributed to the succulence of the plant and the forwardness of the season.

MONTREAL, July 28.--An interesting little episode, showing how an influential portion of the community regards Governor-General Lansdowne has come to light to-day.
WASHINGTON, July 28, 1885. The President has declined to modify his proc lamation requiring cattlemen to remove from the Indian Territory within 40 days.

CHICAGO, July 28.--the indications tonight are that a strike will ne inaugurated tomorrow among the yard and shop employes in this city of the Wabash Railroad Company, and that, as a result, traffic over the road will be partiality or entirely suspended. For a month past the employes have not been in good humor.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 28.--John Teemer, the carsman, having failed to get a race with Hanlan, has decided to go to Australia to row Beach for the championship of the world. He will be ready to start in about eight weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 28.--The announcement was made yesterday that John A. Benson, a civil enginesr and contractor, made an assignment on Saturday to W.S. Wood. His liabilities are $450,000 and his assets are said to be equal to his indebtedness. They consist of real estate in different parts of California.

LONDON, July 28.--The House of Lords today refused to consider the bill providing for woman suffrage. The Marquis of Salisbury said it was impossible to deal with the subject at the fag end of the Parliamentary session.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., July 28.--The long strike at the Pennsylvania Colliery, whereby 709, men have been idle during almost the entire year, was virtually ended to-day when 100 employes resumed work at a 10 per cent. reduction of December wages.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--The following decision was handed down by the court today, in the case of H.B. Claflin Co., of NewYork, against Donald Gordon, of Rochester. WASHINGTON, July 28.--To-day's Presidential appointments provoked no unfavorable comments in Washington. The selection of Mr. eickhoff is commended as in every respect a good one.

CHICAGO, July 28.--Little Lillie Schaffer, who was abducted nearly a month ago, has not yet been found, and the child's mother is quite ill through grief at her home on Wesson-street. A prominent dry goods firm offers a reward of $500, payable at their main store, for the recovery of the lost child. The idea is that this offer will stimulate activity and cause the search to be renewed with greater vigor than ever.
CLEVELAND, July 28.--The quietude which had settled in the Eighteenth Ward was suddenly broken this morning by an attack upon two inoffensive laborers.

AUGUSTA, Ga., July 28.--Mr. H.G. Rawerth, engineer on the South Carolina Railway, has sent in his resignation, to take effect on Aug. 1. Mr. Rawerth is the oldest railroad engineer in the United States.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The Directors of the Board of Trade to-day again took up the cases of Abram Poole, Isaac Gifford, Frank Bliss, and L.B. Mitchell, suspended for 30 days for trading after hours. After considerable discussion the period of suspension was reduced from 30 days to two weeks. The vote was not unanimous, several Directors expressing the opinion that the week's suspension which the offenders had already suffered was sufficient punishment.

TROY, N.Y., July 28.--A meeting of the voters of the First Ward of West Troy to act on a proposition to made the district a union free school district, the purpose being to bring the Roman Catholic parochial schools within the school district and under the school law, and so secure a share of the public school moneys, was held to-day, and was attended by exciting scenes.
Mr. Charles Halle has resigned the conductorship of the London Sacred Harmonic Society.
Gov. Marmaduke, of Missouri, has written a comical letter in reply to a petition for the remission of a fine imposed upon a resident of that State for selling liquor without a license.

During the recent smallpox scare in Long Island City the health board of that city were at first seriously upbraided for alleged nondischarge of their duty in preventing the people from an epidemic. Recent developments show that in one case at least they were overzealous.

Wise, the Republican candidate for Governor. Very different too, judging from appearances at this time, will be the result of the convention.

At a special meeting of the Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday, M. Burr, Jr., was suspended for two weeks, and B.F. Munroe was suspended for one week, for indecorous language and disorderly conduct on the floor of the Exchange.
An officer of the Morrisania police found an Italian who had apparently been engaged in a desperate affray at the William's Bridge railroad station early yesterday morning.
W.S. Bissel, of Buffalo, is at the Hoffman House.

MOBILE, Ala., July 28.--The duel between W.B. Walker and Samuel J. Dalton, of Aberdeen, Miss., was prevented by the arrest of the parties at Starkville last night. They were on their way to Memphis to arrange for a fight.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28.--A most disastrous fire broke out here at 8 o'clock to-night.

BALTIMORE, July 28.--The appointment by President Cleveland to-day of Morris Thomas, of Baltimore, as Indian Inspector will, when generally known, create nearly as much feeling among the better class of Democrats as did the appointment of Eugene Higgins.

TROY, N.Y., July 28.--The Troy Fuel Gas Company was incorporated to-day, with a capital of stock of $300,000. The incorporators are Prof. L.C. Lowe and ex-Attorney-General Wayne MacVeagh, of Pennsylvania; Charles MacVeagh, of New-York, and Gilbert Geer. Jr., and Charles McCarthy, of Troy. The business offices of the company will be located in this city, where the system will be introduced. Ex-Attorney-General Wayne MacVeagh will probably be President of the company.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Julv 28.--The Mexican journalists' excursion party is here to-day, guests of the Chamber of Commerce. The members were introduced on 'Change and were afterterward driven to points of interest in and about the city. They go hence to St. Louis.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The iron propeller Cuba, which was formerly owned by the Commercial Line, discharged her cargo of coal at South Chicago yesterday, and being unable to get a down cargo the agents decided to lay her up here. Capt. Young had a good deal of difficulty in finding dock room for her, but finally got permission from Kelly, Rathbun...
DUBLIN, July 28.--The Bank of Ireland has refused to lend money to the Munster Bank to assist the latter in its embarrassment, and a panic now prevails in Cork and Dublin.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28.--The Coroner held an inquest to-day in the case of Mary McLaughlin, the 15-year-old girl who was thrown into the river at Ridgeway Park, a rather disreputable resort, on Monday night of last week, but the mystery surrounding her murder is as deep as ever.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 28.--Chauncey S. Colton, the original projector of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad, and for twenty years a member of the Board of Directors, died yesterday at his home in Galesburg, aged 85 years.
EDGERTON, Wis., July 28.--Wednesday last Miss Florence M. Coon, aged 20 years, died suddenly while visiting at Oconto.

Some time ago Mrs, Smith--let us call her--left her husband in a way that was somewhat annoying to him. In point of fact she went away with Mr. Brown and remained away up to a very recent period. During this time she met with an accident causing the loss of one of her legs.

William Affentranger, a Swiss, who was 27 years old, hanged himself yesterday at No. 418 West Twenty-fifth-street. He was the son of Frederick Affentranger, a silk spinner, of Henwiel, Canton of Zurich, Switzerland, and came to America in 1883.

Mayor GRACE yeaterday expressed, with emphasis, his hope that the remains of Gen. GRANT might be brought from the political to the commercial capital of the State by the natural highway of the Hudson rather than by rail. Indeed, the advantages of the river as a route for the funeral procession are so many and so great that it seems as if the suggestion had only to be made in order to be adopted.

CHICAGO, July 28.--John Dean Caton, ex-Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of this State, and his wife to-day celebrated their golden wedding at their residence in calumetavenue, Judge Caton was born in Orange County, N.Y., in 1802. He came to Illinois in 1833, and two years later was married to Laura Sherrill, of New-Hartford, Oneida County, N.Y. Six weeks after his return to Illinois Chicago was incorporated as a city.

MOUNT McGREGOR, July 28.--Riverside Park. or Grant Park, as it will probably be rechristened, will be the burial place of Gen. Grant. It was so decided this morning when Col. Grant returned from New-York. He reported to Mrs. Grant what he had done, and submitted to her maps of the several spots that were then visited.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28.--Strawbridge Taylor, counsel for Edward Cooper and Abram S. Hewitt, of New-York, have brought a suit in the United States Circuit Court claiming $100,000 damages from the Pennsylvania Steel Company for the alleged infringement of letters patent of the United States granted to Emile Martin and Pierre E. Martin, of Paris, France, for an improved process for refining and converting cast iron into cast steel.
AUBURN, N.Y., July 28.--The State Lodge Knights of Pythias assembled in this city to-day. Three hundred members were present, including 53 Past Chancellors of Grand Lodge rank.

The West Shore Railroad, its absorption by the New-York Central, and the merits of the terms offered to the West Shore bondholders formed the chief topics of conversation in Wallstreet Yesterday. The general sentiment, as summed up in THE TIMES of yesterday, was that the terms, while not satisfactory to the bondholders, were the best they could get under the circumstances.

A very interesting collection of Grant medals, the property of Robert Hewitt, of the American Numismatic and Archaeological Society, will be on exhibition to-day in the windows of Unz Co., No. 1 Bowling Green. This collection comprises 45 medals, in white metal, brass, and bronze, each illustrating some incident in the military or political life of Gen. Grant.

CLEVELAND, July 28.--Tere was a good attendance, fine weather, and a splendid track for the opening day of the Summer meeting of the Cleveland Driving Park Association. The 2.21 trot was not finished on account of darkness. Following are the summaries of to-day's events:

WASHINGTON, July 28.--Sergt, Michael McGanrau, of the Signal Corps, who recently refused to receive the Colored private, Green, as his assistant at Pansacola, Fla., is in ordinary arrest at Fort Myer. Gen. Hazen to-day submitted to the War Department charges against McGanrau for disobedience of orders, and asked for a court-martial. The accused is regarded as an efficient officer. He remained at his post during the yellow fever epidemic at Pensacola a few years ago.
The Yonkers Aldermen, who began on Monday evening to try charges of malfeasance in office against Police Commissioners Cobb and Dusenberry, finished their labors at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.

William Dowd, President of the Bank of North America, and Manager Camp, representing the Clearing House Committee, were at the Sub-treasury yesterday and received from the different banks deposits of gold in exchange for subsidiary silver coin.

Stuart, the Rev. E.V. McElhone, Philip Ronzone, the Rev. Ferdinand Merlini, Thomas Kirkpatrick, David Ide Tough, Thomas Burkhard, Mrs. John Craig, Alexander Elkam, Mrs. Harry Pitt, the Rev. T.R.G. Peck, and the Rev. W.D. Thompson.
The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday opened bids for the construction of Section No. 1 of the new aqueduct.

CHICAGO, July 29.--Eleven cases of sunstroke, one of which is likely to prove fatal, were reported to the police as the result of yesterday's hot wave. A thunderstorm early this morning cooled the atmosphere somewhat, but the sun is shining again, and with very little air stirring.

LONDON, July 30.--A split in the Tory Camp which threatens to become serious was made public last evening, when Lord Randolph Churchill declined at the last moment to attend a great Tory meeting at Liverpool at which he had been advertised as one of the chief speakers.

A driver employed in Barnes's brewery, Union Hill, N.J., while driving through Guttenberg yesterday morning saw the body of a manlying by the roadside. It proved to be that of John Jenne, a night watchman employed at Peters's ice houses.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 29.--Reports from towns in Southern Wisconsin show that last night's windstorm passed entirely across the State, doing damage of minor importance in nearly all the southern tier of counties.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 29.--At Winsted, Conn., a balloon ascension was made this afternoon by Prof. Brooks and Frederick Moore, a wealthy manufacturer of the town. The balloon was the largest ever used in the State.

RICHMONG, Va., July 29.--Fitzhugh Lee has been nominated by acclamation to be the candidate of the Democratic Party for Governor of Virginia. WILMINGTON, Del., July 29.--A new brick building, just under roof, in course of construction by the Diamond State Iron Company, on the south side, fell to the ground early this afternoon, burying a number of workmen in its debris.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 29.--President Cleveland has sent a subscription of $250 to the fund for rebuilding Music Hall, which was destroyed by fire in March last.

CINCINNATI, July 29.--F.L. Johnson, son of Edgar M. Johnson, Gov. Hoadly's law partner, yesterday eloped with Miss. Mary Cunningham, the daughter of a former neighbor on Walnut Hills. The groom is a Jow, the bride a Methodist.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 29.--About 9 o'clock this morning a bolt of lightning struck the house of E. Salisbury, near Fairfield, and killed Mrs. Salisbury and two young children. One end of the house was torn out and completely wrecked.

A covered wagon, containing bundles of freshly printed newspapers and followed by a clamorous horde of small boys, was making its way rapidly up Centre-street about 5 o'clock last evening, when it came into violent collision with a Fourth-avenue car. Nobody seemed to know who was to blame for the collision.

SAVANNAH, Ga., July 29.--Thomas Brantley, a white man, of Decatur County, was taken from Bainbridge Jail last night and lynched. His offense, which so infuriated the quiet farmers of the southwest part of this State, was barbarous cruelty to his wife.
Work has been begun upon the platform which is to connect the New-York end of the Brooklyn Bridge with the City Hall station of the Third-avenue elevated railroad.
A meeting of the steamship mail lines was held yesterday, at which the Pacific Mail Company, F. Alexandre Son, and James E. Ward Co. were represented.
The Health Home of the New-York Children's Aid Society is filled to its utmost capacity every week with sick infants and children under 4 years of age who are accompanied by their mothers.

Register Reilly, in his attempt to prevent the Title Guarantee and Trust Company from copying the public records in his office, yesterday arrested one of the clerks of the company on a charge of interfering with the records of the office without the permission of the custodian. In the afternoon the clerk was taken to the Tombs Police Court, before Justice Solon B. Smith.

CHICAGO, July 29.--George K. Osberne, the counterfeiter, sentenced to two years in the penitentiary, a fortnight ago, has been allowed to remain in Jail since then pending certain legal steps which were being taken and personal appeals which have been made in his behalf.

Herman Blumenthal, wholesale and retail dealer in tobacco at No. 262 East Houstonstreet, mape an assignment yesterday to Henry M. Goldfogle, giving preferences for $4,015. He began business in November, 1884, and claimed about $5,000 capital.
We learn from trustworthy sources that Messrs. Charles Scribner's Sons are already making preparations for the establishment of a new magazine of the first class, to be called Seribher's Monthly.

PHELPS, N.Y., July 29.--James M. Sanlerson has for two years made his home at the residence of his daughter and son-in-law in the town of Gorham, in Ontario County. He was born in Georgetown, Ohio, and lived there until he was is years old, and has an unusually clear recollection of the early life of Gen. Grant in that place.

MOUNT MCGREGOR, July 29.--The electric lamp under the flag-draped canopy in the cottage parlor sent during the early part of this evening a glow of soft light upon the bony of Gen. Grant in his coffin. It lies as if in peaceful sleep.

Mr. Henry E. Dixey, who is equally amiable and agile, has been rendered somewhat gloomy all Summer over the constant reports of his physical condition, which has been generally represented as on the verge of no condition at all. Some people are born ill, some achieve illness, and others have illness thrust upon them. Mr. Dixey is deeply pained at finding himself in the position last named.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--It was rumored to-day that Mr. Titcomb. Assistant Register of the Treasury, who is now absent from the city on leave, will never return to the discharge of his duties, owing to an intimation that his place is desired for another.

Chief of Police Donovan, of Hoboken, caused the arrest at that place last night of the drivers of swill wagons on their arrival from this City. Twenty-five prisoners were taken. They were carting the refuse to piggeries at Secaucus. The police authorities of Hoboken have decided to rid themselves of this nuisance, and the drivers will have to find some other route home.

MONTREAL, July 29.--Mr. W.P. Mitchell, of the Lincrusta Walton Manufacturing Company, No. 265 Broadway, New-York, was arrested at the St. Lawrence Hall and taken before the police magistrate this morning as a loose, idle, and disorderly person, charged with obstructing the sidewalk.

DETROIT, Mich., July 29.--Frank Simmons, of Boston, a wealthy wool merchant, who for years past has been a regular visitor at Adrian, in this State, at which place he has a business office and an agent who looks after his wool purchase, is the object of no little anxiety just now. Mr. Simmons closed up his business at Adrian on July 8 and came to Detroit with between $6,000 and $7,000 in drafts.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 29.--The Hom John W. Vrooman, Secretary of the Republican State Committee, said to-day that nothing definite had been done about a meeting of the committee to decide on the time and place of the State Convention, but he thought it probable that a meeting would be called for Aug. 13 or Aug. 15 at New-York or Saratoga.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 29.--For 14 innings the Grays and Chicagos struggled this afternoon before the game was decided. Clarkson pitched in fine style, and his support was admirable, and the Providence men again showed that they were unable to gauge his delivery successfully.

The monument erected to the memory of Rebecca Nourse, hanged in Salem July 19, 1692, for witchcraft, will be dedicated on Thursday at the old homestead at Danvers, when the third annual gathering of her descendants will take place.

Railroad wars, THE TIMES has always contended, do more harm than good. When they are protracted and become fierce, business considerations are laid aside and the managers of the warring lines yield to the ordinary human passions of resentment and a blind desire to force their adversaries to yield. The evils resulting from such contests more than offset the temporary advantage which the patrons of the railroads derive from the cutting of rates.
CANAJOHARIE, N.Y.,. July 29.--Astonishment prevails throughout Montgomery County over the financial embarrassment of George Clark, known as the most extensive landowner in Central New-York.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29.--Samuel F. Barger, of New-York, is ill at his cottage on Bellevue-avenue. Among the late arrivals are Prof. Cabelle, of the Norwood Institute at Washington; Mme. G. Cayron Du Cayla, G.L. Rives and wife, and Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Clews of New-York.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 29.--Intelligence received this evening from Indian Territory indicates that the Cherokees are moving to have the leases made by Chief Bushy Head and other Cherokee officials to cattle syndicates abrogated. Over 6,000,000 acres of land are covered by these leases.
TORONTO, July 29.--Three respectable young men went into J.C. Gibson's hotel to play pool on Monday night. After playing several games they left the place without paying for the use of the table.

MONTREAL, July 29.--An action for $200,000 has been entered in the Supreme Court here by Mr. Barry against the Canadian Pacific Railway Company. Mr. Barry is a contractor, and he lately completed a large contract on the line north of Lake Superior.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 1.--Alexander T. Prendergast, son of the founder of Jamestown and father of the late Hon. James Prendergast, fell dead of heart disease at his home here to-day aged 76 years. He leaves a very large estate to his widow. They had just completed a thirty-thousand-dollar monument to their son, and tha bulk of the estate is expected to be devoted to establishing a memorial library for the same son.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--The total subscriptions to the Egyptian loan amounted to $1,000,000,000. The amount of the loan was but $45,000,000. The scrip of this loan is now quoted at 3 1/3 per cent. premium.

SARATOGA, Aug. 2.--The resignation of Daniel Manning, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, is in the hands of Secretary John O'Brien, of Dutcheas. Mr. O'Brien will issue the call that will bring the State Committee together for the purpose of arranging for the State Convention. It is surmised that the committee will meet about the 19th of August and that Saratoga will be the place of meeting.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 3.--Everything is in readiness for holding here this week the national convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union. It is to be a notable assemblage.

The naval display promises to be a prominent feature of the funeral ceremonies of Gen. Grant. Rear Admiral Jouett evinces much interest in all that pertains to the funeral, and is anxious to make as fine a display as possible out of the material at hand.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 3.--At noon today, while under the influence of liquor, Henry Vanderfeight, a baker, leaped from the suspension bridge across the Cumberland River to the water below, a distance of 110 feet. He turned several times in the air, and struck the water with terrific force. He will probably recover.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 3.--Captain Stacy Jarvis, of the schooner Sarah Cullen, was accidentally killed this morning on board his vessel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3.--A delegation representing the cattlemen holding leases in the Cheyenne and Arapahoe country called upon the Secretary of the Interior this afternoon and were accorded an interview.
CONYERS, Ga., Aug. 3.--Edward Cash, held for forgery, escaped from jail here this morning, leaving a note stating he was bound for Arkansas.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 3.--E.D. Bassett, who, as a live politician, was appointed Minister to Hayti, enters into the discussion of Gen. Grant's Christian name.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 4.--The nautical schoolship St. Mary's arrived this afternoon, 35 days from Teneriffe, with all well on board. She will remain here four days, then go to Glen Cove and give the boys 10 days' furlough, and then return to New-London.

The 2,000 persons who attended the NewYork-Buffalo game yesterday witnessed a well played contest, and, to add to the enjoyment for the spectators, the local players won. The scores were too uneven to make the game exciting, but good work both in the field and at the bat was shown on both sides, and this in a measure appeased the onlookers who desire to see a close match every day.

BOSTON, Aug. 4.--The gross earnings of the Little Rock and Fort Smith Railroad for June, 1885, were $31,956, against $92,928 in June, 1884. The earnings for the first six months of 1885 were $245,284, against $236,945 in the corresponding period of last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4.--Major G.L. Gillespie, engineer in charge of improvements of certain rivers and harbors in New-York and NewJersey, has submitted his annual report to Gen. Newton, Chief of Engineers. Among other improvements under Major Gillespie's charge was that of Gedney's Channel, New-York.

Colby, of the Class of '72, was unanimously elected Professor. Mr. Colby is at present connected with the Law School of Yale College.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4.--The President of the United States has awarded a gold medal to Aisne Anstpato, an Indian chief of British Columbia, who rendered valuable services in recovering the bodies of the crew of the wrecked American ship Melville in October, 1882.

Our correspondent who is traveling over this State to pick up such political indications as are observable at this time finds that in the northern and western counties there is already considerable activity among the local leaders, especially those of the Republican Party.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 4.--Gov. Pattison and a committee of 11 members of the House and Senate inspected the Marine Hospital Building to-day to determine whether the State will accept it and convert it into a home for indigent veterans. LAKE MILLS, Wis., Aug. 5.--The village of Milford, Wis., was almost destroyed by fire Monday night. This is the fourth fire within a short time at Milford, and is thought to be the work of an incendiary. All that is left of the place is a cheese factory and a saloon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--There was an active demand for vessel room here to-day. Lake freights were on a basis of 1 to 1 7/8 cents on corn and 2 cents on wheat to Buffalo. Allen, President of the City Council, will meet the party in New-York, and will be the Chairman of the delegation, J.C. Ewald having already been chosen Secretary.

MONTREAL, Aug. 5.--A terrible accident happened on Monday at the Piles Mills, Three Rivers. While trying to clear rubbish away from a large circular saw with a stick, Robert Stanley missed his hold and falling against the revolving saw was cut almost in two. A slice was taken off the heart, so that death was instantaneous. The body was brought to the city by the evening train and will be buried to-morrow.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 5.--Two 8-year-old lads, named Carl Whittier and Howard Stillwell, left their homes here yesterday morning. As they did not return at night their parents searched the surrounding country for them throughout the night. This morning their bodies were found in the Delaware and Raritan Canal. Five persons have been drowned in the same canal within a month.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 6.--Carpie Barehead, a young Creek outlaw, was executed at Eufaula, Indian Territory, on Tuesday last, in Indian fashion, being shot to death while seated on his coffin, by the Creek Light Horse Guards. KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 6.--William Kearney, an insane man, who lives near Humboldt, Neb., and owns a fine farm there, was arrested here to-day. Kearney said he was on his way to Washington to kill President Cleveland, against whom he had a fancied grievance. He had a revolver and about 75 cartridges in a hand bag, and was well supplied with money.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 6.--A sea Captain named Henry Baker was arrested at Crow Harbor to-day on the charge of scuttling the schooner Smiling Water several months ago while bound from Halifax to Cape Breton. The vessel was lost off the coast. The crow rowed ashore and reported having had a very narrow escape. The vessel was owned by Henry Cook, of this city and was insured for $1,200.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--The committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Coast and Geodetic Survey and to inquire into alleged irregularities and official misconduct on the part of the Superintendent, Prof. Hilgard, made their report to the Secretary of the Treasury today. The committee began their investigation July 23, and continued it daily until closed. They took possession of the books, accounts, and records of the survey, and examined a large number of witnesses.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6.--All arrangements are complete for Saturday's memorial services. The funeral car, which is to go at the head of the procession, has an open platform about 30 feet long and 12 feet wide. On this the catafalque rests, rising, with the coffin, to a height of 9 feet.

PANAMA, July 28.--The sanitary condition of the isthmus has not improved. The condition of Colon is something terrible, and a perfect plague seems to have stricken tho place. There are sometimes as many as 25 deaths a day. In a population of less than 10,000 that death rate is something startling.

PARIS, Aug. 6.--The committee in charge of the Grant memorial services, to be held here in the American Chapel next Saturday, have requested Dr. Booth, of New-York, to assist in the ceremonies. LIMA, Aug. 6, via Galveston.--The Bishop of Lopaz, in a letter to the President, declared that the progress of Freemasonry was an evidence of shameless neglect of duty on the part of the Government, and he called upon the President to suppress the order. In reply the President said that freedom of thought should be supported.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 7.--Robert Dickey, a milkman, was driving over the railroad crossing at Rye when, looking up, he saw an express train almost upon him. He tried to back the horse, but it was too late. The locomotive struck the horse, killing him instantly. Mr. Dickey was thrown into a cattle guard and the wagon smashed. Medical aid was summoned, and it was sound that Mr. Dickey well severely injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 7.--The Hon. Hamilton Fish, of New-York, being prevented by ill-health from serving as a pall bearer at Gen. Grant's funeral, the President has appointed Anthony J. Drexel, of this city, to serve in his stead.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--The closing concert of the Thomas season this evening drew out the largest audience of the year. All the seats were occupied, and many persons stood. The members of the orchestra will also enjoy a well-earned vacation.

ELLISVILLE, Miss., Aug. 10.--During a thunderstorm this afternoon lightning struck N.B. Shelby's store, shattering the front of the building and instantly killing Harry Sumeratall, son of W.W. Sumeratall, and badly shocking George Watson.
ERIE, Kan., Aug. 10.--Mrs. Frankie Morris, who was yesterday found guilty of the murder of her mother, was married last evening to Henry D. Copeland, of Wichite.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 10.--Two colored farm hands named Graham and Snyder, working for George Swailes, a farmer, in the littletown of Sodus, engaged in an altercation yesterday afternoon. Graham recently came from Canada.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 10.--The new high license law of Wisconsin increasing the minimum rate of saloom license from $75 to $200 has now been in force three months, and returns from 100 towns in the State show that the aggregate number of saloons has been diminished by 267; that the aggregate amount of annual revenue is $224,000 greater that last year, and that the saloons generally are under better regulation.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10.--When Mayor Smith ordered Megonegal Lovell to close their pool room on Sansom-street the gamblers felt considerably annoyed, but they were not discomfited.
MONTREAL, Aug. 11.--A woman named Taylor was found dead in a house in Pea-lane this evening. Her husband cannot be found and foul play is suspected.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 10.--The tomb of Lieut. Lockwood, tha Arctic explorer, has been erected at the Naval Cemetery, Annapolis, Md. The base is a marble slab covering the entire grave.

LONDON, Ontario, Aug. 10.--The American clerical bycicle tourists left this afternoon for Exeter, where the night will be passed. Tomorrow they are due in Goderich, and will be tendered a reception in the Presbyterian church.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 10.--A large number of people attended the reception of Mr. Ira Hale last Saturday, his eighty-sixty birthday. Many elegant presents were received by Mr. Hale. Mr. Hale is a great favorite among the young folks here.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 10.--For the past few years a gang of thieves have terrorized Calhoun County by their depredations. All efforts to discover the robbers were unavailing until within a few days, when the robbery of a barn in Climax was traced to Andrew Clark. He was arrested and search made in the houses of his brother and father. A large amount of stolen goods was recovered and identified.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 10.--The towboat Albert S. Willis sank this morning in the Ohio River about one mile below Stevensport. She struck on a sunken rock, and could not be saved. The Willis was owned by Capt. Pink Varble, of this city.

READING, Penn., Aug. 10.--Charles Neudinger, aged 12 years, while in the act of adjusting a tooth in a carding machine at the Reading Cotton Factory this afternoon, was caught by the machine, which was started accidentally by his assistant moving the lever. PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--A dispatch to the Times says a burglar last night entered the residence of J.L. Wertz, at Duncanville, Penn., and, going to the room occupied by George Clough, stole his watch. Clough awoke and was about to grapple with the thief, when the latter shot him through the abdomen, inflicting injuries which will probably prove fatal. The burglar escaped.

"This is more of the Metropolitan luck," said the veteran Jack Nelson, after the champions of the American Association had been defeated by the Brooklyn nine yesterday.

Young ARMSTRONG has dispelled by his confession what promised to be an interesting mystery. If he had held his peace it would have been very difficult to fasten upon him the crime of which he was accused.

VIENNA, Aug. 12.--The minutes of the orders issued to the officials of the Northern Railway concerning their conduct during the imperial journey to Kremsier to meet the Czar of Russia have been issued.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12.--The reports which have been received from Manitoba of the satisfactory condition of the crops in that province are corroborated by a special telegram received to-day from Mr. Egan, Western Superintendent of the Canadian Pacific Road, to Mr. Van Horne, General Manager.
The New-Yorks will play in Providence this afternoon.
Application was made before Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, for an order allowing Edward A. Wellenkamp to visit his two children twice a week.

William Ellioot, a boss stonecutter, of No. 514 West Fifty-second-street, drew $500 out of the bank yesterday afternoon to pay off his men, and took a walk along the transverse road through Central Park, near Eighty-fifth-street.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 12.--A meeting of the shareholders of the Northwest Central Railway Company was held here this afternoon, when the shareholders authorized the Directors to issue bonds for $3,000,000 and execute a mortgage securing the same on Government lands and railway.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12.--Joseph Fiset, the youth from Greenefield, Mass., whose alleged faith cure was recently reported, left for home to-day. "I am cured," he said to a friend, "beyond any doubt. Every day I feel stronger and walk with greater ease. The doctors may say there was nothing to prevent me walking before, but I know better. Often and often have I attempted to move without my crutches, but of no avail."

DETROIT, Aug. 12.--From the description of the "gentlemanly burglar" furnished by Judge Brown, of the United States Court, and others who received calls from him during the past few months, the police decided that " Billy" Burns was the man who accomplished these bold and clever jobs.

BLAKELEY, Ga., Aug. 12.--John McLain, one of the most prominent citizens in Damascus, while in one of the stores of that place, which was crowded at the time with customers, drew his revolver from his pocket and emptied four chambers into his own body before he fell dead.
Robert W. Daintree, an Englishman 35 years of age, obtained employment in the surgical instrument factory of A.L. Hernstein, at College-avenue and One Hundred and Thirtyninth-street, some time ago.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12.--A report comes by wap of Three Rivers that a rich gold mine has been discovered in Megantic, and that the fortunate owner of the land upon which it is is about to sell it for a large sum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--The Hon. George B. Loring, ex-Commissioner of Agriculture, has written a letter in reply to Judge Durham's communication, announcing a disallowance of a portion of Mr. Loring's accounts as Commissioner.

An extraordinary attempt made by a French doctor to poison a rival practitioner was brought before the Assize Court of Vaucluse yesterday. The accused, Dr. Estachy, is a practitioner at Pertuis, 40 years of acre, and a member of the Legion of Honor.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12.--The Department of Marine has forwarded to the British Government for presentation a gold watch, awarded to Capt. A.L. Atkinson, master of the steamer Dentrand, of Hartlepool, England in recognition of his humane services in saving the crew of the wrecked bark Ermine, of Maitland.
There were over 100 cases on the calendar of police trials yesterday, the large number being chiefly due to the fact that all the cases noticed for last Wednesday had been adjourned until yesterday.
CAIRO, Aug. 12.--A fearful state of anarchy prevails in Kordofan. There is a famine also existing.
READING, Penn., Aug. 12.--James Edgar, a Scotchman employed on the new Reading and Pottsville Railroad, was killed near Mohrsville last night.

There is a promise of a bitter lawsuit prior to the payment of the contested policies on the life of Mrs. M.H. Bauer, whose body was exhumed at the Lutheran Cemetery on Tuesday for the purpose of making an autopsy.

In Morrisania there is an organization known as the Schnorer Club, whose members are all convivial and nearly all fat, and the club is said to be able to hold more beer than any other society of its size in the United States or Canadas.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12--In connection with the Finch elopement it is learned that Mrs. Finch left yesterday for New-York without saying anything of her purpose to her husband. He has since heard from her, however, and says she will probably return to him.
The seventh champion marksman's class match was shot at Creedmoor yesterday. The weather was trying for the competitors, but some very good scores were made.
A monster tarpon, more popularly known as the king herring, was caught by come fishermen off the coast of Seabright, N.J., on Tuesday, and yesterday the great fish was exhibited in Fulton Market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--Judge Maynard, Second Controller of the Treasury, has disallowed the claim of persons in Tennessee for furniture and other personal property taken by United States troops for hospital purposes during the campaign in East Tennessee in 1863.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--Gov. Hill arrived in Elmira to-day, to remain until Sunday. He held an informal reception all the afternoon and evening at his office. Friends of both parties called on him in large numbers.

The Coney Island Rod and Gun Cub's shoot yesterday was for a silver cup and money prizes. The attendance was not very large. The conditions of the shoot were that, should a man use his second barrel and kill, it should only count as half a bird.

HAVANA, Aug. 8.--Seflor Jose Maria de la Paz Vasquez, who was recently appointed Chilian Consul in this city, arrived here on the steamer Villaverde.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 12.--At the Pennsylvania Greenback Convention to-day Dr. W.C. Whitney, of Warren County, was nominated as the candidate for State Treasurer. Theodore Rynder was re-elected Chairman of the State Committee.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--A crazy tramp sneaked into the basement of John Kempfer's residence, in West Monroe-street, last night and went to sleep.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--The trunk line forces have begun to use arguments with Mr. Garrett against taking the Baltimore and Ohio to New-York City.

The early closing movement in Jersey City shows signs of collapse. It has had the determined opposition of many of the business men of the city and the secret opposition of some who pretended to favor it.

Suit has been commenced by the Campaign Banner and Outfit Company, of NewYork, against Congressman William McAdoo, of Jersey City, to recover $144.75, alleged to be due the company for uniforms furnished the McAdoo Engineer Corps last Fall.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 12.--Frank Bacon, a colored boy 9 years old, was run over and instantly killed by a train on the Ocean View Railroad this afternoon. He was asleep at the time.

READING, Penn., Aug. 12.--Daniel Noll, the man who a few months ago set fire to an outbuilding on the truck farm of Augustus L. Wentzel, which resulted in the loss of life of four men who were sleeping therein, was to-day tried for arson. Noll is 40 years of age.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12.--Ira Russell, a resident of this place, started for his home Monday evening on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad. Near the station he sat down to rest on the platform and fell asleep. The 1 o'clock express came along and struck him, cutting off both legs and smashing his head. He was 27 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--Three officers in the Signal Service--First Lieut. A.W. Greely, Fifth Cavalry; First Lieut. Robert Craig, Fourth Artillery, and First Lieut. H.H.C. Dunwoody--are included in the provisions of the recent order directing line officers who have been on detached duty for four years back to their regiments.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 12.--It is felt in many places in the South that the monument to Gen. Grant should assume the dual character of a monument to Gen. Grant and Gen. Lee. Dr. J.B. Hinckley, of Georgia, one of the best known surgeons of the Army of Northern Virginia, subscribes $500 for this purpose, and calls upon the proper authorities in New-York to give the matter this shape so that Confederates may join in.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--Archbishop Feehan to-day appointed the Rev. B.P. Murray, late assistant at Bridgeport, Chancellor of the Diocese of Chicago, to succeed the Rev. Patrick D. Gill. Father Murray is less than 30 years of age, and was ordained a priest about three years ago.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12.--The office of the Hartford Equitable Indemnity Insurance Company was closed to-day by attachment on a claim of Federick M. Lincoln, Secretary, for salary. The company has a capital of $150,000, with only 10 per cent. called in. It has never done business, which is that of accident insurance, outside of the State, and stopped all its business last August.

OGDENSBURG, Aug. 12.--The little town of Norwood, St. Lawrence County, 30 miles east of this city on the line of the Ogdensburg and Lake Champlain Railroad, was visited by a terrific cyclone at 4:48 this afternoon.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 12.--The storm of Friday night extended over more territory than was at first supposed and reports are just coming in showing that the damage was widespread.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 12.--About 60 members of the Canadian Associated Press are spending the day here. Sir John A. Macdonald is also here. It is thought that the proposed free park on the Canadian side will hereafter receive the vigorous support of the Canadian press.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--Since the morning of July 31 last two prominent members of the "Prairie Rangers," a juvenile society organized for the purpose of hunting buffaloes and grizzly bears and killing Indians, have been missing.

PORT COLBORNE, Ontario, Aug. 12--Natural gas was struck here yesterday at a depth of 420 feet with sufficient force to light up the town. The well was piped and the gas turned on the public streets last night.

Charles H. Waring and a man named Martinez passed the civil service examination for assistant weighers in the Custom House service last January. They went to work on probation. Mr. Waring's period of probation expired last Monday, and Mr. Martinez's term expired on Tuesday.
PROVIDENCE, R.I. Aug. 12.--The steamer Old Colony came into collision with the schooner Hattie C., of St. John, New-Brunswick, last night, off Watch Hill.

BOSTON, Aug. 12.--It is seldom that the conditions of wind, water, and weather combine so favorably for an aquatic contest as they did to-day for the first day's races in the thirteenth annual regatta of tine National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on the Charles River.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company has begun the active shipment of bituminous coat from the lands it recently purchased in the Snowshoe region of this State.

One of the excursion boats of the Stephens Condit's Line of Newark, attempted to pass the draw of the Newark Bay bridge during the height of the storm last night on her trip up from Elm Park, Staten Island. Just as she had entered the opening a squall of wind struck her, throwing her against the bridge and crushing in the guards.

It had rained heavily on Wednesday and the track was in a deplorable condition. The good things which the knowing ones had arranged in their minds were scattered to the winds.

A young man went into the bakery of Lena Rettig, at No. 254 West Thirty-secondstreet, two months ago and purchased a pie and some cakes to the amount of 15 cents. He tendered in payment a ten-dollar bill. Mrs. Rettig gave him 9 single dollars and 85 cents in change.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13.--At the meeting of the Harbor Board this afternoon Chairman Andrew said the tonnage for July, this year, was 125,959 tons, which has only been exceeded once, that being in July, 1883, when 133,440 tons were reached.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The races announced for to-day have been postponed until to-morrow, at which time to-day's programme will be run.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 13.--The convention to nominate a successor to Judge Holland, of the First Judicial Circuit of Maryland, which met hero to-day, is at a deadlock. One hundred and twenty-three ballots have been taken, on all of which the votes were evenly divided. The contestants are Judge Charles. F. Holland and George W. Purnell.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 13.--David Green, a wealthy farmer, of Rush, N.Y., charged with stabbing Richard K. Buggy in the abdomen with a butcher knife on Wednesday night, was to-day held in $20,000 bail to await the result of the injuries. Buggy is in a precarious condition.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13.--According to a telegram from San Francisco Maxwell, the alleged murderer of C. Arthur Preller, now says that in due time he will produce Preller alive and well, and show where he got the body found in the trunk. Maxwell asserts that the body in the trunk was bought by himself and Preller and left in the hotel for the purpose of procuring insurance money upon Preller's life.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 13.--At a meeting of hop growers this afternoon about 100 members were present. The Hon. H.J. Coggeshall was appointed to perfect an organization to be known as the "New-York State Hop Growers' Association."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13, 1885. The Postmaster-General lies appointed Will iam Duff Haynie, of Bloomington, Ill., Chief Clerk to First Assistant Postmaster-General Stevenson, in place of Jaines H. Marr, transferred to another posi tion. Mr. Haynie is a lawyer and an intimate friend of Mr. Stevenson.

It is apparent that the reports forwarded each day from Madrid concerning the number of new cases of cholera and the number of fatal cases are not accurate. The report for Wednesday showed 4,433 new cases and 1,648 deaths.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--Ellen Derry, alias Darien, Who is now in custody for the abduction of the baby, Laura Claxton, has confessed the crime, saying there was no use in withholding the truth any longer. She stated that she had kidnaped the child and afterward represented it to be her own in order to obtain support from her husband and to bring about a reconciliation with him.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 13.--To-day's developments in the matter of the Texas Railroad pool confirm the statement made yesterday that it has been consummated, and only lacks the official signatures of the several railroad executives to put it into effect.

The bark John Gibson, of Sydney, Cape Breton, that arrived at Quarantine last evening, after a voyage of 28 days from Cienfuegos, had a case of yellow fever on board during the voyage. The master, Capt. Nickerson, was stricken down with the disease and died on Aug. 1. He was buried at sea.

According to a cablegram from London, the English holders of the bonds of the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railroad resolved yesterday to begin foreclosure proceedings under the terms of the general and collateral mortgages.

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--The Philadelphias outplayed the Bostons to-day at every point. The visitors made 2 runs in the first inning on Manning's single, a double by Mulvey, a fumble by Hackett, and Sutton's wild throw.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--The schooner Amelia G. Ireland, previously reported sunk in the Delaware River, was bound for Richmond, Maine, with 470 tons of coal. She was in collision with the steamer British Princess about three miles below New-Castle.

READING, Penn., Aug. 13.--Ferdinand Goetz, a prominent citizen, entertained a number of his personal friends, members of the Harmonie Maennerchor, at his residence last evening, it being the birthday anniversary of his wife.

DETROIT, Aug. 13.--The heavy, soaking rains of this morning interfered somewhat with the players this afternoon, but on the whole the game was well played. In the first inning a base on balls, two hits, and two errors gave the visitors 4 unearned runs.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 13.--Rain prevented the completion of the races here to-day, but three heats being trotted in the 2:25 class race. Blue Bell won the first two in 2:27 and 2:26 and Colonel Wood the third in 2:35. The race will be finished to-morrow afternoon. The 2:45 class race was won by Tom K. in three straight heats in 2:37 , 2:36, and 2:40. Major A. was second and Cub third.

Remey, the Lieutenant's brother.

An ingenious French physician, Dr. Chabret, is said to have performed a surgical operation of a very astonishing character indeed. He removed the eye of a girl and replaced it with one taken from a live rabbit. The rabbit's eye is said to be an excellent substitute and quite as serviceable as its predecessor.

ZANZIBAR, Aug. 13.--The Sultan of Zanzibar was noticed yesterday by Admiral Paschen, commanding the German fleet here, that unless he complied within 24 hours with Germany's preliminary demands concerning the possessions claimed in Zanzibar by German subjects friendly relations would be dropped.
