PANAMA, Aug. 5.--The steamer Lima, just arrived from the coast, brings news of another eruption of the celebrated volcano of Cotopaxi.
SOUTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 13.--John B. Gough, who lectured last night, was taken suddenly ill after the lecture, and symptoms indicate prostration from the heart. His condition was improved to-day.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Aug. 13.--A sensation was caused here yesterday by the bold robbery of the San Jose Safe Deposit Bank of Savings. In the afternoon a man entered the bank and obtained a bill of exchange for $65 50. The Cashier and manager were in the bank at the time.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13.--Riel's counsel have carried out their threat in reference to publishing the letter of the Rev. Father Andre, of Batoche, as to the real causes of the rebellion. It contains some startling statements concerning the conduct of the troops in the Northwest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13.--George Turner, ex-United States District Judge of Virginia, and ex-Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of Nevada, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself through the head with a revolver at the Lick House. He left a letter stating that ill-health was the cause of his act. He leaves widow and two children. Of late he had been practising law in this city.

MISSOURI CITY, Mo., Aug. 13.--John Oate, a farmer, aged 70 years, who lived alone, was found murdered in his bed last evening. His hands and feet were bound and severe wounds were found on his head. By whom and with what motives the crime was committed are at present unknown.

Six miles east of West Point, in Harris County, live two remarkable old people. They are Benjamin Gamill and his wife, respectively 73 and 76 years of age. They are now living on the same place that they took possession of when their young hearts were first united and they together started out to fight the battle of life.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The National Veterans' Association has appointed a committee to arrange a reception in this city to Gen. George B. McClellan upon his return from Colorado. The committee met to-day and organized, and instructed its Secretary to ascertain when Gen. McClellan would be back here.

This next is to be a dry moon, says a prophet. Lots of people in Georgia will sympathize with a dry moon.--Macon (Ga.) Telegraph.

ALBANY, Aug. 13.--The Circuit races at Island Park were again hotly contested to-day. The unfinished 2:27 race was first called. ExAttorney-General Russell's mare, which won two of the seven heats trotted yesterday, captured the first heat to-day and thus the race, in fine style.

PARIS, Aug. 13.--Reports received to-day from Marseilles state that the cholera there has received a fresh impetus, owing to the extreme heat; that the number of new cases has steadily increasod, and that the disease is unusually fatal in consequence of the heat.

The Commission on Electrical Subways, appointed under the Daly law to see that the electric wires of this city are placed under ground, met again in the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday to receive communications from the telegraph, telephone, and other electric wire companies, submitting plans for burying their wires.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--President Cleveland has again been made a victim by perfidious politicians of the class referred to by him in his recently published letter to the man who recommended an unfit person for a Judgeship.

Several creditors in this city and in Brooklyn are interested in the flight, or rather the return, of Burton T. Beach, who quitted his law office in this city on July 22, leaving nothing behind him but a load of debt, and who has since been heard of as swindling people in Poughkeepsie.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--The counterfeiters "Johnny" Hughes and Samuel Dare, who were detected recently in operating a private mint in New-Jersey, were to-day held for trial. Hughes went back to jail in default of $5,000, and Dare was released on furnishing $2,000 security.

Coroner James Douglass yesterday resumed the investigation into the causes of the accident by which, on Aug. 4, three persons were killed and three injured seriously by a train of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, near Chatham, N.J. At the inquest yesterday, Mr. Willard W. Cutler appeared as Prosecutor of the Pleas, and Mr. Flavel McGee for the railroad company.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 13.--John E. Owens, the comedian, who has been ill at his country seat, Aigbruth Vale, in Baltimore County, is now represented to be better and quite cheerful, though complications of disease under which he suffers may, at any time, assume an unfavorable turn.

PANAMA, Aug. 5.--The editor of the Star and Herald received notification the other day to the effect that he should publish no more war news or matter relating to Government affairs unless the same were sent direct from the different Secretaries of Government in the public departments to which such matter related.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 13.--At a meeting of the Algonquin Gun Club at Warwick yesterday afternoon Dr. W.B. Bradner, while witnessing the shooting, was accidentally shot in the right eye by John O. Vail. It is feared that the injured man will lose the sight of the eye, and it is possible that the wound may result fatally.

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 13.--The damage done by yesterday's storm is much greater than at first estimated. A sharp flash of lightning was the signal for the storm. Heavy clouds gathered in the west. In half an hour the sky grew lighter, and it was thought that the storm had passed.

BATTLEFORD, Northwest Territory, Aug. 13.--S. Sallandyne reports that there are 200 Indians on the warpath between this place and Swift Current. H. Reed and Agent Rae are off to Poundmaker's reserve with a mounted police force to take notes of the actual state of affairs.

TORONTO, Aug. 13.--T. Christie Co., wholesale hats and furs have called a meeting of their creditors for Tuesday. Their liabilities are estimated at from $40,000 to $50,000. Depression in trade is the cause of the trouble.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--The Brooklyn Club won a game from the Athletic Club to-day by good fielding and the bunching of their hits in the third and fifth innings. The game was without noteworthy features excepting the batting and base running of Stovey.

Conway, Buffalo's new pitcher, is handling the ball very cleverly. Bastian, of the Philadelphia Club, is unable to play. He is suffering from a sore hand.

CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 13.--The new Memorial Hall was dedicated to-day with appropriate exercises in the amphitheatre and at the hall. Chancellor John H. Vincent announced at the outset that the work of teaching Sunday school teachers and workers was to be bettered and broadened at Chautauqua.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13.--A double tragedy occurred on Mad River, Humboldt County, Tuesday evening, near North Fork Mill. A woman named Amanda M. Towne, who was cooking at a logging camp, was murdered in her cabin, having her throat out from ear to ear.

The first practical step toward making Charles E. Loew one of themselves has been taken by the Tammany Hall men. Mr. Loew was formally elected a member of the Tammany General Committee in the Twenty-second Assembly District Wednesday evening, and yesterday he was made a member of the City General Committee and of the Committee on Organization.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 13.--During a quarrel between Perry Starkey and his three sons and Reuben and Jacob Wilson, brothers, in Lodi Township, this morning, Starkey was shot and killed. The two Wilsons are under arrest, it being alleged that both shot Starkey.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 13.--The New-York players failed to get a single hit to-day until the seventh inning, but made a rally in that and the eighth inning, finding Radbourn for a triple, a two-baser, and seven singles, which, with errors by Carroll, Denny, Irwin, Gilligan, and Radbourn, gave them 8 runs, 4 of which were earned.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 13.--This morning W.H. Davis, of the detective force, brought to this place and lodged in jail W.H. Jones and his son, of this county, charged with the murder on April 3 last, 12 miles west of this place. of J.H. Joyce and three other members of the family, then burning the house and the bodies.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 13.--In every breaker in the anthracite coal fields are employed boys ranging in years from 6 to 19. The temptation of parents to put their boys in the breaker to earn a couple of dollars a month is very great, especially if the family is so unfortunate as to lose a father or brother in the mines.

LONDON, Aug. 13.--Reports are continually being received here of a great massing of Afghan troops at Herat.

There was some compensation for the wet feet and clothes caused by the sudden storm of yesterday afternoon in the partial relief it brought from the steaming weather of the past few days. LONDON, Aug. 13.--Mr. Francis, the gentleman who yesterday flogged Mr. Pearce, of the Glasgow shipbuilding firm of John Elder Co., for the alleged betrayal of the former's daughter, to-day instituted a criminal action against Mr. Pearce.

It is worthy of note that the Committee of One Hundred appointed by the Mayor of New-York to escort the remains of Gen. Grant from this city actually paid their own expenses. Such a novel and refreshing example as this ought to be imitated hereafter.

The work of the Floating Hospital and the Seaside Nursery meets a great need among the sick and the poor of the city during the heated term. Large excursions are going out to the seaside three times a week, and the nursery is full.

In the Superior Court yesterday Judge O'Gorman granted a motion for the appointment of a Receiver of the property of the Friendship Boat Club which, until broken up by internal dissensions a few weeks ago, had a boathouse at the foot of Twenty-eighth-street, East River.

Stubbs, of Meadville, Penn., who says she was married to Dr. Stubbs in 1864 at Meadville, and that he deserted her at Corry, Penn.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 13.--The City Central Committee for the purpose of raising funds to erect a Grunt monument at Fort Leavenworth held its first meeting yesterday. The subcommitte for three streets reported subscriptions amounting to $200, raised in the forenoon.

McVay, of Company E, Twenty-second Regiment of the National Guard, is an amateur civil engineer, and during the encampment of his regiment at Peekskill he was asked to make a survey of the camp for the purpose of constructing a topographical map showing its sanitary condition for the use of the Surgeon-General of the Governor's staff.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 13, via Galveston.-- The Cabinet, after a protracted discussion, has decided on the nature of the reply to be made to the representatives of the railway companies on the question of whether the railways were to be exempted from the operation of the decree of June 22.

The picture of the royal wedding which the Queen has commissioned Mr. Caton Woodville to paint will soon be on the easel, the artist having had excellent opportunities afforded him of making a preliminary series of sketches.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 13.--James Horace Jones died on the scaffold in the jail in this city this morning in expiation of the murder of his wife. According to his own statement Jones was born at Melbourne, Australia, of Irish parents, Dec. 24, 1863. His appearance indicated that he was born at least 10 years earlier.

TROY, Ala., Aug. 15.--In a sham battle at the veteran reunion here to-day W.J. Blan, publisher of the Troy Messenger, had both hands blown off and one arm broken above the elbow while loading a cannon. It is supposed the accident was due to failure to swab the gun. Mr. Blan is still alive.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 15.--Advices from Nassau state that the Norwegian steamer Fram, from New-York July 30, for Baracoa, put into that port Aug. 5. She had been in collision with an unknown sailing vessel and several feet of her iron plating above the water line have been stove. She will shortly proceed. WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--Assistant Surgeon J. S. Sayre has been detached from the Independence and ordered to the Naval Hospital, Mare Island.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--Little Jennie Appleton, daughter of the Second Ward Alderman who was robbed of his gold watch by one of his colored constituents last Sunday night, has been dazzling her companions during the past week by wearing a costly diamond badge. The jewel was her father's insignia of office, and had been left at home by him after his experience with his constituent.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 15.--J.C. Gaston, a lawyer of Chester, S.C., reached the city to-day, took a room in the Reed House, locked the door, and placing a pistol in his mouth, blew out his brains. He was several times Solicitor-General and once ran for Congress.
QUEENSTOWN, Aug. 15.--The White Star Line steamship Republic, Capt. Irving, from New-York Aug. 6, for this port and Liverpool, was signaled off Fastnet at 8:30 P.M. to-day.

With the view of affording the public an opportunity to visit Niagara Falls, now that it has been made a free park, the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad has placed a new fast express train in the service, called the Buffalo and Niagara Falls limited. This train leaves New-York daily at 7 P.M., and arrives at Buffalo 7:10 A.M., Niagara Falls 8:23 A.M. Tickets are good for four days.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 15.--The Church of Our Lady Immaculate, the finest edifice of the kind on the Pacific coast, was dedicatd today, Archbishop Gross officiating. It is said that the Archbishop's throne in this church is the finest in the United States.

The eleventh annual picnic of the Ancient Order of Hibernians was held in the Empire City Coloseum yesterday afternoon and last evening. Flags of all nations were hung in profusion and the park was in holiday attire. Early in the afternoon a steady stream of persons began to pour into the inclosure.
Funeral services over William A. Pond, the music publisher, were held yesterday morning at St. Thomas's Church, at Fifth-avenue and Fifty-third-street.

BOSTON, Aug. 15.--Congressman Collins, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, did not reach home to-day from Europe, as expected, to take part in the meeting of the committee. He had been in communication with party leaders, however, and the committeemen proceeded with the arrangements for the State Convention this Fall.

ANDERSON, Penn., Aug. 15.--Great excitement and indignation were occasioned here last night by a fiendish attempt to murder, combined with highway robbery, on the Pennsylvania Railroad track near this place. Thomas Creeps, foreman of a track gang, while walking from Longfellow to Granville, was assaulted by two unknown tramps, gagged, bound, robbed of his watch and a goodly sum of money, and tied fast to the railroad track.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--James Kelly, one of the proprietors of a Polk-street restaurant, was arrested to-day under the law recently adopted in this State, which provides against discrimination against color or race in any public places.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 15.--The week just closing has been an interesting sort of week to all those persons who "go in" for festivity at the seaside. A great many people come down here for rest and quiet and do not care to go through the same old routine of balls and dinner parties as they do in the city in the Winter time.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15.--A tall, muscular man answered to the name of William Sheriff in the Central Station Police Court this afternoon. He did not stand in the dock, as ordinary prisoners do, his reputation as a pugilist and his friends with property enough to go bail having provided against such an indignity.

Frank Mont, a German, 25 years old, attempted to commit suicide at Newark yesterday afternoon by cutting his throat. He has been living in a stable loft, and about 5 o'clock he went up stairs, bid his companion good-bye, and commenced hacking at his throat with a razor. Assistance was called, and although he had inflicted about 12 cuts they are not considered dangerous.

CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Aug. 15.--The fish tug Sea Wing was found off Charlevoix this morning. The sailboat was full of water, and there were two dead bodies in it. The men were identified as William Gibson and Edward Gallagher, of Beaver Island.

Commodore Chandler, of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, received orders from Washington yesterday to fit out as soon as possible the vessels Powhatan, Tallapoosa, Miantonomob, Richmond, Essex, and Intrepid. It is expected that 500 men will be put to work on them to-morrow. Work was begun yesterday in tearing down a row of old buildings locally known as Shinbone Stores. New buildings will replace them.

The King of Bavaria is to be placed under the governance of a Council of Regency. He is the victim of a too rigid and bookish education. His ecclesiastical preceptors wanted to make him a well of science and a sage.
The body of the woman which was found Friday evening in the Grenelle woods at Corona, Long Island, was removed to Newtown yesterday.
Henry Grine, whose failure was reported in THE TIMES yesterday, was twice burned out and not thrice, as a typographical error made it appear.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 15, via Galveston. --Mr. Walter Hinchman, President of the National Railway Company, who has been here endeavoring to reach some understanding with the Government on the subsidy question, left to-night for New-York. The Government adheres firmly to its decrees suspending the subventions and will rigidly enforce all the projected economies outlined in the recent decrees.

YOUNGTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 15.--This morning, following the action of the proprietors of the Enterprise Mill, the Youngstown Mill signed the scale, and both the rolling mills will start full on Monday. There are other idle mills in the valley that are in conference with their men and will undoubtedly sign the scale early next week.

GAINESVILLE, TEXAS, Aug. 15.--Information has just been received of a double killing in the Chickapoo Nation on Thursday. Murray Williams, partners in a cattle ranch on the Washita River, disagreed concerning the payments of their debts. Williams sent two cowboys, Dick Jones and Dick Cavitt, to bring his share of the cattle from the ranch. Murray's men resisted and killed both Jones and Cavitt. Further trouble is apprehended.

MONTREAL, Aug. 15.--A member of the Ninth Battalion of Quebec follows up Father Andre's letter with another, stating that he was personally informed by Solomon Vicene, a rich half breed at Batoche, that Gen. Middleton's troops plundered his house of $12,000.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 15.--A.G. Mead, gain merchant and a Director of the Board of Trade, suspended payment to-day. Mr. Mead states his liabilities with not exceed $7,000, and the assets are four times that amount. He is also the proprietor of the Alton elevator. The suspension is regarded as temporary.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15.--John Banks, a farmer residing on Greenfield Hill, was imposed upon by two sharpers to-day. He had $3,000 in bonds in the house, and at the solicitation of one of the confidence men he went to the bank and cashed them. On his way back he was met and robbed of the $3,000. Mr. Banks is 82 years of age and has been a victim before of swindling schemes.

The Stock List Committee of the Stock Exchage has listed $400,000 additional first mortgage 6 per cent. trust bonds of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company. These bonds are secured by a deposit, with the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company as Trustee, of an equal amount of the bonds of the Jamestown and Northern Railroad Company of Dakota.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15.--The Grand Army of the Republic has considered a suggestion to buy the lot at Point Pleasant, Ohio, on which stands the house where Gen. Grant was born. Their idea was to purchase the lot on the assumption that the house would be sold to some one else. Nothing definite, however, has yet been decided upon.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 15.--The miner at the mines of the Warrior Coal and Coke Company went out on strike to-day on account of an attempt to introduce Italian labor. The attitude of the miners is threatening and trouble is feared.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15.--The Canadian Pacific is auxious to carry the Australian mails, and has sent an agent to South Australia to make a proposition to run a weekly mail service by way of Vancouver, the passage to be made to London in 30 days.

OCALA, Fla., Aug. 15.--Word was received here to-night that two ladies and two children of a Columbia County family died this afternoon from eating poisoned watermelon. Two planters of that county have a watermelon patch which has been raided almost every night. Exasperated at being robbed repeatedly, one of the gentlemen yesterday plugged a number of melons and put in each some poison.

HALIFAX, Aug. 15.--The officers of the steamer Alpha, which arrived to-night from Bermuda, bring the particulars of a terrible tragedy enacted a few days before the vessel's departure. A Branch pilot named Pitcher, who was desperately jealous of a girl named Clementina, murdered her by cutting her throat from ear to ear, and before he could be arrested escaped to his schooner, which was anchored a short distance from shore.

A shabbily dressed, dissipated-looking man, about 50 years old, shambled into the barroom at No. 286 Jay-street, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon, and after fumbling about for some time in his pockets produced a five-cent piece and called for a glass of beer. GLEN GARDNER, N.J., Aug. 17.--The peace-loving inhabitants of the village of Glen Gardner were rudely startled from their Summar siesta to-day by the report that Capt. Williams and a force of 50 policemen were expected to swoop down upon them by way of the evening train and carry half of them off to the Tombs.

TORONTO, Aug. 17.--Henry P. Gisborne, a manufacturing chemist, was drowned here yesterday. Mr. Gisborne was born in England, in August, 1841. He graduated at Oxford University and then studied medicine, and was for a time connected with Guy's Hospital, in London. He came to this country 16 or 18 years ago, and for several years was employed as clerk in the general ...

The Board of Aldermen yesterday fixed the tax rate for this year at $2 40 on each $100 of valuation.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 17.--The Hon. P.L. Spooner, Jr., Insurance Commissioner of this State, has discovered evidence which, it is claimed, tends to show that about 75 insurance companies are doing a surreptitious and illicit business in this State, and he estimates their collections ...

POTTSTOWN, Penn., Aug. 17.--The five remaining furnaces in the plate mill of the Pottstown Iron Company, which have been idle some time, started up to-day. Arrangements are also being made to put the new Universal Mill in operation, employing a large number of additional men.

LAPEER, Mich., Aug. 17.--The roof of the grand stand being erected for the Lapeer Driving Park races collapsed this morning.

NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 17.--The Niagara Lacrosse Club, which leaves here for New-York on Wednesday, is composed of the following players: F. Bowen, A. Mitchell, J. Doherty, J. Blount, R.P. Skinner, Thomas Ramage, William Jagol, John Barnfield, Charles Wilson, Alexander Logan, Alexander Mitchell, and J. Dolan. The spare man is William Farrell and the Captain W.H. Brennan. They will play the Williamsburgs, of Brooklyn, on Thursday and the New-Yorks Saturday on the Staten Island grounds.

LACONIA, N.H., Aug. 17.--Thomas Gray, a Concord hotel keeper, was arrested here today on a charge of stealing a rifle and two shotguns, valued at $700, from the Atlanta (Georgia) Exposition three years ago.

With the exception of the rifles in the armory, which will remain as one of the sights of the Tower of London, the whole of the large store of arms which have been kept at the Tower will be removed to Weedon, the central depot of England.

John Connaughty, a one-armed veteran of the war, lives with his wife, Henrietta, at No. 229 South Fifth-avenue. He is in receipt of a Government pension of $30 a month, and an extra pension of $50 each half year.

A five-dollar Treasury bill was laid down on United States Commissioner Shields's desk yesterday, and Patrick Bowley, of Brooklyn, was arraigned for having attempted to pass this bill on Charles W. Allen, a restaurant keeper, at No. 634 Third-avenue, this city.

The Hon. James Oliver, member of Assembly from Paradise Park, not content with simply looking after the political, social, and religious welfare of his constituents, has lately turned his attention to their aesthetical culture, and determined that they should have music to cheer the tediousness of the Summer evenings.
The Swiss Volksfest at Paterson was continued yesterday. There was a street procession, which proved to be one of the finest of the kind ever witnessed in the city.
Between 800 and 900 dress and cloak makers, who have been working a great many hours a day for $6 and $7 per week, struck for an advance of wages.

MARTIN'S VALLEY, Penn., Aug. 17.--The violent deaths of John, Wyman, and Jason Truby, three brothers, which occurred between 11 o'clock on Friday night and 11 o'clock on Saturday morning, has created a profound sensation in this village. The three men were sons of a widow living here.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 17.--The Whisky Dealers' Protective Association of Mississippi held a meeting to-day in the West Jackson engine house. The meeting was secret, no one except saloonists being admitted. The attendance was not large, but a delegate informed THE TIMES'S ...

The closing days at Monmouth Park promise to be exceptionally brilliant. The programme is a long one, consisting of seven races, the principal event being the special sweepstakes of a mile and a quarter, for which the entries are Pontiac, Miss Woodford, and Freeland, three animals so closely matched in speed that it is a difficult matter to settle on the probable winner.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 17.--Dr. J.N. McCormack, Secretary of the State Board of Health, who has returned with the commission appointed to inspect the herds of cattle afflicted with contagious pleuro-pneumonia, said to-day: "The disease is confined entirely to a small district in Harrison County, where it has existed for more than a year, but it is so severe and has gained such a foothold that unless the ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Controller Durham has written an answer to Dr. Loring's long argument in regard to the legality of the latter's expenditures while Commissioner of Agriculture.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 17.--Gabriel Stewart, alias Henry Smith, a noted negro desperado, of Charles City, has been a fugitive from justice for more than a year. Last Spring he escaped from the county jail and soon afterward entered the barn of J.H. Brockwell and tried to steal a horse.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The Evening Telegraph and the Evening News, penny newspapers of this city, have consolidated their interests, the arrangement to take effect tomorrow. Mr. Scripps, the largest stockholder in the Telegraph, says that paper has sunk $65,000 since it started.

The interpretation put by the Paris newspapers on the recent articles of the North German Gazette and Cologne Gazette attacking France--that they are meant for effect in the Reichstag and portend a heavy military budget--is likely enough to be correct.

The notice of the death of Gen. H.K. Oliver, of Salem, brought to mind an interview with him at a picnic near Salem while he was Mayor of the city. After discussing various subjects music was alluded to.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 17.--Benjamin F. Wilson, a stone contractor, was stabbed and killed in a saloon this evening by Horace Foster, a young lawyer. Foster is in jail. They quarreled over a game of cards.

The Rev. Dr. R.D. Hitchcock returned from an extended tour abroad on the steamship Aurania yesterday. He had been away since the early part of April. "We had a very rough passage," he said, in conversation with a reporter of THE TIMES, "the worst, I think, that I ever experienced. It was decidedly wintery throughout, and many of the passengers suffered inconvenience in consequence.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 17.--Considerable commotion was caused here to-day among the stockholders and workmen of the Union Coal Company by the rumor that S.N. Stetler, President of the concern, had suddenly left town with nearly $9,000 which should have been paid to workmen and other creditors.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 17.--The eighth annual convention of French Canadians of the State of New-York began in this city to-day. Delegates are present from all parts of the State, representing 52 societies.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 17.--Capt. S.H. Buck, recently appointed Postmaster, has resigned the Director-Generalship of the new Exposition, but will remain Director-General of the old Exposition Company in liquidation.

The pooling agreement between the Texas railroads which was formed some time ago has been signed by C.P. Huntington, Jay Gould, B.G. Clarke, and George Sealy, President of the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railroad.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The Rev. Charles F. Deems, D.D., of New-York, lectured this morning to a large audience on evolution, under the title of "A Scotch Verdict." He considered all the current theories and arguments, and concluded simply that the general doctrine was "not proved."

MADRID, Aug. 17.--In the whole of Spain yesterday there were 4,696 new cases of cholera and 1,556 deaths. The places in which the principal increase in cholera occurred yesterday as compared with Friday last were Tarragona and Valladolid.

The business prospects of the country, as indicated by the outlook in this city, which may be regarded as affair gauge, are improving, and in every line of trade which is not devoted wholly to supplying the luxuries of life a more hopeful feeling prevails than has been noted for a long time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--Mr. Krez, the new Collector of the Port of Milwaukee, found himself in a bad box this morning on assuming charge of the Milwaukee Custom House. The entire force struck and left their places without previous warning.
Alfonzo Alardo and Giuseppe Otto met Sunday night in the residence of the latter, No. 428 East One Hundred and Twelfth-street, which is in a part of the city known as "New-Italy."

A plainly dressed young woman got on a Houston-Street Ferry boat at the New-York side shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning. When the boat got out into the river she walked out beyond the guard chain and attempted to jump overboard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Chief Clerk John Tweedale, of the War Department, will act as Secretary of War during the absence of Secretary Endicott. The Secretary will be absent from Washington until about Oct. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17.--The Press will print the following: "Notices were sent out to-day to the members of the Wheelen and Bartol committees on Reading's reorganization to meet at the office of the Reading Company on Wednesday. It is expected that at this meeting the present plan of reorganization will be abandoned and a new method of saving the company will be submitted which is likely to startle the community.
The New-York Central and the West Shore Roads at midnight on Sunday issued orders for the withdrawal of one-cent-a-mile tickets.
The Postal Commission now examining the facilities of the Brooklyn Post Office for caring for the mails have arrived at the conclusion that the facilities are in every way much too limited.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Special Inspector of Customs W.H. Cole to-day seized the corset factory of Solomon Vermylea and turned it over to Collector Warren.
MONTREAL, Aug. 17.--There were 43 interments here last week of persons who died of smallpox.

Every member of the United States Board of Examiners for the customs service in New-York City, save only the Chairman, Mr. JOHN M. COMSTOCK, has resigned. Various colorable pretexts for these resignations have been assigned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--A letter has been received here from Col. C.W. Woolley, of Cincinnati, whose name appears on the petition for Police Lieutenant Mullin's pardon, denying that he ever signed that paper.

Robert G. Grevel, a druggist at No. 546 Jersey-avenue, Jersey City, who lives at No. 267 First-street, hired a cab at the Astor House, yesterday afternoon, and promised the driver, John Feehan, $2 50 if he would drive him up town."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Mr. Randall arrived here to-day and conferred with other prominent Pennsylvania Democrats on the subject of the coming canvass in Pennsylvania and the selection of a candidate for State Treasurer.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 17.--The steamboat Ranger, while on her first trip to the Upper Red River on Saturday, struck a snag and sunk 10 miles above Shreveport. She is a total loss, but part of the cargo has been saved. The insurance is not stated.

While Mr. Samuel P. Hyman, an importer of silks at No. 68 Greene-street, was engaged with a customer in the rear of his store at noon yesterday George Smith, a young man, who says that he lives at No. 274 East One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street, sneaked into the place.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17.--Walter H. Lennox Maxwell, alias Dauquier, the alleged murderer of Preller, awoke at 7 o'clock this morning and acknowledged to Custodian O'Leary, of the calaboose, that he had passed the pleasantest night since he left this city four months ago.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 17, via Galveston. --The trials of the students and editors who are charged with inciting riots are still going on. The Judge has decided that the arrests were in accordance with law.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--The outbreak of Spanish (Texas or splenic) fever is reported at Bloomington, Ill.

Capt. Peter C. Schultz, who died in this city at the age of 79 years on Sunday, was born in the town of Rhinebeck, N.Y., June 17, 1806. At about the age of 15 he went to work for Capt. James Thompson, who was one of the old school of Liverpool commanders.
Al Hayman, the San Francisco theatrical manager, has brought suit against Bartley Campbell for $6,500 for breach of contract.
SPRINGFIELD, Tenn., Aug. 17.--William Cox shot and mortally wounded Henry Fletcher, Jr., in this place to-day.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Mayor Smith, of Philadelphia, and a party of Quaker City officers arrived in town this morning from Niagara Falls, where they spent Sunday. They were met by a committee of Buffalo officers and taken to the City Hall and around the city in carriages. This afternoon they took a trip down the Niagara River. To-morrow they visit Rochester.

A weird little individual rejoicing in the name of Moseman ran up and down the Cunard dock yesterday morning in a state of frantic excitement positively fatiguing to gaze upon. RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 17.--A picnic given near here to-day by the Sons and Daughters of Moab terminated in a general row, in which Frank Anthony was fatally wounded and several others badly hurt.
NEWPORT, Aug. 17.--Newport has been quite lively to-day, and the weather has been very fine for the polo games and other festivities.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 17.--About two weeks ago a man who represented himself to be James W. Conklin, an extensive dealer in Canada horses, and ostensibly engaged in business, came here. Hiring a clerk he opened an account with the Commercial National Bank of this city and made a deposit of several hundred dollars, to which he daily added in a regular business way.

What will the Republicans do this Fall on State and local elections? This is the question that is asked by many people whose interest in the party is great as well as by Democrats who do not underestimate the strength of the forces that will be arrayed against them in the coming election.

NEWCASTLE, Ontario, Aug. 17.--The American clerical cycling party arrived here this afternoon from Toronto en route to Kingston, some of them stopping here and the rest pushing on to Port Hope and Cobourg, intending to do the 200 miles from Cobourg to Kingston to-morrow. Others will start on Wednesday, and the rest will take two days to accomplish the distance.

Col. E. Livingston Price is a well known Democratic politician of Newark, and a brother of ex-Gov. Price, of New-Jersey. In the Court of Chancery yesterday afternoon a bill was filed by Mrs. Emma M. Price, his wife, who asks that he may be compelled to support and maintain her and their four children, whom, she claims, he has neglected and failed to provide for during several years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17.--While Gov. Gray was driving, with his family, along the Michigan road about 8 o'clock last evening some unknown miscreant fired a shot through the carriage, the ball passing close to the person of the Chief Executive. It is not known whether the shot was fired at random or with murderous intent.
Patrick Duffy, a laborer who lives in Hicks-steet, Brooklyn, yesterday applied to Justice Massey for a warrant for the arrest of Alderman John Curran, whom he charged with assault.

William Kernan, the young man who caused Michael Feeney's death on Sunday afternoon by knocking him down on the flagstones at No. 272 Mott-street, appeared in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with his lawyer, John A. O'Brien. Justice Ford committed him to await the result of the Coroner's inquest.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 17.--Hanlan and Lee have signified a desire to make a match with the winners of the double scull race between Courtney and Conley and Hosmer and Gaudaur, which is to take place at Pleasure Island on Thursday, Aug. 20.

David Trainor, the cashier, and Henry Stephens, a waiter, in the barroom of the Rossmore Hotel, were arrested on Sunday evening by an officer of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, charged with having violated the Excise law.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 17.--During a quarrel last Thursday near Churchland, in Norfolk County, between Jack Smother and George Washington, negroes, the former was murdered by the latter, who made his escape.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 17.--Word was received last Thursday morning that Mrs. George Harrison had committed suicide by jumping into an old well.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 17, via Galveston. --A rumor being prevalent that the Government was likely to make some arrangement with the national bank by which the bank's subsidy might be renewed, a reporter called on Minister of Finance Dublan for information.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17.--One-half the members of the Democratic State Committee are in Saratoga to-night. The meeting of the committee has drawn together the usual number of Democratic politicians, New-York and Brooklyn especially being largely represented, and the corridors of the Grand Union are filled with a talkative throng.

At the meeting of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association in New-York 10 days ago it was given out that all differences between the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia and the Louisville and Nashville systems had been adjusted amicably.

BOSTON, Aug. 17.--Mayor O'Brien has declined to accept the resignation of Chairman Simmons, of the Water Board, and this evening sent to the Board of Aldermen a communication removing Mr. Simmons and Dr. John G. Blake, another member of the water Board, from their positions. Messrs. Horace T. Rockwell and Thomas F. Doharty were nominated to fill the vacancies.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 17.--An Indian Territory special says that a question of eligibility has been raised in the case of Robert L. Owen, recently appointed agent for the five tribes of civilized Indians.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--Philip D. Armour has returned to Chicago, and to-day talked about his application for membership in the New-York Stock Exchange and the Exchange itself. "Of course," he said, "I didn't pay $24,000 for a seat in the Stock Exchange without expecting to get some return for the money.

THE TIMES has received $5 from J.C. for the Floating Hospital and Seaside Nursery. The United Hungarian Societies will have a festival in aid of emigrants from their native land to-morrow and next day at Sulzer's Harlem River Park.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 17.--Chief Poundmaker was arraigned before Judge Richardson, at Regina, this afternoon, on the charge of treason-felony.

The friends of Stephen Belknap, a well known stenographer of Newark, took him to headquarters last night in a critical condition, he having taken eight Dover's powders, with the intention of committing suicide.

BOSTON, Aug. 17.--The Boston Manufacturing Company, of Waltham, has shut down operations in its Cotton mill for an indefinite period, thus giving about 600 employes a forced vacation. The Waltham Watch Tool Company has closed its shop, and 60 men are consequently idle.
The wife of Edward F. Regan, of No. 149 Chatham-street, left him last week, and he accused William F. Hare, an acquaintance, of having enticed her away.

John McPherson, a Scotch shoemaker, caroused yesterday in the basement of No. 731 Ninth-avenue, with his bench partner and chums, and his wife took a little of the liquor, so that at 6:30 o'clock last evening she was half intoxicated and crazy, and he was very drunk.

A set of furniture, valued at $80, was bought by Mrs. Anna McAuliffe, a widow, of No. 890 Herkimer-street, Brooklyn, some months ago from Whalen Brothers, furniture dealers, of No. 193 Grand-street, Eastern District. Mrs. McAuliffe, who was a washerwoman, paid a small sum in cash, agreeing to pay the balance on the installment plan.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17.--An explosion occurred on the excursion steamboat Samuel M. Felton at 10:10 o'clock this morning, causing considerable damage to the boat and injury to several persons. That the affair was not an accident due to the machinery was made manifest almost immediately after the explosion.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 17.--While driving this afternoon, near this city, the horses attached to a carriage containing Mrs. W.H. Morris, Mrs. A.E. Hawkins, and three children, became frightened at a locomotive whistle and ran away, throwing the party to the ground.

Volumes of fire and smoke breaking from the rear windows of the third flat at No. 599 Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, at about 9 o'clock yesterday morning, attracted the attention of little Mamie Freeman, the daughter of the janitor, who was playing in the yard, and the child ran screaming into the house to give an alarm.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 17.--It was only a short time ago that William A. White shot a man named Proper at Dover Plains, while in a quarrel over a dissolute woman, and killed him. White was convicted of manslaughter in the second degree and sentenced to 15 years in Sing Sing Prison.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 17.--The outlook in the iron trade has not been more favorable for a number of years than at present. Signs of improvement are coming to the surface every day, and manufacturers are beginning to concede that the black mantle of depression is being gradually lifted from the staple industries of Pittsburg.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17.--It is now definitely understood here that the Rev. Rush R. Shipen, a Unitarian clergyman of Washington, has accepted the pastorate of the Channing Memorial Church, of this city, to succeed the Rev. W.C. Wendte, resigned.
PLYMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 17.--There have been exaggerated accounts published of the last freshet, the damage from which was comparatively trifling here.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 17.--Representatives from labor organizations in all parts of New-Jersey met in Central Hall to-day to hold the seventh annual Labor Congress of the State Federation of Trades and Labor Unions.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 17.--The German Savings Bank, for many years a flourishing institution, made an assignment to-night in favor of John C. Brady, the Receiver of the County Savings Bank, which was wrecked recently.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 17.--Ferdinand Kubitz, employed at the brewery of Hathaway Gordon, on North Water-street, was discovered drowned in a vat of ale about 9 o'clock this morning.

The carpenters' strike against the "lumping system" at the Potter Building was practically settled yesterday. By that system the men averaged about $2 50 a day, and when they made a demand for the union rates of $3 50 a day they were met with a refusal, and went on strike.
DUBLIN, Aug. 17.--Lord and Lady Carnarvon started to-day on a tour through Ireland. Their first stop was at Galway, where a large crowd had assembled to meet the new Viceroy.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18.--A general strike has been ordered by the National Committee of Knights of Labor, and many thousand Knights have been instructed to quit world immediately. In referring to the order a prominent railroad manager said to-day: "This means bloodier times than we saw during the great strike of 1876."

ALBANY, Aug. 18.--Deputy State Treasurer Edgar K. Apgar died this afternoon of embolism of the brain and acute atrophy of the liver. During the Winter Mr. Apgar was very ill and for weeks was in a critical condition. Since then his constitution had been delicate, and it was affected by the slightest disturbance of his system.

A novel method of ridding Cincinnati of rats is about to be adopted. Rewards are to be paid for the capture of live rodents and a wagon labeled "Rats" will make regular rounds to receive the varmints.

Manager Harry Wright, with his team of Philadelphia ball players, started for the City of Brotherly Love last evening in an unhappy frame of mind. He arrived in this city on Monday, fresh from victories over the Providence and Boston Clubs, with the avowed intention of putting a check to the winning career of the New-Yorks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 18.--But a comparatively small number of delegates have arrived for the convention to-morrow and Thursday. A few of the leaders are on the ground and there are strong indications to-night that Gov. Hoadly will have some opposition in the convention.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 18.--The bedroom occupied by an American gentleman named Flatman in a hotel here was entered by thieves last night and robbed of $3,000 in money and jewelry. Mr. Flatman sailed on the Etruria for New-York to-day.
BATH, Me., Aug. 18.--Margaret Freeman, colored, died yesterday, aged 104 years and 3 months.

SARATOGA, Aug. 18.--The Democratic State Convention will be held at Saratoga ou Sept. 24 at 12 o'clock noon. This decision was reached by the State Committee at to-night's meeting in the Grand Union Club House.
The New-Yorks will play in Philadelphia to-day. The Ridgewood Club defeated the Flyaways yesterday 6 to 5.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18.--The will of Moro Phillips, which was filed to-day, bequeathes $25,000 to the Church of St. James the Less, $10,000 to St. Mark's Churoh, and $1,000 to the Old Man's Home.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 18.--The steamer S.M. Felton, on which yesterday's explosion occurred in Philadelphia, lies at the Pusey Jones Company's wharves, where she will remain until the matter has been fully investigated.

MARSHALL, Ill., Aug. 18.--A terrible case of suffering is reported from McKeen, six miles east of this place. On Aug. 6 Davie Black, aged 11 years, was thrown from a horse and his arm broken in two places.
BOSTON, Aug. 18.--The earnings of the Wisconsin Central Railroad for the first week of August are reported to-day as $22,316, against $20,916 last year.

BOMBAY, Aug. 18.--A man, apparently a Catholic priest, who recently arrived here from Cochin China, was arrested on suspicion of being a Russian spy.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18.--The national lawn tennis tournament began to-day at the Casino in the presence of a large assemblage of spectators and lovers of the sport. Rain threatened to fall in the early morning hour, but the weather cleared and came out very pleasant and excellent for playing.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18.--The outlook for the iron trade in this city has grown very much brighter within the last few days, and manufacturers and brokers are feeling greatly encouraged. Word comes from the western part of the State that the same effect is seen there.

READING, Penn., Aug. 18.--The Grand Lodge, Knights of Pythias, of Philadelphia, convened in annual session at Maennerchor Hall this morning. The order has nearly 400 subordinate lodges in this State, with a membership of 40,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 18.--As hundreds of people were promenading the elevated board walk fronting the beach about 8 o'clock this evening the cylinder head of the electric light engine blew out and the entire line of electric lamps along the beach were instantly extinguished.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18, 1885. Information was received at the State Depart ment to-day that the body of ex-Minister Phelps, who died recently at Lima, was sent to New-York by steamer, leaving Aspinwall last night.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18.--The Hon. A.P. Caron, Minister of Militia, was to-day notified by the Governor-General that the Queen has been graciously pleased to confer on him the honor of Knight Commander of St. Michael and St. George in recognition of his services to the country during the late rebellion.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 18.--The City Government of New-Orleans is now in peculiar financial straits. The usual budget was made this year and fortified by the one-twelfth rule, which only allows one-twelfth of the annual appropriation to be spent monthly. Notwithstanding this rule, the departments have all overdrawn their accounts.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 18.--The drivers on the several lines of the Memphis Street Railway Company struck this morning, and travel has been greatly interrupted.

POTTSTOWN, Penn., Aug. 18.--Ellis Lessig have notified their heaters, helpers, rollers, and others working about the rolls in their mills that their wages will be increased, the increase in some cases reaching 20 per cent., with a prospect of the mill going on double time and plenty of work.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18.--The American Society of Microscopists began its ninth annual session to-day with an attendance of over 200 from all parts of America, including several ladies who are expert microscopists.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18.--The wheat market is in a very depressed condition here, and an opportunity has been afforded to those who have to make future deliveries to make a handsome profit.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--The Standard in its news columns this morning says that Russia has received a report from the engineers on the Afghan frontier in regard to the modified proposals relating to the Zulfikar dispute.

NEWPORT, Aug. 18.--Newport continues to be gay. To-day the national lawn tennis tournament began at the Casino, and the various veteran organizations from New-England and other places made an excursion here and attracted much attention.
ATHENS, Ga., Aug. 18.--In a boiler explosion at the sawmill of M. McGinty to-day Thomas Richardson and Philip Barnett were blown into shreds, not a particle of their bodies hanging together.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--Commissioner Black, of the Pension Office, became convinced, from the discovery of a large number of fraudulent names on the Philadelphia and Washington pay rolls, that a similar state of affairs existed in other places.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--"Prof." John Collins, better known in sporting circles as "the Cast Iron Man," who has fought some noted battles with Rooke and other celebrated pugilists, was this week appointed as Assistant Paleontologist under Major Powell, of the Geological Survey.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18.--Drexel Co. announce the theft of three 5 per cent. bonds of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad, numbered respectively 7,846, 7,436, and 7,437. Payment upon them has been stopped.

PARIS, Aug. 5.--The heat that has prevailed in Paris during the last month has developed a new epidemic, designated as mania reformatrix, of which the symptoms are characterized by a host of delirious inventions that crop up in the human brain like so many mushrooms.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Aug. 18.--The first division of the clerical bicyclists has arrived here. The tour has been shortened, and the visitors will not remain here over Sunday, as they had intended. The whole company will pass through in detached parties during the week.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19.--The body of Judge Loranger, who died at Ile d'Orleans, arrived here this afternoon, and will be laid in state tomorrow. He was hurrying to his wife when he suddenly threw up his hands and fell back dead. He was at the time of his death engaged in the codification of the statutes of Lower Canada.

Clarke, Receiver of the Houston and Texas Central, is quoted as saying that the next coupon on the first mortgage bonds of that road will not be paid, but that the grievances of the bondholders will right themselves if the present prospects of the company are realized. Mr. Clarke said that where the company formerly got $1.25 fOr transporting a bale of cotton it now got $3.50.
Since it was announced that General Grant was writing a book for publication great interest has been manifested by the public in it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19, 1885. The transfer of gold coin from the Sub-Treas ury at San Francisco to the Sub-Treasury at NewYork through the mails has been resumed. A package containing $300,000 arrived in New-York yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 19.--The difficulty between the striking street car drivers and officers of the Memphis Street Railway Company remains unsettled. There were only two cars running on the Main-street line to-day. All the cars on the other lines were withdrawn. DETROIT, Aug. 19.--D.C. and H.C. Reed Co., patentees of the spring tooth harrow, recently prosecuted Chase, Taylor Co., of Kalamazoo, for the infringement of a patent. The suit was tried in the United States Court of the Western District of this State before Judge Stanley Matthews. The Justice has now filed an opinion finding for the plaintiffs.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., Aug. 19.--The regatta to-day was a complete success, the water being perfectly smooth. The junior singles was won by Nowlan, of the Albanys, in 11m. 10s., the Norfolks second. The junior doubles was won by the Albany Rowing Club in 10m., the New-York Athletic Club second. The junior four-oared gig race was won by the Norfolks in 9m., the Columbias second.

The dreadful disclosures recently made by a reformed waiter regarding some of the secret practices of his calling is a tale which will shock all humanity and it is an awful rebuke to upholders of the pernicious system of tipping.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 19.--James Bosworth, a lad 7 or 8 years old, of Allepo, Greene County, while lighting a fire this morning with coal oil, was horribly burned and has since died.

It is to be hoped that the lines within which this discussion is to be carried on will be clearly drawn.

MILL CREEK, Penn., Aug. 19.--Information has just reached here of a dastardly outrage committed two weeks ago in the Kisbocoquilas Valley, near Allenville, Mifflin County. William Hazlett, a wealthy farmer, having a wife and two children, had in his employ a 13-year-old girl named Annie Patton.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 19.--The firm of Walker Co., grain and commission merchants, suspended to-day. The alleged cause is the refusal of banks to accept their paper.

Mr. JOSEPH COBURN is a much misunderstood public man. He suffers what we believe to be the unique distinction of having once been pronounced by the Excise Commissioners of this city a person unworthy, by reason of his bad moral character, to hold a license for the sale of liquor at retail.

BUTLER, Ga., Aug. 19.--Jossie Cook, the colored preacher who murdered his wife here two months ago by chopping her to pieces with an axe, was arrested before daylight this morning at Union Springs, Ala. He had lived in the woods ever since the crime was committed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 19.--A few minutes before midnight a tank of the Citizens' Oil Works, in the Eighteenth Ward, exploded, setting fire to the main building, a large brick structure. The flames are reported to be spreading rapidly, and fears are entertained that the entire works will be destroyed.

Last Fall the Suffolk County Agricultural Society offered prizes for peanuts grown on Long Island, and this Summer 106 farmers in different sections of Suffolk County are experimenting with them. So far the crop promises remarkably well. Much interest as attached to the experiment with the peanuts, as, if they succeed, the question of what to do with the sandy plains of the interior of Long Island will be settled.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19.--Congressman Springer, in a letter published here to-day, emphatically denies the allegation that it was he whom President Cleveland rebuked for recommending an unfit appointment and afterward writing the President a letter of regret when the appointment had been made.
Contrary to expectations, the Passenger Agents of the trunk lines were unable at yesterday's meeting to come to an agreement to advance the rates to Chicago and other Western points.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19.--The Baltimore Manufacturers' Record will publish to-morrow nearly five pages of special reports covering the whole South, from Virginia to Texas, showing that the prospects for crops and the outlook for business in that section are remarkably good.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19.--Several large establishments have to-day issued orders that every employe must be vaccinated within 48 hours on pain of dismissal. The Catholic School Commissioners are seriously considering the advisability of closing the schools until the epidemic is stamped out.

William H. Phillips, of No. 169 Steubenstreet, Jersey City, was found in Grove-street yesterday with two infant children in a basket. An officer took him to the station house. One of the children was his own, but the other belonged to his employer, and he had taken it as security for wages due him. As Phillips was intoxicated the mothers of the infants were sent for to take care of them and him.

PUEBLO, Col., Aug. 19.--M. McMullen, a ranchman living 30 miles east of here, was arrested yesterday by a United States Marshal for contempt of court in failing to remove fences placed on Government land. McMullen made a show of resisting arrest and was shot in the leg by the Marshal. McMullen has illegally fenced in 30,000 acres.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 19.--The little mountain town of Heath, in the hills of Franklin County, celebrated to-day its one hundredth anniversary. The town was incorporated on Feb. 14, 1785, but the town deferred the centennial exercises until a more suitable season.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 19.--V.T. Randolph, of New-Jersey, to-day began an attachment suit in the United States Court against W.T. Hudson, K.B.F. Mison, John R. Haley, and George D. Hudson, of Texas, claiming $54,000 actual and exemplary damages for breach of contract. The defendants, who are large cattle dealers, contracted to deliver to Mr. Randolph 5,500 head of cattle on the 1st of July last in the Indian Territory.

An excellent card drew a very large attendance to the Brighton Beach races yesterday. The weather was perfect until after the fourth event, when a thunderstorm prevailed.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 19.--The Democratic State Convention to nominate State officers that met here to-day was the largest that has assembled since the war, almost every county sending a delegation in addition to its regular delegates.

TORONTO, Aug. 19.--E.E. Knott, a real estate and insurance agent and a Director of the Central Bank of Canada here, has fled to NewYork, leaving large liabilities. He succeeded in borrowing several large sums of money before leaving, having been considered financially sound.

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The Rev. W.W. Downes, of the Bowdoin-Square Baptist Church, and Mrs. Frederick J. Tabor, who were arrested night before last charged with adultery, were this morning held in $800 each for their appearance in September.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 19.--Forged checks, purporting to be signed by the Rev. Canon Charles Martin Sills, have been coming to Portland banks, which have been cashed at different points in Central New-York. One check was payable to Robert Graham and the others to Thomas Sills. The latter individual is reported to be a one-eyed man. Canon Sills has been in Europe two months. Episcopal clergymen appear to have been the victims.
ZANZIBAR, Aug. 19.--The German cruiser Bismarck has arrived here, with Admiral Knorr on board.

Crowds stood in store doors and on street corners in Elizabeth yesterday and discussed the arrest of Mrs. Jennie A. Moore, better known as Captain Jennie A. Wilson, of the Salvation Army, for bigamy, on complaint of Mr. Frey, of Vermont, whom she married in 1879. Mrs. Moore made her appearance in Elizabeth last Fall and became quite active in the work.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19.--Henry Holtznorth, for several years until 1883 Captain of the Cleveland detective force, died to-day in the insane asylum. He was first committed to the institution two years ago, and was released about a year since, apparently cured. Two weeks ago he again developed symptoms of insanity. Death was caused by exhaustion.

A census of St. Paul and Minneapolis just completed shows the population of St. Paul to be 111,397, and that of Minneapolis 129,200. Between 1870 and 1880 a ten-year period, the population of St. Paul increased from 20,030 to 41,473.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--Capt. Linden, of the Pinkerton Agency, who has been investigating the probable cause of the explosion on the steamer Felton, has pretty conclusive evidence that dynamite was the explosive used.

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--Frank Mitchell was arraigned to-day charged with the murder of this wife, Ellen, who it is now accepted as certain was the victim of the Charles River bag tragedy. Mitchell pleaded not guilty, and the cage was continued until Aug. 28.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 19, via, Galveston. --Owing to the non-arrival of Consul-General Ewing, of Missouri, who was appointed some months ago, Secretary of Legation Joseph L. Morgan, of South Carolina, has temporarily assumed the duties of the consulate. General business necessities required the immediate filling of the position.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 19.--M.J. Fitzpatrick, Charles Orth, John Kay, Herman Gross, and M. Wise, employes of A.H. Borland Co., wholesale boot and shoe dealers, have been arrested on a charge of plundering the firm.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--Warrants are out for Tony White, a trapeze man, and Harry Harrison, a rider, who are running a one-tent show on the corner of Kinzie-street and Western-avenue. It is suspected that they have abducted Minnie Bautsch, a German girl, 15 years old.

EL PASO, Texas, Aug. 19.--The important announcement comes from Corrallitas, Mexico, today that the Mormon colonists who recently located there have discovered a silver bonanza in several old mines. William Carleton, who wrote "Fritz in Ireland" for J.K. Emmet, killed himself Tuesday night in a cheerless front hall bedroom on the third floor of No. 316 East Fourteenth-street, by turning on the gas after he had stopped crevices through which it could have escaped. Mr. Caricton had been dependent on the Actors' Fund since 1883, and was addicted to intemperance.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 19.--When Horatio Seymour, leaning heavily upon his bamboo cane, entered the Common Council chamber this noon he was greeted with three hearty cheers by the business men there collected from all over the State to confer upon the subject of the most-needed improvements for the Erie Canal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--The text of the decision of Judge Crease, of the Supreme Court of British Columbia, in the Hibbs extradition case has been received at the Post Office Department.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--Gustav Hinstorff, a dealer in books, publications, and stationery at No. 48 Dearborn-street, made an assignment today to William Luboke. Hinstorff's trade was principally among Germans, and it was thought that he was doing an excellent business.

SANFORD, Me., Aug. 19.--Sheriff Luke H. Roberts, of Alfred, while attempting to arrest Frank Borwell, in Springvale to-day, was knocked down by Borwell and his brothers Melville and Charles, who kicked him until he became insensible and robbed him of his revolver and pocketbook. Roberts was taken to his home, where he lies in a critical condition. Charles Borwell was arrested, but the others are still at large.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19.--The great strike announced in last night's dispatches has not yet come to a head. The Executive Committee of the wabash Railroad report every thing quiet along the road to-day.

Deputy Sheriff O'Connor yesterday arrested George Ince, a comedian, who has been appearing in "Pop" in Brooklyn, on a charge of malicious prosecution made by Miss Josie Gregory, a soubrette.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19.--In Webster County Boyle Baker shot and seriously wounded J.B. Curtee. Baker was pursued by friends of Curtee, and exchanged shots with them. On emptying his revolver he jumped into the river and was drowned. Baker and Curtee quarreled about a trival matter.

The Examining Board in the Custom House will be able to continue its work, as the commission has notified members who have resigned that their resignations will be accepted when their successors have qualified.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19.--The annual reunion of the First Kentucky Bridage, known as Hood's Orphan Brigade, took place at Glasgow, Ky., to-day, and was largely attended by ex-Confederates and some Federals. The brigage, commanded by Gen. S.B. Buckner, marched through the town. Addresses were made by Major W.H. Butts, Gens. Buckner, Preston. Lewis, and others. The reunion, which was a success, wound up with a banquet and dance.

BLOCK ISLAND, Rhode Island, Aug. 19.-- This perverse old rock heap. 12 miles off Newport, was never more popular during the time when it was the Mecca of the Narragansett Indians on their Summer excursions here, around A.D. 1500, than it now is with their white brethren. Old Manisees is bronzing more loiterers this Summer than ever before.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19.--Ella Morrison, a young lady ill with typhoid fever at the HuronStreet Hospital, left her room during the abrailing in the upper hall. She fell a distance of 30 feet, striking on a steam heater. Her skull was crushed and both arms broken, and death soon followed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--A Special Agent of the Internal Revenue Bureau reported to Commissioner Miller to-day the seizure of a number of "funny" barrels in New-York containing Peoria spirits.

ALBANY, Aug. 19.--The body of Edgar K. Apgar was taken this evening to Ithaca, where the funeral will be held on Friday afternoon. A short burial service was said at Mr. Apgar's rooms by the Rev. Dr. battershall. An autopsy showed that death was due to inflammation of the liver.

VINITA, Indian Territory, Aug. 19.--Interest in the outcome of the lease issue continues unabated throughout the Cherokee Nation. It was thought that President Cleveland would issue a proclamation expelling the stockmen and abrogating the leases soon after the action in relation to the Cheyenne and Arapahoe leases, and that he has not done so is a source of surprise to many Cherokees.

SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 19.--The State Prohibition Convention met here to-day. The attendance was not as large as was expected. ST. PAUL, Aug. 19.--The harvest is completed in the Southern part of this State and Dakota, and is in full swing in the north. The weather has been cool and pleasant, for the most part, but heavy rain was reported in the Red River Valley yesterday. JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Last year Orrin Sperry, the County Treasurer, defaulted in the sum of $80,000 and has not since been seen about here. MONTREAL, Aug. 20.--James Robinson, of St. John, New-Brunswick, who defrauded the Bank of Montreal to the extent of $35,000 and other banks to a similar extent and was afterward arrested in Mexico, is to be brought back.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 20.--The Brit ish ship Huntingtonshire was wrecked on Point Reys to-day, and 18 lives were lost. Point Reys is about 40 miles north of the Golden Gate, and is a rocky promontory jutting out into the Pacific from the western coast of Marin County. Owing to the lack of direct communication with the Point, only meagre details of the wreck have been received.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 20.--The late John Nichols, Vice-President of the City National Bank, whose sudden death occurred on Monday at the bank, was a defaulter in a large amount. A fire broke out at 1:15 o'clock this morning at Nos. 241, 242, and 243 West-street. The engines were promptly on the scene, however, and by 1:30 the fire was under control.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 20.--There has been filed in the County Clerk's office here a chattel mortgage for $400,000, given by the Greenway Brewing Company to Stephen Bastable, of Syracuse, to secure him as an accommodation indorser of the company's paper for that amount. HUNTINGDON, Penn., Aug. 20.--John Gilbert, who in 1865 married Miss Elizabeth Martin and settled in Pine Grove, Centre County, and who abandoned his young wife and child about a year afterward without making any provision for their maintenance, remaining away in unexplained absence for 20 years, returned to this place last June and sought out his wife of the long ago and endeavored to renew his attachment to her.
CAIRO, Aug. 20.--The news that the rebels have taken and occupied Debbeh and Ambugusi and are now marching on Dongola is to-day confirmed.

The unfinished races of yesterday attracted a large attendance at the course of the North Hudson Driving Park Association this afternoon. In the 2:23 class the b. g. Colonel Wood won the fifth and sixth heats and the race.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Aug. 20.--Willard Fowler, a Seabrook (N.H.) fisherman, this afternoon, about half a mile off Seabrook, picked up a 21-foot canoe painted blue with a red streak at the top.
A rumor was current in Wall-street yesterday that a very prominent operator in stocks on the bear side had been cleaned out by the rise in prices and had made an assignment.
MARSEILLES, Aug. 20.--There have been reported 65 deaths from cholera in this city to-day, showing a serious increase of the epidemic.

Two of New-York's proudest veteran organizations were well represented yesterday at the Camp of Intruction of the National Guard of New-Jersey at Sea Girt. An entire brigade at present occupies the camp and Gen. Steele, who is in command, is a Veteran of the old Seventh Regiment, of this State and city.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20.--No falling off is noticed at the Casino Grounds either in attendance or the interest manifested at the lawn tennis tournament. Indeed the interest is on the increase as the contests begin to narrow down to the finals in both singles and doubles.

MONTREAL, Aug. 20.--Smallpox broke out to-day in the lodge of Ravenscraig, the residence of the late Sir Hugh Allan. There were 32 new cases this afternoon, several of them in Peel and St. Catherine streets, which had hitherto escaped.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 20.--The Cattle King Railway Company, composed principally of heavy cattlemen, has been formed to build a line of railway from Dodge City to Englewood, in Clark County, on the Indian Territory line, 50 miles distant.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--A detective arrived at Joliet yesterday with a warrant and requisition from the Governor of Indiana for the arrest of an ex-convict named Martin Fox, alias Wilson.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 20.--Edward Webster, proprietor of the Webster House at Bartow, Fla., died to-day of an overdose of morphine.

COHOES, N.Y., Aug. 20.--A boy named Phin, 12 years old, stole $19 belonging to his father yesterday, and, with the three sons of John Laughlin, the eldest aged 11, disappeared from the city. The latest trace of them is at Suspension Bridge.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20.--The second day's session of the twelfth annual convention of the National Association of Ex-Union Prisoners of War began at 11 o'clock to-day, President C.C. Shanklin presiding.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 20.--At the meeting of the Republican State Central Committee tonight Judge W. T. Speer, of Warren, was chosen as the candidate to fill the vacancy occasioned by the recent death of Judge Oakey, of the Supreme Court. Judge Speer will be the candidate for the short term.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--The Chicago, Wisconsin and Minnesota Railroad company filed articles of association in the Secretary of State's office at Madison, Wis., yesterday.

MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 20.--The property of Bela Carter, a prominent business man of this city, was to-day attached in a twenty-five thousand-dollar suit by Giles O. Griswold, of Warren, Ohio. Griswold alleged that Carter mismanaged property owned here by Griswold, which has been in Carter's charge for the past seven years, and that the latter sold the estate and retained the proceeds.
Charles Lentz, aged 57 years, shot himself in the temple yesterday at his home, No. 191 Broome-street, Newark, N.J. He has been drinking heavily of late and has done no work.

Frank E. Lyster, of No. 131 East Seventy-sixth-street, who was arrested for forging orders in an attempt to obtain his wife's property from the Lincoln Safe Deposit Company, has for several years been a tutor in this city among well known families. Of late he has been interested in an electrical device by which he hoped to make a fortune.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 21.--Ferdinand Meyer, a farmer, 69 years old, was found this morning hanging from the limb of a tree in a dense wood near Dewitt. He had probably been dead a week.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The members of the Jefferson and Chemung County Democratic Clubs, composed of leading Democrats of this city, held a joint meeting to-night and consolidated under the name of the Excelsior Democratic Club of Elmira. A resolution indorsing the Hon. David B. Hill for Governor was unanimously adopted. Recorder-elect B.C. White was elected President, and Congressman Arnot was elected a Trustee.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21.--Frank N. Hunt, Paying Teller of the Eutaw Savings Bank, was seriously, if not fatally, hurt to-day at Hollsfield station, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. In attempting to get on the train he fell and rolled on the track. One of his legs was cut off below the knee and he received an injury to his head. The conductor of the train, in trying to save him, was also badly hurt.

Thomas H. Ford, a blind negro, fell yesterday from a third-story window at his home, No. 150 West Thirty-second-street, and landed head downward on the roof of an extension building. Several timbers in the roof were splintered, but the negro was not injured.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Aug. 21.--Robert N. Conrad, a farmer residing near this place, has been troubled for several nights past by persons committing depredations in his cornfield. Last night he placed his son William on guard in the field with a shotgun.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 21.--Gen. Middleton has recommended that a medal be struck for the volunteers who took part in the North west campaign. The recommendation has been approved by the Minister of Militia and forwarded to England through the Governor-General.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The Rev. A.L. Durstou, of Syracuse, N.Y., gave a fine rendering of "Shamus O'Brien" in the amphitheatre this morning. Prof. Arthur M. Wheeler, of Yale, delivered an interesting lecture on "Queen Mary" in the temple, at 10 o'clock.

The stockholders of the New-York and Manhattan Beach Railroad Company formally resolved yesterday to consolidate that company with the Long Island City and Manhattan Beach and the New-York, Bay Ridge and Jamaica Railroad Companies.

The recent impulse toward mission work which has been imparted to the young men of the English universities could not have appeared at a more opportune moment. Already a goodly number of workers have reached China under the auspices of Mr. Hudson Taylor, the founder of the China Inland Mission.

The New-York Yacht Club has issued a programme of Fall races to be sailed during the month of September, after the races with the Genesta have been finished.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21.--The final order to strike has not yet been issued by the National Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor, and they say this is the reason that there yet has been no visible uprising. They say that there can be no doubt of the allegiance...

A laughable story was yesterday told by an elderly gentleman living in the city. While out spending the evening he was introduced to a strange gentleman, and after a few preliminary remarks on both sides the strange gentleman inquired about the welfare of his son. The relator felt surprised that his new acquaintance should know he had a son, but answered rather briefly.

Mary Griffin, pale and delicate in appearance, was a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. She acted strangely, and refused to tell her residence or give any information about her friends.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--Dr. E. De La Granja, of the Royal Spanish Cholera Commission, whose report to Minister Foster on the cholera was published in July, has returned to this city. In personal appearance the cholera expert is tall and portly. His beard is trimmed close, and he has the dark hair, clearly defined eyebrows, and olive complexion of the Spanish race.

DEFUNIAK SPRINGS, Fla., Aug. 21.--Arrangements have been completed for a Southern Forestry Congress, to assemble here in December, with the object of the protection of valuable Southern woodlands and the encouragement of tree culture. The Governors of all the Southern States will attend this congress.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 21.--Administrator Skiles has filed the official schedule of the bankrupt estate of the late Amos S. Henderson, the banker. The liabilities are $331,380.38; assets from personal property, $61,793.42. The court has granted an order to sell the real estate, of which the estimated value is $400,000. Depositors may realize 20 per cent.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 21.--As the excitement occasioned by the recent startling disclosures regarding the affairs of the City National Bank subsides, new and interesting developments are brought to light.

The first of the trial races between the yachts volunteering to defend the America's cup was sailed yesterday, and was a magnificent contest. It was a 20-mile beat dead to windward and a run home before the wind. The wind was strong and the sea exceedingly rough.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21, 1885. The General Superintendent of the Life-saving Service has directed the Superintendents of the several districts on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts to open and man all their stations on Sept. 1. The stations will remain in operation until May 1.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 21.--The Rev. W.R. Coovert, who claims to have an interest in a fabulous amount of real estate in New-York City, returned from the metropolis to-day. He is very sanguine of success and believes his case to be a good one.
