A carload of members of the National Electric Light Association went to East Newark, N.J., last night to witness the exhibition of are lighting by the Callender Insulating and Waterproofing, Company by means of their underground system.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 21.--W. Lewis Monell, a well-to-do farmer, died at his home, two miles west of this city, last night, from the effects of blood poisoning. Some days ago, while housing grain, Mr. Monell was accidentally pricked in the palm of the left hand with a pitchfork in the hands of his son.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 21.--Charles Key, son of David Key, of Garysburg, N.C., came to this city two years ago and entered into the employment of the Pittsburg and Weldon Railroad. Subsequently he enlisted in the United States Navy as a fireman. He was about 23 years old and of robust physique.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 21.--It was reported on 'Change to-day that Peoria dealers had sold whisky in Chicago at $1.08, whereas the pool price is $1.13. In consequence the Mill Creek Distilling Company of this city issued a circular announcing that they would sell at a $1.06 rate until Sept. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21.--The sailor named Nieuwenhuizen, who came here from New-York after being discharged there from the ship John Gibson, and who was subsequently taken sick with yellow fever, is now cared for in the Pennsylvania Hospital. The physician pronounces; it a mild case, and says there is no cause for alarm.

George W. Tyson, an Inspector of the Board of Health and foreman of a disinfecting corps, was charged in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday with exacting a bribe from Philip A. Decker, a butcher, of No. 62 Clintonstreet.

MANCHESTER, Aug. 21.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "Business has not improved. The demand is light. The decline in Eastern exchanges prevents buying. Purchases are limited to immediate wants."

Charles Geiss, 32 years old, who came to America in 1874, lost employment as a collector recently, and became very despondent. On the 10th inst, he left his lodging at No. 517 East Eightysixth-street, and went to Fort Lee.

Poland, Vermont; C.C. Bonney, Chicago, and Simson E. Baldwin, Connecticut.

Among the most fertile subjects for discussion and debate in the city of Rahway, N.J., from time immemorial has been what is known as the Main-street ditch. When the place was little more than a post village this ditch was a natural waterway, fed by innumerable springs, which found an outlet into the Rahway River.

The body of a man, with a brick in one pocket of his coat and a cobblestone in the other, was found last night at the foot of West Fifteenth-street. The man was about 50 years old, with full whiskers and a heavy mustache, and was about five feet nine inches in height. He wore a diagonal cloth suit, a white shirt without a collar, low shoes, and brown socks.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 21.--The prize games in the tournament of the National Croquet Association were concluded this afternoon. Botsford, of New-York, and Jacobus, of NewBrunswick, N.J., won 9 out of 11 games and are tied for the first and second prize mallets.

MEADVILLE, Penn., Aug. 21.--Freight train No. 107, on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad, was wrecked this morning two miles below Shenango, and James Berry, a brakeman, of this city, was killed. Harry Thomas and Linde Sherred, brakemen, were badly injured. Seventeen cars were wrecked and the track was torn up for a quarter of a mile. The accident was caused by the train's parting and then coming together again on a grade.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 21.--Peter Gallagher, of Drifton, was arrested to-day for the murder of Patrick Connelly at Freeland on Wednesday last. The Coroner's jury rendered a verdict this afternoon that Connelly came to his death by violence at the hands of Gallagher. The prisoner has been committed to await trial.

Walter D. Gilman, of No. 367 Myrtleavenue, Brooklyn, obtained a warrant yesterday for the arrest of Percival E. Nagle, the saloon keeper, of No. 2,378 Third-avenue, in this city, on a charge of larceny in stealing the sloop yacht Gracle.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 21, via Galveston. --The Nacional announces that the Vera Cruz Railway Company will next month reduce freight rates. The object is to compete with the Central on its through business.

LONDON, Aug. 21.--Lord Salisbury and M. de Giers have reached a definite agreement with regard to the Afghanistan frontier question. A protocol embodying its settlement has been drafted and sent to St. Petersburg, and it is expected that signatures will be exchanged next week.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 21.--Charles H. Braley was nearly killed last evening by the mistake of a boy in a drug store, who gave him laudanum instead of tincture of rhubarb. He was severely affected before medical help was obtained.

PEORIA, Ill., Aug. 21.--Adam Forepaugh's show arrived in town to-day, and the Sheriff seized the whole concern on a writ of attachment on account of indebtedness to a railroad company contracted last year. Forepaugh managed to raise the amount of the bill, and his property was released.

PARIS, Aug. 21.--It is stated that the French Government has ordered that the minutest inquiries be made into the circumstances of the death of Olivier Pain. The result will influence France's attitude toward England.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 21.--Work was resumed in the Waltout Company's mines, in the third pool, to-day at a reduction of cent per bushel in the mining rate. In the fourth pool a number of pits are working at 1 cents, and many miners who have families to support find it difficult to earn a living. The price for mining has not been as low along the Monongahela for years as it is at present.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 21.--The situation here is growing worse. There were 25 deaths from cholera last night, and between 8 A. M. and 5 P.M. to-day 100 deaths were reported, of which 50 were from cholera. There are over 100 patients in the Pharo Hospital.

The telegraph operators at Castle Garden were considerably surprised yesterday morning when they entered their offices to see a lot of letters, envelopes, and blanks scattered all over the floor and the drawers of their desks all broken open.

DETROIT, Aug. 21.--Tuesday morning the infant child of Charles Sullivan, of this city, apparently died and was prepared for burial. Fifteen hours after the supposed death, while the family and friends were gathered about the casket, the baby began to cry, frightening nearly every one from the house. The father retained his senses and took the child from the coffin, and it has been in better health since than for some time.

NEWPORT, Aug. 21.--The fourth and last day of the national lawn tennis tournament opened pleasantly, and this, with the interest in final singles for the all-comers' match, brought together the largest audience of the tournament.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--The court tennis match begun at the Casino this morning has assumed the dignity of an international contest, for the Hon. Henry Herbert, champion player of London and Paris, and Fiske Warren, of Boston, heretofore considered the best court tennis player of America, are engaged in it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--Leave of absence for one month has been graneed Lieut. Col. Nelson B. Sweetzer, Eighth Cavalry. The resignation of Cadet William E. Wood, Fourth Class, Military Academy has been accepted by the Secretary of War, to take effect Sept. 30. The leave of absence granted Capt. William Elderkin, Commissary of Subsistence, has been extended two months, on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

READING, Penn., Aug. 21.--Joan Wagner, a respectable and well-to-do farmer, while crossing the Schuylkill River in a bateau this morning was seen to stop rowing, and one moment later he fell over the edge of the boat into the water and was drowned. The body was soon recovered. Mr. Wagner leaves a widow and two children.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21.--Maxwell, or Brooks, who killed Preller, ws brought into the Court of Criminal Correction this morning. There was a little more than the usual crowd in the court room.

John B. Carson, of Chicago, is at the St. James Hotel. George C. Gorham, of Washington, is at the Victoria Hotel.

NEWPORT, Aug. 21.--F.W. Vanderbilt's steam yacht Vedette was run into on Wednesday night by an unknown steamer off Watch Hill and considerably damaged. She was towed into New-London for repairs. Her cylinder and crosshead burst and made considerable of a sensation. She was struck amidships. Mr. Vanderbilt was on board. It will take about three weeks to have her repaired, and the damage is about $1,000.

"We left there last Monday," said Mr. Palmer, "and at that time Mrs. Grant was feeling quite cheerful--or as cheerful as could possibly be expected. There was a good card at Brighton Beach yesterday, but, with the exception of Fireman's erratic performance in running away for five and a half miles, nothing exceptional occurred. The finish in the first race was very exciting. The favorites and outsiders divided the purses.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--Notice has been posted on the gates of the Calumet Iron and Steel Company's works at Cummings, a suburban town near Chicago, which have been shut down for some time, that the cessation of work is for an indefinite period.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 21.--The United States man-of-war Yantic, Commander Frank Wildes, arrived at quarantine station last Saturday from Aspinwall. As that port is included in the quarantine proclamation the Yantic was detained in accordance with the regulations.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 21.--Work on the Exposition Steam Railway will begin early next week. Arrangements have been made with the City Railroad to connect with the West End Road, hence the starting point from the city will be in front of the Pickwick Clubhouse at Canal and Carondelet streets.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--It was ascertained today from sources which cannot be doubted that the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad is about to begin the construction of a new line from Ottumwa southwest, to Kansas City.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 21.--In the jail of Cayuga County Franz Joseph Petmeky paid the penalty to-day for the murder of Mrs. Pauline Fraitzheim on June 1, 1883. The hanging took place in the corridor. Two hundred men were present, including Sheriffs from a large number of counties and representatives of prominent papers.

On Thursday the New-Yorks defeated the Philadelphia Club in Philadelphia by figures of 7 to 1, and yesterday they met the Quaker City players on the Polo Grounds and beat them by exactly the same figures. LOUISVILLE, Aug. 21.--Fishermen found the body of a young woman floating in the river near Six Mile Island yesterday afternoon and towed it ashore. The Coroner held an inquest, and facts were developed that promise a great sensation.
WILMINGTON, Aug. 21.--The examination of the debris on the deck of the steamer Felton has been completed. Pilot Curry states that no further clues to an infernal machine have been found.
The New-Yorks and Philadelphias meet again to-day. The Star Club will meet the Hoboken nine in Hoboken this afternoon.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 21.--It is reported that the Plant system will put on a new line of steamers between Savannah and New-York about Jan. 1, which will give that system a direct line to Cuba.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 21.--President Cleveland and Dr. Ward have been in camp since Monday at Willis's Pond, nine miles from the Prospect House. The President is enjoying excellent health, and the report that Dr. Ward had summoned Dr. Sawyer, of Au Sable Forks, for consultation is false.

In driving out into the country on a by road a few days ago a lawyer encountered a horse and buggy driven by a woman. As she was driving on the wrong side of the road he made up his mind not to give up his rights. As a consequence the two horses finally came to a standstill, with their noses rubbing each other.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 21.--G.D. Anderson, John E. Vest, and Thomas Kelly, white, and George Taylor, Richard Goodwin, Barney Smith, and Bud McConley, colored, escaped from the penitentiary last evening and have not been recaptured, although pursued by a posse with bloodhounds.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 21.--No nomination has been made by the Democratic Convention since last evening. The deadlock on the Attorney-Generalship continued to a late hour last night without result. The convention met again at 9 this morning and has taken no recess during the day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--For some time past the messengers of the United States Express Company have missed packages from their cars on the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 21.--The telegrams from Greenville, S.C., which appeared in THE TIMES of Tuesday and Thursday last, stating that 108 convicts had escaped from the Asheville and Spartanburg Railroad, is totally untrue.

FORTRESS MONROE, Aug. 21.--Two races were rowed this morning in Mill Creek over the new course. The first race was the senior singles. There were but two entries, Monahan and Newlands, both of the Albany Club.

The champion lacrosse team of the United States, the St. Paul Club, of St. Paul, Minn., fully upheld their reputation on the ground of the Williamsburg Athletic Club yesterday. They won the title on Aug. 30 of last year by defeating the Calumets, of Chicago, in three straight games, and supplemented that last Fourth of July by chicagoing them again.

BERLIN, Aug. 21.--The report of the wreck of the German corvette Augusta is confirmed. Her crew of 238 officers and sailors were lost. Her value was $1,750,000. She was lost in a cyclone in the Red Sea.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 21.--Lightning struck a tenement house to-day and hurled the wife of the Rev. John Moyer, an Episcopal minister, out of her room, a distance of 15 feet. She was picked up for dead, but recovered. The Erie City Boiler Works were also struck and set on fire. The fire was quickly suppressed.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 21.--Superintendent William Brown, of the almshouse, was nearly murdered to-day by an inmate named Reichell, whom he was disciplining for insubordination. The man seized him in the solitary cell and plunged a knife twice into his body. Brown was rescued before a fatal blow could be struck.

EAST SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 21.--A terrible cutting affray occurred at Freeland, 10 miles north of this city, last night, by which a farmer named Benjamin Badgely will lose his life.

MADRID, Aug. 21.--The reply of Germany to Spain's protest in reference to the former's annexation of the Caroline Islands has been received by the Government here. It is couched in friendly terms, and in it the German Government offers to submit the claims of Spain to the Carolines to a fair examination. This reply is considered evasive and unsatisfactory.

Charles H. Bliven shot and killed himself in room No. 332, at the Astor House, during the early hours of yesterday morning. He was a brother-in-law of John Snotwell, of No. 57 Maiden-lane, and J.P. Shaw, son of James M. Shaw, the crockery dealer of No. 25 Duanestreet and No. 78 Chatham-street.

MONTREAL, Aug. 21.--The smallpox epidemic is spreading through the west end of the town and large numbers of the residents are leaving for the country, whither some of them will, no doubt, carry the germs of the disease with them. NEWPORT, Aug. 22.--The match game of lawn tennis this morning between Sears, of Boston, the American champion, and Pettit, the English champion, drew together the largest audience of this week of large assemblies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--Capt. Wyllys Lyman, Fifth Infantry, now in this city on leave of absence, will report Sept. 1 to Lieut.-Col. Robert N. Scott. Third Artillery, for duty in his office in connection with the publication of the official records of the rebellion.

MANDAN, Dakota, Aug. 22.--During the trial of G.S. Ray and others on a charge of robbing a man of $80 in a shallon a witness named John Coleman was shot by one of the defendants named Mabel Gray. Two bullets hit Coleman, one in each leg. The woman was arrested and put in jail.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22.--The ninth annual meeting of the American Dermatological society will be held at Indian Harbor Hotel on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday next. A large attendance is expected.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 22.--Specials to the Age from Hale County, in the heart of the cotton belt of this State, report that the boll worm has made its appearance within the last two or three days, and that the crops will be cut off at least 25 per cent. Farmers has been jubilant over their fine prospects.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 22.--The Canadian schooner Lilly Hamilton foundered in the lake and sank early yesterday morning. Capt. Staneker and the crew of seven escaped in small boats, and when nearly dead from exposure were picked up by a steam barge. They landed here to-day very much exhausted. The cargo of the schooner consisted of 680 tons of bulk salt consigned from Kincardine to Milwaukee. The boat hails from Port Burwell, Canada.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 22.--A review of the case of Nathaniel Sands, on his application to take the poor debtor's oath, before Judge Hall, occupied all day and was not concluded. The time was occupied in cross-examining Mr. Sands on his business transactions during the past 15 years. The case was adjourned to Monday next.
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 22.--The Point Clear Hotel and Improvement Company, of Baldwin County, made an assignment this morning to Joseph Hodgson.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 22.--Henry D. Warren, who was assaulted and robbed two weeks ago by footpads near his home at Black Rock, died last night. There is no clue as yet to his murderous assailants. Mr. Warren was Superintendent of the Pratt Maileable Iron Works, and brother of the late Joseph Warren, of the Buffalo Courier.

Coroner Messemer held an inquest yesterday in the case of Charles Eckelmann, who was caught in a shafting at the spice mills of Crampton Brothers, Rutgers-place and Jefferson-street, on Aug. 11. The jury censured the firm and held them responsible for Eckelmann's death.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 22.--The affairs of the City National Bank continues to engross every one's attention hereabout.

MONTREAL, Aug. 22.--There was less than a dozen new cases of smallpox reported in this city to-day. The demand for vaccine matter is great.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 22.--A sad affair occurred here to-day in the Poor Commissioners' office. Mr. and Mrs. Repose, indigent persons, who were once very wealthy, applied for relief, stifling their pride for the sake of saving their daughter, who was in a terribly emaciated condition. When their turn came to talk to the Directors they discovered that their daughter had died in her chair from sheer starvation.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22.--The attorney for Maxwell, who killed Preller, in a manner outlined his defense to-day. He says that he will make the State first prove that Preller is dead.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 22.--A telegram received from John L. Sullivan to-day definitely consents to the change of date of the contest with McCaffery from the 31st to the 29th inst. McCaffery will arrive here to-morrow morning, and Sullivan is expected to come on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 22.--A big flow of oil was struck this morning, at 2,380 feet, in the Gordon well, near this place, owned by the People's Light and Heat Company, now furnishing the citizens of Washington with natural gas for fuel. Five natural flows were made during the day, and it is believed that the well will prove a 100-barrel gusher and open a new oil territory. The people are wild with excitement.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, Aug. 22.--Sheriff George E. Gard recovered to-day the thirteenthousand-dollar bar of gold bullion stolen from the St. Helena Gold Mine at Las Delicias, in March last by the mine messenger, J.W. Smith. MARSEILLES, Aug. 23.--There was a marked decrease in the cholera mortality yesterday. For the 24 hours 46 deaths were reported. At the Pharo Hospital 8 patients died, 16 were admitted, 6 were discharged cured, and 88 remained under treatment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 23.--This has been the season's gayest week. With hops at all the hotels, concerts and illuminations in Congress Spring Park, piano recitals, afternoon musicales, the Union garden party, and the children's play, "Pretty Bobby Shafto," the week has been a period of enjoyment in spite of the almost incessant showers.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 23.--Of the many attempts made within the past two months to wreck trains on the Denver and Rio Grande Railway probably the most devilish of any was discovered last evening in time to prevent what might have proved a terrible loss of life.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--Boyd Waterman, a stranger in the city, was held for examination by a physician by Justice Meetch to-day, as he displayed a queer phase of insanity. He was arrested on the street selling lithographs of Gen. Grant. He wore a cocked hat, spurs, and a sabre, and when arrested had assaulted several persons, saying he was Gen. Grant and he didn't propose to allow any one to show disrespect to him.

ROCKLAND, Me., Aug. 24.--An altercation occurred on Main-street this forenoon between T.B. Severance, proprietor of the Lindsey House, and Joseph Clinton, Assistant City Constable. Severance struck Clinton, who drew a revolver and fired three shots at Severance, all taking effect, two in the thigh and one in the groin. The wound in the groin is a very dangerous one. Clinton has been taken into custody.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--A crowd of men who, it is said, are members of the Stonecutters' Union, went to the new brewery building in course of erection by Peter Schemm, at Twenty-fifth and Poplar streets, this afternoon, and created a disturbance, which grew in violence until it reached the proportions of a riot. The assailants attacked the men who were at work, compelling them to cease operations.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--The Marquis of Ripon, late Viceroy of India, at a meeting at Bolton this evening, answered in detail the charges of Lord Randolph Churchill. He said he was content to appeal from Churchill's party rhetoric to the people of India for approval of his policy.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Aug. 25.--Fight hundred stevedores struck this morning, overwork being the cause. Everything is quiet.

MARSEILLES, August 25.--Sixty-seven deaths from cholera occurred here yesterday. Seventy new cases were reported to-day and there were 38 deaths from the disease. The report that cholera had broken out in the French squadron anchored near Toulon is confirmed.

BRAINARD, Minn., Aug. 25.--Hole in the Day, the noted Chippewa chief, while en route to St. Paul last night was taken from a Northern Pacific train at a way station, dragged into the woods, and so brutally beaten that he is not expected to recover. The assault is supposed to have been the work of whisky men, against whom he was going to testify in the Federal court.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 25.--The NewYork Academy of Anthropology will hold its Summer session to-morrow at Golden Hill, in this city. Papers will be read by the President, the Rev. E.P. Thwing, Dr. H.S. Drayton, Prof. J.H. Raymond, of Brooklyn; Dr. T.D. Crothers, and others.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 25.--Preparations for the encampment of the Soldiers and Sailors Association at Sodus Point are complete, and the exercises begin to-morrow with a large attendance certain, and prospects of good weather.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 25.--An immense cloud of large butterflies, estimated at many millions, crossed over from Canada to-day and settled at Windsor Beach. The trees for a long distance were absolutely covered with them. They are identified as the common milkweed butterfly.

Andreas Eppler came here from Wurtemberg in 1867, and in the Fall married Annie Deisenroth. Each had a little money, and they opened the Appenzeller Hof, for immigrants, at No. 51 Wooster-street, and prospered.

TRENTON, Aug. 25.--Gov. Abbett said today that it was not true that the fishermen along the New-Jersey coast had asked to have a hearine before him respecting the outrages of the menhaden fisheries, and therefore no time or place for a hearing had been fixed.

On Sunday afternoon there was a Spanish bull fight at Nimes, which lasted three hours. It was under the direction of the famous torreador, Frascuelo. About 25,000 people attended the performance, who had arrived from the neighboring districts by special trains. The fighting occasioned good deal of butchery.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25.--Joseph E. Bowen, who is said to be the oldest member of the Masonic Order in the United States, and the senior member of the Grand Lodge of the State of Pennsylvania, is dead, at the advanced age of 95 years.

THOMASTON, Me., Aug. 25.--The fourmasted schooner William J. Lermond, of 843 tons register, was launched to-day from the yard of Samuel Watts Co. She is to be commanded by Capt. Sydney Puffer, of Rockland.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 25.--Mr. Alfred R. Conkling denies the report of his having challenged any one to fight a duel. He acknowledges, however, that the remarks of the Lieutenant in reference to Gen. Grant, alluded to in the reports, angered him very much, and a slight altercation of words only occurred. All endeavors to ascertain the name of the Tennessee's officer have so far proved futile.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25.--Col. J.S. Mosby, late United States Consul at Hong-Kong, arrived here yesterday in the steamer City of NewYork. Before leaving Hong-Kong he was waited on by a deputation of Chinese merchants and presented with a silver cup and an address.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 25.--Emma J. Cross, a girl 5 years old, has traveled alone from Kendalia, Texas, to Seneca Falls. She passed through this city yesterday. Her railroad ticket was sewed on her clothes. Conductors alone the lines have furnished food and been very attentive to her. She has been given small some of money by various persons, and has a considerable amount. She has been the pet of the passengers on every train.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Aug. 25.--The Canadian Park Commissioners of the Niagara Falls Reservation were in session this morning, examining maps as arranged from the recent survey of the Niagara Reservation on the Canadian side.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25.--Margaret MacLeod, of Dundee, Scotland, who arrived here on the steamship Lord Gough yesterday, left for the West to-day. Miss MacLeod intends to lay the claims of the Scotch crofters before her countrymen who have found a home on this side of the Atlantic, and to make arrangements, if possible, for the transportation of several hundred families from the highlands and lowlands.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25.--Some time ago Mrs. Angela Alice Sampson lived with hot little child in a house owned by Thomas Mackin. The child sickened and nearly died. The doctors ascribed its illness to sewer gas in the house. Mrs. Sampson has begun a suit against Mackin for $10,000 damages for the alleged injury to her child's health.

The order issued by the Executive Board of the Knights of Labor directing its members not to repair rolling stock of the Wabash Railroad went into effect on Monday. Its effect, however, may not be noticeable on the stock or in the receipts of the company for several days.

Michael Slattery, of No. 28 Madisonstreet, attacked his wife, Johanna, last evening, with a cotton hook. He struck her on the head several times, and finally drove it into her neck, tearing a gash three inches long. He was locked up in the Fourth Precinct Station. The woman was taken to Chambers-Street Hospital. Her wounds are not considered dangerous.

Calvin, Secretary of the Beaver Falls Building and Loan Association and a prominent citizen of this place, has been arrested upon a charge of embezzling $10,000 of the funds of the association. WASHINGTON, Aug. 26.--Details of the destruction in Canton, China, and its vicinity by the recent great rainstorm there have been received in this city. NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27.--The cold wave which arrived yesterday and continued "to wave" to-day was as unexpected as it was unwelcome. Thick clothing and wood fires prevail quite generally. PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27--The run on the Spring Garden Bank continued to-day, but the bank weathered the storm triumphantly, and the panic appears to be subsiding. The run is believed to have been started by false reports maliciously circulated regarding the bank's condition.

Johann Baptiste Eduard Wehner, the storage warehouse keeper whose domestic difficulties have been before the public for some time, killed himself with a pistol yesterday afternoon at his place of business, No. 103 West Thirty-third-street. Wehner was born at Wuerzburg, Bavaria, in 1825.

LANARK, Ill., Aug. 27.--Henry Foulds, who has been Postmaster at this place for 15 years, committed suicide this evening by hanging himself in his barn. His mind has been affected several weeks from the effect of a sunstroke. He was 59 years old, and well known in this part of the State.

Blackford, in Fulton Market, yesterday, was a large and peculiar-looking eel, before which crowds gathered all day and gazed with wondering eyes. The fish was a specimen of the Gymnotus electricus or electric eel, and is the first of the species that was ever brought alive to New-York.

DUBLIN, Aug. 27.--Agrarian outrages are increasing fearfully in Kerry County. Every day cases of moonlight work, of incendiarism, and of houghing or hamstringing cattle are reported. Up to date no arrests have been made. Magistrate Bodkin and 100 police went to Ballyfarrissey.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--The Socialists in Philadelphia are badly disorganized. AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 28.--William Lee was killed by lightning to-day in Pelham. Mrs. Chance, who was standing near him, was fatally injures, and a dozen others were more or less hurt. DOVER, N.H., Aug. 28.--Two passenger trains on the Boston and Maine Railroad, one belonging to the Eastern and the other to the Western Division, collided here to-day. PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28.--Mr. Carnegie today sold his interest in the South Pennsylvania Road to Mr. Vanderbilt, which gives the latter the controlling interest. The 10 years' leasehold of the Lyceum Theatre, on Fourth-avenue, near Twenty-thirdstreet, together with the decorations and various theatre properties, passed yesterday from the possession of the American Theatre Building Company to that of William P. Mitchell, of the firm of Louis C. Tiffany Co.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28.--Several gentlemen who have returned from a fishing excursion to Black Mountain, North Carolina, report phenomena resembling the Bald Mountain disturbances of a few years ago.

A lady recently made an application at Lambeth Police Court with regard to her daughter. She stated that th girl when very young went out to different places with a troupe of performers. She had not heard of her for two years, but has been informed she was dead.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--The Hon. L. P. Morton will soon leave here for the Red Sulphur Springs, West Va. He takes with him a party of friends to see a property bought by him several years ago, upon which he has expended over $100,000 in improvements, and yet has never seen.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 28.--The first vessel infected with yellow fever that has been in this port this year is the British bark Victor, which went ashore in the river yesterday. She is from Aspinwall, and was boarded to-day by Health Officer McFarland, who found five of the crew suffering from genuine yellow fever.
"That boy of yours is not adapted for the undertaking business," explained an undertaker to the boy's father, who inquired why he had been discharged.

Near Englewood, N.J., five young gentlemen, bunkers' clerks, have beet spending their vacation. For a lark they took a coach and visited a neighboring melon patch on a recent moonlight night.

In July, 1883, Pauline Campbell, otherwise known as Pauline Wilson, made a curious will, in which she directed that after her decease her remains should be placed in an unpainted pine coffin, not ornamented in any manner, and that a hearse followed by one carriage only should bear it to the grave.

LONDON, Aug. 28.--Mr. Gladstone states that his cruise to Norway and his travels through that country have Greatly benefitted him in health. He pronounces Norway admirable, and says its inhabitants are hospitable, and that he was received everywhere with such cordiality that the only regret he entertains is that he was unable to accept all the invitations tendered him.

Preston, of No. 215 Sixth-avenue, that on the 17th of last July she stole from her a gold watch and chain valued at $500. SHERIDAN, published in another column, relates to the same subject as the communication complaining of the relaxation by Secretary ENDICOTT in one instance of his order requiring all officers, after a certain term of detached service, to rejoin their commands.

An action in equity has been begun in the United States Circuit Court by the Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Railway against the Central Trust Company of this city to cause the payment of certain bonds which, it is claimed, the trust company bas refused to pay.

BOSTON, Aug. 28.--The Common Council held a long session last night, the question under consideration being the reports of the committee on the Fisher Hill investigation. Mr. Osborne, the Chairman of the committee, offered a report which condemned Mr. Simmons and exonerated Dr. Blake.

SARATOGA, Aug. 28.--This was an extra day at the track here. The chilly weather prevented a large attendance, and the contests were devoid of any special interest. Details of the racing are as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--The Women's Missionary Societies of Methodist Church in this city and the ministers of the same denomination are looking forward to the immediate opening here of a Christian training school for women. Property is to be secured, a charter procured, and work at once begun.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 28.--A train on the Georgia Division of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad was wrecked by running through an open switch near Rome today. Williams, a section man, was instantly killed. Engineer Powers, Fireman Bellows, and Porter John Thomas were seriously, and perhaps fatally, injured. No passengers were injured.

HUNTSVILLE. Ala., Aug. 28.--Charlie Townsend, the negro who murdered an old man named Freeman, at Madison, was hanged in the County Jail yard this morning at 4:50 o'clock. Townsend entered the store of Freeman on the evening of Dec. 9, 1884, and asked for a nickel's worth of peanuts.

An illustration of the methods to be hereafter pursued by the American Electric Manufacturing Company, of this city, will soon be made in the lighting of the streets of Portland, Me. The fact is fresh in the minds of our readers that a compact was made a short time ago by which the American and Edison Companies engaged in co-operative work.
Steamship Egypt, (Br.,) Summer, Liverpool Aug. 19, via Queenstown Aug. 20, with mose, and passengers to F.W.J. Hurst.

EMPORIA, Kan., Aug. 28.--At the inquest in the Walkup case to-day Mrs. walkup appeared for the first time. She was not at all abashed as she took the stand, bowing slightly to lawyers and jurors. At the instance of her lawyers, she declined to make any statement.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 28.--The Central Trust Company of New-York to-day began proceedings in the Circuit Court here to foreclose the first mortgage on the Lafayette, Bloomington and Muncie, now the Lake Erie and Western, Railroad Company. The mortgage was given May 1, 1879, and to secure...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28.--The game between the Philadelphia and Providence Clubs to-day was interesting to the finish, and was full of sharp plays. Both pitchers were effective. The home club won by timely hits in the third and fifth innings.
BOSTON, Aug. 28,--The Supreme Council of the American Legion of Honor to-day fixed the salaries to be paid the officers as follows: supreme Commander, $2,000 per annum; Treasurer...

MARLBOROUGH, Mass., Aug. 28.--T.Lacouture's wooden block on Loncoln-street, in process of construction, fell in this afternoon, and five carpenters were thrown from the framework of the second story to the ground, three of whom-- Hector Marcheterre, Frank Cadieux, and J.B. Bordieay--were badly injured.
NASSAU, New-Providence, Aug. 24.--The British schooners Isie of June and Mary Culmer arrived on the 18th inst. from New-York.

Early yesterday morning the cottage of A.H. Porter, at Prospect, Shelter Island, was discovered to be on fire, and a few minutes later it was enveloped in flames. It burned like tinder and was soon in ashes.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 28.--Very little is known here of a filibustering expedition which is said to have sailed from this port last night. It was reported that a few men were seen by some night watchmen going toward a small pier in the upper harbor, accessible only to small...
A fire broke out shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning on the first floor of No. 30 West Houston-street, occupied by C. De. Vulder, dealer in ostrich feathers. Its origin has not been discovered.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--The Rock Island Railroad has given notice that it will withdraw. from the Colorado-Utah pool 30 days from Oct. 1 next. The Rock Island's reason for this stop is its dissatisfaction with the percentage awarded to it the earlier part...

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 28.--The reported lynching of Al Lockie, the murderer, at Blanco City, is confirmed by the stage driver who arrived here this morning. He says that at 9 o'clock on Wednesday night a party of about 60 unmasked men stormed the jail...

Two firemen, passing at 1:40 o'clock yesterday morning the house of Mr. Henry Doherty, of Doherty Wadsworth, silk manufacturers at No. 113 Broadway, Paterson, N.J., discovered smoke issuing from the building.

The Bernard F. Martin Association held a Summer night's festival last evening at Wendel's Elm Park. ATLANTA, Aug. 28.--Some time ago Assemblyman Rufus Connell introduced a bill in the Legislature to tax bachelors $2 a year. Larry Gantt, editor of the Athens (Ga.) Banner Watchman, came out in an editorial attacking Connell, who on the floor of the House of Representatives denounced Gantt as a liar and a thief.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 28.--About 150 feet of the bank at Kleinston went into the river between 8 P.M. and 4 A.M. last night. A portion of the track of the city railroad and several sheds were destroyed.

Schuetzen Park, the pleasure crown of Union Hill, on the outskirts of Jersey City, was turned into a camp yesterday. Around the placid ice pond the serried lines of white tents made a brave display of military order. The hills echoed with the crack of the rifle and reverberated with the roll of countless drums. But the rifle shots were the sounds of a shooting match and the drums rattled in a prize tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--A mysterious double murder was committed at about 12 o'clock last night at Geneva, Kane County, the victims being two of the three officers who constitute the police force of the town. The deed was committed in the centre of that quiet place, near the Court House.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 28.--The steamer Nova Scotian, which arrived here today from Liverpool, via St. Johns, brought from the latter port Capt. Seablossom and 21 of the crew of the American whaling brig Isabella, which was lost in the ice in Hudson Straits.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 28.--The Island of Nantucket is almost as familiar to the NewYorker on a vacation as its more famous and rather more popular sister isle, Martha's Vineyard. Nantucket is above all things a quiet place.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28.--The monthly crop reports issued by the Government have been the source of considerable criticism on 'Change here and in Chicago, and a few weeks ago the following letter was written from this city to the Agricultural Department on the subject by S.H. Seamans, Secretary of the National Miliers Association:

The Comal, a new iron steamship of the Mallory Line, is now lying at Pier No. 20, East River, where she will load for Galveston. The new vessel was built at the Roach shipyard, at Chester, Penn., to take the place of Guadalupe, which was lost on the New-Jersey coast last Winter.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 28.--The Grand Lodge of Good Templars, in session here, after a long discussion adopted the report of the Committee on Political Action, declaring that the Good Templar organization is non-partisan, and that the Grand Lodge does not favor a third party by over a three-fourths vote.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--East-bound freight rates went all to pieces again to-day, all the roads openly reducing their rates to 15 cents on grain to New-York and 20 cents on provisions.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 28.--John L. Sullivan was arrested to-day at the instance of the Law and Order League, but he was given bail, and his battle with Dominick McCaffrey will come off just as though there has been no interference.
MADRID, Aug. 28.--It is reported that Spanish men-of-war have arrived at Yap, the chief island of the Caroline group, and planted the Spanish flag, no German vessel being in sight.

Cyrus W. Field has caused to be printed a number of additional dispatches which have passed between himself and some of his friends and between certain Western Union officers as to the affairs of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company.

NEWPORT, Aug. 28.--The subscription ball at the Casino to-night was the crowaing event of the season. The piazzas were inclosed with red bunting, carpeted with rugs, decorated with red paper fringe and growing plants, and illuminated by hundreds of Chinese lanterns...

TORONTO, Aug. 28.--James F. Lyon, a city druggist and a prominent citizen, dropped dead here to-night while on a platform in the Baptist Church, making an address of welcome to the Rev. Dr. Thomas, the minister of the church, who had just returned from Eurone.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--A little more than two years ago the Bridewell authorities made a contract with the Amazon Hosiery Company agreeing to furnish workmen at 35 cents a day. Machinery for carding, spinning, and knitting was put in, and over 200 men and women have been employed.

BOSTON, Aug. 28.--An interview with Senator Edmunds, of Vermont, largely upon national politics, is given in a St. Albans (Vt.) dispatch to the Evening Record to-night. Asked by the correspondent for his opinion in regard to appointments and his probable attitude in the Senate upon those made not in accordance with the principles of civil service reform, instancing...

NEWPORT, Aug. 28.--Pettit, the world's champion at court tennis, to-day defeated Bookes, the Canadian champion, at the Casino, after a well contested series of games. The scores were 6--5 6--4 4--6 and 6--1.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28.--Napoleon Gauthier, Pierre Gauthier, Jean Baptiste, and Antoine Paineau, the four young men who gave themselves up for complicity in the fatal affray at Verdun, were committed for examination on a charge of willful murder by Coroner Jones this morning. The prisoners were then sent down to the district jail. The detectives were very close upon the track of the men when they surrendered.
The trial of George P. Tyson, the Inspector of the Board of Health who was charged with asking and taking a bribe a few days ago, occurred yesterday at the Court of Special Sessions.
ROME, Aug. 28.--Judge Stallo, successor to William Waldorf Astor as United States Minister to Italy, has arrived here.

A remarkable case of cure from the bite of a cobra in full poison comes from Pachmarhi, a military hill station in the Central Provinces of India. The effective bite of a cobra is usually regarded as certain death, and the successful treatment of the case in question will suggest...

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 28.--William B. Ripley, assistant ticket agent of the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago ticket office at Lafayette, ran away last night, taking about $1,000 of tho company's money, tho proceeds of the sale of excursion tickets yesterday. Ripley came to Lafayette about a year ago from Chicago, and has lately been living a fast life.

MR. CYRUS W. FIELD is at it again, trying to justify himself. It is a singular feature about Mr. FIELD'S transactions that, owing to the machinations of a wicked world, he is always being placed in a position where he finds it necessary to justify himself.

The village of Woodsburg is one of those quiet little clusters of houses that characterize the south side of Long Island, the residents with few exceptions being Farmers and baymen. Joseph Bond is a well digger and lives at Little Neck, a town about 15 miles from Woodsburg.

The Directors of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company met yesterday and unanimously indorsed the policy of President Samuel Sloan in the matter of mining coal. Mr. Sloan has for some time maintained that the proper course for his company to pursue was to mine coal as long as the market was in a condition to take it, irrespective of any fixed quotas.

Surrogate Townsend, of Queens County, has admitted to probate, in his office at Jamaica, the will of the late Warren Harriott, the millionaire flour merchant, who died recently at his residence in Whitestone.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28.--The excitement at the main and branch offices of the Spring Garden Bank bas greatly subsided. A line of about 50 depositors was at the main office at 10 o'clock this morning, but there was no rush as for the past two days.

The City of Richmond, of the Inman Line, which landed at Jersey City yesterday morning, brought a large party of English bicyclists, consisting of R. Cripps, the five-mile bicycle champion; R.H. English, the champion tricyclist at 25 and 50 miles; W.F. Sinclair...

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--Patrick Loftus was charged in Justice Kersten's court to-day with robbing Henry koehler. John H. Sullivan, a saloon keeper, swore that at the time of the robbery Loftus was attending a dog fight in the rear of a Madison-street livery stable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--It is stated at the Treasury Department that A. Wilson Norris, late Pension Agent at Philadelphia, is causing the accounting officers of that department no little trouble because of his failure to forward his accounts for June last.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 28.--Twenty-eight deaths from cholera were reported in this city to-day. At the Pharo Hospital 4 patients died, 9 were admitted, 6 were discharged cured, and 75 remain under treatment.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28.--A prominent railroad official said here to-night that the Southern roads were on the verge of the greatest passenger war ever inaugurated in the South. A cut is being made to New-York and other Eastern points.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--Mrs. Adelaide R. Kenney and Mrs. Maria E. Sheffield were elected Trustees at the school election here, by 19 majority, over two men. Thirty-eight women voted. This was the first time women have been candidates here.

COTTAGE CITY, Martha's Vineyard, Aug. 28.--There has been no perceptible exodus from this island yet, and there are fully as many people here as there have been at any time during the Summer. Many cottagers will remain until the middle of next month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--A train load of Arizona cattle, billed from Prescott, arrived at Chicago to-day, after being 12 days on the road. They came over tho Atlantic and Pacific, the Atchison and Santa Fe, and the Wabash and St. Louis Railroads, traveling a distance of over 2,000 miles.

The latest filibustering expedition to Cuba has apparently begun by moving away from the island. Perhaps, however, it took its few steps to the rear only in order to gather momentum for a spring forward. The first news of the attempt received at Washington was that a small vessel full of armed men had left Cuba...
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 28.--The Lancaster Daily Examiner will publish to-morrow reports of the condition of the tabacco crop from 70 growers and packers, covering all sections of the country.

Mr. Lemuel Clark, a, well-to-do resident of Brooklyn, who lived at No. 354 Grand-street, died on Aug. 5 last, and after his death it was discovered that his pretty young daughter, Euphemia, has been secretly married to Frank Metz, a conductor on the Tompkins-Avenue...
COHOES, N. Y., Aug. 28.--A few years ago Albert Lawrence, of Toronto, ran away from home and never let his parents know where he was.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28.--At the last session of the Dominion Parliament the Richelieu and Ontario Navigation Company was authorized to cancel 3,989 shares of stock, thereby reducing the capital from $1,600,000 to $1,200,000.

PASO DEL NORTE, Mexico, Aug. 28.--Reports reached here to-day which seem to confirm previous rumors that yellow fever is raging on the Pacific coast of Mexico, and has appeared at both Guaymas and Mazatlan.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28.--Mr. Fitzpatrick, Riel's couusel, arrived in the city from Quebec this morning on his way to Winnipeg, where he goes to argue the appeal from the verdict of the court at Regina. Mr. Fitzpatrick said he felt confident that the grounds he purposed raising as to the jurisdiction of the court, should they fail to...

The extension of the Brooklyn Bridge, connecting the car platforms with the elevated railroad station at Tryon-row, was completed yesterday, and at 6 o'clock this morning will be opened for the accommodation of the public.

ALBANY, Aug. 28.--The sad news reaches the capital city that a gulf of frightful depth yawns between Mr. John J. O'Brien, of NewYork, and Mr. Michael J. Dady, of Brooklyn, These two "boys" were great cronies in politics till a very recent date. Mr. Dady is a contractor who really knows his business and who has made money out of it.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 28.--A representative of the Journal to-night had an interview with Vice-President Hendricks, who has just returned from Wisconsin. He was very chary of talk, paying: "I have recently determined not to talk to newspaper men of questions relating to the Government.

The New-York sulphur Disinfecting Company's vacuum process was yesterday shown to be a success. After Wednesday's experiment the disease germs which were exposed were taken away in little vials to the Carnegie Laboratory. There were 8 of these vials and 7 others containing germs which had not been treated.

CAPE MAY. N.J., Aug. 28.--Charles Heyer, of No. 924 Poplar-Street, Philadelphia, aged 21 years was drowned while swimming in deep water about noon to-day. James Miller, colored, of Pittsburg, a waiter at the NewColumbia Hotel, is supposod to have drowned at the same time.

A piece of amber weighing eight pounds is at present being exhinited in the Mark Museum, at Dantzic, for which the owner has refused 1,500. It is probably the largest piece in the world without blemish.

NEWPORT, Aug. 28.--Ex-President Arthur accompanied MRs. August Belmont and her daughter-in-law to the Casino this noon, and was dined by William R. Travers, of New-York. Afterward Mr. Arthur attended the ball at the Casino, upon the invitation of the Governors of that institution.

CHARLESTON, Aug. 28.--There is not an idle man in Charleston to-day, and the work of repairing the ravages of Tuesday's cyclone is being prosecuted rapidly. The city authorities have taken prompt measures to clear away the debris on streets, and the Sanitary Inspectors are exercising an unusual vigilance in seeing that the city is thoroughly cleaned.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--Articles of incorporation of the Chicago, Burlington and Northern Railroad Company were filed to-day at St. Paul and Madison, the capitals of Minnesota and Wisconsin.

The experience of the last week or ten days has satisfied the Grant Monument Committee that the public is just as thoroughly interested note in the project to place a monument over the remains of Gen. Grant as it was in the week immediately following the great solidier's death.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--Some time ago the statement was telegraphed from this city that a conflict of authority has arisen between Secretary Endicott and Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan; also, that a similar conflict has occurred between ex-Secretary Lincoln and the LieutenantGeneral of the Army.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--Detective Matthew Pinkerton returned to this city last night from Detroit with a horrible recital of crime. On July 28 Harvey Keith, ayoung farmer living at Bloomingdale, Van Buren County, Mich., was murdered.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 28.--Col. Daniel S. Lamont, President Cleveland's private secretary, spent nearly the entire day here, and that almost without the knowledge of the local Democratic politicians. The Lake of Constance is only some 50 miles in length, but any one who travels from pier to pier and wishes to know the right time of day at each ought to carry five watches.

LANARK, Ill., Aug. 28.--It appears quite probable that the immediate cause of the suicide of Postmaster Henry Foulds last evening was the visit to Lanark yesterday afternoon of the Government Post Office Inspector.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--Capt. Thomas Johnson, of the tug Flossie Thielkie, ran into a quantity of wreckage about six miles northeast of the Government pier this morning. There were two large masts, with sails, rigging, and running gear attached.

ST. LOUIS. Mo., Aug. 28.--The Great Western Iron Boat Building Company, Theodore Allen and Anthony H. Blaisdell, properietors, filed a deed of assignment this afternoon for the benefit of creditors. The assets are listed at $36,530; liabilities unknown.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28, 1885. The Treasury Department has paid out about $10,000,000 on account of pensions so far this month. It is therefore expected that the decrease of the public debt for August will not be us large as usual.

As already aunounced, Mme. Judic will make her first appearance in this country at Wallack's Theatre about Oct. 1. The piece selected for the American debut of this distinguished artist is the "Mam'zelle Nitouche" of MM. Meilhac and Millaud, for which Herve wrote the music.
The Bolan Railway is making fairly rapid progress; 10 miles on the lower section are open and the bridging is finished for 14 miles further. The line is likely to reach Much by October.
Jacob Leon, who is now an inmate of the Bloomingdale Asylum for the Insane, in obedience to a writ of habeas corpus, was produced in the Supreme Court Chambers before Judge Barrett yesterday.

TORONTO, Aug. 28.--Particulars of a cold blooded murder were received here to-day from Townsend Township, east of this city. Mary J. Coville, a young girl living with her family, left her father's house last Christmas Day to visit a friend several miles distant.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 28.--At the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science to-day several changes were made in the constitution, one being the merging of the section on " Histology and microscopy" with the section on "Biology." BUTLER, Penn., Aug. 28.--An oil well has been discovered in Butler County to-day which has been heretofore wholly unknown to the scouts. This well is veritable wildcat, being situated a long distance from any locality in which oil has been heretofore discovered. So secretly have the operations been conducted that it has been styled by its owners "The Midnight Mystery."

The new postal cards were received yesterday at the Post Office in this city. They differ slightly from the old ones, in that the card, board is of a pinkish tint, the printing is a subdued brown, and the stamp contains a portrait of Thomas Jefferson.

After another close game the New-Yorks defeated the Bostons yesterday, and by doing so placed themselves within one game or their Chicago rivals. Over 3,000 persons witnessed the contest, and they were treated to a fine display of sharp fielding and good pitching. It was a pitcher's game, and Welch played an important part in winning the contest.

WEIRS, N.H., Aug. 28.--At the NewHampshire Veterans' Association reunion today President Linehan was re-elected, and approperiate resolutions upon the death of Gen. Grant were passed. A feature of the afternoon was a sham representation of the battle of Groveton, to-day being the anniversary of its occurrence. It passed off successfully and was witnessed by many thousand persons.

Ellen Sullivan and Mary O'Brien, young woman living at No. 16 Dowling-street, engaged in a fight on Aug. 15, which resulted in Mary's being knocked off a stoop, getting a broxen arm, and receiving internal injuries, from which she died last night. Ellen has been arrested, and is held to await the result of the Coroner's investigation.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 28.--The surviving members of the Condferate battery "St. Mary Cannoneers" held a meeting yesterday in Franklin, St. Mary's Parish, to form a permanent organization to be known as the "Veteran Association of the St. Mary Cannoneers."
FRANKLIN, Ga., Aug. 28.--After playing a game of cards in Heard County, John and Charles James, uncle and nephew, quarreled over the result.

Dennis Nolan, a brass molder, 40 years old, who had been despondent owing to inability to obtain work, committed suicide yesterday morning by hanging himself with a piece of clothes line to a ladder in the cellar of his residence, No. 222 East One Hundred and Eighth-street.

A party of five colored emigrants who are on their way to Africa arrived yesterday from the West Indies on the steamship Santiago. The party consists of two men and three women. Frederico Cayo, the leader of the emigrants.

LONDON, Aug. 28.--In the Mincing-lane markets more confidence has been shown in the sugar trade and the demand has increased. Prices have advanced 6d.@9d. Cane is lower than beet sugar, which, after touching the highest point of the year, is quiet, Refined sugar has improved.

The Autumn meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club begins to-day at Sheepshead Bay, and as usual there is a bewildering array of entries which promise to give the new starter a great deal of trouble and the speculators a hard time in picking the winners. In all 72 horses are announced to start in the six events, the delegations from Brighton Beach and Saratoga being formidable in numbers and "ability."

MONROE, Ga., Aug. 28.--The jury in the case of Bill McGaughey, colored, who was charged with murdering his wife, has returned a verdict of guilty, without recommendation. His sentence has not been pronounced, but he will probably be hanged within the next 10 days.

The recent election of Charles E. Loew to be a Sachem of Tammany and the simultaneous rumor, which gained wide belief among politicians and others, that he was to assume the leadership of the organization in place of John Kelly during the coming campaign, have caused a great deal of speculation in political circles.

The Suffolk County Agricultural Society is preparing for an old-fashioned country fair, to be held at Riverhead, Long Island, on Sept. 29 and 30 and Oct. 1. Arrangements have been made with the Long Island Railroad for excursion tickets that will be good during the fair.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28.--Both Sweeney and Conway were hit freely in to-day's game, but the visitors were morn fortunate in bunching their hits, and the home team made their errors at very critical times.

The town of West Chester refuses to accept a beautiful Gothic building which the estate of the late Peter Van Schaick offers them for a library building free of cost.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 28.--The third day of the Hampden Park meeting was attended by about 3,000 people. There was a good track and a sorry looking set of speculators after the races.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--Mr. A.M. Keiley was at the State Department to-day settling up his accounts. He has not yet resigned as United States Minister to Austria, but will do so. He does not desire a reappointment in the diplomatic service. In fact it was at his own suggestion that he did not go to Vienna when opposition was shown to him, but returned to this country.

WILKESBARRE, Aug. 28.--D.F. Seibert, an ex-member of the Pennsylvania Legislature from Columbia County, is now under arrest charged with burglary. For over a month past many of the principal residences of Berwick have been entered by thieves, and money, jewelry, and other articles have been stolen.

PARIS, Aug. 28.--The body of Admiral Courbet was interred to-day in the Hotel des Invalides. A large assemblage attended the burial ceremonies, notwithstanding the weather was inclement. In the concourse were deputations of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies and attaches of foreign legations.

The splendid day overhead and the superb track caused a large attendance at Brighton Beach yesterday. ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28.--Maxwell, the alleged murderer, received in his mall to-day a letter postmarked and dated Wilkesbarre, Penn., and signed "C.A. Preller." The handwriting resembles that of Preller somewhat, but the police do not take much stock in it, and think that the letter is the work of Maxwell's attorney, in connection with a confederate at Wilkesbarre.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 28.--Henry K. Goodwin, who shot and killed Albert D. Swan yesterday, was arraigned in the police court today and pleaded not guilty. Examination was warned, and he was committed to jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28.--There were 50 cases of smallpox reported yesterday, but of these only 19 have yet been authenticated. There were 28 deaths to-day among the Catholics alone, and 23 yesterday. The Protestant returns are not yet in. There are still 56 cases in the Civic Hospital and the weather continues so cold that it has been impossible to use the tents.

Helen Hamilton, a good-looking girl, 18 years old, tried last night to throw herself from the Hoboken ferryboat Hackensack into the North River. She was caught by deck hands as she was climbing over the guard rails, and upon the arrival of the boat she was turned over to Hoboken officers. She had had a quarrel with her lover.

Two thousand people visited the tomb of Gen. Grant yesterday. A little girl named Mary Castro brought a beautiful wreath of flowers to Capt. Fessenden, and asked that it be placed on the casket. Her request was complied with.

BOSTON, Aug. 29.--The commission of medical experts appointed by the Mayor to investigate the sources of Boston's water supply has made a report which makes some startling revelations of the pollution of the streams which supply the Mystic River and other sources from which water is taken.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--The Current Company to-day made a voluntary assignment for the benefit of its creditors to A.E. Davis, a publisher in Washington-street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--Ex-Secretary of War Lincoln declines to be interviewed as to the subject of his correspondence with Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan published to-day, and which was given to the Army and Navy Journal by the present Secretary, Mr. Endicott.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass, Aug. 29.--Only a fair attendance marked the last day of the circuit meetings at Hampden Park to-day. The week has not proved a financial success, while the bookmakers have also lost heavily.

Symptoms of a mild species of insanity in the actions of Nettie Kassendrook, a pretty young woman who lived with her mother at No. 294 Van Brunt-street, Brooklyn, became painfully apparent a short time ago and caused much uneasiness among her friends and relatives.

The Puritan did not get away from Poillon's shipyard, in Brooklyn, in time yesterday to take her proposed run down the Bay. It was afternoon before all the new ironwork was put on, and she was made quite ready to sail. Then, as it was so late, she was allowed to remain at the yard until about 6 o'clock, when she was given a line by a tug and towed down to Stapleton.

ELMIRA, Aug. 29.--At the Democratic Convention for Chemung County, held here today, W.L. Muller, J.J. O'Connor, and Major Robert P. Bush were elected delegates to the State Convention. Resolutions indorsing the National Administration were adopted, and the nomination of Gov. Hill for Governor was urged.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29.--Lucius White was brought before Commissioner Cullen this afternoon for the preliminary hearing on the charge of counterfeiting Brazilian Treasury notes. He waived examination, and was committed to jail to await the action of the United States Grand Jury at the November term.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Aug. 29.--Nathan Long has filed a $10,000 damage suit against J.H. Hartlein Co. for the killing of Frank Long, aged 7. Hartlein Co. are building a mill and a pile of their lumber fell on the boy, crushing the life out of him.

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 20.--Over 400 Hungarians and Polanders left here to-day for the Northwest, and it is expected that a great many more will leave for the same region in a few days.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 29.--About a year ago George C. Converse, son of a wealthy resident of this city, opened a carriage repository here. He had been known as a plausible man about town, noted somewhat for a predilection for horses and fancy stock.
LONDON, Aug. 29.--Two ladies belonging to families of rank in Mezzevo, in Epirus, European Turkey, were some time ago abducted by brigands from Epirus Mountain.
The South American Subsidy Commission was coldly received in Chili. "The authorities," Commissioner SOLON THATCHER says, "did not express an eagerness to promote commerce between the two countries."

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 29.--A very serious uprising of victimized depositors of the broken German Savings Bank, which closed last week, was prevented this evening by the stockholders signing a deed acknowledging their legal liability to the depositors and agreeing to settle in proporeton to the shares held.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--It is learned from River Du Loup that Mr. F. Meredith, son of Chief-Justice Meredith, had a narrow escape from drowning while boating at that place yesterday. He owed his life to the heroism of Miss Lemoine, who on perceiving his peril plunged into the water and succeeded in rescuing him.

NEWPORT, Aug. 29.--The attendance on the Polo Grounds this afternoon was very large, and over 500 persons were on Deadhead Hill alone.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29.--The Brooklyn Club had very little difficulty in hitting Henderson safely to-day, and their fielding was perfect, while the home team could not do much with Porter's curves, and their work in the field was below the average.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--There were 21 deaths from smallpox reported at the Health Department to-day and 50 new cases, but only one-half of these have been authenticated. Two hundred and nineteen victims of smallpox were buried at the Cote des Neiges Cemetery this week, but only 100 deaths from the disease were reported at the Health Office.

NEWPORT, Aug. 29.--The week now drawing to a close has been a memorable one. Balls, receptions, dinners, c., have followed each other constantly. The Casino attractions and the outdoor sports have had many patrons, and have been thoroughly enjoyed. CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 29.--The joint legislative committee on the dedication of the statue of Daniel Webster, presented to the State by the Hon. B.P. Cheney, of Boston, voted this morning to hold the dedicatory exercises on June 17, 1886, and to invite President Bartlett, of Dartmouth College, to deliver the address.

SANDWICH. Ill., Aug. 29.--William R. Low swallowed by mistake a quantity of carbolic acid this afternoon and died 10 minutes afterward. He was a prominent citizen and a police magistrate, and was for a long time one of the managers of the Sandwich Manufacturing Company. He leaves a wife and four children.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--A man named Boisvert was bear hunting in the township of Ham to-day, when he sighted a dark moving object, at which he fired. The object proved to be his son, who was instantly killed.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 29.--The legislative committee which has been investigating the affairs in the office of the Auditor of Public Accounts, made necessary by the defalcation of First Clerk William R. Smith, has concluded its labors and placed its report in the hands of the Public Printer.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 29.--The only mystery in connection with the South Pennsylvania deal which has not been solved is that which surrounds the terms of payment and the manner in which the payment is to be made.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--An attempt is being made by James V. Wiggins, of Brownsville, Texas, a nephew of the immortal Flanagan, to prove that he has been made a martyr of by Republican officials because he is a Democrat.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 29.--Ex-Gov. Reuben E. Fenton was buried this afternoon, 6,000 strangers joining with the 15,000 residents in attending the funeral. The weather was delightful, and gave opportunity for the display of an immense amount of black drapery, which gave to the business streets a mournful appearance.

Vice-Presidents Hayes and Hoxie and General Manager Tulmadge, of the Wabash and Missouri Pacific Railroads, left New-York on Friday evening for the Southwest. It is their intention to make a tour of inspection over Jay Gould's Southwestern system. Meanwhile the Knights of Labor have been asked to wait until Mr. Talmadge can work his way around to St. Louis.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 29.--At 10:44 o'clock this morning Gov. Currier sent a message adjourning both branches of the Legislature until the last Wednesday of May, 1887. During the session just closed 215 bills and joint resolutions, including the Valued Insurance Policy bill, were passed and approved by the Governor.

EMPORIA, Kan., Aug. 29.--There was the sound of wheels this afternoon in front of the residence of Mrs. Minnie Walkup, who is under arrest on the charge of poisoning her husband, and the Sheriff, who was in the house, went down and opened the door.

The indications of a prosperous season of German opera at the Metropolitan Opera House are very flattering, even at this early day, and Director Stanton is correspondingly elated. No attempt has yet been made to canvass for subscriptions, and if the promise of the past week is fulfilled the management will not be obliged to resort to that method of disposing of seats for the season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Detective Block to-day arrested John Dickerson, formerly Superintendent of the Pension Bureau, for the larceny of a flag from the Government. This is one of the results of the recent investigation into the late Superintendent's conduct of the bureau affairs.

The Coney Island Jockey Club began its Autumn meeting yesterday with the usual large crowd in attendance and with favorable weather. Although the sky was overcast during the afternoon there were no indications of immediate rain and the temperature was moderate enough to allow the spectators to dispense with overcoats and wraps, which the majority had brought with them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Serious as is the action of Controller Durham in refusing to pass the accounts of the Alabama Claims Court, it is reported that a much more awkward point will be made by Solicitor of the Treasury McCue.
There will be a number of striking theatrical events during the present week, but the most important of all will be the Saturday night production of the "Comedy of Errors" at the Star Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--The period of time allowed by the President in his proclamation for the settlers upon the Crow Creek lands in Dakota to vacate expired more than a month ago, but no steps have been taken by the Government toward the forcible removal of the settlers.

LIMA, Aug. 29, via, Galveston.--It is stated here that the situation at Arequipa is becoming daily more gloomy. Of the Cacerist garrison two battalions have revolted and dispersed, only 150 men remaining in that city. Many reports of outrages by Cacerist troops have been received.
A dispatch from Bremen states that Capt. Otto Heimbruch, of the steamship Fulda, which recently arrived at Bremen from this port, died during the voyage. Capt. Heimbruch was about 40 years of age.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26.--May Rosenberg, alias Byron Douglas, is a smart, taking, and well-dressed young man, who claims to be an actor and a teacher of acting. He struck an attitude of injured innocence before Magistrate Smith to-day, when he appeared in the role of a swindler.

BOSTON, Aug. 29.--To-day completes Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes's seventy-sixth-year. The occasion was celebrated by the poet-physician and his family by a dinner. He was the recipient of many congratulations, flowers, and gifts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--The full returns of the census just taken in Dakota show that the population of the entire Territory has increased from 135,177 in 1880 to 263,465, while the number of farms has increased from 17,435 to 82,767, and the manufacturing establishments from 251 to 1,054.
CHANUTE, Kan., Aug. 29.--Considerable excitement has been occasioned here by the exhuming of the remains of Nancy J. Poinsette, who was poisoned to obtain the insurance on her life.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--A prophetic feature of one of the illustrated journals this week is the leading cartoon, which represents Sir John Macdonald in a fix about Riel. Sir John is pictured standing upon two horses--one foot on each--which are facing different ways and look as if ready to start off.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 29.--There is a purple haze over the woods and hills to-day--a soft, mysterious veil that is preguant with meaning. It is the soft September haze of the American Autumn. There is a gentle westerly wind blowing, and the surf has died down to a mere ripple that breaks upon the brown sand of the beach with a low crooning that sounds like the lullaby of the season.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29.--Only a, small crowd witnessed the closing contest between the Buffalo and St. Louis clubs to-day. It resulted in the fourth successive defeat of the home team. The visitors won the game on its merits, outplaying the home club at every point.

To-day is the feast of St. Rose of Lima. This first canonized female saint of the New World was born at Lima, in Peru in 1586, and was baptized Isabella, but because of the lovely reseate bloom upon her cheeks when an infant in the cradle she was called by the name of Rose. CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 30.--Albert Barrass, a lithographer, of Philadelphia, was drowned near the steamboat wharf this morning. He had assisted in getting off a yacht which had been aground, and as soon as he reached deep water jumped overboard to swim ashore, but immediately sank, uttering a cry shore help. Although several persons were on shore near at hand they were powerless to assist the young man. His body has not been recovered.

An enterprising keeper of a hotel on the shore of the Sound lately announced that he had made an offer of $6,000 for the house in which Gen. GRANT was born, and that if this offer was accepted he would remove the house and set it up in the grounds of his hotel.

One day this last week a man who used to be a notable figure in student life in New-York was shot dead while hard at work in his laboratory, out in a small Dakota town.

The congregation of the Beth-Elohim, of Brooklyn, dedicated yesterday its new place of worship, on State-street, near Hoyt. The building was purchased from a Congregational society early in the Summer and has been thoroughly renovated.
A number of boys were playing about the quarries at West New-York, N.J., on Saturday afternoon. None of them was over 6 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, 30.--The funeral of John E. Bowen, who was conceded to be the oldest Mason in this State, took place this afternoon from his late residence, No. 2,024 Sansomstreet.
The Royal United Service Institution has had its attention directed to a system of torpedo warfare to be carried on in the air by means of balloons.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--A special dispatch to the Times from Atlantic City, N.J., says: "Charles Fields, Sr., who is over 85 years of age, and who has been in business in Philadelphia for over 50 years, was to-day victimized out of $9,500 by a brace of bunco men in Atlantic City.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--A story has been published to the effect that Emory Storrs would go to Salt Lake City to act as Counsel for the saints there in their fight against the United States Government.
The International Inventions Exhibition of London has awarded a modal to Warner Brothers, of this city, for the superiority of their Coraline for Corsets.
George Forshay, the son of an undertaker at No. 244 Bleecker-street, got very drunk on Saturday night and acted in a disorderly manner at Bleecker and Cornelia streets.

The Albers Association, which is said to be composed of ex-members of the "Hook gang" of loafers who frequent The Allen's den, and of a number of east side roughs, went on an excursion yesterday to Fort Washington. They chartered the barges Moses Grinnell and Harvest Queen and the tug Robert Roe, and went on board at the foot of Clinton-street.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 30.--At a mass meeting last night the committee on the Grant memorial reported in favor of a new auditorium if the sum of $15,000 could be raised for its construction; if not, it preferred a young people's temple.

The proclamation issued by President CLEVELAND on April 17 last with reference to the Crow Creek and Winnebago Indian Reservation in Dakota foreshadowed the Indian policy of the new Administration. It has been followed by other acts and proclamations that show very plainly what that policy is.

Many contradictory statements as to the practical results of the work done under the auspices of the International Association for the Exploration and Civilization of Africa have of late appeared in public prints, both in this country and in Europe.

LANDER, Wyoming, Aug. 30.--Ed Le Clair, a well known frontiersman, has just returned from a scout among the haunts of the Teton Basin horse thieves, in Eastern Idaho. He rode through a good portion of the country they hold, and says that they have a large force.
BOSTON, Aug. 30.--Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, who was 76 years old yesterday, was remembered by many friends. Quantities of roses, pink, water lilies, and other flowers were sent to him.

MADRID, Aug. 30.--A riot has occurred at Almeria, in Andalusia. The increasing cholera mortality having driven most of the wealthy residents from the city, a large number of poor people were deprived of employment. This desertion on the part of rich employers incensed the laboring people, and the feeling of indignation culminated in a riotous outbreak.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 30.--B.F. Coates, of Portsmouth, Ohio, has been appointed Receiver of the Cincinnati and Eastern Road, vice John R. McLean, resigned.

The retirement of Mr. BELL from the office of Supervising Architect seems to have been determined upon. It does not appear who his successor is to be. By law that question is left entirely in the discretion of the Secretary of the Treasury.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30--The monotony of a stormy Sabbath was relieved by three religious meetings conducted by Moody and Sankey and the presence of several eminent clergymen who occupied pulpits throughout the city.
