The stock market last week might have been written down intensely dull and uninteresting had it not been for the dynamite which was found in its tail. The discovery was made public about 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, although it was evident that some people knew all about it earlier in the day.

The Most Rev. Archbishop Corrigan celebrated the 7 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth-avenue, yesterday morning. The Archbishop will resume his series of short sermons in the Cathedral at the 6 o'clock mass on next Sunday morning, when the solemn high mass will be celebrated at 10:30 o'clock with both choirs present, the quartet and chorus having returned from their vacation.
The beginning of the oyster year is again at hand, and the lovers of the succulent bivalve can to-morrow revel in them without any uncomfortable reminder that there is no "r" in the month.
Frederick Stuhr, 47 years of age, a milkman, married for his second wife a prepossessing young woman about one month ago, and they took up their residence at No. 119 Monroe-street, Hoboken.

A hastily prepared placard outside the Madison-Square Theatre last night informed those who went there to see the performance of Sardou's play, "Anselma" with Mme. Janish in the principal role, that the performance was postponed until Wednesday, when the legal difficulties connected with the play would be argued in court.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31.--AttorneyGeneral Cassidy telegraphed to Dr. David Hostetter, of Pittsburg, on Sunday that he wanted to see him at his office in this city at noon today. Dr. Hostetter arrived in this city this morning and was closeted with the Attorney-General for some time.

Banks in this city and elsewhere are making daily application at the Sub-Treasury for five-dollar bills. The supply in Assistant Treasurer Acton's hands is very nearly exhausted, and he is unable to meet the demands in full. Some banks want $10,000 in fives, others $20,000, and one or two have applied for $50,000.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The new street railway just opened here has been largely patronized. This is the first street railway here, although the city has had a population of more than 20,000 for some time.

The funeral of George W. Southwick, one of the oldest letter carriers in this city, who died on Saturday, took place at his late residence, No. 135 East One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, last evening.

LITTLE ROCK, Aug. 31.--Attorney-General Garland arrived here rather unexpectedly yesterday morning. He will return to Washington about Sept. 15. He will leave for his country manor, Heming Hill, 18 or 20 miles from town, to-morrow. The place is almost inaccessible, the surrounding country being thinly settled, and the hunting and fishing are excellent. Mr. Garland has no opinion to express concerning politics.

EMPORIA, Kansas, Aug. 31.--Late this afternoon the Coroner's jury returned a verdict finding that Mr. Walkup came to his death by arsenical poisoning, and that from all the evidence the jurymen believed that the arsenic was administered to him feloniously by his wife, Minnie Wallace Walkup. A warrant has been sworn out for Mrs. Walkup's arrest, and she will have a preliminary hearing to-morrow morning.

Much anxiety has been expressed of late in regard to the position of the National Administration in the State canvass. Gov. HILL'S followers have tried to make it appear that his candidacy is in favor with the powers at Washington, but with indifferent success, or rather with no success whatever.
ST. PAUD, Minn., Aug. 31.--Bristol McArthur, printers and binders, made an assignment late on Saturday night for the benefit of their creditors. Their liabilities are $25,000 and the assets $35,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 31.--The oven room of S.S. Marvin Co.'s steam bakery on Liberty-street was the scene of a natural gas explosion this morning, by which five persons were terribly burned, two of them, it is thought, fatally.

BOSTON, Aug. 31.--Prof. George F. Moore, D.D., has declined to accept the Presidency of Marietta College, Ohio, recently tendered to him by the Trustees of that institution, on the ground that his duty is to the work he has undertaken at Andover.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 31.--Reports to the Troy Times show that the heavy rainfall of August greatly injured the potato crop. Farmers say many hills do not contain a potato, and everywhere is heard complaints of rot.

More people were in the Hotel Brunswick yesterday than at any other time this Summer. They were workmen, however, who were putting the finishing touches to the place preparatory to its reopening to-day.
IRONTON, Ohio, Aug. 31.--In Texas Hollow, 13 miles from here, W.E. Booth, on Saturday night made an ineffectual attempt to kill two women and killed himself.

The Metropolitan players are in poor luck. They outbatted the Athletic Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday and played a better game in the field, and their defeat can be attributed to nothing but bad luck. Mathew's delivery was hit safely eight times for a total of 12 bases and four men went to their base on errors, but, strange to say, only one of these men succeeded in tallying a run.
SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The earnings at Sing Sing Prison for the month of August were $19,924 46, and the expenditures $13,919 97. making a profit of $6,004 49.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--Seventy-five men who have been in the employ of the Superintendent of Repairs at the Government building were paid off to-day.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31.--A free fight which took place in the German and Polish Synagogue yesterday at the annual meeting for the election of officers has been the talk of the town to-day. DES MOINES, Aug. 31.--Just before the death of D.F. Call, Professor of Greek at the Iowa State University, he was given a vacation for the Fall term on account of his health, and his sister, Miss Leona Call, had been designated to take his chair ad interim. The Trustees have continued the arrangement and Miss Call has accepted, with an excellent prospect that she will be regularly installed as Professor.

NORTHPORT, Long Island, Aug. 31.--The body of Lawrence Lapeer, who was drowned Saturday, was found late this evening by men who had been grappling for it all day.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31.--Henderson pitched a good game against the Brooklyn Club to-day, but he was miserably supported and the visitors won with ease. Sommer made two costly errors at third base, and Traffley mined a ball that let in 2 runs.

MADRID, Aug. 31.--The Spanish Government has forwarded to Germany a copy of an agreement, signed three years ago by the native chiefs, in which they recognize the sovereignty of Spain over the Caroline Islands.

MADRID, Aug. 31.--There were 3,833 new cases of cholera and 1,248 deaths reported throughout Spain yesterday. The statistics for the past week show roughly that there was a daily average decrease of 300 new cases and 140 deaths. In Granada and Saragossa this decrease was most notable, while in Madrid and Barcelona there was no change. In Palencia, Toledo, and Zamora there was an increase in the number of new cases and deaths.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31.--The series of polo matches for pairs were ended to-day and A. Rutherford and Elliott Roosevelt were the winnets, beating W.K. Thorn and C. Oliver Iselin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31.--Edward B. Graul, chief steward of a restaurant in this city, shot Mrs. Lily Crowser, of Oakland, Cal., last night because she refused to marry him, and then sent a bullet through his own head. The woman is not expected to live. Graul died this morning.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 31.--A destructive haiistorm, whose area was confined in width to about one mile and which extended across the town from the southwest to the northeast, prevailed for half an hour between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning.
DUBLIN, Sept. 1.--Teller Moriarty, of the Hibernian Bank, has absconded. He is guilty of a defalcation of $10,000. A warrant has been issued for his arrest.
The annual Fall regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club will be sailed on Wednesday. Sept. 30. The main course will be from the club anchorage at Port Morris, around Gangway Buoy, and return.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 31.--A neighbor of Mrs. Hannah Gibson, a widow who lived alone in Plymouth, white on his way to catch an early train Friday morning found Mrs. Gibson's house burned to the ground and the body of that lady in the ruins. It is thought that Walter Paine, an insane nephew of Mrs. Gibson, set the house on fire. He was taken to the insane hospital at Augusta this morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--Helen Coon, an octoroon, living at No. 4,644 Butterfield-street, died from starvation and exposure early this morning. She was considered very eccentric by her neighbors, upon whom she depended entirely for food, but refused to partake of any offered during the last three or four days. She had $300 on deposit in one of the banks of the city.

Sunday night and all day yesterday New-Yorkers began coming in from the different Summer resorts, and the express and baggagemen were kept bush in looking after the personal effects of the returning travelers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31.--Chief Clerk Pickerell, of the Railroad Bureau, has returned from a tour of inspection of the Central and Union Pacific Railroads, the Rock Island and Pacific, the Sioux City and Pacific Railroad, and other lines. So far as accounts are concerned little attention was devoted to the condition of ...
COLUMBUS, Aug. 31.--The Ohio State Fair opened to-day, but the crush of exhibitors was such that beyond the putting in place of the vast number of exhibits little was done.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 31.--The report that Vanderbilt has entered into an arrangement with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company by which the latter is to have practical control of the tonnage traffic of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Road is ...
LONDON, Aug. 31.--Sir Michael HicksBeach will open the electoral campaign at Cirencester on Sept. 15. The yacht Sunbeam, with Mr. Gladstone and party on board, arrived at Wick, Scotland, to-day.

UTICA, Aug. 31.--The Republican city committee voted this evening to hold primaries in the 12 wards of Utica Wednesday, Sept. 2. for the choice of delegates to the County and District Conventions. The call will be published to-morrow morning. The delegates to be chosen to the County Convention will nominate a candidate for the State Senate, candidates for County ...

Charles F. Holtz is a member of the firm of Holtz Koenecke, wine merchants, of No. 349 Broadway, New-York, and in a long, prosperous business career he has accumulated a fortune estimated at a million.

NEWBURG, Aug. 31.--Train No. 55 on the West Shore Railroad, known as the Pacific express and due at Catskill at 12:25 A.M., ran off the track at Rightmyer's Fill, two miles south of Catskill, a little after midnight this morning.

"Yes," said he, "I have seen the statement, which is credited to Mr. R. Stewart, formerly General Manager of this company, that the company is losing not less than $50,000 a month.

NEW-BRIGHTON, Penn., Aug. 31.--As Chief Kennedy was passing up Broadway last evening, near the residence of Dr. White, in the vicinity of the Souerbeck Hotel, he was told by the bartender that there was a disturbance at the bar.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 31.--More than 100 representatives of Rhode Island's manufacturing and business interests met in Lyceum Hall this afternoon. The call for the meeting was issued in response to the circular recently issued by the Secretary of the Treasury.
NEWSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The following was published in the Poughkeepsie NewsPress this morning under the head of "The Johns-Steinberg marriage":
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 31.--The Third National Bank, of this city, to-day increased its capital stock from $120,000 to $200,000. Nearly all the new stock is held by Northern capitalists.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 31.--An effort is being made to arrange a match between Harry Wilkes and Clingstone, to take place at Home wood, near this city, at an early date, the stakes to be the same as in the Wilkes-Phallas race.

Col. E. Livingston Price, of Newark, whose wife is suing him for alimony and support in the New-Jersey Court of Chancery, filed his answer to his wife's complaint yesterday. He denied that he had squandered the estate his father left him in riotous living, but insisted that he had spent it in gratifying his wife's desires.

Senator Daly, the author of the Underground Wire bills, sat between Commissioners Loew and Moss at the meeting of the Electric Subway Commission, in its new rooms, No. 23 West Twenty-third-street, yesterday, and listened to the descriptions given by different inventors of their systems for burying wires. Dr. Norwin Green, President of the Western Union ...

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31.--The Eastern yacht squadron arrived this evening, after a disagreeable experience in the run from NewBedford. The signal for the start was given at 1 o'clock, a majority of the yachts getting well away together.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 31.--The schooner Emily F. Northam arrived to-day with three of the crew of the schooner Gustie Wilson, from New-York, which foundered off Hatteras in a hurricane on Aug. 26. Mate A.L. Pettingill, of Portland, Me.; Daniel Curne, seaman, of Middletown, Conn., and J. Click, the colored cook, of Boston, were lost. Capt. Thomas Crapo, of NewBedford; Ned Walsh, and Charles Wickland, ...

BOSTON, Aug. 31.--John E. Russell, Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture, who was selected to preside at the Democratic State Convention, declines to serve. In his letter, to be published in the morning, he explains his position, and also takes occasion to express his views upon national politics and the tone which, in his judgment, the convention should take.

Maria Louise Beebe, of Quogue, Long Island, who is President of the Young Women's Christian Association, filed plans yesterday with Superintendent D'Oench for an association building and chapel to be erected at No. 7 East Fifteenth-street. It will post $100,000, be five stories high, and have an area of 75 by 100 feet. R.H. Robertson is the architect.

Bets are freely offered on the Puritan, but, except in insignificant sums, they find no takers. One Wall-street man has had $5,000 in his hands for at least a week to bet on the Yankee sloop, but up to last evening had not been able to place it. There was some talk yesterday among Wall-street men of cabling to an English gentleman, who, it is said, was chiefly instrumental in persuading Sir Richard ...

For the past three years Mrs. Caroline Gammen, a woman of about 35 years of age and the wife of a carpenter of No. 144 Ewen-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, has been suffering from rheumatism in the head, and at times has ...

Gen. Charles P. Stone, engineer-in-chief of the pedestal of the Bartholdi statue, has submitted his report to the Executive Committee of the progross of his work since its beginning. After going into the early history of the excavations for the structure, he says:

In the September number of the Century Magazine, which is Published to-day, is printed the promised paper by Gen. Grant on "The Siege of Vicksburg." This is the second of the four papers written by Gen. Grant for the Century, the first being the one on Shilob, which was published in the February number.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31.--Joseph and Jacob Tobler, two negroes, were arrested yesterday near Eufaula, Indian Territory, for the murder of Messrs. Goodykoontz and Cass, two prominent merchants of Vinita, near the Sac and Fox Agency on Aug. 18. They were taken to Vinita, where they confessed the crime. They will be taken to Fort Smith.
QUEBEC, Aug. 31.--The Colorado beetle has caused great havoc among the potato vines in this neighborhood, and the crop is expected to be a light one.

The first public sale of lumber in the yards of the New-York Lumber Auction Company, on the North River, foot of West Twentythird-street, occurred yesterday morning. The lumber was sold in lots of 5,000 feet and over, and the sales aggregated 500,000 feet.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1.--The ceremony of laying the cornerstone of the statue to the memory of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry, of Lake Erie fame, was performed this morning with all the pomp and ritual of the Grand Lodge of Masons. The statue is now beside the base, and will be placed in position to-morrow.
Mr. Harrigan opened his new theatre last evening with every promise of a successful career. The house was crowded, the actors were warmly welcomed, and the play received approval.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--It is learned from good authority that at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Northwestern Railway Company, held in Saratoga a day or two ago, at which Mr. W.H. Vanderbilt and President Keep and Vice-Presidents Hughitt ...

During one of the hottest days of last Summer a woman who said she was Mary Tildeman, 29 years old, visited Mayor Low, of Brooklyn, accompanied by a well-dressed gentleman, and asked the Mayor to marry them, which he did.

The reason why the Directors of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad reduced the dividend on the preferred stock has been an interesting subject of conjecture in Wall-street. Officers of the company authorized the following statement yesterday:
After a number of inquiries among lumbermen we find that, although there is no quotable rise in prices, the feeling is everywhere one of firmness with an impression that any change must be upward.

In response to the invitation of Capt. Dean La Banta, the organizer of Company C, Twelfth Regiment, known as the "Temperance Phalanx," several gentlemen met at his residence, No. 125 East Sixteenth-street, last evening, for the purpose of organizing a bureau for simultaneously introducing the temperance ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 1.--The Grand Trunk has issued from its division office in this city a circular addressed to agents of the Erie, which says that "an arrangement has been arrived at between our respective companies to discontinue the payment of commissions on and after Sept. 1."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1.--In the United States District Court to-day a preliminary hearing was had on the complaint of Postmaster Gardner against Albert E. Bosworth, Treasurer of the Stafford Mills, Fall River, for the sending of an obscene letter through the mails addressed to a lady of eminent respectability residing in this city in May last.

PAUL SMITH'S, ST. REGIS LAKE, Sept. 1.-- President Cleveland and Dr. Ward left the Prospect House yesterday afternoon and remained here last night. They left this morning at 10 o'clock. They will remain at the Stevens House, Lake Placid, to-night, stopping briefly en route. They will take a train at Westport on Saturday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 1.--The analysis recently ordered on the body of Stephen L. Butler, of Torrington, shows that he died a natural death. This is the case where the body was exhumed and an attempt made to throw suspicion of arsenical poisoning upon the widow of the deceased.

There have been more guesses made in regard to the Twin City Handicap than any other race since the Suburban was decided in the Spring, and there were so many "sure winners" cropping out from unexpected places that it became somewhat be wildering to the average ...

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 1.--The Boston players defeated the Providence men to-day on a single hit and costly errors by Shaw, Irwin, Radford, and Gilligan. Shaw pitched in fine form, but he was poorly supported at critical points.

Capt. Baas, of the ship Sarah Hignett, which arrived yesterday from Iloilo, reports that he passed through a terrific hurricane last week when below Cape Hatteras. On Aug. 25, in latitude 33 30' and longitude 72 30', the sky became overcast and the wind blew strongly.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 1.--An Indian Territory special says the removal of cattle from the Cheyenne and Arapahoe Reservation is progressing as rapidly as the conditions will permit. Several of the largest cattle owners have removed their entire herds, excepting such stock as escaped the recent round-up.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1.--The Government Examining Board made the first of their visits of a three days' inspection of the torpedo stations in this harbor to-day. On the launch that threaded its way among the many yachts in the harbor were Commodore Lewis A. Kimberly, ...

ALBANY, Sept. 1.--The list of those Democrats who have been kindly mentioned in connection with the Gubernatorial nomination is not quite so formidable as that on the Republican side. It includes these gentlemen:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--The Washington indorsers of Judd, the ex-Colorado Agent of the Bureau of Labor Statistics were much elated today by the receipt of a letter from Denver. It was from Judd himself, and announced his acquittal of all charges.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 1.--At Carthage, Moore County, Benjamin Cole, white, aged 70, was to-day sentenced to be hanged on Sept. 30. His crime was poisoning his wife, who was a sister of Solicitor of the District James S. McIver.

BUFFALO, Sept. 1.--The September interest on the second mortgage bonds of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia, due yesterday, was not paid. At the Farmers and Mechanics' Bank, in this city, the depository designated by the Trustees, the money to pay the interest, $17,500, had not been received.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--The following is a recapitulation of the debt statement issued today. (New form:)

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 1.--Patrick Mullens and Daniel Donovan, section hands, were instantly killed this morning by being run over by an engine on the Rock Island Railroad. Two others were seriously injured. The engineer is under arrest on a charge of criminal carelessness.

The Brooklyn baseball nine won an uninteresting game from the Metropolitan team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Mets started the game in a brilliant manner. By good batting they tallied 3 runs in the first inning.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 1.--The river coal miners met at Monongahela City to-day and decided to strike next Friday unless the operators concede them 3 cents per bushel for mining.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--S.W. Carey, 23 years old, who lives with a family named Kelly at No. 153 Huron-street, and John Cooley, a worthless fellow, with no known place of abode, fell into a dispute at noon to-day in the back part of Dennis Cavanagh's saloon, in Clark-street.

KANKAKEE, Ill., Sept. 1.--The epidemic of Texas fever which appeared on the farm of Hiram Goodwin, of Rockville Township, last week, threatens to devastate his entire herd of over 200 cattle. Twenty-five have already died, and a dozen more in a dying condition.

A Parliamentary return (navy, ships built) was issued yesterday, showing the amount of shipping--tons weight of hull--estimated for and calculated to have been actually built from the year 1865-6 to the last financial year.

Commissioners French, Porter, and McClave, of the Police Board, held a meeting yesterday. They received a formal request from Capt. Williams that his name be forwarded to the Civil Service Board for examination as to his qualifications for the office of Inspector of Police, with a view to his promotion to that office. The request was granted by the Commissioners, who passed a resolution to that effect.

G.B. McCoy, Clerk in the General Sessions Court, discovered his boy playing with a five-dollar bill yesterday and asked him where he got it. "It's no good," the boy said; "Joe McGiveny has got a lot of them."

DUXBURY, Mass., Sept. 1.--The steamer Minia, Capt. Trott, has picked up both ends of the French cable of 1869, and will probably make the final splice to-night. This cable was broken about the middle of June.

Hundreds of plays are written every year, but very few of them ever get as far as the stage. Writers who have been industriously filling managers' pigeon-holes or waste baskets and who are not too proud to accept instruction will be glad to know that Mr. JOAQUIN MILLER is ready and willing to teach, although, as ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--The General Freight Agents of the roads running east from this city were unable at their meeting to-day to come to any agreement respecting the present demoralization in freight rates, and the impression is that the trouble is likely to continue for some time.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 1.--James Anthony, a member of the Board of Health, predicts that there will be 2,000 more cases of smallpox here, as the place where the cases were discovered is the worst pest spot in the city.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 1.--Collector Theodore D. Jervey took charge of the Charleston Custom House to-day. The formal transfer was made by retiring Collector Johnston. Deputy Collector Ostendorff resigned, and Capt. Legare J. Walker took his place. Upon retiring Collector Johnston was presented with a hand some gold-headed cane by the employes under his administration.

The Police Mutual Aid Association met on Monday to take action relative to suspending collections in the association until something definite is arrived at as to the proper manner and legal way of putting into force and operation the Police Relief Fund act.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--The new buildings of the Veterinary Department of the Pennsylvania University were opened this morning without ceremonies. The first patient was a bay mare afficted with lameness. It was accommodated with a stall in one of the stables, ...

ALBANY, Sept. 1.--The Prohibition County Convention nominated the following ticket this afternoon: For Senator--Levi Dederick, of Albany; for Sheriff--Robert Campbell, of Cohoes; for member of Assembly, Second District --Henry Baxter; Third District--Charles Parsons; Fourth District--Wesley Miller.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Sept. 1.--Last Fall Alexander Easterby and wife disappeared mysteriouly from the neighborhood of Effingham, a village seven miles from here, and no trace of them was discovered until to-day, ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--At a meeting of the Iroquois Club this evening Mr. F.W. Bleike, from the committee to invite the American Free Trade League to hold its next conference in Chicago, and to tender the members the hospitality ...

As Augustus Justus, of Yonkers, was going home about 10 o'clock on Monday night, and while walking along Nepperham-avenue, he was attacked by half a dozen men, who threw stones at him and hit him several times.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--There arrived here yesterday morning a train of 20 cars with 750 bales of compressed wool from Portland, Oregon. This is the largest shipment of wool ever brought here from Oregon, its value being $80,544.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 1.--Yesterday Emma and Mary Vanderhuyden, daughters of John Vanderhuyden, of Glenville, started out in a wagon with David Reynolds for the hop fields. The bridge over a creek had been swept away by the freshets and there was no way to cross but to ford the stream.

Looking as wise as owls on a limb, the members of the Aldermen's Committee on Railroads listened for two hours yesterday to arguments on the proposed horse railroad on Thirty-second and Thirty-third streets from river to river. There was the belligerent Alderman Cleary, who is Chairman of ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--The assignment papers of the Current have been filed in the County Court, together with a schedule of assets and liabilities. The liabilities are fixed at $4,944 and the assets, consisting principally of material and office furniture, at $8,680.
We published yesterday morning the resolutions of an important convention of Rhode Island manufacturers and business men against any attempt to revise the tariff at the coming session of Congress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--Mr. D.P. Negley learned to-day that in order to establish the charge against Judge Aleck Boarman, of Louisiana, of undue intimacy with Mrs. Negley, it would be necessary, in this State, to substantiate ...

The letter of Mr. JOHN E. RUSSELL declining to preside over the Democratic Convention of Massachusetts is worthy of more than a passing notice, for it points the way, not only for the Democrats of his own State, but for the party generally, to the only ground on which ...
The northern parlor of the Murray Hill Hotel took the semblance yesterday of the shrine of a secret society. The doors were draped with a friendship garland of seven links.

Miss Ella Holtz, the second victim of Druggist Charles G. Am Ende's carelessness, died at her home in Hoboken just before 2 o'clock yesterday morning. Early in the evening she had partially recovered consciousness, but soon after midnight she sank into a slumber that easily passed into coma.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 1.--The Board of Trustees of Vassar College held another meeting at the college this morning for the purpose of electing a President of the college and for the transaction of other business.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 1.--Last Winter the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad system broke out of the Southern cotton pool, and for some weeks there was fear that the Southern Railway and Steamship Association would be disorganized.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 1.--Several months ago the emoloyes of the Lackawanna and Pittsburg Railway succeeded in getting some of their back pay by a strike. Probably encouraged by this the men struck again on Monday night, and not a car has been moved since.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for the excursion to-morrow of the women and children of the east side tenement house districts to the number of about 10,000. A fleet of vessels will leave the pier at the foot of East Thirty-second-street at 9 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--John Peckler, a saloon keeper in Jackson-street, realized this afternoon that he was not making money, and he straightway tried to commit suicide by shooting himself in the right temple.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1.--The State Board of Equalization met at noon to-day, listened to complaints from Kings, New-York, and Schoharie Counties, and adjourned until Sept. 29, when the equalized tables will be submitted.

There are some circumstances attending the killing of TOM DAVIS, the gambler and sharper, which are worthy the serious consideration of Inspector MURRAY and the Police Department generally. It is undisputed that the rascal kept several headquarters in this city entirely devoted to swindling.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--Senator William J. Sewell, of New-Jersey, is expected to arrive in New-York to-morrow, after an absence of three months in Europe. He sailed from Antwerp on Aug. 22, on the steamer Noordland, which is due to-day or to-morrow. Elaborate preparations are being made in Camden to give the returning statesman a rousing welcome.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 1.--To-morrow the cornerstone for the new Capitol of Georgia will be laid with imposing Masonic ceremonies. The oration will be delivered by Gen. A.R. Lawton, who was appointed Minister to Russia by President Cleveland. The building is being built of oolitic stone, will cost $1,000,000, and will be completed in four years.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 1.--To-day the cotton mills at Woodberry, four in number, giving employment to upward of 2,000 operatives, are making arrangements to go to work on full time. The Meadow Mill, which has been idle for a year, will start to-day with a full force--600-- and on full time. The Woodberry, Clapper, and Park Mills and the Druid Mill will be run on full time on Monday next, as will also the Mount Vernon Mill.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1.--The conduct of the Government in delaying the payment of the balance due to the Ninth Battalion is likely to prove very detrimental to the volunteer movement in Quebec. Many members of the battalion and other city corps openly declare that when their time is up they and their friends, if they can influence them, will never serve the Dominion under arms again.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1.--To-day the Canadian Pacific Railway Company paid over to the Government the $5,000,000 which was loaned them last session on the security of $8,000,000 of bonds. Some time ago the Government repaid a large amount which it owed the Bank of Montreal.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Sept. 1.--Martin Archibald, a wealthy farmer, residing in Huntingdon, broke into the house of Mrs. Mary Adams, here, and attempted to outrage her. Her son, arriving on the scene, struck him with an axe and he released his hold, when Mrs. Adams seized the axe, and attacking Archibald, almost severed his head from his body.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 1.--The rehearing of the Riel case was postponed to-day, but will go on to-morrow before the Supreme Court Judges. Every effort is being made by Riel's friends to save him, and an enormous amount of money has been subscribed here and elsewhere for his defense.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--The Board of Trade to-day reinstated W.N. Sturgis and W.M. Day, who a year ago were suspended because of failure to settle business claims.
LONDON, Sept. 1.--Advices from Cabul report that that city is quiet, and that the Ameer has sent large orders to Parsee agents at Bombay for military uniforms and equipments.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 1.--Emil Seitz, proprietor of the Sunlight Knitting Mill, has made an assignment. The preferences are the employes, the Central National Bank of this city, the Oneida National Bank of Utica, James Akin, of Philmont, N.Y.; Emma A. Bunnell and Julia ...

ST.PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1.--Reports received here show that frost prevailed from Fort Garry south to Huron, Dakota, and Moorhead, Minn., but not heavy enough to kill vegetation. There was also slight frost at Fort Buford and Bismarck. The weather is still cold and a heavier frost is feared to-night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--The will of Judge T. Lyle Dickey was admitted to probate to-day by Judge Prendergast. It was written on a sheet of common letter paper, and bears date of Nov. 10 last. By its terms the entire estate of Judge Dickey, which is valued at about $50,000, is given to his widow, who is also made Executrix of the will.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 1.--The last day of the annual meeting of the American Society for the Advancement of Science showed a considerable decrease in the attendance. In general session the Nominating Committee reported officers for the next meeting, who were elected, ...

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--Moses Alexander, a patriarchal man, was before Justice C.J. White to-day for disorderly conduct. Moses is one of a crowd which gathers to mock and jeer prisoners as they are loaded into the Bridewell omnibus at the police stations.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 1.--North Manchester, about nine miles from Hartford, came near being the scene of a riot last night. Some time ago the Selectmen appointed Daniel O'Conners a special constable against the wishes of very many people who considered him entirely unfit for the position.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1.--The interest of the Wabash employes now awaiting the decision of the committees and their coming conference with Manager Talmadge is centered or transferred to a side issue at St. Charles. A.C. Coughlan, of the Wabash committee, visited that ...

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 1.--Until a few months ago there were two towns called Whitaker's in this State, one in the eastern section and one in Cleveland County. This fact was the cause of mixing up of freight and mail, and at last it was decided that one of the Whitakers had to go.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--The Reading and Lehigh Valley Railroad Companies admit that it is utterly impossible to even maintain rates of coal so long as the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western refuses to enter upon a restriction in production.
MADRID, Sept. 1.--There were 3,669 new cases of cholera and 1,120 deaths from the disease reported yesterday throughout Spain.
Miss Lottie Stamler, daughter of Mrs. Jacob A. Stamler, was united in marriage last evening to Mr. Paul Paquet at St. George's Church, in Stuyvesant-square.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 1.--In Cassia County, Idaho, last Saturday, Chief Justice Hayes affirmed the constitutionality of the Territorial election law prescribing the antipolygamy test oath. This will largely reduce the Mormon vote.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 1.--Much discussion is caused in local railway circles by the report that there is a scheme on foot in NewYork to form a combination between the Northern Pacific and the Rock Island, ...

When Ferdinand Ward appeared for examination in the court room of the General Term yesterday his face showed the effects of a summering at the Ludlow-Street Jail. Its lack of color was in conspicuous contrast with the skin of Referee Hamilton Cole, which has been bronzed on his Claverack farm up the Hudson, ...

MONTREAL, Sept. 1.--The Trustees of the Polish and German Synagogue met this morning to discuss the disgraceful fracas which took place on Sunday. The meeting was private, but it was learned that the Board of Trustees passed resolutions condemning the action of Mr. Goldstone on Sunday and expelled him from the ...
VIENNA, Sept. 1.--Ludwig Restter, a cloth merchant of Brunn, has failed. His liabilities amount to $100,000.

Mme. Tillard, wife of an ex-Lieutenant of the French Army, lived with her husband at No. 159 Christopher-street. When he came home on Monday night from his business he found his wife lying on a bed, evidently suffering much pain. He found that she had been shot in the neck. The woman was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, where the doctors declared her wound serious.

READING, Penn., Sept. 1.--The arbitration between the molders and employers of the stove foundry of Orr, Painter Co., in this city, has led to the granting of a 10 per cent. increase in wages. The molders will go to work to-morrow. This advance will govern a number of other stove firms in Eastern Pennsylvania who have an understanding as to a uniform rate of wages.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 1.--At Dayton, Washington Territory, on Sunday, Mrs. Ora A. Bowen, an aged widow, while fighting fire in the woods which threatened to destroy her home, was burned to death. Her clothing caught fire and she was horribly burned, her hands, face, and feet being reduced to a crisp. When discovered she was lifeless and charred beyond recognition.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1.--Mr. Higgins has had little to say for some time. But he has kept up considerable thinking, and has at last come out with some decided opinions on civil service reform. "I cannot pick up this book without finding some flaw in it," said Mr. Higgins to a Post reporter, who discovered him yesterday reading a copy of the civil service regulations.

The Stock List Committee of the Stock Exchange decided yesterday to list the certificates issued by Drexel, Morgan Co. in exchange for West Shore bonds. It took the greater part of the day to arrange details, and the decision of the committee will probably be officially announced this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--Thomas L. Huggard, Cashier of the broken Shackamaxon Bank, appeared before Magistrate Lennon today to answer the charge of conspiring with George W. and William Bumm and Samuel P. Milligan to embezzle the funds of the bank.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--Judge Lambert Tree, of this city, the new Minister to Belgium, who will depart for his post in a few days, will leave behind him a memento of considerable interest to the members of the Police and Fire Departments.

BOSTON, Sept. 1.--A quarrel at the breakfast table in a sailor's boarding house this morning over a trivial matter resulted in the murder of a negro, one of the boarders, by a white woman, the housekeeper. The house is known as "Dave" Hennessy's and is at No. 168 Northstreet, in the old North End.

The following appointments were yesterday announced by the Mayor of Brooklyn: Assessors--Benjamin W. Wilson, reappointed, and David S. Arnott, in place of Benjamin B. Hopkins. Park Commissioners--George W. Alexander, of the Ninth Ward, in place of ...
