Gernsheim, and J.W. Paramore state that they have become a committee to protect the interests of such holders of ...

Not since the Australian eleven of cricketers played on the St. George's Ground, in Hoboken, some years ago, has there been such a large throng of spectators at a cricket match as that which assembled on the Staten Island Cricket Grounds yesterday.

Recent publications on the subject of cocaine and the various therapeutic uses to which it can be put have caused a widespread demand for this valuable drug. This increased demand for cocaine is a source of marked satisfaction among all the druggists because, like everything also which is new and valuable, it commands a large price and insures a handsome profit.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 1.--At about 8 o'clock last evening Charles V. Sweet, of No. 205 Pavonia-avenue, Jersey City, found in Prospect Park, near the brink of Niagara Falls, a man's blue coat. Receipts and other papers indicated that it belonged to Chauncey Hough, of Batavia.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 1.--At 6 o'clock last evening Felix McGovern was walking on the Hudson River Railroad track at Dutchess Junction. A passenger train came behind him and killed him. The train was stopped and the body was picked up. The Coroner held an inquest to-day. A verdict was rendered in accordance with the facts.

LITTLETON, N.H., Sept. 1.--The annual meeting of the United States Hay Fever Association was opened this afternoon in Bethlehem. Remarks relative to remedies for hay fever, which have been used with more or less success, were made by the Rev. John Peacock, of Holmesburg, Penn.; H.S. Dewey, of Brooklyn; Prof. Lockword, of Freehold, N.J.; Dr. Westbrook, of Philadelphia, and Mr. Van Voorhis, of New-York. The officers will be chosen next Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--The Illinois Central and Michigan Central Railroads are considering plans for the erection of a new union passenger station, to take the place of the present ruin at the foot of Lake-street.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1.--The Detroits opened their final series with the Maroons to-day in the presence of a very small crowd. The defeat of the home club places it at the tail end in the League race.

John R. Brown writes to THE TIMES from Kansas City in regard to a news article published on Aug. 26 which related the legal troubles of Mr. Brown over his son, whom the decree of the Kansas City court gave to the custody of Miss Brush, of Huntington, Long Island, ...

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1.--A petition is being quietly circulated among influential members of the Cincinnati Conference of the Methodist Church, asking for an investigation of the conduct of the Rev. Dr. Leonard, the Prohibition candidate for Governor, and Pastor of the Central Church of Springfield.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Sept. 1.--"I am the oldest man in the employ of the two biggest corporations in this country," said Isaac Fisher, 80 years old, to a reporter to-day. "One is the United States Government itself and the other is the Pennsylvania Railroad Company."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 1.--A great sensation was created two months ago by a series of eight or ten bold burglaries in rapid succession. The series closed with two particularly brilliant efforts. One was at the residence of Charles Ray, the millionaire banker, who was called out of bed and compelled to get out all of his valuables by a polite masked stranger.

NYACK, Sept. 1.--A Democratic politician of Piermont was sent to the county jail at New City yesterday for 40 days. John Burns is the man's name and he is a member of the Democratic Town Committee of Orangetown.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 1.--Government Inspector Armstrong has just returned from an inspection of the Indian Agencies in Arizona. He reports that among the residents of that Territory all fears of further Indian depredations have disappeared; that the Apaches at the San Carlos Agency have raised a large crop of grain this year and are peaceable and contented.

The patriarch of politics in Kentucky is ex-Gov. and ex-United States Senator John W. Stevenson, of Covington. At the New-York Hotel last night he remarked that the next contest for United States Senator in Kentucky will be the most remarkable struggle ever known in ...
GREENSBURG, Ind., Sept. 1.--Sheriff Walsh, Marshal Clemans, and two assistants started yesterday in a carriage to find and arrest Barney Connor, a desperado. The first two were armed with shotguns.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 1.--Edmond T. Maines, a traveling salesman for Cowan, McClurg Co.'s large wholesale dry goods house in this city, was found this morning at about 11 o'clock at White Spring, one mile east of here, with an ugly bullet hole through his head.

MADRID, Sept. 1.--Mr. John W. Foster, the American Minister, spent a fortnight at the Royal Palace of La Granja de San Ildefonso. He had frequent interviews with Senor Elduayen, Minister of Foreign Affairs, on the subject ...

The Civil Service Board of the customs service of this city will examine candidates for positions as openers and packers in the Appraiser's office at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning in the Post Office Building.

Mrs. Emma Sands failed to appear in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, in obedience to an order directing her to submit to examination respecting the manner in which she became possessed of certain securities standing ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 1.--The Chronicle to-night exposes a scheme by which the county poor fund has been robbed since the 1st of January last of probably $10,000 by Thomas McGrath, one of the Poor Directors, with the connivance of storekeepers throughout the county.

Three girls and one man are kept busy in the office of the Grant Monument Association in mailing circulars and subscription lists to bankers, manufacturers, and prominent persons in all parts of the country.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 1, via Galveston. --The General Managership of the Mexican Central Railway was transferred to-day by Manager Robinson to Edward W. Jackson, until recently General Superintendent of the Vera Cruz Railway. Mr. Jackson started this morning on a tour of inspection over the entire line to the Texas border.

We yesterday called attention to Mr. CLIFFORD LLOYD'S letter in the London Times, in which he proposes that both the Viceroyalty and the Secretaryship for Ireland shall be abolished. About the propriety of abolishing the viceroyalty there can be no dispute.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1.--Mr. J.A. St. John, of this city, has mailed to the Turf, Field and Farm a proposition which is intended to bring together in a grand race all the leading scullers of the country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1.--Warm weather has returned. Among to-day's arrivals were Commodores Batchellor and Kimberly, of the Navy; Jose De Pedroso, of Washington, and H. J. Desalis and C.F. Desalis, of England. Among the cottagers entertaining to-day were Mrs. J. C. Ayer, Mrs. Francis Parkman Freeman, Mrs. George R. Fearing, Mrs. John Carter Brown and Edgerton L. Winthrop.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 1.--The work of loading the United States steamship Swatara with silver coin from the Mint began yesterday morning under the personal supervision of the Special Treasury Agents, Messrs. Mubleman, Forsyth, and McKellden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--John T. Morgan, Jr., son of Senator Morgan, of Alabama, and a lady, whose name cannot yet be learned, went up the river to-night in a canoe and when near the chain bridge were caught in a squall, the canoe overturned and both were drowned. The bodies have not yet been recovered.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1.--The opening day of the Grand Central Circuit meeting at Narragansett Park was very successful. The attendance was fair, the track in splendid shape, and though the weather was remarkably pleasant it was a little too cool for very fast work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--During the temporary absence of the clerk in Bateman Co.'s bank on F-street this afternoon a sneak thief stole $1,135 from the till of the Cashier's desk. A short, stout man was seen to leave the bank hurriedly, but at the time only a passing glance was given him.

The following letter indorsing the plan for the absorption of the West Shore by the New-York Central Railroad Company has been received by a gentleman in this city from Pool Commissioner Albert Fink, who is taking a short vacation in Switzerland:

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 1.--About 60 members of the political branch of the Workingmen's Assembly of New-York met in annual session in Rome to-day. George Blair, Chairman, called the meeting to order and delivered a lengthy address, in which he congratulated the members upon the passage of the life and limb law and mechanics' lien law, urged by the workingmen, and stated that the Child Labor ...

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--The annual statement, out to-day, shows the net income of the St. Paul and Duluth Railroad Company, which now operates 225 miles of main line and 55 miles of side tracks, for the fiscal years ending June 30, 1884 and 1885, was as follows:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1.--Robert Bonner's celebrated mare Maud S. will attempt to beat her record of 2:08 at Narragansett Park on Thursday afternoon. The trial will be for a cup given by the Narragansett Park Association.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 1.--The commercial year which closed last evening does not present for Galveston the brilliant array of growing figures which she has exhibited in years past. The great falling off in the cotton crop of last season has noticeably affected all branches of the city's commerce.

Of the 2,332 Presidential Postmasters in the United States, changes have been made in 487 cases since the adjournment of the Senate. A list of nominations for these offices is now being made at the Post Office Department to receive the signature of the President and be transmitted to the Senate upon the beginning of the next session.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 1.--The trial of the Rev. H.D. Jardine, Rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church, of this city, before an ecclesiastical court on charges of immorality and personal misconduct was resumed to-day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--Judge Prendergast to-day decided the demurrer in the Smith-Harrison contest for the Mayoralty, overruling it in some points and sustaining it in others. He held that the court had jurisdiction and that many of the objections of Harrison's counsel were frivolous and untenable.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1.--Forty-four cases of smallpox were reported at the Health Office yesterday, of which 24 were authenticated. There were 14 deaths from the disease in the city during the day. There are 10 cases in one house called "Noah's Ark."

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 1.--Dr. George W. Curry, one of the best known of the young men of Red Bank, went into French's wholesale liquor store early last evening and asked to see William Stephens, the bookkeeper.

HARTFORD, Sept. 1.--Last Fall a fire which destroyed a wooden structure around the family tomb of ex-Gov. Morgan, of NewYork, in Cedar Hill Cemetery, this city, destroyed also the costly marble work of the tomb itself, which workmen were at the time putting in place.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 1.--A great many French Canadians employed in Cohoes and this vicinity have been swindled by a person who gives different names and who claims to be a lawyer from Joliet, in the Province of Quebec.

DUBLIN, Sept. 1.--A banquet was given by the Lord Mayor at the Mansion House this evening in honor of Mr. Parnell and his Irish colleagues in the House of Commons. There were 300 guests present exclusive of the members of Parliament.

Mrs. Ann Curry, who is 50 years of age, has suffered for two years with malignant cancer of the abdomen. She consulted several physicians of this city, and all said the trouble was cancer, but none of them would undertake to perform an operation for its removal.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 1.--"There is as much superstition in New-England to-day as there was in those old times when they slashed Quakers and built bonfires for witches." It was a NewYork man who gave expression to this rather startling statement.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 1.--The National Convention of Masonic Boards of Relief resumed its session to-day at Masonic Temple. It is learned that the Committee on Organization reported in favor of organizing permanently for the purpose of facilitating the exposure of persons ...

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1.--The Sheriff of Dauphin County, in which court the AttorneyGeneral has filed his bill asking an injunction against the transfer of the South Pennsylvania Railroad to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, appeared in this city ...
A policeman was placed on each car that ran over the new cable road on Tenth-avenue yesterday to keep the crowd off. From early morning until late in the afternoon only four cars were in operation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1.--Major Charles W. Foster, Quartermaster, has been appointed to act as inspector on certain subsistence stores at St. Louis, reported upon by a board of survey as requiring the action of an inspector, and for which Lieut.-Col. Amos Beckwith, Assistant Commissary-General of Subsistence, Purchasing and Depot Commissary of Subsistence, is responsible.
The question having been raised whether the 70-year age limit applied to Surrogates, the matter was taken into the courts by the Westchester County authorities to get a judicial opinion.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1.--Edwin Booth and his daughter have just placed in the Episcopal church at Middletown a memorial window to mark their affection for the deceased wife of the actor. Its measurement is 13 by 9 feet, and critics declare it one of the most perfect windows, especially in regard to colors, they have ever seen.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 1.--For months past the internal revenue authorities have been quietly investigating reports regarding the manufacture of crooked whisky in various counties.

Theodore Davis, the "sawdust swindler," who, after seeing his brother "Tom" killed by a Texan whom they were both attempting to defraud Monday afternoon, secured the money over which the trouble occurred before he paid any attention to the dying man, told the story of the shooting in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with many manifestations of grief.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2.--It is stated in political circles to-day that, the Canadian Pacific Railway Company having paid off the loan received from the Government last session, it is...

The requirements of Health Officer SMITH, which were sustained last week by Quarantine Commissioners PLATT and NICHOLS against the vote of Commissioner JUDD in the matter of disinfecting rags, appear in the light of the evidence thus far elicited to be a flagrant outrage upon the importers.

WALLINGFORD, Sept. 2.--It will be weeks before this village will recover from the shock it has experienced to-day. There has been nothing like it since the cyclone of 1878, which carried the Cony House 20 miles over into the Connecticut Valley, and then came back after the clerk.
Miss Clara Morris, supported by Mr. Joseph Wheelock and Miss Bijou Heron, began her Autumn and Winter season at the new Chicago opera house on Monday night. The play was "Article 47."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 2.--A bold train robbery occurred on the Chicago and Alton Railroad to-night, but owing to the sudden fright of the robbers but little booty was secured.
BALTIMORE Sept. 2.--John Peters and James Mooney, prisoners in the State penitentiary in this city, made a desperate attempt to escape this afternoon.

NEWARK, Sept. 2.--An unknown man, apparently about 25 years of age, was struck and killed by the Philadelphia express train at the Chestnut-street station to-night. He attempted to cross the track, when he was struck and hurled 15 feet in the air, alighting on the top of a street lamp. The body was terribly mangled.

There are many indications that the general business of the country is undergoing a change for the better. The demand for dry goods and other goods from the South and Southwest is perceptibly stronger and more confident.

Mrs. Ann Curry, from whose abdomen Dr. Thomas H. Allen extracted an enormous cancer on Tuesday afternoon, died at 4 o'clock yesterday morning at, the Charity Hospital after having survived the operation for 12 hours.

Mr. and Mrs. Jesse R. Grant and Mrs. Sartoris sailed for England yesterday morning an the North German Lloyd steamship Werra. Col. Grant and his wife, Mrs. Ulysses Grant, Mrs. Corbin, Dr. Newman, and a few other friends went down to the vessel to see them off.
Some of the citizens of Kansas City are anxious to have a connecting line of the Missouri Pacific Railroad built from that city to Paola, Kan., a distance of 43 miles.
The Executive Committee of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company gave recommended the payment of a dividend of 1 per cent. on Oct. 1, and the dividend will be paid.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 2.--Since the present Administration got fairly to work the old line Michigan Democrats have been greatly puzzled at the remarkable political strength displayed by young Don M. Dickinson, of Detroit.
DUBLIN, Sept. 2.--Moonlight outrages are on the increase in County Kerry. The houses of two bailiffs were fired into last night by men in disguise, but fortunately no one was injured.

The 10 and 11 o'clock boats of the Staten Island Ferry carried quite a number of passengers yesterday who were evidently going to see the finish of the cricket match between the English amatuer team and the Staten Island twelve. The talk wns all cricket.

ROME, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The political branch of the State Labor Assembly met to-day, and F.F. Donovan, of Brooklyn, was made Chairman; Thomas E. Bankrantz, of Durhamville, Vice-President; John E. Cannon, of Troy, and L.B. Sherman, of Rome, Secretaries, and Samuel McElwee, of Rochester, Treasurer.

A public meeting will be held in Irving Hall to-morrow evening in aid of the sufferers from cholera in Spain. It is expected that the attendance will be large, and Spanish residents of the city are especially invited to be present.

The extra day of the North Hudson Driving Park Association, at Guttenburg, N.J., yesterday, bid fair to be a very dull one until the third heat of the first race. Then it became lively in a very unexpected manner.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--There was considerable hilarity in Postmaster Judd's office to-day when that official found the following among his letters:

United States Senator William J. Sewell, of New-Jersey, returned from Europe yesterday on the steamship Noordland. He had been away for three months, during which he traveled most of the time, visiting England, Ireland, Scotland, France, Austria, and Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2, 1885. Gen. Newton, Chief of Engineers, estimates than an appropriation of about $18,000,000 or $20,000,000 will be required to continue the work of river and harbor improvement during the next fiscal year.
TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 2.--Fred P. Brown, son of one of the largest and best known stock dealers in this county, drew $5,500 from the First National Bank, of this city, last Friday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--The weather has been fair and warm, and the attendance at Washington Park to-day was very good. The track was fast. Following were the events:

STEVENS HOUSE, Lake Placid, N.Y., Sept. 2.--President Cleveland was tendered a reception here last evening, and there was a display of fireworks in his honor. He visited Auchincloss cottage this morning with Dr. Ward, and both left at 11 o'clock to return to Saranac Lake.
ST. JOHN'S New-Foundland, Sept. 2.--The Allen Line mall steamer Hanoverian is a total loss, having gone ashore this morning at Portugal Cove, 14 miles north by west of Cape Race.

Mr. Thomas W. Keene is presenting his impersonation of Richard III. nightly this week at that popular east side theatre, the People's, in tho Bowery. Mr. Keene's audiences are large and moderately enthusiastic.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2.--There is an exodus of Hungarians from the mining regions of this State, which, if kept up much longer, will greatly deplete their numbers, if not remove them all from Pennsylvania.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 2.--A great deal of pressure was brought to bear on Billy Tate, the referee in the Sullivan-McCaffrey contest, yesterday, by friends of McCaffrey to decide in favor of the little Pittsburger. There was such an air of mystery about just what the original articles of agreement were that Mr. Tate during the...

COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 2.--There is a bright outlook here in the knit goods trade. A number of the mills are running until 9 o'clock P.M. filling big orders, which state of affaris promises to continue for some time.

The body of John Ennis, the fireman who was killed while on duty at the chair factory fire in East Sixty-first-street early on Sunday morning, was taken to the Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist, at First-avenue and Fifty-fifth-street, yesterday morning.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 2.--Owing to the low water and the threatened close of navigation on the Missassippi above Winona, the gate of the Government dam at Winnebegoshish Reservoir was raised yesterday morninig and a rise of five feet of water is reported at Brainerd, and

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--The particulars of the tragedy on the Potomac last evening, by which Mr. John H. Morgan, the only son of Senator Morgan, of Alabama, and Mrs. Emma Delta Seta, a lady living at No. 2,116 G-street, northwest, lost their lives, are as follows:
The dissolution of the firm of Husted Hazeltine, grain and produce merchants, was announced in the Produce Exchange yesterday, and caused some surprise.
The at artists who are engaged in decorating the ceiling of the auditorium of the Academy of Music have nearly completed their work.

The general complaint of the backers of the Puritan is that they cannot find anybody to take their bets. A few wagers were made yesterday at odds of one hundred to ninety and one hundred to seventy-five in favor of the Puritan, but the great bulk of the money offered finds no takers.
After a thorough investigation of the metal faucets used by saloon keepers and others who keep beer, soda and mineral waters, and...
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2.--During the past 15 years there has been much discussion and many claims made as to the youngest volunteer soldier in the late rebellion.

William Henry Smith, of Irvington, made an assignment yesterday in this city to Charles T. Smith, giving two preferences. Mr. Smith was President of the Manhattan Company's Bank for about three years, retiring from that position in 1883.
Capt. Howard, of the schooner Davida, which, arrived yesterday from Nova Scotia, reports that on Aug. 27, in latitude 42 36' and longitude 68 31' he fell in with the waterlogged and...

MONTREAL, Sept. 2.--Joseph Laing, champion amateur oarsman of Canada, feels so aggrieved at the action of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen of America in refusing his entry for the Charles River regatta, that he has resolved to give up his amateur standing.

The weather at Brighton Beach yesterday was bracing and invigorating, and there was more than an average attendance upon the races. The track was in good condition. A sad accident occurred in the second race, by which Moran, one of the most promising of young jockeys, was instantly killed, and two other jockeys, Garrison and Lane, narrowly escaped the same fate.
This will to the third day of the Autumn meeting at the Sheepshead Bay track, and a fine programme of six races will be given.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 2.--The trouble between the timber stowers and the stevedores at Pensacola, over an attempt by the former to regulate their working days by the tonnage of a vessel has proved a serious obstacle to the progress of business in that port.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 2.--The report of the Tobacco Association shows sales of 3,299,000 pounds of leaf tobacco for the month of August, as against 2,101,000 pounds for the corresponding month last year. The amount of tobacco sold during the last 11 months was 33,620,000 Pounds, as against 20,270,000 pounds for the same period last year.
Every young Plattdeutscher took his best girl to Ridgewood Park, Long Island, yesterday, and every husband belonging to any of the 26 societies took his family.

The Metropolitan players showed up in their old form yesterday, and won a game from the Brooklyn Club by figures of 6 to 3. Roseman made two pretty catches, and Nelson caught a line ball that prevented the Brooklynites from tallying 2 runs.

Secretary Thorpe was in a very sanguine frame of mind at the meeting of the Aneke Jans heirs, who think they can get possession of Trinity's handsome property, held in Newark, N.J., yesterday. He thought the difficulty had been heretofore in petty jealousies.
A shock was felt by the literary people of the period when the original Spiritual ists proved that spirits could write poetry, and, what is more, prose.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 2.--A large prohibition mass meeting is being held in Representative Hall to-night, and is being addressed by prominent speakers.
ELBERTON, Ga., Sept. 2.--A colored centenarian, George Hughes, with a curious history, died here to-day. He was 115 years of age. He worked on the Richmond Canal 80 years ago, ...

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 2.--These yachts of the Eastern Yacht Club arrived in the harbor this afternoon and evening from Newport: Schooners--Fortuna, Gitana, Foam, Meta, Mohican, Phantom, Rebecca, Tioga, and Silvie; sloops and cutters-Thesis, Huron, Stranger, Clara, Addie, and Imperia.
Samuel Neuman, 9 years old, was found yesterday at No. 127 Pitt-street sick of smallpox, which he caught in Hamburg or on the steamship Frisia before Aug. 24, when be landed in this country.
MARSEILLES, Sept. 2.--With cooler weather here cholera is decreasing. During the 24 hours ending to-night 23 new cases were reported. There are still 79 cases in the hospital.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2.--Kirkwood, a railway station 12 miles from St. Louis on the Missouri Pacific Railroad, was thrown into a great state of excitement this evening by the appearance on the highway of Sheriff Allen and Edward Bueschel, a locksmith.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 2.--Last night, after the breaking up of a colored festival, near the graveyard, Arnold Moore shot and instantly killed Isaac Nathaniel, the ball passing through his neck, and painfully wounding Willie Anderson and Alexander Sharkey. Moore is a school teacher and is almost a stranger in town.
A tramp entered the residence of John Cunningham, at Kensico, on Tuesday evening and found Mrs. Cunningham alone. He asked for something to eat, which was given him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--Capt. Frank D. Baldwin, Fifth Infantry, has at his own request been releived from duty as Acting Judge-Advocate. Department of the Columbia, to take effect Oct. 1, when he will join his company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--The following is a synopsis of sundry decisions rendered by the Treasury Department in customs cases during the past week:

WATERTOWN, Sept. 2.--The existing political complications in St. Lawrence County were very much heightened by unlooked-for developments at the Gouverneur Town Fair today. The managers of the fair had advertised for some time that speeches would be made by Gen. H.W. Slocum, the Hon. R.P. Flower, and...

Coroner Levy sat behind his desk yesterday with a large revolver on either side of the paper before him during the inquest in the case of "Tom" Davis, the sporting man. At his left hand stood "The" Davis, the brother of the murdered man, in earnest conversation with...

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2.--Those who claim that all public interest in the Maxwell case has died out were surprised this morning to find that the Court of Criminal Correction was crowded with people anxious to catch a view of the prisoner.

ALBANY, Sept. 2.--Since the departure of Secretary of the Treasury Manning for NewYork this morning, the leaders among the local Democrats who have been silent on the subject of the Governorship in the absence of any instructions from Washington, are talking quietly...

Controller Loew yesterday decided not to approve of any more contracts for local improvements under the direction of the Departments of Public Works or Public Parks because of the insufficiency of appropriations.
Secretary Manning reached the city late yesterday afternoon from Albany, by way of Greystone, having spent the greater part of the day with Samuel J. Tilden.

The Executive Committee appointed by the Canal Convention recently held in Utica met for the first time in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation, in this city, yesterday. The Hon. Orlando B. Potter presided.
NEWARK, Sept. 2.--Assemblyman and Alderman John Wade, to-night met R.M. Loomis, ex-editor and proprietor of the Hudson County Dispatch, at the Harrison tation, and attempted...

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2.--The members of the Government Examining Board appointed to witness the annual examinations of the class of naval officers detailed for instruction in torpedo warfare during the Summer term here, went to the station this morning and were met by Commander Sampson.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2.--James Roark, who was on trial at Greenville for complicity in the murder of Mrs. Carrie Hunter in February, 1884, was discharged to-day. Three men are already under sentence of death for committing the crime, and Roark was the principal witness against them.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2.--Deputy Collector J.M. Phillips and Special Deputies J.W. Small and B.P. McClelland, connected with the revenue service, having been provided with warrants for the arrest of moonshiners in Putnam County, started in search of them.

The more facts come to light about the killing of DAVIS the more likely it appears that the crime was simply an incident of a swindling match. At first it seemed that the Texan, though very guilty toward society at large, was guiltless toward the thief he killed.
Germany continues to address courteous notes to Spain, but the irritation of the latter country over the occupation of the Carolines does not subside.

The bodies of the Misses Holtz, who diet in Hoboken in consequence of Druggist Am Ende's mistake in compounding morphine for quinine, were lying side by side in caskets in the parlor of the Holtz residence, on Hudsonstreet, yesterday morning.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 2.--Letters received here report that Hezekiah Allen, of NewBedford, mate of the whaling bark Stamboul, of San Francisco, shot himself dead in his berth He feared that he would become disabled with rheumatism.

LONG BRANCH, Sept. 2.--Edmund Meredith, bookkeeper at the Pennsylvania Club--the well known sporting resort near the West End Hotel kept by Philip Daly--was found dead in his bed in the clubhouse this morning.
George H. Mellish, a stenographer at Police Headquarters, is taking a short vacation at Ocean Beach, New-Jersey. Yesterday morning he engaged Mr. Polland to take him out bluefishing.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Sept. 2.--A horrible drowning accident occurred at the St. Paul Railroad bridge across the river here at 6 o'clock this morning. The draw being open, 11 persons, nine girls and two men, nearly all of them employes in the Diamond Match Works, attempted to cross the open channel in a boat.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 2.--A special dispatch to the Pioncer Press from Mandan, Dakota, say that a largely attended indignation meeting was held last night to protest against the change of venue to Bismarck in the case of the Marquis DeMores and Paddock,

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2.--The Republican County Convention, after an all-day session, adjourned at 8 o'clock this evening with its work only half done. It is the first instance within the memory of the present generation of a county convention failing to accomplish its work in one day.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2.--The Grand Jury found a true bill to-day against Mr. Shepherd, proprietor of the Toronto News, for criminally libeling the officers and men of the Sixty-fifth Battalion.

A conference of railroad and hotel men was held in the office of Richard K. Fox yesterday for the purpose of arranging a professional double scull regatta at Rockaway, to be held during the present month.
William H. Cole, publisher of the Irish American, drew $160 from the Nassau Bank on Tuesday afternoon, and placing it in a loose roll in his trousers pocket went down town to transact some business.

JAMESTOWN, N,Y., Sept. 2.--The Chautauqua County soldiers closed a two-day reunion at Point Chautauqua this afternoon. Between two and three hundred persons attended, the largest number since the war.
A lot of complicated telegraphic instruments burdened a table near the door of the United States Circuit Court room yesterday. Judge Wallace looked at them in dismay when he entered the room.

Since the publication in THE TIMES exclusively of a description of the new torpedo boat constructed at Fort Lafayette, under the personal direction of Lieut. Zalinski, United States Army, a steady stream of visitors has endeavored to obtain a look at the marine monster. It has been a difficult matter to add the last...

William Schaan was arraigned before Justice Dean in Newark yesterday for killing a cat. According to the complaint, he "did cruelty torture, torment, and needlessly kill a certain living animal, to wit: a female cat; that...
CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--James Nesbitt, office manager of the Current Company, returned tonight from a trip up into Northern Wisconsin to a place the name of which he declines to give.
The reference in the case of the Mayor and Council of the city of Hoboken against John McMahon and his bondsmen was commenced yesterday before Charles K. Cannon.
ABERDEEN, Sept. 2.--Mr. Gladstone, in answer to inquiries made to the Provost of Aberdeen, has stated that he is "extremely well," although "still a little hoarse."
KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The milkmen of this city were treated to a genuine surpriseyesterday morning by the appearance of an inspector in their midst.

It is becoming recongized that active and earnest efforts are necessary in order to make a success of the work of collecting sufficient money to provide a suitable memorial over the grave of Gen. Grant. That the requisite funds will be forthcoming is generally believed.

For some time past past Elmer Carpenter, son of ex-Sheriff Seiba Carpenter, proprietor of the Vincent House at Tarrytown, has been waiting upon Miss Hattie Sniffen, daughter of James Sniffen, a prosperous farmer of the town of Greenburg.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2.--The offer of George M. Pullman, President of the Pullman Car Company, to give the stockholders of the Central Transportation Company one share of stock in his company for four shares of their holdings was rejected by the Central Transportation Company.
PROVIDENCE, R.I. Sept. 2.--The second day's events of the Grand Central Circuit meeting at Narragansett Park were very interesting. First came the unfinished 2:18 pacing race.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--Mrs. D.P. Negley, the woman who has gained notoriety in Chicago of late because of her troubles with her husband, and whose name has been mentioned in connection with that of Judge Boarman, of Louisiana, assumed the offensive to-day, and began suit for a divorce on the grounds of cruelty.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The Republican caucuses were largely attended to-day and closely contested in the interest of local candidates.

A circular has been issued by James F. Joy, O.D. Ashley, T.H. Hubbard, and Edgar T. Welles, who comprise the Purchasing Committee of the Wabash security holders, giving the outlines of the agreement for carrying into effect the plan of reorganization.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2.--The American Construction Company, which has the contract for the construction of the South Pennsylvania Railroad, has induced all its contractors, with two or three exceptions, to agree to assign their contracts to some person to be hereafter named by the construction company.

Primary elections were held yesterday in the Seventh and Eighth Wards of Paterson, N.J., comprising the Fourth Assembly District of Passaic County, to select delegates to nominate the Democratic candidate for that district.

"Ike" Hall's old Battery bath was destroyed by fire yesterday at 2:30 A.M., in the basin south of the West Twenty-second-street pier. The bath had just been sold by Marshall C. Dexter to Dr. H.E. Hunt, of Gilford,

A session of the Quarantine Commissioners was held yesterday for the purpose of hearing grievances of rag importers and merchants in respect to disinfecting and lighterage charges. Commissioner Thomas C. Platt presided, and Commissioners Nichols and Judd sat by his side.
NEWARK, Sept. 2.--Eva Wright lies at the City Hospital at the point of death, resulting from a fail yesterday from the third-story window of the house at No. 122 Walnut-street,

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 2.--An accident, resulting in the death of four men and the serious and perhaps fatal injury of three others, occurred this morning at the Oakwood shaft of the Prospect Colliery, belonging to the Lehigh Valley Coal Company, in the northern part of the city. About 7 o'clock Patrick Smith, John J. Martin, John Gallagher, ...
Gen. Joseph B. Carr, Secretary of State, was the guest of members of the Grand Army of the Republic of Brooklyn last evening.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 2.--Joseph Coleman, 38 years old, an engineer at the docks of the Pennsylvania Coal Company in this city, was drowned in the Hudson River at the docks this morning at about 8 o'clock.

The funeral services of the Rev. Dr. Josoph Alden were held at the family residence, No. 105 West fifty-fourth-street, yesterday afternoon. Dr. Henry M. Field conducted the services, reading a few verses from the fourth chapter of First Thessalonians and paying an eloquent tribute to the character and usefulness of the dead clergyman.
NEW--HAVEN, Sept. 2.--Many members of the New-Haven Civil Service Reform Association are out of town just now. When they return there is likely to be music in the local air.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 2.--On the evening of Aug. 31, W.R. Brooks, of Phelps, N.Y., discovered a suspected comet, which to-night was verified by Prof. Lewis Swift, Director of the Warner Observatory, of this city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--The Democrats of Virginia and Maryland are very much disappointed by the results of the recent examinations for foremen of the navy yards at Norfolk and Washington.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 2.--The chilly weather did not prevent a large attendance at the opening races of the Connecticut Bicycle Club at Charter Oak Park this afternoon.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2.--There are no new developments in the Maines murder case further than the arrest of two men as accomplices. They were with Maines and Sellers for several hours, and one theory is that they fixed up the plot with a woman to entice Maines up for the purpose of rebbing him.

William Livingstone, an expressman, of No. 171 East Eighty-fourth-street, was engaged yesterday by Mrs. Antoinette Hoguet, of No. 112 East Ninety-second-street, to take to her house from the Grand Central Station two trunks marked "Hoguet, New-York," and a leather trunk similarly marked.

COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The Prohibition ists' Assembly and county ticket just made out gives Cohoes the Assemblyman in Wesley Miller, a, bookkeeper in the Peck Axe Factory and a member of the Methodist Church, with quite a following. Robert Campbell, a plumber and also a Methodist, has been nominated for Sheriff.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 2.--The National Convention of the Masonic Lodge of Relief to-day elected the following officers for the year ensuing:--President--Martin Collins, St. Louis;

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 2.--Another shooting affair has occurred in Dutchess County this time at Little Rest, three miles east of Millbrook. Ex-County Superintendent of the Poor David Tallman, is Highway Commissioner of the town in which Little Rest is situated.

The postponement of the hearing in the case between Agnes Ethel and the managers of Mme. Janish throws over the opening of "Anselma" at the Madison-Square Theatre until Friday night, when it is announced by the management that this much postponed production will occur.

LONDON, Sept. 2.--It is reported from Paris that M. de Freyomet, French Minister for Foreign Affairs, will not meet the Marquis of Salisbury to discuss the questions pending between France and England, as requested by the latter, until the result of Sir Henry Drummond Wolff's mission to the Porte is known to France.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 2.--Reports from various sections of the Northwest show that the frost of Monday night was general and severe. Garden stuff was greatly damaged, corn was also injured, and in the north the crop is thought to be practically ruined.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2.--The weather is decidedly cool and thick clothing is much sought after. Among the cottagers entertaining to-day were L.N. Beach, Robert Goelet, Mrs. S.J. Calford, who gave a children's party; Miss S.E. Blatchford, Mrs. M.O. Roberts, E.L. Winthrop, Thomas F. Cushing, E.J. Herrick, and Admiral Baldwin. Several other cottagers gave minor entertainments.

BOSTON, Sept. 2.--Col. Carroll D. Wright has not yet received the letter which Judd, the recently dismissed statistical agent of the Bureau of Labor, says he has forwarded to this city, stating that the stories about his alleged confession were the work of his political enemies.

NEWARK, Sept. 2.--Chief Tuite to-night received word that three boys had stolen a coupon of a 4 per cent. United States bond of 1891 from the private letter box of Dr. George Meeker, No. 420 Washington-street, and that thus had been endeavoring to sell it.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2.--There were 13 deaths from smallpox yesterday and 30 new cases reported, of which 8 were authenticated.
Mrs. Anne Reiley left her home in County Cavan, Ireland, about a fortnight ago in search of her son John, who lived somewhere in America, but exactly where she did not know.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--12:15 A.M.--For New-England, warmer, fair weather, southerly winds, lower barometer.

Commissioners oF Accounts William Pitt Shearman and John B. Adamson have fairly begun their examination of the Department of Public Works. They have been instructed to conduct their investigation with all due diligence and dispatch, and, with the approval of Mayor Grace, have determined to examine into departmental affairs from the conclusion of Mayor Grace's first term to the present time.

The Hon. Augustus Schoonmaker, one of the State Board of Civil Service Commissioners, was in town yesterday. He was met at the New-York Hotel as he was about to leave for his home at Kingston and questioned regarding the purpose of his visit to the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3.--Col. Faulkner, of New-York, a Director of the Philadelphia Midland Railroad, was in this city to-day. He said the engineer corps had nearly completed the survey to West Chester, and was making some changes from the original survey in order to better the grades.

Politicians in this part of the State are not accustomed to give their attention to the selection of candidates for the Legislature until some time after the State nominations have been made, but in the country districts there is already a good deal of activity in this line of business. Aspiring candidates are putting forth...

ALBANY, Sept. 3.--At a meeting of the Jacksonian Association, a prominent Democratic club here, a resolution was passed to attend the Democratic State Convention in a body to work for the nomination of Gov. D.B. Hill. The association, with a band, will go to Saratoga 200 strong.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 2.--Competent authority informs your correspondent that by this evening every fire insurance company doing business in this State will have notified their agents to cease doing business, and all the...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 3.--T.P. Magruder, of Mississippi, and John B. Seelye, of NewYork, were to-day successful in the physical examination for naval cadetships. They both passed in the mental examination last May.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 3.--Dr. George H. Curry, who shot himself after trying to kill Miss Susie Westcott on Monday, was buried today from his father's house, Many people gathered about the grounds while the services were going on.

ALBANY, Sept. 3.--It has fallen to the lot of the wily Governor to illustrate how a ward politician goes about the business of promoting his personal ambitions. For eight months he has been steadily at work to procure the nomination this Fall. During two of those months he has been madly galloping over the State seeking opportunities for consulting local wire pullers and advancing his canvass.

The silver question is getting very warm, if not burning. The position of the Treasury Department in the matter is so well defined and tends to bring out so clearly the actual operation of the silver law that it is causing the business men of the country to realize, more completely than they have ever done before, exactly what the law is and what its effects will be...

PANAMA, Aug. 25.--The leading topic of interest here at present is the continued arrival of Pacific Mail steamers without the customary New-York and San Francisco mails, which causes much inconvenience in the commercial community. The New-York mails of the 1st and 10th insts. came via Jamaica by a Royal Mail steamer.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 3.--The first event to-day was the race for the 2:25 class. In this there were eleven entries and seven starters appeared on the quarter stretch in answer to the judges' summons.

In your review of Mr. Ashe's memoir of S.T. Coleridge you say, with reference to Coleridge's obligations to southey, that " we are not told" how his wife and family " managed to live after 1811 on 75 a year."

An unsuccessful effort was made yesterday to launch the torpedo boat recently built at Fort Lafayette. The effort was unsuccessful because a high wind and a heavy sea interfered with the structure prapared for the purpose of facilitating the launch.

READING, Sept. 3.--The Mount Penn Stove Works of this city have increased the wages of molders 10 per cent., to go into effect on Monday next. McIlvain's boiler plate mill, which has been running on single turn since last November, will start double turn next Monday. Large orders have been received. There is renewed activity in most of the iron industries, and the signs are propitious for a good Fall trade.

Tucson, Arizona, Sept. 3.--A Fort Bowie special says: "Lieut. Guy E. Huse, just returned from Mexico with 32 men, having made 1,000 miles since May 19, has in charge 15 of Geronimo's squaws and children as prisoners.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 3.--President Sloan and his family arrived in this city last evening en route to Niagara Falls. The trip over the Lackawanna from Binghamton to East Buffalo, 197 miles, was made in 119 minutes, inclusive of 22 minutes stoppage for water, oiling, and at railroad crossings, making the actual running time 197 minutes, or a mile a minute. The party went from here to Niagara Falls over the New-York Central last night.

OTTAWA, Sept. 3.--At a banquet at Papineauville, Ottawa County, last night, the occasion being the presentation of an address and a sword to an officer of the Sixty-fifth Regiment, the health of the rebel leaders Riel and Dumont was proposed and enthusiastically drank by all present, among whom were several Catholic priests.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3.--The first race of the second day of the Connecticut Bicycle Club tournament was the five-mile run for the League of American Wheelmen championship. Rich of Brooklyn, N.Y., led under the wire on the first mile, with Weber, of Smithville, N.J., second, and Rowe, of Lynn, Mass., third.

ST.PAUL, Minn., Sept.3.--Gov. Hubbard called the Waterways Convention to order, and after prayer had been offered stated that the object of the convention was to secure national recognition of the vast commercial interests of the Northwest, the greatest producing section of this continent.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3.--The trotting horse Iron Age, owned in Norwich, Conn., dropped dead while trotting at the Gentlemen's Driving Park this afternoon. Heart disease is attributed as the cause. The animal was valued at $3,000.

People docked to see the Puritan-taken out of the water at noon yesterday at the screw docks on the East River near Market-slip. The Puritan left Stapleton under tow about. 11:30 o'clock, and reached her destination about 12:15. Before she could be put upon thedock her centreboard had to be taken out, and that tedious and difficult job occupied at least an hour and a quarter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3, 1885. The Acting Postmaster-General has appointed she following named fourth-class Postmasters in New-York; At Greenfield, Chandler L. Winant; Lackawak, John Shiell; Scooba, Mrs. M.A. Stewart.

The tax rate in this city for the year 1884 would have been $2 45 if $2,678,002 of the sum appropriated and expended had not been supplied by the unexpended balances of twelve years. The use of this accumulated surplus reduced the rate to $2 25.
READING, Penn., Sept. 3.--While Mrs. Henry Traub, a widow, residing with her fatherin-law near Treichiersville, was preparing dinner yesterday her clothing caught fire in some unaccountable manner.

While the good ship Sunbeam--the narnative of whose cruise first familiarized the nonnautical world with the queer sounding phrase, "the trades the tropics, and the roaring forties" --is cleaving her way through Scandinavian waters, the feminine representatives of the last of these categories are having, each in her own way, a high old time of it on shore.

About 600 persons visited the West Side Driving Park, in jersey City, yesterday, to witness the trotting, match between James O'Neil's Aunty and Shaw's Emily H. The match was for $400, best three out of five heats.
After a consultation with the officers of the Kings County Elevated Railroad Company Mayor Low, of Brooklyn, yesterday made an announcement...
HUNTINGTON, Ind., Sept. 3.--At the annual election of Directors of the Chicago and Atlantic Railway to-day the following board was chosen: Hugh J. Jewett, John King, Jr.,
PHELPS, N.Y., Sept. 3.--Prof. Brooks, of the Red house Observatory, secured observations of the wonderful new star in the great nebula of Andromeda last night and this morning.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--Communications from business men and manufacturers in reply to Secretary Manning's letter of invitation for suggestions in relation to the tariff have about ceased coming in.
MADRID, Sept. 3.--Throughout Spain yesterday there were 2,841 new cases of cholera and 1,000 deaths.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3.--Patrick Hartnett, the wife murderer, of Cincinnati, who was to have been hanged between 2 and 3 o'clock tomorrow morning was to-night respited by Gov. Hoadly to Sept. 30, to give the attorneys an opportunity to take the case before the Supreme Court.

McKEESPORT, Penn., Sept. 3.--The coal miners' strike was inaugurated to-day instead of Saturday as intended. Fifteen hundred men in the second pool quit work, and it is expected that by to-morrow evening fully 4,000 miners will be out.
The making of the inventory of Victor Hugo's manuscripts has raised some curious qestions. "Les Deux Jumeaux" has disappeared.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 3.--To-day was the final day of duty at the station for members of the class in torpedo instruction. No practical work within or without the buildings was called for, the exercises for the day being confined to work with pencil and paper, which oc cupied two hours and a half.

Rather more than a year ago the American journal, the Critic, asked for the opinions of its subscribers as to the 40 Americans who, in the event of the establishment of an American Academy after the model of the Academic Francaise, would be first entitled to become, members of it.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3.--A French pamphlet which has just appeared, entitled, "Riel Patriotism versus Loyalty," contains some exceedingly bitter attacks on the English people. It charges the English volunteers with having maltreated the Sixty-fifth and Ninetieth battalions in the Northwest, stolen their provisions, and compelted them to carry the baggage for the whole force, while they, the English soldiers, tranquilly rested. The pamphlet goes on to say:

India is indebted to Lady Dufferin for starting a movement which will not only supply a great want, but which also promises to have a powerful effect in paving the way for the most urgent of all Indian reforms--the amelioration of the position of women.

The time given by President CLEVELAND to the lessees of the Cheyenne and Arapahoe grass lands for removing themselves and their herds out of the Indian Territory expired on Tuesday. According to the latest indications at the War Department the troops held in readiness at Fort Reno and elsewhere to enforce the President's proclamation of Duty 23 will have no serious trouble.
Treasurer Henry F.Spaulding has submitted to the American committee on the Bartholdi statue a report of the disbursements at Bedice's Island from the beginning of the work to Aug. 15.
ROCK SPRING, Wyoming, Sept. 3.--The largest coal mines in the entire Union Pacific system are at Rock Springs, 250 miles west of Cheyenne.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3.--The Republican County Contention an hour ago--the evening of the second day--concluded the work which it was expected to accomplish in a few hours. The result is a ticket that ought to be beaten, and it is a reasonably safe prediction to say that parts of it at least will be beaten.

PASO, DEL NORTE, Sept. 3.--Great fear exists in the upper part of Chihuahua, Mexico, that the band of Indians from Sonora which has appeared in that part of the State will commit serious depredations before retiring to the mountains.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3.--In view of the decreased earnings of the trunk lines a strong belief prevails here that the Pennsylvania Railroad Company will not be able to maintain its present rate of dividend--6 per cent.--this year.

ROME, N.Y., Sept. 3.--The Executive Committee of the Trades Assembly for the coming year, which remained after the State Convention adjourned, organized by electing John Franey, of Buffalo Chairman; George L. Guetig. of Syracuse, Vice-Chairman; F.F. Donovan,
Joseph Connors was at his work in one of the Blissville factories on Wednesday evening, when Owen Hughes, one of the day em ployes, rushed in saying. "Where's Connors? he's killed my Annie."
Surprise and excitement tools possession of the grain ring in the Produce Exchange yesterday when a notice was posted that Thomas Benham, one of the oldest firms down town, had suspended.
Special Officers Thomas Day and Thomas H. Hynes, of the Manhattan Beach Police, were arrested yesterday afternoon by order of Supervisor McKane, of the town of Gravesend.

PANAMA, Aug 25.--The notorious Don Pedro Prestan was executed at midday on the 18th inst. in Aspinwall, in accordance with the sentence passed upon him by the court-martial which met on the 17th to try him.

"You may talk about opium joints until snow flies," sighed a very young man, with his hands buried deep in his pockets, " but they are nothing compared with the irretrievable ruin brought about by ice cream joints.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, Sept. 3.--The Chairman of the Iowa State Prohibition Committee has issued a call for a State Convention at Cedar Rapids, Sept. 23, to nominate a candidate for Governor.

WELLS, Me., Sept. 3.--"There's luck for ye," said an oil-skin-covered fisherman to THE TIMES'S correspondeut, holding up his sail, showing it full of rents and holes. "Wind and weather not much, but them cussed dogfish, they've sot in solid."

READING, Penn., Sept. 3.--Smallpox has made its appearance in this city. A red patch has been painted on the door of the residence of H.C.L. Crecelius, on Fifth-street, below Laurel, whose daughter is lying ill with the disease. Mr.Crecelius is well known in Masonic circles and among iron men. This city has been free from the smallpox scourge for a half dozen years. It is not known how the disease was brought to this city.

We lately mentioned a project for presenting to the American poet Walt Whitman a "free-will offering" from some of his British admirers who are not well satisfied with the apathetic or hostile reception which his works encounter in his own country.
A boy with a little whistle caused an excitement among the police in his neighborhood last night. His name is Shouse, and he had plenty of fun during the evening.

ALBANY, Sept.3.--Postmaster O'Leary this afternoon denied the reported interview between himself and Secretary Manning. "I called to see Mr.Manning," said the Postmaster to an Evening Times reporter, "at the office of the President of the Commercial Bank.

When the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher delivers his expected address in eulogy of Gen. Grant at Tremont Temple, by invitation of the City Council, Oct. 29, his name will take its place in a list of municipal orators to be numbered with whom is a distinction of which any man may be proud.

READING, Penn., Sept. 3.--The Rev. John Gregg, who holds a pulpit at Geigertown, and who is one of the most enthusiastic of Methodist camp meeting orators, came to this city with $750 on his person to pay for a real estate purchase.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--The police in the town of Lake last evening arrested Mrs. Ann Cantwell, 74 years old, who has been living with her daughter in Wenthworth-avenue, and locked her up on the charge of disorderly conduct.

For some weeks a novelty in the shape of a fare and change box for street railway cars has been on exhibition at various places in the city. It was yesterday viewed at the office of the City and Lake Railway Company, No. 102 Canal-street, and explained by one of it patentees, Mr.John T.Wilson.

A statement was made to the Quarantine Commissioners yesterday which set them thinking pretty hard on the subject of rag disinfection. Mr.Braker, of the firm of H.J. Braker Co., importers, at No. 215 Pearl-street, appeared before two of the members of the commission, accompanied by his engineer, to whose intelligence, skill, and reliability he born high testimony.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--Capt. Hall, of the United States Secret Service, says that the story of the discovery at a point on the Illinois shore, opposite Clarksvllle, Mo., of $100,000 in five-dollar, ten-dollar, and twenty-dollar counterfeit bills on the Traders' National Bank, of this city, is probably untrue.

Charles F.Holtz, whose daughters Marguerite and Ella died early in the week in consequence of having taken morphine put up by Druggist Am Ende in mistake for quinine, walked into Recorder McDonough's court, in Hoboken, yesterday. Dr.Loewenthal, who was to have married the elder daughter in a few weeks, accompanied him.

ST.JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Sept. 3.--A special correspondent who visited the wrecked steamer Hanovorian this morning reports the following: "When the steamer was off Cape Mutton, on the morning of Wednesday, the Captain saw button buoys, he thought, around Cape Race, and took Cape Mutton for Cape Ballard.

The programme at the Sheepshead Bay race track was good enough yesterday to attract a large crowd thither, and they witnessed some excellent performances of well known thorough breds. The track was much better than on Tuesday, and fast time was the result.

DES MOINED, Sept. 3.--Ex-Senator Lafe. young, editor of the Atlantic Telegraph, was nominated to the State Senate to-day at Corning on the eight hundred and fifty-sixth ballot. Dr. Underwood has been nominated to succeed the deceased Senator Eastman, known as" Old...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 3.--Collector Troup is not more a man of words than a man of deeds. He called to-day upon three more Republican deputies to resign by Oct.1, when he proposes to appoint Democratic successors. He has only five of the old deputies left. They will all be dismissed before Christmas.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 3.--On Tuesday night several residents or Birmingham, while returning home at a late hour, were attacked by two highwaymen and relieved of their money.

Controller Loew has returned to Commissioner Squire, without his approval, 19 proposed contracts for regulating or paving or putting sewers in streets in various parts of the city, mainly the upper west side.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 3.--Twenty men were arrested here this evening for making book bets on races run outside of the State. The men were bound over for trial, the Legislature having passed a law prohibiting pool selling.

LONDON, Sept.3.--Lord Randolph "Churchill, Secretary of Sate for India, delivered an address at Sheiffield this evening, in the course of which he said that there was no reason as yet to regret the absence of coercion in Ireland. He also said he was glad to announce that the Afghan frontier question had been settled, Russia having largely modified her claims.

A boy camp running into Superintendent J.C. Jones's office, at the House of Refuge, on Randall's Island, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and shouted, "The stooking factory is on fire!" When the Superintendent came out the bank door of the House of Refuge the rear of the shop was in flames.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 3.--The officers of the Amalgamated Association have received intelligence that the Neidering house Stamping Company, of St. Louis, has signed the sheet mill scale. The Neidering house mill is one of the most extensive sheet mills in the West.

Preparations for the spectacular production of "The Comedy of Errors at the Star Theatre to-morrow night are nearly completed. Messrs. Robson and Crane have invited a number of their friends to attend a dress rehearsal of the play this evening.

Patrolman Moritz Fleschner's disappearance continues to furnish gossip in Newark police circles. On Tuesday he walked into the police station, threw his badge and club on the Sergeant's desk, and a paper with them.

PROSPECT HOUSE, Adirondacks, N.Y., Sept. 3.--President Cleveland returned here last night. It is expected that he will remain until Saturday morning, when he will leave for Albany and Washington, via, Plattsburg.

BOSTON, Sept. 3.--John L. Sullivan reached home to-day, looking fresh and altogether in frond trim. He was accompanied by his trainer, Tom Delay, and by Dan Murphy. Seveval of his admirers met him at the station.

The following is a specimen of the almost painful exactitude of German police courts. A barge hand had recently been condemned for theft to a money fine of 5 marks 40 pfennigs or five days' imprisonment.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--All sorts of wild rumors were in circulation to-day, regarding east-bound freight rates. It was currently reported that one company had taken a large lot of grain at a ten-cent rate to New-York. The report, however, could not be verified, all the roads denying that they had taken any, business at such a rate.

CHICAGO, Sept.3.--Marion Leonard, a woman who made a sensation around the Court House some months ago by threatening to shoot Judge Collins because she lost a suit before him, was in court to-day in a different capacity.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 3.--At the reunion of the Sherman Brigade at Lakeville yesterday Gen. Sherman and Senator John Sherman were present.

The New-Yorks administered an over whelming defeat to the Philadelphia players on the Polo Grounds yesterday in the presence of a large number of spectator. They batted the curves of Ferguson, Harry Wright's pet pitcher, all over the field, hitting the ball 19 times for a total of 23 bases.

William J. Palmer, President of the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railway Company, has issued a circular to the holders of the first mortgage 6 per cent. gold bonds of that company. Default exists in the interest on those bonds since the payment of the coupon due March 1, 1884.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 3.--Sidney Sommers and James Healy, miners, who were at work in No. 5 colliery of the Pennsylvania Coal Company this morning, were instantly killed. They entered a portion of the mine where a squeeze had displaced the roof and were buried beneath a mass of falling coal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--Inspector Henderson, of the Post Office Department, has returned from North Carolina, where he succeeded in causing the arrest of two mail robbers, who, though were lads, had by the neatness and dexterity of their operntions baffled the skill of the Inspectors for a long time. Since June 1 a number of complaints have reached the Post Office...
RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 3.--Darwin C. Pierce, 45 years old, a transfer mail agent in the station for 18 years, was arrested to-day charged with robbing the mails and put under $2,000 bonds.
AMSTERDAM, Sept.3.--The Democratic Convention at Fonda to-day to select delegates to represent Montgomery County in the State Convention was harmonious in all its proceedings.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--Henry Clews, of NewYork, and 12 other persons have filed a bill in the Circuit Court here against the First National Bank of this city, one of the strongest institutions in the country. Mr. Clews and his fellow complainants were stockholders in the First National Bank, which was organized in 1862 and expired in 1882.

Ferdinand Ward continued yesterday, before Referee Cole, in the General Term court room, to identify the checks, due bills, and memoranda, which constitute the record of his dealings with W.S. Warner. Gen. Hubbard conducted the examination, as on Tuesday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 3.--The booty secured by the men who last night robbed the passengers of a train on the Chicago and Alton Road, near Blue Springs, amounted to about $30 in money, nothing else being taken. The robbers are described as appearing awkward and nervous and evidently unused to such work.

VIENNA, Ga., Sept.3.--The camp meeting held were this week was thrown into confusion by the elopement of Mr. F.E. Varnado and Miss Zoe Scott.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3.--Advices received here to-day from the sugar-producing parishes of Louisiana are to the effect that the cane crop promises a larger yield than that of 1884.

Sarah Curran, who had been a chambermaid in a hotel at Long Beach, went to Long Island City Wednesday night. wrote a long message in the telegraph office, only to tear it up, got on board a train for Manhattan Beach.

CINCINNATI, Sept.3.--About dusk this evening the entire Fire Department of Cincinnati was called to the corner of Sixth and Hoadly streets, where a fire had gained much headway in the freight station of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--Reports from Kankakee County say the cattle disease there is a very serious matter. The location is on the farm of Hiram Goodwin, eight miles northwest of Kankakee City.

TOULON, Sept. 4.--The cholera epidemic shows no signs of abatement here. Twelve deaths from the disease were reported to-day and 7 last night. At the hospital 12 patients were admitted and 17 were discharged. There are now 117 persons under treatment in the hospitals. M. Allain-Targe, Minister of the Interior, has arrived here to inspect the sanitary, condition of the city.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 4.--The Directors of the Shelbyville Savings Bank to-day executed an assignment to J.N. Sullivan for the benefit of the creditors of the institution.

PROSPECT HOUSE, New-York, Sept. 4.-- President Cleveland and Dr. Ward will leave here to-morrow morning. They will be driven by Paul Smith, to Au Sable Station, on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, and go to Plattsburg, where they will take the regular 8:45 P.M. train for Albany, occupying a special palace car.

Contributions to the amount of over $1,400 were received by the Grant Monument Association yesterday, a very large proportion of which came from people in this city. This is progression in the right direction, and if the New-York offerings continue to flow into the treasury it will stimulate others to participate in the work of the association.

The Boston team, with Purcell, Nash, and Johnston, their three latest acquisitions, arrived in this city yesterday and played a postponed game with the New-Yorks in the presence of 3,000 persons. The Bostonians were full of confidence.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Sept. 4.--A horrible accident occurred at Gastonville, between this place and Pittsburg, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railway lastnight. A flagman whose name is given as Maine, and who resides at Newark, Ohio, had fallen asleep upon the track, and a passenger train coming along dashed over him, cutting his body horribly.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--The California, which arrived here to-day from the lower lakes, baought 40 passengers who left Chicago a few days ago on the Armenia for Montreal. When the Armenia arrived at the mouth of the Welland Canal the passengers learned of the rapid spread of smallpox in Canada, and rather than risk the danger of the disease they surrendered their round-trip tickets and fled from the Dominion.

United States Commissioner Joseph M. Deuel has an office boy, John H. Sharrott, 16 years old, a son of Sergt. Sharrott, of the Staten Island police force. Among the boy's friends is Harry B. Kelly, about 15 years of age, the son of a reputable man doing business in this city.

BOSTON, Sept. 4.--Charles Hayes, a mulatto, who lived with a creole woman named Tilly Robinson in a tenement of two rooms in Brewery-street. East Cambridge, went to his home last evening, and found no supper awaiting him.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 4.--This island has been visited by an unusually heavy rainfall for the past three days. Since 5 o'clock last Tuesday evening 9 30-100 inches of rain have fallen, inundating the streets in many places to the depth of 15 inches.

TORONTO, Ont., Sept. 4.--Information was received here this morning to the effect that the people in Campbellford, a small village in this Province, east of Toronto, had experienced a severe shock of earthquake.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--Mrs. Emma M. Markley, who was credited with being the heaviest woman in the country, was buried from her home at No. 526 Lombardstreet to-day. She was known to the amusement public as Mme. Victoria.

ALBANY, Sept. 4.--The Republican General Committee to-night issued a call for Assembly conventions and primaries. A resolution was adopted urging the nomination of Dr. John Swinburne for Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4.--A nearly fatal case of taking the wrong medicine occurred last night in West Philadelphia. Everett Betts to get some medicine to relieve his trouble.

MONTREAL, Sept. 4.--Owing to a plethora of money the leading banks here have reduced the rate of interest allowod on deposits from 4 to 3 per cent.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 4.--The product of the Lake Superior copper mines for August was: Calumet and Hecla, 2,570 tons; Quincy, 336 tons; Atlantic, 205 tons; Franklin, 108 tons; Huron, 102 tons.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 4.--A tank car on the West Pennsylvania Railroad, containing oil, exploded this morning, fatally burning Brakeman Thomas Ryan, of Cleveland, Ohio, and setting fire to the train. The flames were subdued before serious damage resulted.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 4.--The schooner Dallas Hill, which arrived here from St. John, New-Brunswick, Aug. 28, was docked at Chelsea. Capt. Robson was taken sick shortly afterward, and to-day the disease was pronounced malignant smallpox, and the patient was taken to Galloup's Island. The vessel was then thororoughly fumigated.

ALBANY, Sept. 4.--The State Constitution explicitly declares that "no person shall be eligible to the office of Governor or LieutenantGovernor except a citizen of the United States, of the age of not less than 30 years, and who shall have been five years, next preceding his election, a resident of this State."

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--There was a rainstorm last night, and the weather this morning was not favorable for the Washington Park races. It was damp and cold. The track was not good, and any chance of fast time in the extra race was given up. As the conditions required a good day and track the race was declared off.

Kossuth Marx Co., wholesale dealers in jewelry and importers of diamonds at No. 39 Maiden-lane, failed yesterday, and the partners, Kossuth, Adolphus, and Jacob Marx, made an assignment for the benefit of creditors to Julius Lipman, lawyer of No. 206 Broadway.

Three o'clock yesterday afternoon was the hour fixed for the launching of the torpedo boat at Fort Lafayette. A few invited guests were present, including the inventor, J.T. Holland, Lieut. Zalinski, and Dr. Cyrus Edson.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 4.--A yearling filly by St. Martin, out of the dam of Waverley and other crack racers, was sold here to-day by L. G. Strauss to P.G. Cocks of Yazoo City, Miss., for $750. The breeding is exceptionally fine. The dam owned by Messrs. Strauss is bred to King Ban, sire of Ban Fox, the colt that lately won the great Stallion Stake, and was sold for $20,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--A Springfield man has published a curious contribution to political literature. It is a book containing a history of the contest for United States Senator in the last General Assembly of this State which resulted in the election of Gen. John A. Logan.

Indications point to a many-sided fight at the annual election of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company this month. It is unlikely, however, that any attempt will be made to displace President Harris. The fight will be to gain votes in the new directory.

The Genesta was officially measured yesterday, and the result showed that instead of receiving a time allowance she would have to allow the Puritan time. Her sailing length, which is compounded of her water line measurement and sail area, was found to be 83 5-10 feet, and it is estimated by some that she will have to allow the Puritan nearly a minute and a half.

MADRID, Sept. 4.--The Spanish ironclad Aragon has landed troops on the Pelew Islands, and the Spanish Admiral has been ordered to occupy Yap, Babelthuap, Ponapi, and other islands of the Caroline group. The German officials in those waters have been instructed not to interfere with the carrying out of the Spanish Admiral's orders.

Mr. C.M. Woodward, Dean of the Polytechnic School of the Washington University and Director of the Manual Training School, returned yesterday from Europe, where he has been for five months studying the educational institutions.

The oldest ex-Mayor of Lancaster, Penn., the Hon. Christian Kiefer, died yesterday morning at the age of 85 years. He was born in Franklin County, near Buchanan's birthplace, on Oct. 29, 1799, and went to Lancaster in 1810.

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 4.--Darwin C. Pierce, who was arrested on Thursday charged with stealing from the mails, will probably be released at the hearing to-morrow. He has proved that he was in Salem, N.Y., on July 11, when the mail was stolen, and the prosecutiug officers accept the proof of an alibi. The case is much complicated and new revelations are expected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4.--The attempt to prevent rates on east-bound freigtht going below a basis of 12 cents on grain to New-York is a failure. Contracts were made to-day at 10 cents on grain and 12 cents on provisions.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, Sept. 4.--Martin Archibald, who, while attempting to criminally assault a woman named Adams, was overpowered by her and her son, and frightfully hacked about the head and upper part of the body by the woman with an axe, died this evening. The woman and her son have been arrested. Archibald was a wealthy farmer.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 4.--To-night about 10:30 o'clock a large body of masked men passed down Gay-street in the direction of the jail. They marched in regular step and were joined at various points along the street by at least 200 citizens.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4.--The Naval War College on Coaster's Harbor Island has now become a fixed and established fact. The term of instruction at the torpedo station closed Thursday and to-day the term at the War College opened, making a continuous course of instruction.

The Rev. Dr. Stephen H. Tyng died at Irvington, N.Y., Thursday night at about midnight. He was 85 years of age last March. He had recently been in good health and enjoyed walking about his grounds, but on Thursday he took a slight cold and kept his bed nearly all day.

Nearly 5,000 people went to Manhattan Beach and Sheepshead Bay yesterday afternoon to witness the three-mile single scull race that had been advertised for two weeks between Hanlan, Lee, and Ross for a nurse of $2,000.

In switching one of the Brooklyn Bridge cars at the Brooklyn end, at about 9 o'clock last night, the car became unmanageable. It jumped the switch and half geared the abutment at High-street before it could be stopped. Here it remained, half on and half off the structure, all night. There was no one on or in the car at the time and no one was hurt.

AMHERSTBURG, Ontario, Sept. 4.--The water bottom of the steam barge Cleveland blew out this morning on the lake near this place, allowing the steam to escape. John Ward, a deckhand, who was in the forehold, could not escape, and was scalded to death.

Of the 200 saloon passengers who landed yesterday morning from the Inman steamship City of Berlin no less than 24 were clergymen. On Sept. 1 an entertainment, consisting of singing and recitations, was given in the cabin for the benefit of the Liverpool Seamen's Orphanage.

VINCENNES, Ind., Sept. 4.--Three township Trustees of Daviess County, Ind., have disappeared. It is said they issued fraudulent orders in their respective townships, and on the credit of the orders easily raised money and absconded with it.

Col. John A. McCaull was yesterday arraigned in the Tombs Police Court on complaint of the actor Heinrich Conried, who charged him with having pulled his nose in front of the Casino on Aug. 19. Col. McCaull gave bail to answer.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 4.--Charles E. Marsh was arrested this morning on the charge of bigamy. Wife No. 2 was with him. She said she had been married to Marsh on the 25th of last April, and showed a marriage certificate.

DUBLIN, Sept. 4.--Archbishop Walsh arrived here to-day and was given an enthusiastic reception. He received addresses of welcome from the Lord Mayor and the municipal authorities. Upon his arrival at Kingstown the Archbishop was met by local bodies of Parnellites, which presented him with addresses of welcome.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 4.--The schoolhouse presented to this town by Henry H. Rogers, of New-York, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. There being no large hall in the schoolhouse the exercises were held in the Conregational Church. Addresses were made by Prof. Frank Dexter, of Yale College;
