BOSTON, Sept. 4.--Thomas D. Heathfield Son, grain dealers, State-street, have failed. Liabilities unknown.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Sept. 4.--The whaling schooner Ellen Rizpah, Capt. Dunham, arrived here last night with 50 barrels of sperm oil. She reports that the fleet have done nothing during the past month, and whalers are very scarce.

Mrs. Pauline Traeger recovered judgment for $150 against John Wiegand, at the end of a peculiar trial in Judge Randolph's court, Jersey City, yesterday. Wiegand married in Germany 20 years ago, and soon after came to Weehawken with his bride.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 4.--The list of entries for the international, three days' bicycle tournament, which will begin here next Tuesday, includes the names of 70 riders, and the entries aggregate 403.
The Quarantine Board decided yesterday by a unanimous vote that it had the lawful authority to limit the charges for the disinfection of rags arriving in this port.

A report was current, and generally believed, in Wall-street yesterday that the Clearing House Committee had arranged with a syndicate to dispose of the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia securities held on account of the suspended Metropolitan Bank.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4.--The Knights of Labor must strike now, for General Manager Talmadge, in behalf of the Wabash Road, has refused to yield to their demands. The conference this morning between Mr. Talmadge, and Chairman T.V. Powderly and Secretary Frederick Turner, of the Executive Board of the Knights of Labor, did not last longer than 15 minutes.

MONTICELLO, Ill., Sept. 4.--Jacob Swartz, a farmer living seven miles west of this city, was accidentally shot and killed last night by his son, Sylvestcr. After the family had retired a disturbance occurred among the chickens.

Rear-Admiral JOUETT, of the navy, has just been fined $400 for being a Rear-Admiral. The circumstances under which the penalty for this offense was inflicted should and probably may lead to a revision of the law so as to mitigate the punishment for rising to high rank in the navy, when the culprit can prove a good character in other respects.

There was one of the largest assemblages of the season at Brighton Beach yesterday, and the racing, in point of close contests and exciting finishes, well repaid those who were present. The track was in good condition. The betting was very heavy, and only one favorite won.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Sept. 4.--Farmers in the northern part of the county report a strange fatality among their hogs. The disease seems to be a lung trouble, and is killing off the hogs at a rapid rate.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 4.--Coroner R.T. Smith to-day held an inquest to inquire into the death of Dr. George H. Curry, who on Monday night last committed suicide after failing to kill Miss Susie Westcott. She told much the same story as has been already published.

PALESTINE, Texas, Sept. 5.--At the local option election held in this (Anderson) county to-day, the Prohibitionists were defeated by 600 majority. This is the home of Congressman Reagan, who took no active part in the canvase beyond expressing the opinion that local option should not be made a party issue.

LYONS, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Farmers are apprehensive of the loss of their potato crop by reason of a small shiny bug that has appeared there. It works its way into the hills of potatoes by going down the stalks of the plants. It then eats its way into the potatoes and deposits eggs, which are hatched within the vegetable.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The new route between Chicago and St. Paul lately established by a combination of the Burlington, Illinois Cental and Minnesota and Northwestern will be regularly opened for passenger traffic Sept. 15.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Frank Payne, aged 15 years, in the employ of W.A. Hutchinson, a merchant of Youngstown, Niagara County, shot John Schoomaker, aged 13 years, who entered Hutchinson's store, it is claimed, to rifle the money drawer, on July 11.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 6.--Some desperate measures will be taken by the depositors of the wrecked Humboldt Bank unless the stockholders come to their relief and pay up. A meeting was held to-night, and some of the more excited victims openly advocated lynching as a remedy: This is the third savings bank wrecked here in one year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--Reports received at the War Department from the Indian Territory indicate that the terms of the President's recent proclamation in regard to the removal of cattle are being fully complied with and that the cattlemen are moving their cattle as rapidly as possible.

BOSTON, Sept. 5.--At a special meeting of the members of the Bowdoin-Square Baptist church, held last evening and largely attended, Frederick J. Taber, upon the recommendation of the prudential committee of the church, was expelled by a unanimous vote.

PORT JEFFERSON, Long Island, Sept. 5.-- An Indian named Pharaoh, employed as mate on a vessel sailing from this port, is missing under suspicious circumstances. OGDENSBURG, Sept. 5.--At the Republican ward caucus last night Gen. N.M. Curtis carried the Third Ward, 57 to 26, and the Second Ward, 94 to 54. He lost the First Ward, 56 to 47, and the Fourth Ward by the managers declaring the result and refusing a division.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 5.--William Mullans, a pickpocket, was arrested here last night on suspicion of having been connected with the Blue Springs train robbery. Mullans says he was on the train as a passenger. Two men have been arrested at Lexington on other charges, whom the officers here suspect of complicity in the robbery.
PARIS, Aug.18.--I have been to Antwerp, and 1 have returned from Antwerp, and considering everything am glad to have gone there, and still gladder to have come back in safety snd with all my luggage.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 5.--Darwin C. Pierce, who was arrested on Thursday on the charge of stealing from the mails at Rutland on Saturday, July 11, has shown an alibi. The Metropolitans won another game from their Brooklyn opponents on the Polo Grounds yesterday. They played a stronger game in the field and managed to make their base hits when they proved of most value. On the other hand, the visitors made costly errors and failed to bat the curves of Lynch when the bases were occupied.
VINCENNES, Ind., Sept. 5.--A thorough investigation of the township Trustee swindle as perpetrated in Daviess County, Ind., 20 miles east of this city, reveals most astounding official corruption.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 5.--President Cleveland and Dr. Ward arrived from Au Sable at 6 o'clock this morning. After having supper at the Fouquet House Mr. Cleveland held an informal reception. He left with Dr. Ward at 9 o'clook in a special car attached to a regular train on the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company's road for the south.

PASO DEL NORTE, Mexico, Sept. 5, via Galveston.--J. Shean, roadmaster of the Mexican Central Railway, was murdered here at midnight Thursday night by a cutthroat named Davis. Shean, feeling ill, visited a low saloon in the vicinity of his residence to procure some bitters.

Mrs. Elizabeth Duffuls, a well known character of Hudson County,.N. J., died yesterday at her home, in Pamrapo. She was 65 years old, and was a full-blooded negress.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Sept. 5.--Brehm's Block, a long two-story frame building, situated on Ocean-avenue, next above the Seabright Inn, was burned to the ground at an early hour this morning, with several other buildings. The entire loss will aggregate $38,000.

CHEROKEE, Kan., Sept. 6.--The Rev. Charles W. Price, a Presbyterian clergyman of this place, hanged himself this morning. His mind was thought to have been unsettled by the death of a brother and sister. Mr. Price came here from Plattsburg, Mo.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--A sad and extraordinary tragedy occurred this morning in the handsome house No. 600 North Sixth-street. Oscar Parry, a bright little boy not yet 12 years of age, took his own life by shooting himself with a pistol. What could have prompted the act is a mystery, and his father, who doted upon him, is almost crazed with grief.

The Maryland and Delaware peach season is drawing to a close, and there will be few desirable peaches from those states after tomorrow excepting Smocks. This season is somewhat later than last, but up to Sept. 1 nearly 100 carloads more of peaches had been sent over the road than up to that date of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--The delegates of the Irish Catholic Benevolent Union elected to attend the National Assembly at Brooklyn met in their rooms at Philapatrian Hall to-day and decided to leave next Tuesday night in a body.

HILLSDALE, Mich., Sept. 6.--The Sheriff, two Deputies, and the Prosecuting Attorney have arrested five men in Amber, near the Ohio River, who are charged with belonging to a gang of thieves who have been committing depredations in Southern Michigan and Northern Indiana and Ohio for a year or more.

A New-York artist whom I count among my friends is just back from a month of rambling along the St. Lawrence from Montreal to Quebec. He comes home refreshed and with many a story to tell. One is a strange tale, tinged with a dash of the supernatural. His incidents of travel were mostly derived from stops by night and by day in the happy villages of the Canadian habitans.

There seems to exist in the minds of a great many people in this city the idea that the public schools will be opened to-day. This idea is erroneous, as the schools will not be opened until Monday, Sept. 14. Some annoyance has been occasioned by this confusing of dates, and at the Board of Education building, yesterday, the clerks were very anxious that the right date should be published.

The defeat received by the New-Yorks at the hands of the Philadelphia players on Saturday has somewhat lessened the chances of the Giants winning the pennant, but they are not too far behind to shake the faith of their admirers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--The cool weather of the past week has helped the theatres greatly and there have been good houses to see everything worth seeing. Old Sport, Handsome, and the other features of the "Rag Baby" have filled the Grand Opera every night and at the usual matinees.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6.--George H. Bidwell, a member of the firm of Holmes Co., printers, of this city, shot himself at his home, in Fair Haven, this afternoon. The weapon used was a heavy navy revolver, and the bullet passed directly through his heart. He died almost instantly. He was 65 years of age. He had been in low spirits for some time.
LONDON, Sept. 6.--Mrs. Russell Stevenson, sister of the Countess of Dufferin, died at sea while on her way from Canada to England. The body has been landed at Londonderry.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 6.--Both east and west bound traffic for the past week has been heavy beyond parallel for early September, and the calls for cars indicate that the movement is to continue unless there should be a considerable advance in rates.

DEADWOOD, Dakota, Sept. 6.--The unpleasant weather of the past two weeks culminated in a snowstorm yesterday morning. The thermometer has ranged from 50 to 60 , and more or less rain has fallen daily for some time.
The body of Saintemme Diolot, a jeweler, of No. 173 Broadway, was found yesterday in a secluded piece of woods midway between King's Bridge and Fordham, where he had evidently committed suicide.

This Fall the voters of Brooklyn will have to elect a Mayor for the third time under the system of concentrated power and concentrated responsibility in the incumbent of the office. Under Mr. Low, both in the first and in the second of the terms for which he was chosen, the system has been amply vindicated.

The Democratic town caucuses throughout Richmond County were held on Saturday night. Delegates were chosen from all the election districts. Two sets of delegates were selected instead of one, as in the past.

AMERICUS, Ga., Sept. 6.--Stonewall Tondee, son of the Treasurer of Schley County, was assassinated in Ellaville last night at 9 o'clock. He was waiting on some customers in the store when some one approached from the outside and shot through the window at Tondee, killing him instantly. Twelve buckshot entered his side.

MADRID, Sept. 6.--The Council of Ministers, with the sanction of King Alfonso, has framed and dispatched to the German Government an ultimatum, requesting Germany to evacuate the Caroline Islands. Spain in the meantime will refrain from a material occupation of the islands, and thus afford a basis for further parleying.

BILLINGS, Montana, Sept. 6.--The first shipment of cattle from the beef round-up left last night, being nine carloads. Severance Co. are shipping a lot of sheep, and more are on the way here. The season opens late, but bids fair to be very lively.

MADRID, Sept. 6.--Returns from all the infected districts of Spain show that on Saturday there were reported 2,147 new cases of cholera and 779 deaths from the disease.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 6.--Samuel Tappan, a wealthy liquor dealer of this city, cut his throat from ear to ear in an outhouse this afternoon. He was dead when found. Ill health was the cause of his act.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The Utica steam cotton mills and the Mohawk Valley mills, employing about 1,000 hands, will resume operations to-morrow. They have been idle for a month.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 6.--Mrs. Jane Moriarty died in this city yesterday morning, aged 65 years, Mrs. Moriarty was one of the best known women in New-Haven, and her chop and ale house has been for years the favorite resort of Yale students.

The old trouble in the Abyssinian Colored Baptist Church, in Waverley-place, west of Sixth-avenue, broke out in a new form yesterday. One of the factions, headed by the Pastor, the Rev. William Spelman, determined that services should be held, the church having just been repaired after its partial destruction by fire in February last.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 6.--Bob Haylor, the train engineer who stuck to his post in last Wednesday's accident on the Indiana, Bloomington and Western Railroad, died here to-night from the result of his injuries.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 7.--Sarah McKnight was a young and handsome woman of good family, residing here. For some time past she had seemed to be in ill-health, and her condition at last became such that her friends suspected she was about to become a mother.

LONDON, Sept.7.--The returns issued by the Board of Trade show that the imports during the month of August decreased 650,000, as compared with those of August last year, and that the exports decreased 1,810,000 as compared with the corresponding month in 1884.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 7.--The attendance at the State Fair was good on Saturday and Sunday, a sermon by the Rev. Mr. Baugh, of Chicago, being the feature of the latter day. A cold rain set in this forenoon, and a bad track is likely for to-morrow also.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 7.--When the mob that-lynched Charles Williams last night reached the jail they were met at the gate by the two local military companies, but the letter had no ammunition, and had received no orders from the Governor. Once inside the mob began battering away at the front door. For a time they made no impression on the door.

"There is the jolliest consumptive that I have ever seen," said Dr. Helfrich, a physician in the Homeopathic Hospital on Ward's Island yestdrday. "He knows that his end is near, but he laughs, cracks jokes, and seems to regard death in a matter-of-fact sort of way."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 7.--Among the crowds who saw the Buffalos defeated by the Syracuse Stars was Charles E. Courtney. the oarsman, and C.T. Brockway, the regatta manager. The object of Courtney's visit, he said this evening, was to make arrangements for a single-scull race with John Teemer, of McKeesport, Penn.

BRADFORD, Penn., Sept. 7.--Samuel Shank is a rich farmer, living near Guilford. He recently advertised his farm for sale. Early last week a well dressed, fine-looking stranger called on Shank and inquired the price of the farm.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7.--Superintendent Fox, of the Mint, has received an order from the Secretary of the Treasury to coin 1,700,000 standard Silver dollars this month. Last month the order was for $1,800,000.

DETROIT, Sept. 7.--The passenger steamer Island Belle, owned by N.S. Whipple, of Detroit, took fire and was burned to the water's edge yesterday, and is a total loss. She was valued at $11,000 in Inland Lloyds and was insured in different companies for $9,000.

JACKSON, Mich., Sept. 7.--The police force of this city having been found inadequate to the task of keeping the disorderly elements straight, a Police Commission was organized with power to control the police force.

Yesterday was the fourth annual holiday of the Central Labor Union of New-York and vicinity. Forty-nine different organizations, representing all trades and crafts, took part in the demonstration. Chief Marshal Paul Mayer and his 10 aides--Messrs. Miller, Austin, McGeary, Archibald, Bailey, Vogt, Freymuller.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 7.--The labor demonstration here to-day was an affair of considerable magnitude. The day was a perfect one for the parade, and fully 8,000 men were in line, representing the various trades assemblies and unions of the city.
BOSTON, Sept. 7.--All Boston eyes were turned toward New-York to-day, and during the afternoon the news of the yacht contest was awaited with lively interest.

An old gentleman of respectable appearance was noticed by a passer-by last evening seated on one of the benches in Central Park near the Casino. He was in evident distress, and a Park policeman was notified of the fact. On going to the spot the officer found the gentleman in an unconscious condition.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 7.--Kate Conley, a single woman, 40 years old, was run over by a pilot engine on the Shore Line Railroad this afternoon and instantly killed. The woman was holding a parasol over her head as she crossed the track and did not see the engine. For three hours she lay beside the track before and ambulance could be secured.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 7.--Funeral services were held over the body of the Hon. Christian Kieffer, ex-Mayor of Lancaster, at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, the Rev. J. Max Hark, of the Moravian church, officiating.

MADARID, Sept. 7.--Dispatches regarding the German occupation of Yap state that the Spaniards on the island had hoisted the Spanish flag and had lowered it at sunset for the night, as is customary with all nationalities, and that immediately afterward the German gunboat ran in, landed marines and sailors, hoisted the German colors, and formally occupied the place despite the protestations of the Spaniards.

PHELPS, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The new comet discovered by Prof. Brooks, of the Red House Observatory last week, has been successfully observed almost nightly. COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 7.--Additional reports of the recent disastrous storm on the sea coast continue to come in. A sad incident of the late storm was the fate of E.F. Johannes, of New-York, who had been around Beaufort for some time as Southern agent for the sale of the "Life of Blaine."

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 7.--Capt. Gustav Jarecki and John C. Sturgeon, President and Cashier of the Humboldt Bank that suspended the other day, were arrested to-day on the criminal charge of receiving deposits, knowing the bank to be insolvent. Bail was accepted in $10,000 each.

UTICA, Sept. 7.--The First Oneida District Democrats have chosen Congressman J Thomas Spriggs. David A. Dishler, and Theodore Ballou delegates to the State Convention. They are uninstructed, but are expected to discover the winning candidate and vote for him from the start.

KANKAKEE, Ill., Sept. 7.--The Texas fever is spreading in this county. Some of Mr. Goodwin's steers broke out of the pasture and got into the adjoining pastures of H. Smiley and Eli Hawkins some time ago, and a number are sick in their herds. About 70 of Goodwin's herd have died.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 7.--The death by suicide in Philadelphia on Sunday morning of the 11-year-old son of William H. Parry, formerly of this city, caused special interest here from the fact that the troubles of the father and mother of the boy have been publicly known for the past three years.

The Stock List Committee of the Stock Exchange have ordered that the old second mortgage bonds of the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway Company be stricken from the regular list. Those bonds are now being called in by the company, and in their place are being issued new bonds known as the "Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe gold 6s of 1923." The Stock List Committee listed $2,144,000 of the new bonds yesterday.

SANDY HILL, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Republican District Convention for the Second District of Washington County was hold at North Granville to-day. The following State delegates were chosen: H.G. Burleigh, John Dwyer, I.V. Baker, Jr., H. Davis Northrup. Judicial Delegate--J. Sanford Potter. For member of Assembly--James H. Manville, of Whitehall. The State delegates are understood to be for Gen. Carr for Governor, the judicial delegates for the Hon. Joseph Potter for Supreme Judge.

NEWPORT, Sept. 7.--Among the cottagers entertaining to-day were Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Frederic W. Vanderbilt, Mrs. S.S. Whiting, Miss Leary, Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mrs. George R. Fearing, and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse.

The eighth annual convention of the American Society of Professors of Dancing, of New-York, was commenced at the Grand Union Hotel yesterday, and will be continued to-day and to-morrow. The session yesterday was devoted to the nomination of officers.

BRADFORD, Penn., Sept. 7.--A little daughter of David Norf, of Dubois, died a few weeks ago. Willis, her 5-year-old brother, mourned constantly for her, and repeatedly declared that he wanted to go to heaven to see her.

GREENVILLE, Ohio, Sept. 7.--On Saturday night John Essick shot and killed William Wise. Essick while in his back yard heard his wife scream in the house, and on entering he saw William Wise, a neighbor, run out at the front door. Seizing a shotgun he fired at him and sent the charge through Wise's body. Wise died at midnight, but before his death he denied that he was at Essick's house with any wrong intention.

BRADFORD, Penn., Sept. 7.--On Saturday John Bole, a farmer living near Hill's Mills, laid his vest on his barn floor while he was at work. In one of the pockets were several matches. During his absence at dinner two pigs entered the barn and began tearing at the vest. They ignited the matches, and the barn and all its contents, including a number of horses, were burned up. The loss was over $3,000.

CHEYENNE, Sept. 7.--The Sheriff of Sweetwater County has arrested 22 of the supposed leaders in the Rock Springs riot, among them Isaiah Whitehouse, member-elect of the Legislature. The prisoners have been taken to Green River City and lodged in jail. They will have a preliminary hearing to-morrow. More arrests will follow. The charges against the prisoners are murder, arson, rioting, and robbery.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 8.--A fight occurred at Mappsville, in Accomac County, late last night, between John H. Fisher and John W. Savage in which Fisher was fatally cut in the stomach. The wound was a fearful one, and extended almost across the abdomen, the bowels protruding. Savage was arrested and committed to jail. The affair created considerable excitement in the locality in which in occurred, as both of the parties are well known.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 8.--Jackson Briant, proprietor of the Davis House at Bridgeton, filed a bill in the Court of Chancery to-day asking the court to put a stop to the noises made by the Salvatlon Army, whose barracks adjoin his ...
Judge J.S. Sinclair, of Hamilton, and Messrs. J.W. Langmuir, formerly Inspector of Prisons for Ontario, and D.A. O'Sullivan, of Toronto, are at the New-York Hotel.

HANCOCK, Mich., Sept. 8.--The prospects for the copper men in this vicinity are not considered especially good. The full product will be got out this season, but it will be at prices which will not enable many of the mines to declare dividends.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8.--La Patrie, the organ of Mayor Beaugrand, says it has learned from a reliable source that the Federal Government, by means of its salaried employes in the Northwest, is about to have petitions circulated asking that justice take its course and that Riel be executed.

There was a food attendance on the Newark cricket ground yesterday to witness the return match between the home club and the Manhattan Club of Brooklyn. The Manhattans had won the previous match, and both sides had obtained as good representative elevens as possible.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 8.--It appears that the friends of Lawrence Brainerd, the defaulting President of the North American Bank at St. Albans, Vt., who for the past two years has resided in safety at Winnipeg, and who was recently abducted and carried over into United States territory by American detectives, intend taking legal action to have him returned to Canadian soil.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 8.--The clearing weather and the extension of the State Fair through Saturday may save the society from entirely exhausting its cash reserve.

The programme for the fifth day's racing of the Coney Island Jockey-Club presented many attractive features, and yesterday saw another great crowd at the Sheepshead Bay tract. The racing was of the most exciting description, and as only two favorites were successful the knowing ones had rather a hard time of it.

Among the passengers of the Anchor steamship Auchoria which arrived yesterday from Glasgow were the Rev. Joseph Boardman, the Rev. E.E. Chivers, Dr. E.S. Frisbee, the Rev. W.H. Jeffers, and Capt. Turtle.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 8.--The latest returns from the election which was held yesterday in the Third Arkansas Congressional District indicate the election of Thomas McRae (Dem.) over E.C. Mitchel (Ind.) by a majority of from 1,000 to 2,000. There are 19 counties in the district, and while the Democratic majority is about 3,000, it was believed that owing to the defection of Democrats and apathy the Independent candidate could be elected.

READING, Penn., Sept. 8.--Clayton Klick, a lad 19 years old, with his father and mother took a ramble on the Blue Mountains in Lebanon County on Wednesday of last week to gather mountain rod tea. TRENTON, Sept. 8.--The annual conclave of the Grand Commandery Knights Templar of New-Jersey was held in the Masonic Temple today. Officers were elected as follows: Right Eminent Grand Commander--J.H. Ackerson, of Jersey City; Deputy Grand Commander--Isaac ...
Dividends on railroad stocks were the principal things that Wall-street operators had to talk about yesterday.

The residence of Timothy O'Neil, at Port Chester, was entered on Monday night by burglars, who carried away, in addition to some small articles, a five-gallon demijohn of port wine. The latter caused their arrest, for they imbibed too freely of it and became so befogged that they went into David Lyon's barn to sleep it off, and were captured with the plunder in their possession.
"Une Cause Celebre," by MM. Dennery and Cormon, is soon to be revived at the Ambigu in Paris.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 8.--Advices from New-Zealand have been received to the effect that the House of Representatives has carried, by a large majority, a motion made by Sir Julius Vogel, to retain the San Francisco mail service. The Government will call for tenders for an 18-day mail service between San Francisco and New-Zealand. Auckland will be the terminal point of the line.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 8.--Employes of the Windsor Hotel, in Dearborn-street, this morning forced open the door of a room which had been occupied since yesterday afternoon by a man who had registered as I.N. Harlan, of Wilmington, N.C. Harlan was lying on the bed, ...

The mishap by which the Puritan and the Genesta were disabled yesterday just before the start for an ocean race of forty miles is especially lamentable. The conditions of weather seem to have been entirely favorable for high speed.

James A. Brown was murdered in Edward Danner's saloon, No. 250 Eighth-avenue, on the morning of Dec. 1, 1882, but it was not until Sunday last that the murderer was in custody. Brown was a member of the Linwood Club, which gave a ball at the Grand Opera House Hall on Nov. 30, 1882.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8.--After waiting until this afternoon Charles E. Courtney, the Union Springs oarsman, left Syracuse for home without receiving any word from John Teemer or his backers.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 8.--Miss Margaret Hawver was found murdered this morning in her residence at Kinderhook, Columbia County. The discovery was made by the washerwoman of the deceased. Money was lying on the floor and there were blood stains in four rooms. Coroner Waldron, of Hudson, was summoned and law is holding an inquest.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The State Prohibition Convention met in the Alhambra Rink this morning at 9 o'clock, when 300 or 400 delegates assembled for a two hours' prayer meeting. Notwithstanding their good intentions, however, they failed to carry out the letter of their purpose.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 8.--The fourth annual tournament of the Springfield Bicycle Club opened to-day under the most auspicious circumstances, with an attendance of 6,000. Many events were hotly contested. The Englishmen won eight out of the ten races.

LONDON, Sept. 9.--A dispatch from Madrid to the Times says: "Emperor william has sent a dispatch to King Alfonso saying that he has no intention of trenching upon Spanish rights, and will do nothing to prejudice ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 8.--The Miners' Journal to-morrow will have the following: "The charges made by the Journal yesterday morning of the outrageous crime committed upon some of the poor unfortunates of the female department of the county insane asylum were investigated yesterday afternoon by the local Committee of Lunacy--J.A.M. Passmore, ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8, 1885. It is stated at the Treasury Department that the only significance of the recent cancellation of silver certificates to the amount of about $15,000,000 lies in the fact, as shown by experience, that the certificates of large denomination are practically worthless as a circulating medium.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8.--The trial of the case of William Sharon against Sarah Althea Hill was begun in the Uuited States Circuit Court to-day. The action is to declare void the marriage contract upon which Judge Sullivan granted a divorce in the Sharon divorce case. All the testimony had previously been taken in secret sessions before Master in Chancery Houghton, and was read to the court to-day by W.H. T. Barnes, counsel for the plaintiff.

Club men and Wall-street men residing in the Twenty-ninth Precinct seem to be deeply interested in the course which the Civil Service Board of this city will take in regard to Capt. Alexander Williams's examination. By the promotion of Inspector Murray to the grade of Superintendent an Inspectorship became vacant, ...

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 8.--Thomas J. Hancock, a son of Dr. J.T. Hancock, of Shuqulak, Miss., has been indicted, arrested, and placed in jail, without bond, for setting fire to his father's house and other buildings, whereby the whole business quarter of Shuqulak was reduced to ruins on the 17th and 18th of August.

The Case of HOLLAND, the Texan who shot and killed a notorious swindler, will shortly come up for trial. The man will be given, undoubtedly, a fair chance to show that his killing was not premeditated murder.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 8.--The Democrats of the First Assemly District of Oswego County to-day elected Willard Johnson, Patrick Grace, and C.J. Scully delegates to the State Convention. Cleveland's and Hill's Administrations were indorsed. The delegates are for Hill.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 8.--Tne National Retail Druggists' Association adjourned finally at noon to-day after electing the following Executive Committee: W.H. Bartlett, of Boston; Charles Holsheler, of Newark; H.C. Porter, of ...

The identification of Mary Burg, or Marie Berg, the young Alsatian girl who shot herself in Central Park on Saturday night, is not yet positive, although it is regarded as very probable that the story she told Dr. Wall, of the Presbyterian Hospital, is true, and that her name is Berg.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 8.--Gov. Hill arrived here this morning in response to an invitation extended by the Great Council of the Improved Order of Red Men of the United States, now in session here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8.--A party of distinguished foreigners arrived in this city this morning. They were Mme. Salamon, wife of Gen. Salamon, the President of the Republic of Hayti; Mrs. Magnus, her ...

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 8.--Reports received to-day show that the condition of the cotton crop in this State is not so promising as earlier advices indicated. The falling off is reckoned at from 10 to 40 per cent. in the bottoms and more in the hills. There is general complaint of shedding, and picking is general.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 8.--A private letter by the steamer City of Sydney, which arrived here last night, announces the death of Gerald Eyre, the actor, at Melbourne, Australia. He died on the 6th of August, after an illness of two days.

The preliminary unveiling of the bronze statue of Garibaldi, by Turini, the sculptor of the Mazzini bust in Central Park, took place last night amid the cheers of 3,000 Italians at Bauer's Union Park, in Harlem.

The first meeting, of the County Com-- mittee of the County Democracy since the last election was held last night at No. 1 Unionsquare. The meeting was called to agree upon a date for the holding of primaries for the election of delegates to the State and various local conventions and to fix the dates for holding the conventions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8.--Amon L. Boyer, a well known stock broker of Reading, left home early this morning and came to this city to transact some business with Narr Gerlach, stock brokers at No. 322 Chestnut-street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.--Second Controller Maynard has received a letter from Rear-Admiral Jouett in regard to the disputed expenditure of $400 for the entertainment of official visitors to the flagship Tennessee at New-Orleans during the Cotton Exposition. He requests that the case be re-examined, and calls ...
LYONS, N.Y., Sept. 8.--Delegates opposed to the nomination of State Senator Thomas Robinson have been elected here.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Sept. 8.--Miss Letitia Douglass, of Berlin Township, this county, committed suicide to-day by wading out into Lake Erie, near her home, and lying down in the water. She was about 50 years of age and is supposed to have been temporarily insane at the time the act was committed.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 8.--The Governor to-day issued death warrants for the execution in New-Orleans of Patrick Ford and John Murphy, convicted of the murder of Andrew H. Murphy. The execution will take place on Friday, Nov. 13, between 12 M. and 2 P.M.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8.--The Directors of the Board of Trade to-day adopted as its ocean bill of lading the export ocean bill used by the NewYork Produce Exchange. The Directors will, however, oppose all attempts to have it made a law by Congress.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 8.--A report originating in St. Louis, and gaining general currency, represents the Erlanger syndicate, in control of the Queen and Crescent system of railways, as about to surrender the lease of the Cincinnati Southern, owned by this city.
The Committee of One Hundred Brooklyn Republicans, which has recently held several meetings to discuss the Fall campaign, has issued the following address:

OSAGE MISSION, Kan., Sept. 8.--Judge Stillwell, in the Frankie Morris murder trial, has granted a new trial to the defendant on the ground that opprobrious expressions of the County Attorney were outside of the record and prejudicial to the interests of the defendant.
John P. Hill, the accomplice of "Tom" Davis's murderer, spent nearly an hour in private consultation with the District Attorney yesterday.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 8.--The family of Policeman John McEvoy, who live on Franklinstreet, in this city, have had a narrow escape from death by poison.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 8.--About three months ago a man giving the name of Hirsh Levy rented a room in the basement of the People's Bank Building and commenced what he called a notion jobbing business.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8.--The Indian Harbor Hotel will close this week. Many of the guests are returning to the city, but most of those occupying houses will stay until Oct. 1. The hotels have had a very prosperous season. On Saturday there will be a boat race and game of baseball and in the evening a pool tournament.

Everything appeared propitious yesterday for a fair trial of speed between the Genesta and the Puritan, but an unfortunate accident has again delayed the race. In manoeuvring to gain the advantage of being on the windward side at the start the two yachts fouled each other.

LEBANON, Ohio, Sept. 8.--Senator John Sherman delivered a speech here to-night, devoted mainly to replying to the address of Gov. Hoadly. When the Luckenbach left Pier No. 3 East River at 8:20 o'clock yesterday morning the sky was cloudless and the horizon clear. There was a light wind from the southwest in the Upper Bay and the tide was still running food. The tug, after touching at Tompkinsville, reached the Horseshoe at 10 o'clock.

More than a dozen Custom House brokers filed into the Collector's office after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, desiring to confer with Mr. Hedden on the subject of pro forma invoices. The grievance of the brokers is that Collector Hedden has seen fit to exercise the discretion which the law allows him, and has discontinued the issuing of pro forma invoice certificates.

While doing excavating work in the lots at Nos. 191 and 193 Adams-street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, some workmen came across a heap of human bones, which were found to be the remains of 13 men. Never in the recollection of the oldest inhabitant was there a burial ground on the spot, and the presence of so many skeletons there is a mystery.

Coroner Elijah Purdy, of White Plains, is using all the means at his command to find the murderer of James Gilhooly, who was killed at White Plains on Saturday night by some unknown person. On Monday the Coroner had under arrest a young man named Frank Greenough, who had been arrested simply because he ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.--The proposition of Prince Bismarck, to submit the Caroline Islands dispute between Spain and Germany to arbitration, has suggested in diplomatic circles that the United States may be chosen to decide the matter.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 8.--The South Pennsylvania and Beech Creek injunction suits were called up by Attorney-General Cassidy today before Judges Simonton and McPherson. Numerons counsel were present to represent the parties in interest.

St. George's Episcopal Church, large as it is, was unable to hold the throngs which gathered within its walls yesterday to be present at the funeral of its old Pastor, the Rev. Dr. Stephen H. Tyng. Every seat was occupied, both on the main floor and in the galleries, while a crowd of several hundred ladies and gentlemen filled the aisles and overflowed out ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 8.--The National Telephone Exchange Association opened its annual meeting here this morning. Delegates were present from all parts of the country, numbering nearly 75. The meeting was called to order by Morris F. Tylet, of New-Haven.

ALBANY, Sept. 8.--The craze for building horse railroads in New-York City on paper, has broken out again, four large companies having been incorporated at the office of the Secretary of State-to-day under the provisions of the General Surface Railroad act of 1884. YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 8.--A collision occurred at noon to-day on the Erie and Pittsburg Road which caused the death of two persons, the destruction of cars and engines, and injury to quite a number. The accident occurred one mile east of Middlesex.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The Chief Signal Officer at Washington ordered up the storm signals at all stations on the lakes from Oswego westward at 10:30, as a well defined storm was discovered, central in Iowa, and moving northeastward, accompanied by heavy rains in almost all sections.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The State Convention of the Anti-Monopoly League was called to order at 11:15 A.M. to-day by Frank R. Purcell, of New-York, who, after a short address, presented the name of Henry Nichols, President of the league, ...

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 8.--In the settlement of the estate of Elmore P. Ross to-day $400,000, face value, in railroad and other stocks were sold for less than $100,000. Auburn street railway stock, face value, $20,000, brought 10 cents.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 8.--Nearly all the representatives of the lines in the Transcontinental Association arrived this morning. The meeting will probably last until Friday.

The Republican General Committee of Kings County held its first meeting this Fall last night at the Music Hall, Brooklyn, with David A. Baldwin in the chair, and decided to hold the coming primaries in each ward and county town in Kings ...

MONTREAL, Sept. 8.--The Provincial Board of Health for Quebec held their second meeting yesterday afternoon, when it was decided that circulars should be at once issued and forwarded to all the municipalities in the province, instructing them to appoint local Boards of Health immediately.

The Metropolitans opened their last series of the season with the Western clubs yesterday and met with a defeat at the hands of the Pittsburg men. With the exception of Broughton, the Mets played splendidly. Cushman was at his best.

About 15 gentlemen, members of the American Society of Professors of Dancing, in New-York, at present in convention, met yesterday at the dancing academy of L. De G. Brookes, at No. 361 Broome-street, and devoted the day to healthful terpsichorean practices.

LONDON, Sept. 8.--Mr. Chamberlain, in a speech at Warrington to-day, gave the full Radical platform. He said the Radicals now formed a great majority of the Liberal Party, and they would oppose Mr. Parnell tooth and nail. This declaration was greeted with prolonged cheering. Continuing, he said the granting of home rule to Ireland would mean the destruction of the British Empire.

Three years ago there were in the Northwest a great many persons who thought that Congress had become extravagant. The extravagance that excited their opposition had been prominently exhibited in the passage of a River and Harbor bill much larger than any that had preceded it.

The report that United States Treasurer Jordan was in town led many Wall-street bankers to inquire for him at the Clearing House and Sub-Treasury yesterday. He did not visit either place. The scarcity of small bills and the superabundance of silver dollars is becoming a matter of serious annoyance to bankers and business men.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 8.--John Jackson, a farm hand in the employ of Abraham Devine, lives with his wife and child in a tenement house owned by Samuel Hastings, about a mile from Devine's farm, in the town of Pleasant Valley. Early every morning Jackson leaves his home to go to the Devine farm to work.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 8.--The steamer Minia, which left Sydney on Sunday night, finished the repairs of the Direct Cable Company's main cable yesterday.

Herman Farragh, of No. 100 Myrtle street, Brooklyn, a conductor on the De Kalbavenue street car line, Brooklyn, suddenly became violently insane while attending to his duties on his car early last evening.

A little rustic summer house, overgrown with woodbine, stands in the shade of the forest trees which line the pathway leading from Seventh-avenue into Central Part. It is about 200 feet from the Park entrance.

A lonely looking, pig-tailed Chinaman stood just within the Aldermanic coat room yesterday, and looked timidly at the Aldermen as they assembled for the meeting of the board. When Alderman "Fatty" Walsh appeared the Chinaman walked up to him, and handed him an application for a permit, which he wished to have indorsed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.--The extension of leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability granted Major James C. McKee, Surgeon, has been still further extended three months on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 8.--Hugh McHenry and Howard Pierce, living on a farm in this county, were arrested yesterday, charged with taking part in the Blue Springs (Mo.) train robbery on the 3d inst. The officers say they tracked their men from the scene of the robbery by a roundabout course to their home, passing through Kansas City on Friday night. The prisoners have been lodged in jail here.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The body of Chauncey Hough was taken out of the river below the Falls last evening. Hough came here a week ago from Batavia, where he resided.

DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 8.--Word was received here late to-night that a terribly destructive storm raged in the vicinity of Washington Court House, 48 miles southeast of here, early this evening. It was attended by a large destruction of property and some loss of life. Some six or eight brick buildings were blown down and many houses unroofed. The particulars at this hour are very meagre from the fact that telegraphic communication has been cut off.
MARSEILLES, Sept. 8.--The cholera epidemic is decreasing here. Only 8 deaths were reported to-day, and only 37 patients remain under treatment in the Pharo Hospital.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 8.--Two carrier pigeons alighted near the home of James Manning, on Wallace-street, this afternoon, and one of them flew into an upper room.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8.--The special term of the Superior Court was adjourned this morning out of respect to the memory of the late Judge George W. Clinton. The motion for adjournment was made in fitting terms by W.C. Bryant.
GENOA, Sept. 8.--The steamer Will, from Genoa for Malaga, has sunk. It is feared that 40 persons have been drowned.

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Sept. 7, via Galveston.--Twenty Liberal Senators have met and named a committee for the organization of a convention. The commitees of all parties, having been completed, will meet to-morrow to determine upon the basis of the convention.

GAINESVILLE, Texas, Sept. 8.--This community was startled at daylight this morning by the announcement that the famous Lee brothers, the terror of North Texas, had actually been killed. The first intimation of the killing was the arrival of a farmer's wagon about 1 o'clock this morning containing the dead bodies of the notorious outlaws, Jim and Pink Lee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8.--Lew Goldman and Heinrich Conried, owners of the copyright of the opera "Nanon," obtained an injunction yesterday to prevent the production of the opera at the Tivoli, a theatre owned by Kreling Brothers.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 8.--Jacob Fisher, aged 71 years, handed himself in the grape arbor at the house of his son-in-law here to-day. His suicide is said to have been caused by family troubles.
The National Board of Steam Navigation during its session at the Hoffman House yesterday approved of a resolution that a committee be appointed to center with the Shipping ...

NEWPORT, Sept. 9.--The weather to-day has been very unpleasant. A fog has hung over the city during the afternoon and evening, and there was a heavy fall of rain early this morning.
The Young Men's Republican Club lastnight resolved to hold a meeting on the evening of the 16th inst. to discuss a report on the committee which had charge of legislative matters last Winter.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 9.--John Curtis, of Mount Carmel, Conn., drove to this city with a load of hay to-day, and on his return home passed by Lake Whitney, the main reservoir of the city. Several young ladies were trying to gather water lilies in the lake.

The fever-stricken Italian brig La Regina, which arrived at Lower Quarantine Tuesday, was towed to Upper Quarantine yesterday. The Health Officer thought that the disease of which the men died was undoubtedly yellow fever. Three of the crew who were suffering from the fever when the vessel arrived have been removed to the hospital in the Lower Bay.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--The eighteenth annual reunion of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee began here to-day. A business meeting was held this morning at which about 200 officers and members of the society were present. Gen. William T. Sherman, President of the association, occupied the chair. On the stage with him were Gen. Logan and Govs. Marshall, Ogiesby, Sherman, and Fletcher.
TORORTO, Sept. 9.--The cricket match between the English Gentlemen and the Ontarios, which was to have begun to-day, has been postnoned, owing to rain, until to-morrow, Friday, and Saturday.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 9.--The movement of the Spring wheat crop in the Northwest has just begun. As a rule farmers are not thrashing as early as last year, and it looks now as though the early movement would be much lighter than usual. Some elevator companies say their receipts so far have been only about 25 per cent. of what they were for the same time last year.

Francis Dwyer, 5 years old, living at No. 415 Cherry-street, was run over by a Belt Line street car last evening, at the corner of Cherry and Jackson streets, and instantly killed. The driver of the car was arrested.
The Archbishop of York has written a letter on the subject of funeral reform, containing suggestions "for what they are worth."

SALAMANCA, Sept. 9.--The delegates elected to the Democratic State Convention from the Second District of Cattaragus County are Hudson Ansley, Joseph Schock, and J.E. Leach. Resolutions indorsing Hill for Governor were adopted.

TRENTON, Sept. 9.--The annual convocation of the Grand Chapter of Royal Arch Masons, of New-Jersey, was held to-day.
INDIAN SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 9.--Bob Williams killed his brother Jim this evening by shooting him with a gun. Jim Williams was chastising a little son of Bob's.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9.--Washington Court House, the scene of one of the most disastrous visitations by the elements last night, is the county seat of Fayette County. It has had a most extraordinary business growth within the past 15 years, and, being, the centre of a rich agricultural district, with excellent railroad facilities, it has grown to be a business place of considerable importance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9.--William Murray, 30 years old, is in the County Jail under an indictment charging him with breaking into a jewelry store and stealing a lot of gold chains. It is also charged that he sold the chains to Andre Andrews, a State-street pawnbroker.

Last night was a solemn occasion with the Israelites all over the world. The inauguration of the new year 5646, which is supposed to represent the number of years which have elapsed since the creation of the world, took place. This is observed in orthodox congregations for two days, while in reform synagogues its ceremonies extend over one day only.

The Fire Departments of Queens and Suffolk Counties had a parade and tournament in Jamaica yesterday. Over 1,500 men were present, and their heel-and-toe practice was enlivened by 16 bands and four drum corps.

Charlotte, the Duchess d'Auxy, has brought a suit in the United States Circuit Court against William K. Soutter, as Executor, and Agnes Gordon Soutter, as Executrix, of the wlil of James T. Soutter, Sr., and against William K. Soutter and Franklin Edwards, as members of the firm of Soutter Co., bankers and brokers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9, 1885. First Lieut, Robert Craig, Fourth Artillery, Acting Signal Officer, will be relieved from duty in San Francisco and will repair to this city and report to the Chief Signal Officer. It is reported that Lieut. Glassford will relieve Lieut. Craig.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9.--Joseph N. Kreling, one of the proprietors of the Tivoli Opera House, where "Nanon" was produced Monday night despite the injunction granted by Judge Beardon, was yesterday convicted of contempt of court, fined $500, and sentenced to imprisonment in the County Jail for five days. John and William Kreling, part proprietors of the Tivoli, were each fined $250 and sentenced to imprisonment for two days.
NASHVILLE, Sept. 9.--The Directors of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railroad contemplate the extension of several important branches of the road.

Mary Pribil, 32 years old, who lived with her husband, Joseph Pribil, a Bohemian cigarmaker, in small apartments on the fourth floor at No. 1,426 Avenue A, was found on the pavement in front of the house yesterday morning.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 9.--As a gang of 14 miners were coming out of Alto Colliery, at Branchdale, eight miles west of this city, this morning, a tremendous explosion of gas occurred. John Linn was instantly killed, and the 13 others were all more or less burned and mangled, some of them fatally.

Thus far Prince BISMARCK'S scheme in the Carolines has profited almost as much by the Spanish moves as by his own. The affair has steadily grown in gravity, with decisiveness of action and show of diplomatic courtesy on the German side and a commingling of tardiness with rashness on the other.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 9.--Lawrence Brainerd, the absconding President of the St. Albans (Vt.) Bank, who was kidnaped the other day in Manitoba by Boston detectives, is again missing. The two detectives, with their prisoner, reached Minneapolis yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 9.--At the mass meeting of Irishmen, held here last evening, at which Vice-President Hendricks spoke in favor of the movement to afford sympathy and aid to Parnell in his campaign in Ireland, a long series of preambles and resolutions were adopted commending Parnell's leadership.

BOSTON, Sept. 9.--Courtney and Conley have challenged Hanlan and Lee to row a double scull race and two single scull races for $500 a side each race, the distance in each race to be three miles with a turn.

Mr. Daly has issued the "call" for his regular season for next Saturday, the 12th inst. The ladies and gentlemen of his company are requested to assemble in the foyer of his theatre on Saturday noon on business preliminary to the regular season, which begins Oct. 7.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--A delegation from Baltimore, including Representative Findlay and J. Hall Pleasants, President of the Civil Service Association of that city, called upon Secretary Lamar to-day to urge the removal of Morris A. Thomas, who was appointed in June last as an Indian Inspector.

MADRID, Sept. 9.--Count Solms-Sonnewalde, the German Ambassador, has informed Senor Canovas del Castillo that the retreat of the Spanish Government officials at Yap before the German gunboat would not affect the question whether Spain actually occupied the island first.

ALBANY, Sept. 9.--Gen. Carr may have some trouble in securing the support of his own county in his Gubernatorial canvass. Rensselaer is entitled to 17 delegates, and in order to impress his claims upon the delegates of other counties he would naturally be compelled to obtain them all.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Sept. 9.--A telegram announces the instant death of Aaron Griffith, a former resident of this place, but now of Marion County, Ky., who was struck by lightning this morning.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 9.--Judgment in the Riel appeal case was given to-day. The previous sentence at Regina is confirmed. The French and half breed population is greatly excited in consequence, while the bulk of the whites are jubilant. The general opinion is that Riel will be hanged. The white rebel, Scott, is now on trial at Regina.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--Second Controller Maynard has made a report to the Secretary of the Treasury on the application of C.P. Huntington, Vice-President of the Central Pacific Railroad Company, to have compensation earned by the company in the Government service over the non-subsidized portions of its lines paid over to the company.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 9.--Miss Ida Maxwell, a beautiful young lady of this city, eluded the vigilance of her parents to-day and met her lover, John Shelton, and was married.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 9.--The phosphate pool, which for the last three years had fixed the price for land rock at $6.50 per ton, has dissolved, and sales are made below the pool figures. The pool covered only land miners.
MONTREAL, Sept. 9.--Col. Amyot, of the Ninth Battalion of Quebec, is trying to get his men to form a settlement of their own in the Northwest with the scrip given them by the Government.

The Metropolitan and Pittsburg Clubs gave a very pretty exhibition of ball playing on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and the game resulted in favor of the Mets by figures of 3 to 2. Every run was earned. There were a few misplays on the part of the local team, but these were made at stages of the game when they failed to affect the score.

AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Gov. Hill arrived here at midnight last night from Elmira, accompanied by his clerk, M.S. Eustace. His arrival was unexpected. This morning the Governor went to the State prison, where he met Superintendent of Prisons Baker and Pardon Clerk Brown.

There was a fatal accident at shaft No. 17 of the new Croton Aqueduct, situated near the North Yonkers station of the New-York City and Northern Railroad early yesterday morning.

Archdeacon FARRAR is too well known in thousands of American homes to receive anything short of a hearty welcome during his intended brief sojourn in this country. His antecedents as an author and his position in the Church of England have already given him an extended reputation.

The proposition of certain members of the Produce Exchange to convert the whole of that portion of the city below Wall-street into a separate postal district is meeting with opposition from the members of the other Exchanges.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9.--Fifteen thousand persons witnessed the second day's races of the Springfield bicycle tournament. The track was not well dried at the start, but the inner part dried in a short time wide enough for two or three riders, and the rest improved during the afternoon.

A large lot of miscellaneous stocks and bonds was sold at auction in the Real Estate Exchange by Adrian H. Muller Son yesterday. The securities were sold for the account of Adolph Matthiesson, Executor of the late Claude Gignoux.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9.--The Jeffersonian Club of this city, a former radical Cleveland organization, met to-night and adopted resolutions recommending the Hon. R. P. Flower for the Governorship and indorsing the remainder of the State ticket. Much enthusiasm was evinced over this action.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Ora See, 8 years of age, was crushed to death to-day in the town of Lorraine, this county, by being caught beneath the roots of a tree which had been blown over. The tree was being sawed off to let the roots fall back. The boy was missing for three hours before he was found.

Carr Walsh, whose pool rooms are on Washington-street, Hoboken, opened their place yesterday and commenced to sell tickets on the Brighton Beach races. The police authorities heard of it and compelled them to stop operations.

It grows clearer as the time for a new election to Parliament approaches that the Irish question is the only burning question in British politics. The Afghan difficulty, if it be not settled, is in abeyance. The Egyptian question will settle itself in much the same way, whichever party prevails.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 9.--J.H.H. Chapman, who has for some years conducted a grocery at Water and Second streets, in this city, has made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors, to Alexander Leslie, who has long been a clerk with him.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Sept. 9.--Drilling has been going on at the Gordon oil well for several days, and the production has greatly increased. The excitement is becoming intense. From 12 o'clock yesterday until 5 o'clock this evening the well had flowed 195 barrels of oil. The Standard Oil Company has arranged to take the oil from the People's Light and Heat Company--owners of this well--for which they are to pay 32 cents above the market price.
ANDERSON, Ind., Sept. 9.--The second term of George Ross as County Treasurer of Madison County expired Aug. 15. He owed a balance of $71,000 to the county.
